PETITION.TITLE: Compass Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the overwhelming support of the Australian people for the resumption of Compass Airlines operation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:-
recognise the overwhelming public support for Compass resuming operations;
agree to work with interested parties to facilitate Compass resuming operations;
provide clear guidelines under aviation deregulation to ensure that fair and adequate facilities are made available to all operators and the public immediately.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 14 citizens), Mr Beale (from 14 citizens), Dr Charlesworth (from 14 citizens), Mr Cobb (from 14 citizens), Mr Dubois (from 14 citizens), Mr Duncan (from 14 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from 14 citizens), Mr Filing (from 14 citizens), Mr Hand (from 14 citizens), Mr Hawker (from 14 citizens), Mr Hicks (from 14 citizens), Mr MacKellar (from 14 citizens), Mr Moore (from 14 citizens), Mr Peter Morris (from 14 citizens), Mr O'Keefe (from 14 citizens), Mr Price (from 14 citizens), Mr Sawford (from 14 citizens), Mr Bruce Scott (from 14 citizens), Mr Sharp (from 14 citizens), Mr Snow (from 14 citizens), Mr Truss (from 14 citizens) and Mr Wilson (from 14 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Abortions: Government Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:

PARA.TAB: Every abortion kills an unborn human baby. More unborn Australians are killed every year (80,000) than the Australian death toll for the whole of World War II (30,000).
Australia's population is ageing. Our live birth rate is below replacement level.
About 98 percent of abortions in Australia are performed for non-medical reasons (see SA Health Commission statistics).
Post abortion depression is a silent epidemic and is linked with the growing incidence of child abuse by mothers who have previously had abortions.
The Australian Government should not fund the killing of future Australian citizens.
Mothers with problem pregnancies need positive help to carry their babies to full term.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
pass the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, and
help pregnant women with problems to continue their pregnancies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 18 citizens) and Mr Duncan (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE Videos, Films and Publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because Parliament has a direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in Videos, Films and Publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into television standards,
ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the programme limits of Television standards,
control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of the Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The humble petition of electors of the Division of Wakefield respectively showeth:

PARA.TAB: That there is a general dissatisfaction in the community at levels of road funding made available by the Federal Government.

While noting the commitment of the Government to maintain a high standard of roads in Australia, we are specifically concerned at the real cutbacks for roadfunding in the Local Government area, affecting in particular the Burra/Morgan road.
We especially note that roadworks are a labour intensive industry and cutbacks will create unemployment and hardship in rural areas.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled give due consideration to increasing the amount of funds available to Local Government authorities for roadworks, with special reference to the Burra/Morgan section of road.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1988/89 the Federal Government paid $6.9 million from taxpayers' funds for 64,788 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by supporting the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1989 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
(1)(a)makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children,

TAB.TAB: (b)makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.

PARA.TAB: (2)creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
(3)will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
(1)By Act, Parliament ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
(2)The Parliament take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House the tragic war in Croatia which has caused an immense loss of human life, widespread suffering of Croatia's civilian population and the systematic destruction of Croatian cultural monuments, civilian centres and economic infrastructure.
Your petitioners pray that the House as a matter of urgency:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Continues to publicly express its abhorrence at the war of aggression being perpetrated by the Serb-led Yugoslav Army on Croatian territory and against Croatian people;
2.Urges the Australia Government:
2.1To use its influence with allies, including the United States of America, to stop this brutal aggression;
2.2To implement immediately the motion moved by Member for Corio, Hon. Gordon Scholes M.P., and unanimously carried by the House on 13th November, 1991;
2.3To recognise the independence of Croatia and Slovenia without delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the House to the threat to free speech contained within the recommendations of the majority report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

PARA.TAB: We believe that all persons have the right to express their views through paid commercial advertising on television and radio and that any limitation on that right constitutes a threat to the peoples' freedom of speech and to the Australian democratic system.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Parliament rejects the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and preserves the right of all persons and political parties to exercise their right to free speech through any media they choose.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Resource Security Legislation
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain citizens of Australia and stewards of the Earth draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the continuing destruction of Australia's native forests.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
Reject the Government's Resource Security Legislation for Major New Industrial Wood Processing Projects, and
Direct the Government to instead develop an Ecologically Sustainable National Forest and Forestry Strategy for Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby;
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights;
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life;
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect;
That in 1989/90 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 69,587 abortions totalling $7.8 million;
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Itemised Telecom Accounts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the procedure for payment of Telecom accounts in rural areas.

There is no provision in rural areas for accounts to be itemised. Residents feel their right to dispute ambiguous Telecom accounts is therefore limited. This situation contrasts with those living in the major metropolitan areas who are provided with itemised accounts.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take urgent action to remedy this inequity to provide rural residents with an itemised Telecom account so that customer expenditure can be justified.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
The readily available range of sex and fantasy audio text services transmitted via Telecom through the use of the 0055 prefix.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
Move to disband this `adult' information and entertainment service. Your petitioners are deeply concerned as to what effect these messages have on our youth and Australia's moral standing.

PETITION.TITLE: Ambulant Dementia Sufferers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens having a concern and interest in the care of moderate to severe dementia sufferers in both Nursing Homes and Hostels throughout Australia draws to the attention of the House:

the current inappropriate policy of retaining ambulant dementia sufferers in accommodation with mentally alert frail aged people thereby creating additional stress for residents, families and staff alike.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House give proper recognition by adequate funding for special hostels. We believe this type of care to be more appropriate and cost-effective when compared to that of Nursing Homes, in which the subsidy is $24,500 per person per annum. Currently the maintenance cost in a special hostel is about $16,800, whereas the present subsidy is $10,800. An additional subsidy to cover the present deficit and thereby prevent unnecessary admission to nursing homes is required. This would then represent a saving of $7,700 per person to the Government and ultimately, the tax-payer.

PETITION.TITLE: Jervis Bay Territory Entry Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The Petition by residents of and visitors to the City of Shoalhaven respectfully showeth that they are totally opposed to the proposal of the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, to introduce an entry fee for persons and vehicles entering the Jervis Bay Territory and particularly the residents of the surrounding Shoalhaven area.

Your Petitioners, therefore humbly pray that the House will agree to abandon the proposal to introduce an entry fee for persons and vehicles entering the Jervis Bay Territory as proposed by the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories and your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Day Care Centre, Milford Lodge, Buderim
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of electors of the division of Fairfax draws the attention of the House to the terrible predicament into which many innocent victims have been led through misinterpretation of the requirements for lodgement of forms to the Department of Social Security in relation to the Child Care Fee Relief Scheme. Due to misunderstanding we, the parents, are now liable to pay the Day Care Centre, Milford Lodge, Buderim, varied sums of monies ranging from $30.00 to $1600.00 in total a tidy sum of around $8,000.00.
Payment of monies to centre will force many of us into a financially impossible situation.
Non payment of monies places the Child Care Centre into a financially difficult situation.

PETITION.PARA: Our relationship with the Day Care Centre is at risk.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled consider our plight and require the government to re-structure certain legislation which allows the Department of Social Security and the Department of Children's Services to find a compassionate solution to the predicament into which we have been led.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 November 1991, on motion by Mr Lavarch:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I rise to speak on the report tabled on behalf of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I understand other members of the Committee will be participating in this debate a little later on. The Committee's task in undertaking this particular inquiry was to examine the corporate practices which predominated in Australia during the late 1980s and specifically to determine whether the existing legislative controls over the operation of Australian corporations adequately protected the rights of shareholders. Mostly, the Committee was concerned with the operation of listed companies, that is, those listed on the Australian Stock Exchange. In terms of shareholders, we were mostly concerned with small non-institutional shareholders. In conducting this inquiry, however, the Committee was keen to make sure that we were not simply looking for scapegoats, but rather that our examination would lead to a series of recommendations which would improve the standard of corporate behaviour in Australia while at the same time not putting undue burden on the operation of the Australian business community.

PARA.TAB: While we were principally interested in the role of small non-institutional shareholders, it is, of course, interesting to note that Australia has not traditionally been a nation of shareholders. The proportion of Australians who hold shares in our listed companies is relatively small by international standards. Certainly, it is much less than that of the United States and of similar countries in Europe. I suppose the flip side of that is that institutional shareholders have always been major players in the Australian market and that trend is continuing. Indeed, as we move towards the next century, we could see that Australian shareholders would have their interests in the share markets looked at almost entirely by large institutions such as superannuation funds. It is unlikely that we will see large numbers of small Australian shareholders. This may change. There are, I suppose, some trends moving against that. One would be the move towards privatisation of government assets. Certainly, with the partial float of the Commonwealth Bank, there was a large number of small shareholders in that particular venture. However, if the experience of privatisation is any guide, it is quite possible that even over time the float of government assets will still lead to larger concentrations of shares in a smaller number of hands.

Having said that, I note that the Committee was concerned to make sure that the market did operate effectively and that shareholders could hold interests with some sort of level of confidence. Even though big players, as such, may be able to look after themselves, it is still no consolation to small shareholders if they find themselves completely at the mercy of unscrupulous company directors, company officers, or at the hands of auditors and the accounting profession.

Notwithstanding the experience of the 1980s, there have, of course, been some significant changes which again this Committee's report has to be considered in the light of. The most important of those has been the move towards a truly national system of company regulation through the Australian Securities Commission, this national system replacing the State system. I think that it was fairly held by the Committee to be the most significant reform that could be undertaken to improve the operation of the Australian business system. Coupled with that has been the significant increase in resources available to the Australian Securities Commission when compared with its predecessor. Those two factors alone, having a national system and having that national system adequately resourced, will probably do far more to improve corporate behaviour in Australia than any reconsideration of the operation of the legal system or any change in a raft of laws. Notwithstanding those changes, the Committee did examine the role of the major players, that is, the Australian Securities Commission, the Australian Stock Exchange and the other major contributors to a secure corporate system, the accounting profession, particularly auditors, and shareholders themselves, in the area of self-help; what remedies were there for shareholders to protect their own interests.

The Committee's major recommendation on this was that there should be a system whereby shareholders can effectively look after themselves. The major reform advanced by the Committee was the virtual abolition of the old rule in the case of Foss v. Harbottle. This rule effectively precludes individual shareholders from challenging decisions made by the directors, except in a specified number of exemptions. This rule, even though it has been watered down over the years by the interpretation of the courts, does prove to be an effective bar against shareholders challenging the actions of directors. When one combines that with the excessive cost of attempting to take actions, one can see that the position of smaller shareholders is indeed very stark.

I suppose the most telling example brought to the Committee of the position of individual shareholders was the position of shareholders in the IRL group. I note that certain directors of that group of companies are now subject to charges before the courts. I will not canvass the particular issues involving those directors except to say that things only got to that stage due to the very determined effort of a group of shareholders, a couple of whom fortunately had the financial resources to pursue it. Those particular shareholders must have expended sums in the hundreds of thousands of dollars in order to pursue court remedies to try to bring into line the actions of the directors of that particular group of companies. Only if we can make shareholders' remedies more effective can shareholders have some confidence in the concept of self-help.

The Committee's recommendation in this regard was the adoption of a system which has been trialled in Canada known as derivative actions. The basis of this is to allow the individual shareholder to take action against company officers and have recourse, once a prima facie case is established, to the resources of the company in order to pursue that action. That is a significant reform. It has been canvassed in Australia for some time. The Committee looked at the reform particularly carefully to make sure that it would not be able to be used by particular shareholders as a technique in a guerilla warfare against the officers of the company. Despite a few reservations on behalf of individual Committee members, the Committee as a whole resolved to adopt this new action.

I believe that is a significant reform. I do urge the Government to give very serious consideration to the introduction of such a derivative action. It does overcome the rule in Foss v. Harbottle and I believe that, if it is adopted, it will mean a significant improvement for the right of individual shareholders.

Finally, I would like to place on record my appreciation of the efforts of the members of the Subcommittee, in particular, who examined this report—the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), the former Deputy Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), and the staff of the Committee secretariat, particularly Mr Donald Nairn, all of whom put a large amount of work into getting this report up and running. I believe it is a good report with solid recommendations. I know other honourable members will canvass other aspects of it, but I do believe it is worthy of serious consideration on behalf of the Attorney-General. I hope that we will see some amendments to the corporations law along the lines suggested in the Committee's report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make some observations upon the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on corporate practices and the rights of shareholders.
—Leave is granted. It is so nice to see the right honourable member this morning.
—Mr Speaker, I am glad to know you are not in court today but here enjoying our contribution to the well-being of the nation.
—Touche! Better not to be in court than to be in bed, though, I suppose.

—You are just jealous. Mr Speaker, I refer to aspects of this report which I think are worthy of wider understanding and comprehension. First, I think it is important that as legislators we do not overreact to the events of the 1980s. I am most concerned that in the professional fields—not peculiarly those covered by this legislation but across the whole ambit, from medicine through law, accounting and indeed in every one of the professions in Australia—the highest possible standards, firstly, should be set. Secondly, we should not try to enforce in the 1990s a legislative inhibition which will deny the community the opportunity to retain the skills and disciplines of those who, over the years, have built the qualities of their respective professions and which, with respect to corporate law, will deny people the chance to participate as external directors, to act as auditors, or indeed to act as legal counsel or accountants. If we are not careful, the changes that are being sought by some could well mean that we are no longer able to maintain the incentive to perform that really is characteristic of our capitalist system.

PARA.TAB: In that respect I have been very pleased to see the conclusions that have been reached in this report in three areas to which I want to advert. The first is with respect to auditors. It is obviously extraordinarily difficult to interpret exactly what the true and fair obligation of an auditor is in stating his view about matters before him. There have been some very sad company failures. Some, no doubt, have distinctly been the product of those who have been the entrepreneurs of yesteryear who have gone beyond the reasonable bounds of propriety and for whom there should be no public or legislative sympathy. But to enforce upon an auditor a requirement that he should always have second vision and be able to see behind the accounts as presented to him is not equitable, nor is it possible.

For that reason the Committee, in reaching its conclusions with respect to auditors—and I refer those who have a particular interest to recommendations 16, 17, 18 and 19—tried to ensure that while there should be requirements to notify the Australian Securities Commission of malpractices that the audit has revealed, it has not tried to rewrite the laws. The Committee has suggested that the Australian Auditing Standards Board needs to be given similar recognition in corporations law to that of the Australian Accounting Standards Board. In that way there can be continued development of auditing standards and maintenance by the profession, under the general supervision of the Australian Securities Commission, of the extent to which there is a requirement to maintain a true and proper auditing standard to ensure that malpractices to the disadvantage of creditors or shareholders appear.

The second area that I think is particularly important in relation to the prime purport of this inquiry, and that is the rights of shareholders and their interface with directors, is a series of recommendations that pick up the business judgment rule, that define it, under recommendation 20. It looks a little further at the rights and responsibilities of directors in recommendations 21 and 22 and so on. And then, finally, the report looks at an interpretation in the final recommendation with respect to the criminal liability provisions of the corporations law.

I think they are particularly important and I, like the Chairman of the Committee who has just spoken, would say to government, `I think the recommendations make sense but above all do not go too far. Do not try to write into corporate law responsibilities that, as I have suggested, are going to pass onto today's and tomorrow's generations, criminal liability because of those circumstances of the 1980s'. Indeed, one of my criticisms of the economic statement handed down by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) the other night is that I do not think he has really given the incentive to corporate investors to generate the jobs that are needed. And while it is not the jobs of directors that this House need particularly be concerned about, unless there is an opportunity for people to exercise responsibility as directors, the opportunity for employment in the rest of the corporate sector is no doubt lessened.

So, what we have tried to do is to get a balance between the proper exercise of responsibility by directors, and their interpretation within the corporations law, and the rights of shareholders. I think that the recommendations here make sense. There is no doubt that, to the extent to which further recommendations relate to the Australian Stock Exchange listing, they also bear upon the responsibilities both of disclosure and of the way in which a director undertakes both his legislative and his corporate responsibility.

In that respect I think it is particularly important that the extent to which the stock exchange rules develop should not always be necessarily matched by some type of legislative change. I am one who believes that the stock exchange does have a capacity to provide a listing requirement which ensures that there are disclosures of matters of particular significance to a company. There is a recommendation in the report which covers that, recommendation 14, so that there are obligations on the directors to comply with the listing rules.

Those listing rules are matters which, of course, can take more account of changing patterns and practices and community requirements. But, what I am saying is that in respect of the maintenance of a liability of disclosure, of liability of exercising due and proper care with the assets of a company and conducting affairs in a proper manner, I think this report goes a reasonable distance in trying to blend the enhanced recognition of the listing rules of stock exchanges while not going so far in the change of corporate law to prevent people from accepting what are significant and onerous responsibilities as external directors.

The third field is in the field to which the Chairman of the Committee—who has just resumed his seat—referred, and that is the derivative action concept. Recommendation 27 specifically refers to that. It is very difficult to know to what degree, both in the field of derivative action and in the requirement for disclosure, there can be a proper balance set between the need to ensure that there is, on the shareholder's part, an opportunity to know what is happening to the assets of the company of which he is a shareholder and the requirement by the board of a company to maintain confidentiality to enable commercial in confidence decisions to be taken without risk; that by those other actions they are going to be revealed in such a way that it will prejudice the interests of the company.

While there was significant debate within the Committee on the nature and character of these provisions, I think that the recommendations happily reach a fair compromise. Quite obviously there did need to be a consideration of the rule in Foss v. Harbottle and of a way by which there can be some legislative variation to that. What the Committee has recommended in its amendments to the corporations law is that there should be a change to provide standing to particular persons set out in recommendation 26, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: . any member or former member, of the corporation or a related corporation; . any director or officer, or former director or officer, of the corporation or a related corporation;
It then allows through a further recommendation that there be a capacity for people who have particular standing to seek leave to proceed on behalf of the company and to pursue a derivative action.

PARA.TAB: I think that really does help to improve the situation of shareholders who, in a number of circumstances known to many of us, seem to me to have been disadvantaged. So, we have tried to blend, in the recommendations of the Committee, the balance between the proper exercise of directors' responsibility and proper access for shareholders.

So I believe that the Committee's report does make a significant advance in those three areas: the role and exercise of responsibilities by auditors; the role and exercise of responsibilities by directors and the access to the records of the company by shareholders.

I recommend the report to the Government and trust that, in moving, it does not take the recommendations any further. If it does so, as I have suggested, we will be unduly imposing on today's directors a discipline and consequence of the affairs of the 1980s, which I do not think is in the best interests of the corporate sector, nor of the development of our economy in the parlous plight in which it now finds itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This was a very wide-ranging inquiry which extended over a long period of time and was mooted at a time when the circumstances in the commercial world were quite different from those which operated at the time when the report was brought down or the hearings were concluded.

PARA.TAB: I want to make some remarks about evidence which was given relating to the status of audited balance sheets and the availability of information on which potential shareholders can make a judgment as to the assets and the value of the assets of organisations.

It is the conventional wisdom in Australia, which has subsequently proven to be incorrect, that an audited balance sheet does accurately reflect the state of the company or organisation concerned and that the auditor will ensure that the documents which he presents and signs are an accurate set of documents in respect of the financial status of the organisation.

In evidence before the Committee it was clearly stated that, in fact, in valuing assets, for instance, the auditors take account of the method of valuation prescribed by the directors of the organisation. In other words, it is available to the directors to have an audited balance sheet made out on the best case scenario in respect of the value of assets of an organisation.

So we had the circumstance in 1986 of a balance sheet which was presented in respect of the Connell bank—Rothwells—which reflected nothing of the financial situation of the bank, on which, however, a reasonable judgment could have been made by potential investors that the organisation was structurally financially sound and backed by adequate, and more than adequate, assets. It was clearly proven by subsequent events to be not true.

In 1987 a similar report was prepared and it was only after challenges by the regulatory bodies, in particular Mr Bosch, that the auditors decided that they would not sign the balance sheet, even though apparently, dishonest as the balance sheet may have been, it met the legal requirements for an audited balance sheet. Mr Bosch actually told the Committee that he had sought to prosecute the auditors for their earlier balance sheet which was totally inaccurate, but that he was unable to do so because of the nature of the law and the requirements which are placed on auditors. There are changes taking place but I am not certain that those changes will, in fact, prevent the practices which I have mentioned from recurring.

I use another example. Everyone is aware that a building society in my electorate, or based in my electorate, collapsed a couple of years ago. Most people, like myself, would have believed that it was a very soundly based organisation with adequate assets trading largely in housing.

In fact, on 10 February 1990, the Geelong Advertiser had a headline `Record profit is his answer to `rivals' rumours', introducing an interview with Mr Clarke, one of the directors. The chairman of the organisation had reported in the annual report that the company had record profits and had set down a balance sheet which showed a surplus of assets over liabilities of some half a billion dollars. It was marginally less than that.

The auditors had found that balance sheet to be correct. But it appears that that balance sheet was based on the book value of the assets, not their actual value. This was at a time when property values had already started to decline. Some of the properties depended on boom in the property market in order to make a profit at the end and were overvalued for the purposes of the loans made against them. These were, to say the least, very risky ventures and the assessments of the valuations were also risky.

A balance sheet subsequently prepared, by the same auditors, using market value for the same period, showed a change of something like $700m in the asset backing, on which that profit had been declared. It was some 30 per cent of the total asset. That was a variation in a balance sheet.

What is any ordinary citizen to think who reads something like this in a local paper, `The corporation's success has come at a time when other financial institutions are entering tough times' and who discovers that the organisation at that time was in fact insolvent when its balance sheet said it was in profit? That balance sheet was legally and correctly audited in accordance with the instructions which existed at the time. What hope does the ordinary citizen have in those circumstances? For 12 months, a public relations firm was able to convince newspaper editors—not only the local ones—and others, that rumours, not bad management, had caused the downfall.

The truth may be known at some time in the future when the Victorian Supreme Court decides to get itself out of the road and allow an inquiry, which has been held up by it for some time, to actually report. There is, of course, the problem that, if there happens to be a change of government in Victoria, the report will probably be buried in government pigeonholes because the Liberal Party has close connections with the organisations involved in this exercise.

There is one other thing that I think is important that we understand about the responsibility of auditors. If, in fact, there are attached to the audit report, qualifications—and there usually are—which indicate that the auditors do not feel that the audit has been properly conducted, or that the audit does not necessarily reflect the current situation of the company, it should be an obligation for the balance sheet of the company to carry that qualification clearly and precisely. That is not always done; certainly, it is information that a potential investor is entitled to have.

One other matter which concerns me—and this also forms part of the audited balance sheet of this particular organisation—is that, in announcing the annual report, the chairman was able to indicate that the liquidity ratio was 17.2 per cent. It is now known that that liquidity ratio included what were called non-redeemable shares, a device which was thought up probably somewhere else but, nevertheless, was used to inject what was said to be equity into the organisation without the principals having to advance funds.

In the Victorian Supreme Court in recent weeks, Mr Justice Vincent has indicated that that equity was raised in some cases by false pretences. I do not know whether charges will be laid because the report of the inquiry has not come down. But it is clear that many thousands of people were misled into believing that, in buying shares in this particular organisation, they were in fact investing in another form of deposit investment, not in a liability share where they had no guarantee whatsoever of a refund of their moneys.

Quite honestly, I cannot understand why many of those shareholders have not sued the principals of the organisation, including the directors, who have some responsibility if their shares were sold under false pretences. That is the import of what Mr Justice Vincent found. No-one is clean in this area, but we are inquiring into the nature of the law and the right of shareholders to know what is going on in an organisation and the manner in which stock exchanges are able to conduct their business, so that shareholders are able to make a judgment on their own as to the value of what they might purchase or the competing interests of those who are selling. Under the present law that judgment cannot be made. The audit standards are one area where the law has to come up to date in order to ensure that information that bears an auditor's signature has the status and standing that I believe most members of the community believe it has and that I certainly believe it should have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This is a very important report and I am going to quote comments made by the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), especially, and comments made by some of my colleagues. Whilst I appreciate the comments of the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) about a certain building society in Victoria, I think it is unfortunate that he perhaps lowered the debate somewhat by crystal balling what the Liberal Party may or may not do. If the honourable member of Corio were really fair dinkum about all this, he would have put in everything, rather than pulling out a parcel of what may or may not happen in relation to the Pyramid Building Society.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that, if there were to be fairness about this and overall responsibility, he would have even mentioned the comments of the former Treasurer of Victoria, Mr Jolly, in February of the year of the collapse, when he said that the organisation was rock solid and there was no need for anyone to have any concerns about the financial viability of it. If we are going to allocate responsibility for community perceptions in relation to this matter, I think the Victorian Labor Government has equal responsibility with many others involved, both within and outside the organisation.
But I do not want to speak about that in particular today. The Chairman perhaps summed up the rationale for this report when he addressed the House on 28 November and quite rightly said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's approach has not been to seek scapegoats for the failures in corporate behaviour and regulations, rather to identify deficiencies in the regulatory landscape and to suggest mechanisms to empower market participants, particularly investors, in enforcing their rights and responsibilities.

I congratulate the Chairman on that comment because I think it takes a sensible approach to what is indeed a matter that caused us all great concern during the 1980s. My colleague the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) made the comment that it is appropriate not to overreact to these sorts of things. My concern is that, if we go down the path of rigidity, there is some risk that we can actually direct endeavours into antisocial practices, as opposed to perhaps achieving what we wanted to achieve, and that is to avoid them. Although I am a believer in some regulation, I believe that rigidity of regulation can sometimes achieve what it actually did not want to achieve and it can take an opposite purpose.

PARA.TAB: Self-regulation versus legislative regulation is a matter which I suspect has been coming before this House since 1901. I am sure that the question will be raised again in the next 100 years. I have no doubt that the honourable member for Fisher and I will not be here in 100 years but I am sure that the matters we are debating today will be raging into the next 10 or 15 years.

I was not on the Committee when this report was tabled so I was not privy to the discussions nor indeed was I privy to the discussions that the Committee had with various people around Australia. I am sorry that I was not on the Committee at that stage because I believe, from speaking to my colleagues, that some very interesting discussions took place with a great number of people.

The other thing we need to do is look at what the driving force is that pushes those people into antisocial and anti-commercial practices. Of course, this report could never have addressed that but I think that it is an interesting question that we need to address further down the line. Is it a matter of greed; is it a matter of overt enthusiasm for the particular institution that a company officer might be working for; or is it a perception that the Government is not assisting that particular business or business in general? I would like to sit down with someone who has been involved in this antisocial behaviour to find out what their motives were for it. I can see the smile on the honourable member for Fisher's face. Perhaps he would be interested to join me in those discussions to try to get away from the legislative and legal parts and find out exactly what the reasons were.

The difficulty, of course, in any question on regulation is that there is a fine line between interfering with the rights of company officers to properly run the business and the rights of shareholders. I think that this report seeks to put a far greater onus—an onus that I certainly support—on those who have an intimate knowledge of the running of the company. I think that it is fair to say that the 99 per cent of Australian shareholders who are normally small investors would know very little about the particular company in which they have a shareholding. There would be very few who would go to annual general meetings of those organisations. They do not have an intimate knowledge. They rely very heavily on the good faith of the officers of that company. Therefore, when looking at the regulatory model that needs to be set up in relation to the proper conduct of Australian business, it has to be appreciated that that onus lies with those who have the more intimate knowledge. I think that recommendation 18 addresses the sorts of concerns that I have. It allows, in effect, third parties to regulate the way that Australian business is conducted.

A number of my colleagues have expressed some concerns in a reservation, and I have my name on that, in relation to recommendation 26. I think that my colleague the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) encapsulated my concerns about that when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: My concern was that, by empowering former shareholders and former directors to bring such actions, people who had no connection with the wrong that was being taken up in the company's name and who possibly had no interest in the outcome of the action would be bringing actions in the company's name.

I think it is important that, when it comes to allowing the derivative action, the court should assess who is the most appropriate person to bring the corporation's right of action. It may be that a former shareholder who was not there at the time the wrong was committed and has no interest in the outcome is not the right person to enforce the corporation's right of action. If provision is made for the court to take that into account, as I have said in the reservation, I have no difficulty; but I think to widen the class and not make any specific proposal as to how that can be taken into account is too bald and too wide on the basis of the evidence that came before the Committee. That is why we entered that reservation.

PARA.TAB: In summary, I believe this is an important report not just for this Parliament but for corporations in this country, because it gives them direction and shows them that this Parliament does not necessarily want to wield a big stick, but the Parliament quite rightly expects that antisocial corporate behaviour should not continue. I think that we can go forward with these recommendations, which set a framework for a realistic and responsible approach. I hope the Government will take up the recommendations.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
Bill presented by Mr Hawker.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pity that this Bill was ever necessary. It is a great pity that the Government could not consult properly with interest groups, that the Government could not listen. What this Bill is all about is to repeal part of the Australian design rule No. 19.01 which deals with electrical connections on motorcycles. The aim of the Australian design rule which has come into force as of 1 March 1992 is to force all new motorcycles that are sold from 1 March onwards to have the headlight wired on so that, when the engine is started, the headlight will automatically come on. In this Bill we deal specifically with clause 19.6.106.9 of that Australian design rule No. 19.01. We are specifically moving that this be removed.

PARA.TAB: I must say that in my time as a shadow Minister, I have never seen an issue so unite an interest group in total opposition. I have not had one single motorcyclist come to me and say that this is a good move—not one. I have, as I say, consulted widely; I have met with many, and all of them give the same answer, that compulsorily having lights on is not the way to go to improve road safety.

The key point is that when you look for the research evidence, both in Australia and overseas, you find that what is lacking is conclusive evidence that having lights wired on is in fact going to add to road safety. It means, therefore, that the decision to have a light wired on is one that has been taken by the Government in haste, one that has been taken without properly researching the issue and one that has clearly been taken without properly consulting those most directly affected.

I believe very strongly that the decision to turn on the light on a motorcycle during the day should be the responsibility of the individual rider. While the majority of cyclists do turn their lights on at least some of the time when they are riding, there are other times when experienced riders are quite adamant that having the light on can add to the risk and in fact is sometimes downright dangerous.

There are a couple of other points that I do not believe the Government has thought through in changing the Australian design rule. One of them is the question of legal liability. It is still not clear whether or not this will add to the liability of the motorcyclist who may be involved in an accident with a motor car because it will be very difficult in most cases to prove whether or not the light was actually on. The globe might have blown five seconds before the accident, or the day before. It will be very hard to prove whether that was the case or whether in fact the globe was smashed in the accident. So the question of legal liability could become quite an interesting one and, of course, there are ramifications for insurance.

The other point about changing the design rule is that it could add to a false sense of security, if people believe by having the light wired on it will somehow make them safer. Of course, in many cases, it could be the exact opposite. There are other concerns, which I will explore when there is a full debate. There is the question of the difficulty some motorists have in judging the speed and the distance apart of an oncoming vehicle with its headlights on. Again, this is where it could, in fact, add to danger rather than add to safety. Then, of course, we have the nonsense with agbikes having to have the light on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ridiculous.

—It is quite ridiculous, as my colleague points out. So I would like to say that, while I support very strongly all efforts to improve road safety, I believe this whole lights on issue is just a misguided diversion—one where the Minister responsible has totally misread what has happened. Frankly, I think it is an indication of a government that has lost touch with the people.

PARA.TAB: Bill read a first time.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—In accordance with sessional order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
Bill presented by Mr Cobb.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Crimes (Protection of Australian Flags) Bill 1992 which says, in essence, that a person who desecrates or otherwise dishonours the Australian national flag or an Australian ensign, or without lawful authority burns, mutilates or otherwise destroys the Australian national flag or an Australian ensign, shall be guilty of an offence with a maximum penalty of $5,000 or imprisonment for two years or both.

PARA.TAB: The history of the introduction of this Bill has been long and tortuous. I first introduced an almost identical Bill into the House on 4 May 1989. The Government did not allow it to come on for debate, so the coalition moved for debate as a matter of urgency in the Budget session of that year; but the Government refused to allow a second reading debate and gagged the motion.

The following year, on 31 May 1990, I reintroduced the Bill, as it had lapsed. On 23 August 1990 and on 18 October 1990 there was a brief, almost token, second reading debate during private members' business before the debate was terminated. During that debate there was unanimous support from coalition members for this Bill, and I was pleased to see there was considerable support from Government members also for the Bill.

Nevertheless, it was allowed to lapse again and on 30 May 1991 I had to reintroduce the Bill. The Government chose to let it lapse yet again and today, on 5 March 1992, I have reintroduced this Bill for the fourth time. On the times this Bill has been introduced previously, I have detailed how the need for it came about. Basically, there is no penalty in Australia for those who deface or dishonour our flag. I strongly believe that, if a flag is worth having, it is worth protecting.

The great majority of Australian people have had a gutful of unkempt demonstrators burning our flag in front of television cameras. Most citizens of this country find such behaviour grossly offensive and distressing. I believe such behaviour mocks our traditions and mocks our heritage simply for selfish gain and to get some cheap publicity for their cause—which is usually totally unrelated to what they are doing to our flag. There are penalties against such behaviour in many countries, and I believe it is well overdue that such penalties were also introduced here.

The arguments against this Bill are usually based on superficialities or misunderstandings. Some say that the penalties, for example, are too severe. I stress that they are maximum penalties and, like all penalties, the penalty will reflect the degree of the offence and usually would be of much less severity. There is nothing particularly draconian about these penalties in this Bill. They are par for the course for an offence of this nature, and they are similar to what is in legislation in other countries such as Norway, New Zealand, Japan and America.

Some say that stopping this activity will infringe civil liberties. It never ceases to amaze me why civil liberty people seem all too ready to jump to the defence of those who want to burn our national flag in protest. The energies of these people would be much better directed towards the victims of crimes in society. Civil libertarians always seem pretty thin on the ground in this area.

There are ample opportunities in this country for people to protest without offending the great majority of Australian people by burning Australian flags. We have to have limits on behaviour in this country. We do not allow graffiti artists to display their efforts on the walls of the Australian National Gallery, for example. We have to draw the line somewhere. I stress that these people who protest are not actually protesting against the flag as such but against something else which is totally unrelated. I make no apology for wanting to draw the line about our national symbol.

If we ban burning the flag, it will actually do these people's cause good because all they do is alienate the great mass of the Australian community. Some people believe that this would include flags on T-shirts, but I stress that these are not flags at all; these are only reproductions. At the worst it would only be a breach of etiquette, protocol or convention. People who display flags on T-shirts and such are not exactly dishonouring the flag; they actually are very proud of it. I urge support of the Bill. (Time expired)
Bill read a first time.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—In accordance with sessional order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
Debate resumed from 5 September 1991, on motion by Mr Hawker:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Flags Amendment Bill has one aim and one aim only, that is, to entrench the current Australian flag so that the flag cannot be altered except by a referendum passed by a majority of electors throughout the Australian States and Territories.

PARA.TAB: I want to say two principal things about this amendment Bill. Firstly, in trying to achieve its aim it is fundamentally flawed. Secondly, I wish to canvass the principal issue involved, which concerns whether Australia should at this stage be considering changing its flag and what mechanisms should be employed if that consideration is to go ahead.

Where this particular Bill is flawed is that it attempts to impose a requirement of a referendum before the flag can be changed by adding a new section 9(1) to the Flags Act. This proposed new section requires that a referendum be held before the flag can be changed. However, the difficulty that the mover of this private member's Bill has is that, while that Act can be changed to put in a requirement that there be a referendum before the flag can be changed, he has not put in a requirement that that proposed new section, if incorporated into the principle Act, could not be removed by subsequent amendment.

The aim of the exercise is to take out of the hands of this Parliament basically the change of the Australian flag and put it in the hands of the Australian people, but he does not take out of the hands of this Parliament the ability to merely remove that provision, if enacted, out of the Act. That might seem a moot point, but it is not. It came to light in Queensland in the mid-1970s when the then Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, was somewhat concerned with the way in which the Whitlam Government was going at that stage.

Honourable members might recall that the Whitlam Government started moving down the track of asserting Australian independence and cutting some of the remaining ties between Australia and Great Britain. I suppose the most notable of those actions was the removal of the right of appeal from the Australian High Court to the Privy Council. As well as removing that right of appeal, the Whitlam Government went down the track of installing an Australian honours system and attempting to remove the imperial honours system. Even though that did exist for a considerable time in some of the States, it was removed at a national level.

Sir Joh was apparently alarmed that this may then extend to the Queen no longer being the Queen of Australia, even though it was, in fact, a Whitlam Government which installed the Queen as Queen of Australia. In response, however, Sir Joh succeeded in changing the Queensland Constitution to make the Queen the Queen of Queensland. As is the case with this particular Act, the Flags Act, the Queensland Constitution is merely an Act of the Queensland Parliament. That is, it is not like the Commonwealth Constitution which can be amended only by way of referendum. The Queensland Constitution is like any Act of parliament, and can be amended by a subsequent parliament.

Sir Joh, realising this and being somewhat more suspicious of the motives of the Labor Party than those of the good honourable member who has introduced this particular Bill, attempted to doubly entrench the provision to make the Queen the Queen of Queensland. By that, he required not only that there be a referendum so that this provision of the Queen of Queensland could be changed, but that the provision installing that in the Constitution could itself be removed only by referendum.

That raised a whole variety of interesting legal points, particularly around whether a parliament can bind a subsequent parliament in that way in an interpretation of section 11 of the Colonial Laws Validity Act. I will not get into the constitutional niceties of the argument except to say that it was broadly accepted in legal circles in Queensland after the Queensland Parliament passed provisions in that way. It was effectively entrenched that the status of the Queen of Queensland now can be removed only by way of referendum.

The mover of this particular private member's Bill attempts to secure the same end, that is, to have the Australian flag changed only by way of referendum. But unfortunately for the mover, he has not placed his mind to the fact that the provision itself requiring the referendum can be removed by Act of parliament. Hence in a legal way it is really quite useless. Having said that, I think it would be quite wrong that if this amendment were passed by this Parliament a subsequent parliament should ignore the express wishes of this Act and attempt to circumvent its clear intention, by merely removing the provision, even though that course would be open.

Whether you want to take point with the effectiveness of the procedure or not, the point then turns upon whether Australia should, at this time, be considering the flag and whether it is still appropriate for Australia. Like most members in this place, one of my more pleasant duties is to present Australian flags to schools, organisations and clubs, and I suppose during the four and a bit years that I have been a member of this place, the number of flags I have presented is probably now in the hundreds. They are one of the few things members of parliament actually can give away for free, so it is always a great joy to be able to give something rather than always seeming to take things.

I believe that there is a strong patriotism amongst Australians. Wearing their hearts on their sleeves is not something which Australians are renowned for, but in times of national crisis or great national pride we certainly do see public expressions of patriotism in this country. Like any issue, to two different people, patriotism can mean two different things.

To many Australians, to be patriotic means sticking to what they see to be the traditions of this country and paying great credence to our British heritage, of which the Australian flag is a very important symbol. There is also the argument that the flag was a symbol which was used by Australia in time of war, and is always flown when Australia is competing at Olympic Games or other international events, when we are present at the United Nations, and things of that nature.

I respect people's views about this, and to that extent it is probably appropriate that before we change the Australian flag there should be a deep public debate and ultimately a vote on behalf of the Australian people. Whether it is necessary to require by Act of this Parliament that there be a referendum before the change can take place, or whether the procedure should rather be as when we selected Advance Australia Fair as our national anthem—by way of a referendum not required by law—is again a matter we could have some debate about.

My personal view about the flag is that it should be changed. I do not believe that it is particularly appropriate, as Australia approaches its centenary as an independent nation, that the Union Jack should feature as part of our national flag, but I understand that many people could have deeply and sincerely held views opposite to that.

The major feature of our flag which symbolises the great southern continent is the Southern Cross, and I think a flag based around a design of the Southern Cross would be an appropriate national symbol. I think we now are at the stage that we should be debating this issue, maybe up to the centenary of our nationhood. Maybe at that time it would be appropriate for there to be a referendum and the selection of a new flag, if that is what the majority of Australians want.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to speak in support of the Flags Amendment Bill because I wholeheartedly agree with the provisions it contains. In 1985 my Liberal colleague, Senator Peter Durack, introduced a similar Bill into the Senate. It was passed unanimously.

PARA.TAB: The same outcome has yet to be achieved in the House of Representatives, although it has not been for want of trying. This is the fourth time the Coalition has attempted to have this Bill passed. It is a simple, straightforward piece of legislation, not complicated in any way.

The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Flags Act 1953 to ensure our Australian national flag cannot be altered except with the approval of the Australian people voting in a referendum. Anyone who argues that this Bill has been designed to prevent our flag being changed has missed the whole point of the exercise. There is nothing in this Bill that states or even implies that changes cannot or will not be made; only that they cannot be imposed without the consent of the Australian people.

If a majority of Australians say, `Yes, we want the flag changed', then it will be changed. If the majority says no, then under the provisions of this Bill the flag will remain as it is. Surely this is what democracy is all about. Unfortunately, some members of the Government do not seem to agree with this simple and basic democratic proposition. If they did, they would be supporting the passage of this Bill. Instead, they argue that protection is not necessary because they do not have any plans to alter our flag—at the moment.

Their protestations and assurances are of little consequence and even less relevance, because the Bill does not only apply to this present Government but to all future governments, irrespective of their particular political persuasion. If and when this Bill is passed, and the proposed amendment becomes law, it will be just as binding on a Liberal-National Party government as on a Labor one, and that is exactly how it should be, because the flag we are talking about in this debate—the Australian national flag—is not the property of the government of the day, or of the Parliament. It is the people's flag and it belongs to all Australians, and the right and proper way to find out whether or not the Australian people want it changed is to ask them by way of a referendum. What could be more reasonable or sensible? What could be a fairer or more accurate test of public opinion?

Of course, there will be those who protest that it is often very difficult to achieve change via a referendum pathway. There is certainly some evidence to indicate that the Australian people are inherently suspicious of referenda and are therefore inclined to vote to preserve the status quo. And on past experience, who can blame them?

However, I am very confident that the majority of the Australian people are well able to assess the merits of a particular proposal. They know whether they want to accept it or reject it and they cast their votes accordingly. The fact that so relatively few proposals get the nod at referendum time is not so much a reflection on the abilities of the voters to grasp the issues as on the quality of the proposals put before them.

At the same time as members of the coalition parties are endeavouring to secure Government support for this legislation, there is a concerted effort by an organisation known as Ausflag Ltd to deprive the Australian people of their right to determine the future of our most important national symbol. The supporters of Ausflag Ltd want to change our flag, and they want to change it now. They want to change it for all the wrong reasons—and most regrettably—they want to change it via the back door.

In a letter sent to members of parliament towards the end of last year, Mr Scruby, the Executive Director of Ausflag, left no questions in anyone's mind as to the Ausflag agenda, or how it intends to implement it. When I started to read Mr Scruby's letter I was not sure whether he was confused or simply ill-informed. Mr Scruby wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: It is vital in these times that Australia has its own flag.

I could not agree more, Mr Scruby. It is vital that we have our own flag. Fortunately, we have a very good one and we have had it now for almost 100 years. If our Australian national flag is not our flag, then whose is it?

PARA.TAB: But then I read on and it became alarmingly clear that Mr Scruby and the organisation he represents are not really concerned about Australia having its own flag at all. What they actually want is for us to have their flag and they are determined to impose it on us whether we like it or not.

The problem seems to be the Union Jack which Mr Scruby and Ausflag are not very keen on at all. Mr Scruby is at pains to point out in his letter that the Australian people do not even have to be consulted about this matter.He suggests:

SPEECH.PARA: A change to the Australian flag can be effected by a simple Act of Parliament.

He makes it all sound so easy. A simple Act of Parliament. I would not describe it as a simple Act, Mr Scruby; I would describe it as a grossly irresponsible and totally unacceptable Act. And I do not believe for one moment that members of this Parliament, even the Prime Minister, who recently advocated changing our flag, would countenance such an underhanded, divisive and basically dishonest course of action.

PARA.TAB: In their determination to convince Australians that the Union Jack should be expunged from our flag, the Ausflag people go to quite extraordinary lengths to deceive and mislead. Among other things, they suggest that our present flag has some detrimental effect on our potential to increase our export markets. Where is the proof to back up this absurd claim? Where is the evidence of one major—or for that matter, one minor—contract lost because of the appearance of our flag? Waterfront reform and an improved industrial relations system are what is needed to improve our export potential and competitiveness. Our flag has nothing to do with it.

They also claim that our flag is confusing to the rest of the world. Actually, it is not our flag but New Zealand's flag, which looks very like ours, that seems to be causing all the trouble. I have a simple solution to both these problems. Why do we not export Ausflag Ltd to New Zealand and let it try to convince our friends across the Tasman to change their flag? In that way we can kill two birds with one stone—an increase in our exports and an end to all the confusion.

The Ausflag people and others of similar ilk may want to change our flag but they cannot change our past. Whether they like it or not, altering the design of our flag will not and cannot alter facts that are now history. Australia was a British colony, a part of the British Empire, and our flag reflects that fact. Our language, our parliamentary system, our legal system, and the protections and safeguards of our system of government, which are reinforced by a constitutional monarchy, are all institutions which we have inherited from Britain, and they are inextricably woven into the fabric of our Australian heritage and our Australian society.

To claim that we need a new flag to signify that we are an independent nation in our own right is to replace reality with absurdity. Rather than proving we are coming of age, it would be a startling example of our ongoing immaturity. We are already an independent nation. If some of us have not yet come to grips with this fact, a new flag certainly will not help. Flags cannot create national pride and confidence or a sense of national purpose and identity; they can only reflect it. If we are uncertain about who we are, why we are and where we are going, the problem lies with us, not with our flag.
Finally, I would like to read some verses of a poem entitled Our Flag. The author may be unknown, but the sentiments expressed are certainly worth sharing:

SPEECH.PARA: Our Flag bears the stars that blaze at night,
In our southern skies of blue,
And a little old flag in the corner
That's part of our heritage, too.
It's for the English, the Scots and the Irish,
Who were sent to the ends of the earth,
The rogues and schemers, the doers and dreamers,
Who gave modern Australia birth.
And you who are shouting to change it—
You don't seem to understand,
It's the Flag of OUR law and OUR language,
Not the flag of some faraway land.
It doesn't mean we owe allegiance
To a forgotten imperial dream,
We've the stars to show where we're going—
And the old flag to show where we've been.
Mr Deputy Speaker, the coalition parties have never wavered in their support for and determination to protect our beloved Australian flag—long and proudly may it fly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not planned to speak on this Bill today, but as the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) is ill, I have had to step into the breach. I have listened with a great deal of interest to the debate so far. As I understand it, the Bill seeks to compel anybody who wants to change the Australian flag to hold a referendum. I must say that this is rather novel in the federal sense because, at least up until now, referendums have only been used to try to change the Constitution and, as it has been pointed out, not very successfully. In fact, I think the only time referendums have got up in the past has been when the Labor Party has joined with the Government to ensure that the proposals have been passed.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the latest set of referendum proposals, it gives us a fair idea of how much value the Liberal Party and the National Party put on referendums. For those who cannot remember, in 1988 the Government put up four different proposals, one of which was to recognise local government. One would have thought that in the grand scheme of things local government plays a significant part in Australian government, and yet the Liberal Party and the National Party advocated a no vote against recognition of local government in the Australian Constitution. If they are as shameless as that about something as important as the role of local government in Australian government and they advocate a no vote for that, how can they be trusted with anything else?

I honestly think the holding of referendums should be, as it is now, only to change our Constitution. Let us face it, the Opposition now is putting up a proposal radically to change our tax system, with no talk of a referendum for that. The difference between the daily impact of changing our flag and of changing our tax system is obvious. Obviously, the well-being of the Australian people would be very much more disadvantaged financially by the proposals being put up by the Liberal and National parties to tax food and clothing, and yet there is no talk of a referendum on that. The honourable members of the Opposition are quite happy for those sorts of pieces of legislation to go through this Parliament, but mention the flag and the reaction is, `Oh no, we cannot put that through the Parliament. This Parliament is not representative enough to change the flag', and yet they think food and clothing can be taxed without having recourse to the Australian people.

I have noticed that today the honourable member opposite introduced another Bill to do with the flag. It seems to me the Liberal Party and the National Party have a fetish about flags when they are in opposition. Between 1975 and 1983 they were the Government. I would have thought that this fetish, had it existed back then, could have been accommodated then. They could have passed legislation then because they controlled the Senate and the House of Representatives. So how is it, here in 1992 when they are in opposition, that they bring up this proposal when they were not prepared to do it when they were in government?

It seems to me to be self-evident. The honourable members opposite have not much to talk about so here we are talking about the flag. Let us just assume that they are dinkum about this referendum proposal, that there are good reasons for it and forget everything I have said. Consider just the practical difficulties. One assumes, of course, that there is a choice between the existing flag and one other. It may not be. Ausflag, to which the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) referred, had a number of proposals. A referendum cannot sort that out. The mechanics of it just cannot work with a referendum. I think that if we were to change our flag then this Parliament should do it, or it should be announced.

I do not know the legal obstacles to changing the flag. I know a few years ago we changed the national anthem from God Save the Queen to Advance Australia Fair. That was announced by the Prime Minister and the sun still came up the next day. Australia still carried on. There was no talk then about referendums about changing the national anthem. I think the legislation that has been put up is totally unnecessary. I am not going to support it, even though I think that in 1992, as we come towards the year 2001, the 100th anniversary of the Commonwealth, it would be a good time to change the flag, there is no doubt about that. I think Australia in 2001 will be a totally different country to what it was in 1901. The make-up of our population, the aspirations we have, are certainly much different now than they were back then. So for those reasons I would favour a change and also the proclamation of a republic at the same time. It seems that, as we mature as a country and as we make our way in the world, both of those things could happen in 2001.

I am always reminded of this matter, as are other speakers, when I go to schools to present flags. At one school I went to I asked them what they knew about the flag, and their response was very little. So I gave them the little book that we all hand out. But I did ask them how many of them knew what the Canadian flag looked like and everybody in the school put up their hand. These were only primary school children. I cannot remember exactly but they might have been years five or six. They all knew the Canadian flag, a very distinctive flag.

I lived in Canada for about two years and I know the sorts of arguments we are getting in Australia about changing the flag. We are told how everybody died for the flag, when in actual fact they died more for their country than for their flag. The Canadians had this argument about 30 years ago, but they overcame it. Do honourable members know who the greatest defenders of the flag are now? The greatest defenders of the flag are their equivalent of our RSL. They think it is a great flag. There are people in Canada who would not even know what the old Canadian flag was like. It was a fairly unspectacular flag, unlike the one they have now.

I think the change of the flag in Canada actually gave the country a much better identity, or a more identifiable character.
