It is certainly supported by all the people in Canada now and they would never get a proposition to go back to the old one. I suppose the most visible display of somebody wanting to change the flag occurred at the time of the America's Cup back in 1983 when Mr Bond and the Challenge crew did not use the Australian flag but used a green flag with a boxing kangaroo on it to identify themselves as Australians. They did that because outside this country, nobody knows our flag.

On occasion, when Australians have travelled overseas, the New Zealand flag has been hoisted up in error because they are so similar. We can see the frustration of an international sporting crew, like the America's Cup crew, who actually won the cup, having to design a flag of their own to identify themselves as Australians. That sort of thing should not happen, and it really does display to us the fact that the Australian flag just is not doing the job. For all of those reasons, I would say that the Australian Flag should be changed.

In a previous debate there was some talk about the time when we changed the currency. I was only a kid back then, but I think it was Sir Robert Menzies who wanted to call the new currency the `royal', or something like that. Thank goodness that it ended up as the dollar. Could honourable members imagine spending 40 royals or 50 royals a week? It is just mad stuff.

I suppose that this debate also just points to the difference between the Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties. The Labor Party is the party of progress, the party that is looking to the future, whereas the conservatives are trapped in the past, want to hang onto everything in the past, and really would be more happy in the 1950s than in the 1990s.
For all of those reasons, I oppose the Bill. Like many members on this side, I look forward to the day on which Australia does have a new flag and, hopefully, becomes a republic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the Flags Amendment Bill, which argues that, before our national flag can be changed, a referendum should be held so that the voice of the Australian people can be heard. I am amazed at the opposition from the Government members who have spoken this morning. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), said that we cannot have a referendum on such things. If my memory serves me correctly, it was the Fraser Government that had a referendum on determining what Australia's national song would be. I voted for the wrong one; I voted for Waltzing Matilda at the time. That is how we determined that we would have Advance Australia Fair.

PARA.TAB: I also find it very distressing, as I believe the majority of Australian people do, that the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) seems hell-bent on having our national flag changed or, more specifically, having the Union Jack removed from the top left-hand corner of our flag.

As well as that, he has combined this opposition to our flag with slamming the British. It is interesting to examine why he might be doing this. There probably are a number of reasons. In part, it is his bog Irish coming out. He seems to have a cultural imprint which has imprisoned him with certain prejudices and which has sequestered his mind in such a way that he cannot rise above this irrational and paranoid dislike of everything English. In part, it is also because he wants to create a diversion. This is an old ploy; it has been used back since the time of the French Revolution and probably earlier than that: he wants to create a diversion away from the economic mess this country is in today, with a million jobless and a net overseas debt of $145 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder he wants a diversion.

—Exactly. The inadequacy of the economic statement did nothing for the misery and hardship in this country today. I have to acknowledge that, in creating this diversion, he was largely successful. Also, in part, he has raised this thing of Australia becoming a republic and doing away with our flag because he has wanted to unite the left wing behind him in his own Party. Again, I have to acknowledge that he has been successful. The left wing has been gullible in this. Those who were opposing him only a couple of weeks ago seem, from statements they have made, to have fallen in behind him, though I often wonder where the allegiances of these people lie. I noted, when the Queen was here only last week, that those who have been most often in opposition to her were in the front line to shake her hand and meet her, standing there giggling with excitement and expectation and fawning all over her. I have some difficulty in finding what they actually do believe in.

PARA.TAB: I remind honourable members who are in opposition to this Bill that the flag was not imposed upon the Australian people by some anglophile bureaucrat or politician; it was decided by the Australian people themselves. On 1 January 1901 the six colonies that occupied this continent decided to unite into one Commonwealth of Australia.

We decided, naturally enough, that it would be a good idea to have a flag, and we had a competition to choose an Australian flag. There were over 30,000 entries. There was a panel set up to judge the best entries. Five people were chosen because they had similar designs. Those five people were: Mrs A. Dorrington of Perth, Mr E. J. Nuttall of Melbourne, Mr Ivor Evans of Melbourne, Mr Leslie Hawkins of Sydney, and, interestingly enough, Mr W. Stephens of Auckland. So the flag we have today was chosen by the Australian people.

I think most Australians are very proud, as I am, of the flag. It reflects many things. It reflects our present and it reflects our past. The Southern Cross reflects our present, which can, to all intents and purposes, only be seen from the southern hemisphere. The number of points on each of the stars is significant. There are seven points on each of the stars—except for the little fifth one on the Southern Cross—representing the six States: one each for the States and one for the two Territories. Also, the blue of the flag represents the sea that surrounds this country.

The past is represented by the Union Jack in the corner; it represents our heritage and it is from there—as the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) said—that we got our system of democracy, our system of justice with common law and fair play and the Australian version of that, a fair go for all. We also got our education system and our language from England—though I do note that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) sometimes abuses that. But 75 per cent of Australians still come from that part of the world—England, Scotland or Ireland. The freedoms that we enjoy, including the freedoms that the Prime Minister enjoys, are based upon that heritage. Why the Prime Minister wants to deny that part of our history is quite beyond me.

Those who oppose our present flag talk about a cultural cringe. They say that the Union Jack says that we somehow are subservient or inferior or whatever, that we have not proven ourselves by fully displaying our independence. But to me that is similar to saying that you have to change your surname when you turn 21, or else you cannot prove that you are independent of your father. The whole concept is a nonsense. I believe that instead we should be proud of our lineage and we should acknowledge it. I would say that it is the Prime Minister himself who suffers from the cultural cringe.

New Zealand is happy to have the Union Jack on its flag, as is Hawaii and as is South Africa. The Prime Minister cites the case of the Canadian flag, which was changed 20-odd years ago. While it is a very attractive flag, it has not united the country any more. The country is just as divided between the francophiles and the anglophiles.
I would like to quote from the Prime Minister's radio interview that he gave on 31 January on 6WF in Perth. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . .the flag has to be the emblem of a united country, it has been that. But I think there is probably some ambivalence in our message as we go into the international forums and the international marketplace draped in a somewhat ambivalent garb with a flag which has obviously, a flag of another country in its corner. I should think Australians would think they were advantaged in the world in the international marketplace where we are now trading much more than we ever were in the past with something which was the emblem of a country which unambiguously has a flag which represents it and nobody else.
Later in the interview he said:

It doesn't surprise me this debate is around because people, I suppose people around the world are entitled to say, well look, we look at your flag, you have the flag of another country in the corner. I mean are you a colony or are you a nation? You are entitled to ask the question. The Canadians gave them an answer, they said now we are one country, we are ourselves, we are independent, we look like we are and we represent ourselves as an independent country.
Another question from the interviewer Kennedy was:
Is it a change you would like to see while you are Prime Minister?
The Prime Minister replied:
I think it is something that ought to come in its turn, as the community feels that such a change is warranted. . .

It is totally unambiguous that the Prime Minister wants the flag changed and the Union Jack taken out. But the arguments that he puts are nonsense. Who amongst us has ever been asked by overseas countries, before we do trade with them, whether we are ashamed to have the Union Jack in the corner? It is a very distinctive flag. There are very few distinctive flags in the world. The flags of most nations are only two or three stripes of different colours. Many flags are very similar and there is no demand for them to be changed. It is actually very hard to design a flag. I think the Ausflag competition in 1988 ended up with a design showing the Southern Cross and a yellow stripe along the bottom.

TALK.START.PARA: —All over the place.

—Exactly. That brought home to me just how beautiful our flag is. It is a distinctive flag, it is well accepted, it is working well. Why change it? I believe it is a disgrace to have the Prime Minister give a vote of no confidence in the flag. If the Prime Minister persists with this, instead of uniting the country he will divide it—for his own ends, selfishly—as he never has before. I believe he should shake off his cultural cringe and his dislike of everything Australian. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Flags Amendment Bill, I must say it seems fundamental to me that a referendum should take place on issues so important. There are very few things more symbolic than the flag, and it seems to me highly equitable and very proper that a referendum should take place. I know of no national flag in the world that has a longer history than the Australian flag. It embodies all our history, history that we are irrevocably heir to, together with what we have achieved in our own right since that time.

PARA.TAB: I want to quote here Dame Mary Gilmore, who must be seen as one of the great Australian nationalists. It is a line that I saw fit to print on a publication I have circulated, entitled An Australian Retrospective. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: Never allow the thoughtless to declare that we have no tradition here.

She is absolutely right. There are great traditions in Australia, traditions we should be proud to uphold. I suspect that the pressure to change the flag is coming from the people who would like to take away those traditions. As one member of this House mentioned earlier, there is a group in Australia—I would call it a dissident group—that has always been looking for a republic or looking to change the flag. That group has never really amounted to much. In recent times it has been taken over by the multicultural industry.

PARA.TAB: The multicultural industry was foisted on the people of Australia by both political parties. The Australian people have never been given an opportunity to vote on this matter. If we had a referendum tomorrow on multiculturalism, the people of Australia, both the migrants and the native-born, would throw it out because it is probably the most divisive thing that has ever been established in this country.

What are the multiculturalists, and the people who run with them, seeking to do? The people in groups such as the Ausflag group and the Australian Republican Movement have been taken over by the multiculturalists. They are seeking to destroy the Anglo-Celtic culture, to remove it from our history so that they can have a blank piece of paper on which they can write their new history of Australia. They see Australia as a little republic that is going to open its arms to the whole world and become a melting pot for the whole world.

I saw recently that one of these advocates said that Australia could accommodate a population of 100 million people quite comfortably. Yes, Australia could accommodate 100 million people, but at a living standard somewhat worse than Bangladesh. I had never heard so much nonsense spoken. It appals me that it is given currency by some of the members in this House.

It is quite clear that this is where the pressure is coming from. There is also an element in Australia that says that we must show our independence, we must do something. What Australia must do is genuine achievement. I say to these people that there is no pressure from Britain threatening Australia's nationhood. There is no pressure from Britain undermining this country in any way. That pressure is coming from elsewhere. It is ready to create straw men to attack the flag that we have inherited.

We should consider what is really threatening Australia. Many of those people who seek to make Australia a republic and seek to change the flag are the very people who are busily taking us into north-east Asia. They are saying to us, in effect, `We must stop being colonies; we must stop being a colony of Britain'—the reality is that we have not been a colony of Britain for many, many years—`and we must now become a colony of Asia; we must tie ourselves to this new rising star'. These are the same people who took us from being a colony of Britain and tied us to the apron strings of America, something which I have objected to for many years. This was the continuation of the colonial cringe. What is happening is that this cringe is being sold to the Australian public as nationalism. It is not; it is the antithesis of Australian nationalism. It is a continuation of that cringe. I think it is a very dangerous way to be going.

We have heard that Canada changed its flag 25 years ago. Yes, it did change its flag. It now has a spectacular flag. It reminds me of an emblem that used to appear on a certain brand of flour. It certainly has not united the Canadian nation. I think it is inevitable that Canada is slowly but surely sinking to becoming a State of the United States. It already has a trade agreement with the United States. It is causing a lot of problems in Canada. I would say that the future for Canada under its new flag is not a great one.

We then come to the economic imperative. People are saying `Yes, we must have our own flag so that we can be more comfortable with our trading nations'. Quite frankly, the nations we trade with do not give a damn what flag we have. They trade with us for natural advantage. If we are supplying to them cheaper or better or more quickly, they will buy from us. They will buy from us no matter what the flag is. It is a matter of no consequence at all.

It is just another manifestation of this cultural cringe. People also say, `We Australians must seek approval from the world'. For my part, I say, `To hell with the world. This is our flag and we will make decisions about it. We are not going to be influenced by what the world thinks'. I think that is a message that ought to be drummed home to every politician in this House.

We are looking at the future. We are living in times of great change and we see enormous instability. There are people I see who are mindlessly applauding what is taking place in the Soviet Union, a Soviet Union that is very slowly groping towards the light, you might say, has been convulsed by what is virtually revolution and is now disintegrating. What we will see out of that as likely as a rise of democracy—in fact, I believe far more likely—is a rise of Islamic fundamentalism in its Asian provinces and a rise of the new German empire on its western front. Many of those small enclaves that have separated themselves from the Soviet Union are more likely to become fascist states than they are to become democratic. There is no history of democracy there.

Under these circumstances, it is going to put intolerable strain on the European Common Market. Already the French are getting wary of the Germans spanning into Eastern Europe and still trying to maintain their dominance of western Europe through the Common Market. I predict that the Common Market itself will come under intolerable strains. And even in Britain we see the same thing: this phenomenon rising where the Scots and the Welsh, or some of them, are wanting to go their own way.

It may be that, in a very short time, we could have a unique flag, a flag that told the world the history that is embodied in our flag. And what a great history it is. There is a tendency amongst the multicultural brigade to say, `All cultures are equal'. This is nonsense. All cultures are not equal. What the British culture has done is give the world the rule of law. It is this that is embodied in the United States. It is this that we have built on. It is that culture that has given us the sense of fair play that is expressed in Australia as the `fair go'. These are cultural things which are of great value and I see no harm in recognising whence they come.

I believe that changing the flag would be divisive. I do not see why, in the mad pursuit for some contrived unity, we should change the flag which is supported by the majority to placate a minority. In any case, where is this minority? To go back to multiculturalism, most migrants do not approve of it. Most migrants come to this country in a desire to be Australian. They come here because they see Australia as a place for the future, a place of advantage for their children. In many cases, they do not want to continue the shackles of life in their original country. I believe there is no great pressure from migrants to change the flag. Even if there were, should we as a nation succumb to that pressure? I say certainly not, and certainly not without a referendum.

I do have to say a couple of things about the national anthem. I did not vote for the national anthem that we have today. I think it is the anthem of a Third World country. The words are cringing and grovelling. I voted for Waltzing Matilda. I thought that would be an anthem that said, very proudly, `This is Australia'. Wherever one goes in the world, Waltzing Matilda is the Australian song. People say to me, `How can you possibly have an anthem about a sheep thief? I say, `It is our song and we can have what we like'. I do not care what the world thinks about our anthem. I would very proudly sing Waltzing Matilda. For one thing, I and most Australians know the words. If we are going to have any changes in Australia, I would advocate changing that pompous anthem that we have and going for something that is truly Australian, not the contrived drivel that we now stand for and mumble to simply because we do not know the words or, in some cases, because we do not approve of them.

In conclusion let me say that this is a fundamental issue. A referendum is absolutely essential before the flag is changed. I believe that any government that attempts to do otherwise will be severely rebuked by the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Flags Amendment Bill introduced by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). In doing so, I want to make a comment or two about the remarks made by my colleague the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I want to say to those who are in the gallery and those who may be listening to the Parliament on the airwaves that the remarks made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie are remarks that ought to be lauded and applauded around Australia. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie in many ways reflects what the life of this Parliament is all about. I can find sundry and assorted things on which he and I will disagree, numerous issues of policy on which we will disagree, but he is prepared to stand up and put a healthy independence into the debate, and I applaud him for it.

PARA.TAB: I am proud to be on this side of the Parliament because here independence is welcomed. Over half of my South Australian Liberal Federal parliamentary colleagues have crossed the floor because they believed in something that was bigger than the party. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie is a lone member of the Australian Labor Party who reflects a similar healthy independence, and it ought to be lauded and applauded and welcomed on his side of the House.

The Parliament has been largely failed, not by the party system but by the Press Gallery—and I do not reflect on Australian Associated Press—which has failed to see that sort of independence as democracy at its best. Instead, when members have crossed the floor, members of the press have wanted to allege that the leader was losing control.

I support this Bill, which seeks to have the flag that Australia owns as its own changed only by referendum. In common with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I spent my schoolboy days standing in a school yard and saying, `I love my country, I salute her flag, I honour her Queen, and I promise to obey her laws'. I did it with all the appropriate actions, in concert with the rest of the school. From my schoolboy perspective, King George VI and later Queen Elizabeth II were on the throne and lived in Buckingham Palace; Sir Robert Menzies lived in Canberra; and Sir Thomas Playford lived in Adelaide. My world was secure. It may not have been good—the influence may not have been perfect—but I insist that I was proud of it and that those traditions did not leave me warped, humiliated or negative. I felt no cultural cringe in claiming to love my country and salute her flag, and this morning I refuse to apologise for or abandon my heritage and my traditions.

I support the honourable member for Wannon's Flags Amendment Bill. Every Australian should ensure that the traditions that are so proudly ours cannot be altered except by referendum. We heard from the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) that, when the Opposition parties were in government, we did not introduce this sort of legislation. He is right; we did not—we had no need to. There was never any suggestion that we would propose a change to the flag unless the people of Australia had first sought it and a clear majority believed that it was in their interest.

He then drew the sort of long bow I could not believe, even from a man of his articulateness, in drawing a comparison between taxation changes in this country and our flag. That was almost indecent. We are not saying that the flag should never be changed, though personally I am quite comfortable with it in its present form, reflecting as it does almost 100 years of proud Australian history. What we are saying is that we on this side of the House do not wish to dictate the terms to the people of Australia. We believe that so important a change should occur only by referendum. That is what we are asking for, that is what the honourable member for Kalgoorlie endorses, and that simple proposition ought to be passed by this House and embraced by the Government. It is its refusal to embrace this very simple, reasonable proposition that makes us so suspicious about what its real agenda might be.

Our flag is a symbol designed to unite our nation in a common cause. If one belongs to a particular religious persuasion, one will know that there are symbols that are a part of every religious group and a part of their worship. If one belongs to a service club, one will know that, whether it is Rotary, Lions or Apex, each of these clubs has a symbol that gives its members an identity as Rotarians, Lions or Apexians. Even more acutely, all of our sporting bodies have symbols so that all of the people know whom they are barracking for, who their team is, and they can be united in a common cause to support that team.

Our flag is nothing more than a symbol of our national unity. As the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) has pointed out, a competition in which thousands of Australians participated resulted in five people coming up with a common theme, a flag with the Southern Cross dominating it, quite appropriately, and in its top left-hand corner the Union Jack. Are we supposed to apologise because the Union Jack is part of the Australian flag? This Union Jack, this symbol which is so much part of our culture, this flag of the nation that gave us our principles of law, our language and our parliamentary institution, is quite appropriately in the corner of our flag. In 1992, when we celebrate a nation now made up of people who are not just those with English origins but those who have come from all around the globe to be part of the Australian community, is it not appropriate that in the top left-hand corner of our flag there should be a symbol of unity—the Union Jack, the coming together of the flags of St Andrew, St Patrick and St George? It hardly seems inappropriate to me that that should be part of our flag.

What is proposed as an alternative? Should we take away the Union Jack and find some other symbol of Australia? A pie and chips perhaps? Of course we should not. Here we have a flag that for Australians has been a symbol of being Australian. We stand here to defend it and, even more appropriately, to say that it should change only when the majority of Australians want that sort of change.

The task of this Parliament, a task we all share, is a task of building a cohesive nation, not a divided one. I would be grateful if that message could be conveyed to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). What has been of major concern to me over the last month has not been his emphasis on various economic statements, but rather the way he seems to have gone about dividing the nation, as if he was more at ease being destructive than being constructive.

The role of the Prime Minister is to be constructive in bringing the nation together and in encouraging the nation to pull together. I think that he owes it to the people of Australia to promote not those things that are divisive but those things that are most likely to be cohesive.

In common with all of the members of this chamber, I enjoy going to schools and presenting the flag. I would remind the schoolchildren that this flag of ours, this 100-year-old symbol, has flown where Australians have participated in two world wars and in other conflicts. It has been displayed wherever we have proudly been successful in sporting events and it has been there when courageous Australians such as Mawson have undertaken what are literally impossible feats of human endurance in the name of our country. Mawson, as the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) pointed out, was proud of the flag.

Why should we feel strangely apologetic about a flag that includes the Union Jack symbol? The white on the French flag is a symbol of a monarchy that has been gone from France for 100 years. The red stripes on the flag of the United States are a part of what was once the British red ensign. It may be that we will find our future in South East Asia but our flag is not an impediment to trade—as the member for Casey (Mr Halverson) has pointed out—and much more important will be micro-economic reform. I want to conclude with this statement from Mr Anto Santoro:

SPEECH.PARA: To say that the need to strip the Union Jack from our flag to show that we are a Sovereign Nation, is like saying that a person who turns 18 must burn their birth certificate in order to prove that they are an adult.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired and the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)expresses serious concern at the overreaction of the banks to their lax lending during the 1980s, and the resulting bad debts, as demonstrated by their being excessively restrictive in their current lending policies; and

(2)calls on the banks to review their lending policies and to relax them as far as is commercially appropriate so that the banks resume their normal role of contributing to Australia's economic recovery and national development.

During the recess I came across a well based, sound small business in my electorate that had applied for an increase in its overdraft from $300,000 to $500,000 and had not been able to get it. It is a high-tech firm which was established in Perth, with branches in several Australian capital cities and with a good record of profit. It had always finished each year with substantial profits—in the last two, for example, $600,000 before tax in 1989-90 and $300,000 before tax in 1990-91. It had a turnover of $8m a year and it was involved in high value business when it applied for this increase in its overdraft. No trading bank would lend it that money. In the ACT the firm has 25 employees and it has a turnover of $1.5m. When the local branch in the ACT requested an overdraft based on its debtor listing, which was a strong list, it was told it could not get the overdraft it sought. It had a prepayment of $0.75m but that, of course, was assigned to the costs of fulfilling a contract. The bank offered to increase the overdraft of the local branch by $100,000, provided it kept $100,000 on deposit and also provided the directors were prepared to guarantee the loan by mortgaging their own houses.

PARA.TAB: That is really excessively restrictive. This firm is doing well. It is in a growing area of the high-tech market. It depended on an overdraft to expand. It is not in the business of owning property. Yet the bank said it was prepared to increase its lending only if the firm put property in as security. That really means that that particular firm could not expand and was being throttled by the banks which were lending to it. That is just one example of many instances which I understand have occurred in recent months.

Australian businesses, particularly small businesses, are being strangled by a credit squeeze imposed by the banks. This bank imposed credit squeeze was identified by many observers. One, based on careful and comprehensive research by the Bureau of Industry Economics, was released late last year. There is evidence that the squeeze has since grown even worse. Reserve Bank statistics show that credit growth is at its lowest level ever recorded.

A look at the statistical record shows that, in the late 1980s, bank lending to business borrowers grew very rapidly, at a rate nearly twice as fast as the growth in deposits. However, the current financial year is likely to reverse that trend dramatically. Bank lending to business borrowers is estimated to expand by a tiny 1 to 2 per cent, so that there is no real growth at all, while deposits this year should expand by more than twice that rate, that is, by over 4 per cent. That means that the banks' resources are being transferred away from business lending.

Over the 1980s, the finance industry has shown the folly of relying simply on self-regulation. With deregulation, the Government gave practically all responsibility for allocating credit to the private sector. What did it do with that responsibility? It went on an irresponsible dash for short term profits which damaged large parts of the Australian economy. Asset prices boomed in an inflationary delusion and then crashed. Credit was mindlessly poured into takeovers, land speculation, empty office blocks and empty resorts.

At the same time, manufacturing and public infrastructure on which our real wealth depends was starved of funds. The current recession has worsened even further the banks' disappointing record of inadequate lending to productive Australian businesses—businesses which do not shuffle paper but which produce real wealth and productive jobs. This lending cut comes at a time when the big Australian banks are still very profitable and very well capitalised.

Mr Graham Byrne, the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, takes this problem very seriously. He said in February, `The overly-conservative lending practices of the banking community are throttling many struggling small businesses'. He particularly criticises the banks for `the practice of credit lines, such as overdrafts, being reduced or terminated with little or no notice or consultation with the affected small business'.

The banks have been failing small business, which provides nearly half of Australia's private sector employment—three million workers—and about one-third of Australia's national income. The bank imposed credit squeeze has exacerbated the already unequal access to finance faced by small businesses in Australia. This unequal access has been long recognised by inquiries such as the 1936 Royal Commission into the Australian Banking and Monetary System from which came, eventually, the Commonwealth Development Bank. Later inquiries such as the 1971 Wiltshire report, the 1981 Campbell report and the 1990 Beddall report have identified a continuing failure of the banks to provide adequate finance to small businesses.

The banks claim that they are not squeezing credit but there is a reduced demand for credit. That is simply not true, as I have illustrated not only by my anecdotal evidence but also by the well-considered comments by the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce. The banks are short-sightedly cutting the credit limits of many small businesses. They bear a share of the responsibility for the surge in bankruptcies which is wasting away Australia's employment and export potential.

Fortunately the economic statement last week contained some important measures to break the bank imposed credit squeeze. Most importantly the tax treatment and Reserve Bank rules, which discouraged Australian banks from providing equity capital, have been relaxed. Equity investment by Japanese and German banks plays an important part in their role as long term financiers of manufacturing industry. By taking equity, the Australian banks will now have a stake in the future of their business clients. This means the banks will work harder to make the company a success rather than selling it up as soon as it has a set-back.

Access to bank lending by small business is hindered by the banks' oligopoly. Banks have used their market power to give special deals to favoured customers and pass the cost on to smaller customers. This oligopoly power could be reduced by placing the financial sector under public surveillance by, for example, the Prices Surveillance Authority.

The Labor Government has been very successful in reducing inflation, raising business investment and expanding employment, even with the present problems. This success has been supported by the many innovations and improvements the Government has made in the provision of finance and managerial assistance to innovative new firms. This nurturing approach is in stark contrast to the slash and burn policies resulting from the market fetish of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

As a Government we must continue with imaginative and targeted policies. The report into Australia's current account deficit I tabled last October details this approach. We must help to build the new businesses Australia needs to be internationally competitive, and the banks must respond to the Government's new initiative and resume accessible lending to small business.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I happily second the motion moved by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). In speaking to the motion, I want to concur with the remarks that have been made by the honourable member for Fraser. I believe that he has really gone to the kernel of the matter in relation to the problems that are being faced by business today because of the attitude of the banks.

PARA.TAB: It was only a matter of 10 days ago that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) announced that the banks are going to take a more generous approach to business in relation to their lending practices. I am pleased that they are saying that, but I have some grave doubts that this is going to come to fruition and I have grave doubts that it is going to apply to small business.

When one looks at banking practices in the last three to five years, one can only say the banks have a shocking reputation. They have been implementing their own credit squeeze. In doing so they have been threatening the livelihood of thousands of small business families, and they have been forcing people who normally work in these small businesses onto the dole. I can only sum up by saying that many of their attitudes and practices have been anti-Australian.

There is no doubt that they have been implementing their own credit squeeze. You have only to look at what they have been doing in relation to applications that have come before them. They have refused to lend to prospective purchasers of existing small businesses. They have been rejecting applications for finance for new businesses. They are refusing to extend overdrafts to small business proprietors. They are refusing to roll loans over. They are no longer capitalising interest. They are refusing to lend on a number of enterprises such as motels and hotels. They have been calling up loans, even though the borrowers have been performing and are continuing to perform. They are refusing requests for normal balloon repayment schemes. In such schemes one takes a five-year loan and has low principal and interest repayments for, say, the first two years. Then, because of the borrower's greater capacity to repay, the payments are rescheduled and increased. They are refusing those structures. They are holding up overdrafts.

The banks are even continuing to have penalty rates. I had a case only the other day of a fellow paying 16 per cent interest, but then he has a penalty rate of 2 per cent on top of that. They are also using cocktail loans, where people borrow part of the money on overdraft—in one instance I have here, at 15.5 per cent—but the other part of the loan, perhaps another $10,000, is at 23 per cent. It is simply unfair, it is anti-Australian, and it is certainly not the sort of practice we expect of Australian banks.

We can add to that that the banks are cancelling the floor plan arrangements for car dealers, they are calling up loans, and they are forcing fire sales of stocks. It is simply not fair to these businessmen who in some cases have been working for decades to build up their businesses.

They are demanding up to three valuations when a person comes forward wanting to sell his property. I had a case where a bank manager had the local valuation of a motel done and he approved the loan. It then went to a Brisbane manager of the same bank, who had it valued again, against related property in Brisbane, and again approved the loan. It then went before a property finance review committee within that bank, with three people sitting on that committee. They demanded another valuation, which cost the prospective purchaser $4,000. They then refused the loan—an unbelievable situation, yet that is the sort of thing that goes on.

They are breaking down the usual practice of approving a loan in principle if the prospective buyer has met the conditions. Instead they are now forcing borrowers to spend large sums of money before the loan is even approved. It is simply not fair to prospective borrowers or to those who have those businesses. They are almost going back to the 1960 mentality, when it was a common saying, `If a bank will lend you money, you don't need it any more'. It seems that is the case again.

I have a number of examples I want to bring to the attention of the House. One is of a motel on the Sunshine Coast. The fellow wanted to borrow 52 per cent of the contract price; the valuation was within 0.5 per cent of the contract price. He had sufficient income from the business after wages to service 161 per cent of the principal and interest. He was competent, he was experienced in business—he had been in business for a long period of time. It was rejected; the reason, he was told—after all this evaluation—was that the motel was too old.

There was a distributing business in Brisbane, with government clients. The businessman required $560,000; he was offered only $420,000, even though his assets were twice the amount he wished to borrow. He had first-class real estate security and he had $80,000 cash. His application was rejected and no reason was given.

I suggest that we need to have a hard, hard look at the banks. One could go on with all sorts of cases where they simply will not lend on motels and hotels; they are going against small business people. It is simply causing problems in the economy. They are not playing their part as lenders, as finance providers in this nation, which could help recovery. We should remember that small business employs hundreds of thousands of people. If we want to get this country back on its feet, as this Government is now doing, we need to make sure that small business can borrow the moneys it needs. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested to join in this debate. I noted that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), suggested that there should be a hard, hard look at the banks. This House, through its Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, has just conducted such an inquiry. It seems that the previous speaker has not read that report.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this motion before the House should be put into its proper context. It deals with only a very small part of the problem. It would be my view that this motion should be worded along these lines: `That this House expresses serious concern at the failure of the Government to adequately plan and implement the deregulation of the banking industry, resulting from inappropriate monetary policies and Government response to the economic climate of the time; the maintenance of a tax system which encouraged debt; the inadequate reactive rather than proactive prudential supervision of the banks; and the lax lending policies of the banks in the 1980s'. Then the motion could go on with its wish list of saying, `Please, banks, don't let the pendulum swing too far in a direction opposite to that of the 1980s, given that it went far too lax in that period'.
Honourable members may wonder how I can support that argument. Let me quote what was given in evidence from the Reserve Bank to the banking inquiry:

SPEECH.PARA: Economic cycles occur for all sorts of reasons including domestic and external factors and shocks, but the banking system is important in both trying to accommodate and to minimise those cycles and to take some of the fluctuation out of them.
Here are the critical words:
The authorities use the banks as the main mechanism through which monetary policy is exercised.

What, then, were the authorities doing in the 1980s?What they were doing was a consequence of their complete failure to understand the implications of the deregulation of the banking industry. I support its deregulation—have always supported its deregulation. But one does not deregulate something that has been in a straitjacket for many years, without studying in advance the likely consequences for those involved in the deregulated marketplace and making sure that all the participants are aware of those likely consequences. This Government hastily deregulated the banks, did not think through the likely consequences of it and, as a result of its failure to think them through, its inadequate economic policies during the 1980s, its hopeless tax system in relation to debt and equity during the 1980s, the Government is responsible for what is now occurring in relation to the banks. The banks, too, were not prepared for deregulation. In speeches on the banking committee's report I have said these words:
The deregulation learning curve was a long and slow one. Bankers, regulators and bank customers were ill prepared for the changes which occurred. Even the Reserve Bank, like the Treasury,—
for its advice clearly was inadequate, or the Government, having received adequate advice, did not apply it, the latter being the more likely situation—
failed to anticipate or comprehend the impact of the forces unleashed by deregulation and their potential to undermine the safety of banks.

In undermining the safety of banks, through lax lending on their part, great pain and suffering were caused for the very people about whom the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) has spoken. It is quite clear that the banks have made strategic mistakes during the 1980s. And it was put this way at a conference on banking held in Sydney earlier this week. Those mistakes included excessive lending to entrepreneurial, real estate and construction companies; a decline in credit standards with risk assessment being clouded by the enticement of high fees and spreads; participation in syndicated loans without applying appropriate credit assessment; and engaging in activities that were not a good fit or which did not have a suitable risk reward ratio.

PARA.TAB: I have mentioned risk several times, and it is risk that has been the problem. The banks going after profit, which they are entitled to do, blinded themselves by the euphoria of competition and the drive for market share, to a point where they were not assessing the risks related to the loans. And that was not only at the big end of town, it was right across the spectrum of their loan portfolios. What we found was that, in the early 1980s, credit growth as a whole had been between 15.7 per cent and 18.2 per cent up till 1984. Then what happened on deregulation? In 1985 credit growth rose to 23.2 per cent, to a high in 1988 of 28.2 per cent. Of course, there had to be a market correction. As always occurs when there is a market correction, where it has gone too far one way it goes too far the other way, not only in the macro context but also in the micro circumstances of individual borrowers applying to banks.

The banks changed their psychology. The bankers did not understand the change nor did their customers. Bankers became marketeers of money, vendors of money, whereas, previously, they had been allocators of rationed funds. The customers went into their banks believing their bankers were their advisers, but the bankers had become salesmen, rather than consultants who could objectively make an assessment of the credibility of the proposition put before them. They wanted to lend their money and they would lend it on high risk ventures. The customer believed that, because the banker would lend the money, the proposition must have been right.

The honourable member for Fraser and his colleagues spoke as though cocktail loans were new. Cocktail loans existed long before bank deregulation and, in fact, were one of the safety valves as far as customers and banks were concerned, because if one could not get it from the bank out of rationed funds that were lent on a low risk basis, because the risks were higher, one then went to a finance company. One got a risk reward assessment of the proposition and paid in accordance then with the estimated risk.

Since deregulation the Government has failed the Australian people. It failed them because it said that there were advantages to be gained from deregulation—as there are and there were. But the price that we have paid for that transition from a regulated banking environment to a deregulated one is much higher than it need have been. It is not the banks' fault; it is certainly not wholly their fault. The major people to blame are the members of the Government. The Government did not put in place appropriate economic policies, it did not put in place adequate monetary controls and it did not do what the Reserve Bank said that the authorities normally do, which is to use the banks to moderate cyclical variations.

Furthermore, it did not put in place an adequate supervisory arrangement. It is my view that, if there had been in place at the time of deregulation a prudential supervisory regime of the sort that is gradually, far too slowly, coming into operation now, the Reserve Bank would have taken a much more stringent and concerned view about what was going on in the way that banks were increasing their bank assets at a percentage far too good for the health of the banking industry as a whole. To the extent that the banking industry became unhealthy, the people who have borne the burden of that problem are the very persons to whom the honourable member for Fraser has referred.

Therefore, whilst I am concerned about inadequacies within the banking system about lax lending, it is totally wrong for this House to put the whole weight of the blame on the bankers themselves. A very large proportion of that responsibility should be laid at the feet of the very Government that the honourable member for Fraser supports.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take issue with the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) on one point; that is, that the Government has been successful in reducing interest rates and inflation. Many of us on this side of the House recall that in 1989 and in early 1990, when the former Treasurer, now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), was pushing interest rates up through the roof, forcing businesses into bankruptcy and forcing home owners out of their homes, at no stage was a policy objective stated as low inflation and low interest rates. The policy was to soak up consumption—demand for imports. The effect of the fall in interest rates was as a direct consequence of the recession and not a long term policy objective of the Government.

PARA.TAB: The motion before the House is a classic case of the chicken and the egg. The honourable member for Fraser argues that the banks' restrictive lending policies are prolonging the recession. I would argue, on the basis of my experience in my electorate in Queensland, that the banks' restrictive lending policies are a consequence of the recession.

Like my colleague the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), I was a member of the banking inquiry conducted during the course of 1991. The findings of that inquiry have been well documented, are well known and have also been covered by my colleague. Evidence before the inquiry showed that the banks can be less than proud of their performance in the early years of operation in a deregulated system. Also, bank management was not well prepared when banks moved from an ultra conservative lending practice to entrepreneurial lending.

Prior to deregulation, most of such high risk lending, particularly in property development, was carried out by finance companies at higher levels of risk and at higher levels of interest. The expertise in the finance company sector was not transferred to the banking sector, and was not utilised by the banking sector, when it assumed its less conservative and more entrepreneurial role during the course of the 1980s.

The experience of the 1980s of massive accumulated bad debts by the banks is now history. It came about due to rapid asset inflation, as other speakers have said, which in the long term could not be sustained—leaving the banks dangerously exposed when the recession we had to have finally deflated asset values.

It is clear that the banks respond to economic indicators and policy. The economy does not respond to banking policy. Banks are a business and respond to economic conditions as do other businesses. The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) quoted the case of banks refusing to lend to hotels. If you have a look at the economic indicators of retail sales released for the month of December it shows a steady decline in the turnover of retail sales throughout Australia.

Poor economic management and forecasting by this Government is directly responsible for the attitude of the banks today. The miscalculations of former Treasurer Keating after the 1987 stock market crash resulted in massive injections of cash and massive injections of credit into the economy and brought about the boom of the late 1980s. Banks, as did other businesses, responded to the boom and the Government's lead by increasing lending, particularly for property development on inflated asset prices.

The Treasurer at the time, realising his mistake, put the brakes on the economy by using monetary policy and increasing interest rates. We all know now that the former Treasurer put the brakes on too hard and gave us the worst recession we have had in 60 years. The bad debt book of the banks is now over $30 billion. The recession Treasurer Keating engineered increased rapidly and sharply the exposure of banks to bad debts as asset prices tumbled and security of lending diminished.

Of course the banks reacted sharply to economic management. Of course the banks are applying stricter lending conditions today. Of course banks are moving to reduce their risk exposure. Banks, like all other businesses, have lost confidence due to the recession. But the ball is in the Government's court. It is in the honourable member for Fraser's court. If the Government is prepared to take the tough decisions that are necessary, the banks will respond. Those decisions are in the Fightback package, they are not in its One Nation statement. It is hoping to kick-start the economy, but I am saying that a kick-start will not work when there is no petrol left in the tank. There is no confidence left in the business community.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired and the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House supports the request of the Isolated Children's Parents' Association for a significant increase in the Assistance for Isolated Children allowance as a matter of urgency, particularly in view of the rapidly deteriorating economic circumstances prevailing throughout regional Australia and the collapse in the real value of the allowance in recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: Notice of this motion was given by me in October of last year, and I thank the Government for accepting it. It was given at a time, I might add, when the Australian Financial Review had commented in its editorial that if Australia was in a recession, then rural Australia was undoubtedly in a fully fledged depression. So the situation out there is extraordinarily serious and is acknowledged to be so.

PARA.TAB: In addressing the question of education assistance for children in the isolated parts of Australia, I believe that I must initially seek to dispel two particular myths which seem very hard to get rid of. The first is that assistance for isolated children, or the AIC scheme, is not some sort of hand-out designed to benefit mainly wealthy graziers so that they can more readily send their children to expensive boarding schools in the big cities. In fact, a wide range of families from isolated parts of this vast and very thinly populated land need access to educational facilities for their children. They include not only farmers, and not only graziers who are by no means wealthy at the moment in the current environment, but also property managers, farm workers, miners, outback shopkeepers, fuel suppliers and so forth—even lighthouse attendants. A whole range of people in isolated situations in this country need access to schools.

Secondly, and I think this is very important to understand, we are not talking here about welfare benefits. Rather, we are talking about access to education, and the very important principle that all Australian children should enjoy the same opportunity to get to the school gate. An example used by the ICPA itself to illustrate the point is that of a Newcastle family, perhaps unlucky enough to fall victim to that terrible earthquake.

Though their home could be flattened and their car written off and water and gas could be disconnected, with the resulting financial mayhem, the fact is that mum and dad can still put the kids on the school bus, which will take them off for the day in order that they can enjoy access to education.

Furthermore, it makes no difference at all whether that family are welfare dependent, at one end of the spectrum, or are wealthier citizens of Newcastle, at the other; access to school is provided on an equal basis. This is not the case for isolated Australians. So far as it is possible to correct the situation, we as a nation must seek to do so, both for reasons of simple justice and fairness and for economic reasons.

The justice argument is simple enough. As I have said, all Australian children should have that essential opportunity for an adequate education. If there is no place for them in the bush, they need to be given the skills, the abilities and the capabilities to have an equal footing with their peers from urban areas, from populated areas, to enter the labour market.

The economic argument is also highly significant. The fact is that a great deal of Australia's export wealth is disproportionately generated by people who live outside the heavily populated areas of Australia. We have a vested interest as a nation in keeping people out there in those mining areas and agricultural areas. It needs to be kept in mind that educated people will, as a rule of thumb, be more productive people—the evidence is quite clear on that point—and that families will not stay in areas where they cannot educate their children. That means that they will not remain productive in those areas, either.

The AIC scheme was first set up in 1973. Originally, it funded 55 per cent of average boarding costs for children. At its peak, some 32,000 children were being assisted, at a cost of some $28m. Today, however, only around 12,000 are receiving assistance, at a cost of around $14m to $15m. The annual decline in numbers is of the order of 1,000 children, which, I imagine, reflects in no small part the already very worrying level of exodus from the bush.

Over the years from 1973 the base allowance slipped away from that level of 55 per cent of average boarding costs to a low of just 21 per cent, in the face of consistent inflation—the great cancer that this Government refused to properly address, let alone acknowledge, until it landed us in a recession or, can I say, a depression in the bush and it became convenient to point towards broken inflation as a big plus. As Max Walsh pointed out, inflation always is low in a depression.

Two years ago the Government, to its credit, increased the base boarding allowance to the non-means and non-assets tested portion to $1,500, which brought its value back up to 32 per cent of average boarding costs. Then, in the first of many lifts from our Fightback package, the Government increased the base to $2,500, or 51 per cent of average boarding costs. That was done just before Christmas. That very considerable improvement is greatly appreciated by isolated families; they commend the Government for it and so do I.

Unfortunately, more help is needed. The total amount available to those in need who pass the means test and claim the second tier or, as it is known, the additional boarding allowance was increased by just $150 to $3,354; that is to say, all isolated children as defined receive the base boarding allowance of $2,500 and, if they are eligible, some additional $850 is made available, to a ceiling of $3,354.

The trouble with that is that most of those in deepest need were already able to claim that much before the increase in the base. They are no further ahead now than they were before the increase was announced before Christmas. If they are ahead, it is only by the order of $150-odd. That needs to be contrasted with the average boarding cost across Australia, which is now some $4,969 per student per year. In New South Wales, for example, State boarding schools charge $5,550 per year, and in Western Australia the Government hostels charge $4,900 per year. Probably it needs to be kept in mind as well that about 80 per cent of children cannot access these State boarding facilities in the first place.

For some unknown reason, the maximum allowance is apparently tied to the maximum level in Austudy—the Austudy living at home allowance rate, which does seem to me to be totally irrelevant. Firstly, most of these children are not able to stay at home—that is precisely the point. Secondly, Austudy is an income support scheme designed to help kids stay at school, whereas the AIC is a mechanism to enable children to get to the school gate, to give them access to educational facilities.

Another major stumbling block remains, inasmuch as the assets test on the additional boarding allowance remains. We have committed ourselves to abolishing that because it is an anomaly, and it does have a very restrictive effect on the availability of this aid for isolated children. It is obviously not a fair test. A city family left without income can still access local schools on free, or very low cost, school buses and trains, regardless of the value of their assets. Therefore, isolated families should be freed of the assets test.

The current situation is, as I have mentioned, quite desperate out there. While acknowledging the Government's moves in the right direction, the Isolated Children's Parents Association has requested that, firstly, the base boarding allowance plus the additional boarding allowance should be adjusted so that they meet the full average boarding cost per student—at least for families on zero or negative incomes. This enables them to get their children to the school gate—nothing more than that.

Secondly, they would like the assets test lifted on AIC school access allowances and continued through to year 12. In addition, they would like some attention to Austudy availability for isolated school students, and to the unrealistic levels of the correspondence allowance.

The total cost of these measures would be somewhere around $20m, which is chickenfeed when set against both the current and potential wealth generation capacity of isolated Australia. It is also cheap social justice. It should be kept in mind that it still would constitute something like a $7m saving on the 1987 cost of the scheme; that saving results from the lower number of children who are estimated to need aid.

In conclusion, I commend this motion to the House and I join with the ICPA in urging the adoption of these urgently needed measures to avoid further escalation in the already tragically high numbers of isolated children being withdrawn from education.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—In speaking to this motion, I must commend the Isolated Children's Parents Association. Under the circumstances—difficult circumstances—it has done a magnificent job, and as a lobby group it has been very effective.

PARA.TAB: Assistance to isolated children was, in fact, brought in in 1973 when there were 32,000 recipients. It was brought in by the Whitlam Government. At that time, the allowance made to children was about 55 per cent of the average boarding costs. By December 1990, there were 12,948 isolated children and there would be even fewer today. I think those figures themselves tell a story, for this motion goes far beyond just the content of the motion. It gets to the heart of what is happening in Australia.

I believe Australia is in great danger of dividing as a nation. At a time when there is talk about unity, we have a situation where we are having people in the country—an area where most of Australia's wealth is still generated from—in danger of becoming second-class citizens. The city is becoming affluent and the country is becoming more prone to poverty. This is an untenable situation; it is a situation that will divide this nation. I believe it has to be addressed. I think the Government is to be commended for increasing the non-means tested allocation to isolated children to $2,500. It has once again restored it to about 55 per cent of boarding costs.

I mainly want to speak about the non-means tested section, because I do not think it is clearly understood what we are about. There are two issues. One is access to schools. Every student in Australia should have access; and in my view it should be equal access. The other issue is income support. Parents in the country have the problem of getting education for their children. They have to bear a cost which is not borne by people in the cities. Therefore I think the non-means tested allocation should be the full average boarding cost across Australia. That would work out to a shade under $5,000, and I would be quite happy to round it off to $5,000. The payment of that amount would restore some access and equity to the system.

However, the truth is that the richest people in Australia can send their children to school in the cities of Australia for virtually nothing. The richest people in Australia living in the country face considerable costs. The richest people can obviously afford it, but there are many people in the bush who simply cannot. The figures from ABARE indicate that in this current financial year 30 per cent of primary producers will have a negative income. There is a very grave danger that those people will withdraw their children from school. Their children's education will therefore suffer at a time when we are trying to build a clever country. If we are going to have a clever country we need to have clever people in those industries which are vital to Australia. There are no industries more vital to Australia today than the mining and the agricultural industries—the very industries that are threatened by the cost of education.

The benefits are considerable. If the education of these children were improved, it would mean that with increased efficiency in rural areas and an increasing decline in population, they would be equipped to get jobs in the cities. It would mean that if they stayed on the land they would be more efficient in their production of the export income that Australia desperately needs. It seems strange to me that, when the cost of providing this equity is so small, we do not do more about it. As the previous speaker said, if we were to grant the ICPA its entire wish list it would come to about $20m, or some $7m less than it would have cost in 1987. That would be $20m that would be very well spent. It would do more to help restore equity and unity to this nation than virtually any other expenditure I can think of.

I have had a lot of experience of isolated education. My brother's children were brought up on the School of the Air throughout primary school, and the education standard is very good. They have no trouble competing in conventional schools at an academic level, but they do have problems with social intercourse. I notice in my brother's children, even today, a shyness and a reluctance to meet people. We ought to be investing a lot more in isolated education. We ought to be using some of the funds that are poured into education to assist with more trips for these isolated kids, and to give them more ability to mix with their peers in regular schools. This would prove a great benefit to Australia.

I do not think there is anything particularly controversial in this proposal. As I have said, it was in fact the Labor Government that introduced it. It is the Labor Government that has raised the allowances. I am glad to see that this is being supported by the National Party and the Liberal Party. I hope that when the Government is framing the Budget it looks to implementing some needed reform in this area. We have pressures in Australia—and it was discussed in this place this morning—emanating from what I call the multicultural industry. While it costs Australia uncounted billions of dollars for people who are seeking to divide this country with a philosophy that Australia does not want, we are neglecting the simple areas where equity can be restored.

There is a lot of confusion between the assistance for isolated children and Austudy. Austudy is about income support. It should be totally independent of any assistance to isolated children. Any assistance to isolated children should not be counted when looking at Austudy calculations. As I have said, all that the assistance for isolated children does is provide them with entry to the school gate. We have not yet got to full compensation. I certainly hope that we can move in that direction. The costs vary considerably across Australia. I am told that at the convent in Quilpie a child can board for something like $2,900 a year. That sounds rather austere. In Western Australia, the average cost for government boarding schools is about $4,900. In New South Wales it is somewhat higher, but that seems to be an average figure.

There are simply not enough hostels and they are not located strategically enough to cover all isolated children. We must be flexible in the construction of these hostels and we must realise that there is always going to be a demand or a need for children to attend schools in the cities. This is not about giving handouts to the rich, to the squattocracy; this is about simple equity—providing education to children on an equal basis.

I might add that it is going to become increasingly important for Australia to do better in those areas in which it does well. We are going to have to look at downstream processing of a lot of our minerals. It is likely that we will even see an increase in the number of children requiring this assistance. That is something that the country should not baulk at or shy away from. As a nation, if we are going to have unity, we must have equity in the system, and equity is certainly overdue to these people. I have heard it said on many occasions, `If you do not like it in the country, why do you not move to the city?'. If everyone did that, the economy of this country would crumble.

I know that, in the past, mining companies have adopted the rather macho attitude that people who work in export producing industries are somehow more important than people in other industries. That is nonsense. We certainly cannot convince the people who are driving buses around some of our cities that they are not working very hard. In fact, they are working harder than many people. What we should realise is that work in the country produces lots of jobs in the city. If city people can be taught how much their jobs, their employment, and the affluence in the cities rest on people who develop things in the country, then I believe we will be well on the way to giving the sort of justice to country people that is long overdue. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to support the motion of the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), who in his contribution talked about justice and fairness. It seems to me that, when we talk about this issue of assistance for isolated children, we talk about not an issue of access but one of equity. There is a lack of equity because we cannot afford to build primary schools, secondary schools and tertiary institutions through the outback of this great and vast nation. Any support of equity demands that we support those families who inhabit the vast regions of Australia, who contribute to our wealth and contribute to our social cohesion, as a matter of equity, by making sure that their children can afford to go to school.

PARA.TAB: I would like to thank the Government and congratulate it for its initiative at Christmas time in increasing the base allowance for isolated children. I am not sure that the Government has gone far enough, as the secondary portion of the allowance has not been increased by more than 5 per cent.

I point out to the House that in March of this year the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, in bringing down a report into student financial assistance, recommended to the Government that it increase the portion of the assistance to isolated children allowance that is not subject to the means and assets test. That was in March.

I would also like to bring to the House's attention the fact that in November the Opposition, in its financial package called Fightback, also offered to increase the base portion of the allowance. The Opposition went further and said that the secondary portion of the allowance should be means tested but not assets tested, that it should in fact be assets test free. It is interesting, but not funny, that DEET advises us that in 1990-91 the expenditure on AIC was $15.5m, $0.824m less than the appropriation, because both the average benefit and the number of students assisted were less than had been estimated. That was so, I would maintain, because of a deep recession and because of country people leaving country areas.

In my view, the assets test is questionable on equity grounds. For the children of parents who live a long way away from all three levels of schooling, both assistance for isolated children and Austudy are a matter of means but not a matter of assets. One might own several hundred thousand square miles and not have a cracker to be able to afford to send one's children to school, or afford even the correspondence course. It is my view that the assets test in this instance is not equitable.

I note that this year the Department's form 9 caused many families in the bush a great deal of trouble. Form 9 is really quite obtrusive. If you want to obtain assistance through the AIC program or if you apply for Austudy, for most farm families the filling out of this form is likely to require the assistance of an accountant and therefore further expense at a time when the families have little or no income.

The Isolated Children's Parents Association makes the point that it was an isolated child who discovered the Chinese boat people wandering around the Top End of Australia this past year. Where the Government and the military surveillance failed to find these people wandering free in our nation, it was an isolated child who found them. The families who inhabit the vast regions of this country are important to our economy, they are an important part of our infrastructure and they play a very important role in Australian society. As a matter of equity, we must support the motion of the honourable member for Gwydir. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the comments that have been made by previous speakers when they argue that there is a need for more moneys to be made available for this scheme, and I concur with that view. But I think we ought to look at what has taken place since 1973, when the Whitlam Government introduced the scheme, because it demonstrates that Labor governments have over these decades recognised the special problems that people in isolated areas face when it comes to educating their children.

PARA.TAB: The scheme goes back to 1973, when the basic boarding allowance was only $350. It took a long time to increase it. In 1975 it went to $500, and then there was no increase between 1975 and 1981, when the Opposition was in government. It sometimes surprises me that when in opposition honourable members opposite can come here and say, `You have not done enough', yet for virtually their whole period in government they did nothing about increasing it; it stayed at $500 from 1975 through to 1981. This Government increased it last year from the—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know why, but I will not let honourable members use my time. In 1985 the amount was $989. In 1991 it was increased to $1,500 and now in 1992 it has been increased to $2,500. I am pleased that the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) at least acknowledged this and congratulated the Government. That is in line with what the Isolated Children's Parents Association is saying. I have a copy of a letter here of 17 December 1991 in which it says that it would like to thank the Federal Government, and particularly the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), for the prompt response to the desperate plea for help.

PARA.TAB: This is an issue that all members of parliament who represent country electorates and regional electorates have been conscious of and have been pressing for. It has come back to a matter of funds, but this Government has acted in providing another $8.6m to underpin these costs and to ensure that young people in isolated areas can get to school. I agree that there is always need for more, because even $2,500 is not very much when one is trying to send a person of 15 or 16 off to secondary school. It is not very much when one realises that there are income tests on the additional living allowance.

The Government has seen fit to ensure that, if a family wants to buy into a second home or rent a second home, these moneys are still payable. Whilst the honourable member for La Trobe talks about assets tests, it needs to be placed on the record that this Government is conscious of the problems that he mentioned about someone owning so many hundreds of square miles of land but having no income, because only half the value of the asset is taken into consideration. Also, there are times when the assets test is not even considered. Under the rural adjustment scheme, if a rural family is on a pension, then there are special exemptions again. So the Government is conscious of the problems. This has been seen in the fact that these latest increases are going to benefit some 8,500 students across Australia. That is about 65 per cent of all the students receiving assistance under the isolated children's scheme.

The problems that I see concern those who are not on the land. Many of my constituents, who work for local authorities, who work as fettlers, really are caught up in earning a little more than the $20,700, which is the income test level, but do not have assets. They do not have the capacity to go to the bank and say, `I have got $500,000 worth of land: what can I borrow?'. These are ordinary people who are caught up in the same sort of problem.

Whilst they are able to get that extra allowance in some cases, it is income tested up to $3,300; and there is a need to review that. There is also a need to review the distance criteria and the general problems in children living away, because $50 a week simply is not enough.

I commend the Government for what it has done. A shift from $1,500 to $2,500 is praiseworthy.
