The Opposition is acknowledging that, the organisation is acknowledging that and the families are acknowledging that, but we do need to reconsider the situation further. There are real problems in geographical isolation. There are real problems when families are trying to eke out an existence working in those small isolated areas. I have in my electorate towns such as St Lawrence, 150 kilometres from Mackay and 105 kilometres from Rockhampton, virtually in the middle of nowhere, which are facing major problems. Many of these people work for local authorities; they work in the council areas; they work on properties. But they do not have the assets to go and borrow.

I commend the Government for what it is doing and for what it is trying to do to equal up the situation to ensure that these young people are able to get an education. But we need to ensure that we monitor it further. There is a review going at the moment; there is an options paper out. I would hope that the special problems faced by the low income families in these areas are also acknowledged. I welcome what the Government has done and I am sure that all honourable members support what is taking place. (Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! It being approximately 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to express a grievance on behalf of my constituents, the constituents of the Gold Coast, but I divert for one minute to refer to a radio program I heard this morning on the subject of Canberra. It was a local Canberra radio program, of course, on which both Geoffrey Blainey and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) were interviewed and gave views on the current controversy of Canberra being bagged by a journalist from another State.

PARA.TAB: The gist of the program was that Canberra residents are resentful of being referred to as `Canberra', as though it is synonymous with the Federal Government. Gold Coast residents have a similar sort of grievance. But I would like to say a couple of words about Canberra first.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are making it hard on the Gold Coast.

—They are doing it extremely hard on the Gold Coast, a matter about which I will be expressing my grievance very shortly. They are very badly hurt by this Government's policies. Canberra residents really need to understand that they are not alone in this stereotyping. They ought also to understand that they are as guilty as anyone else in Australia in stereotyping other areas of Australia. It is, after all, Canberra residents who advise this Government on disbursements of funds. As somebody who represents the Gold Coast, I have said several times in this House that I resent the stereotyping of my constituents on the Gold Coast as wealthy spivs.

PARA.TAB: One has to say that to a certain extent Canberra brings it on itself. There is no better measure of this than its voting patterns. For example, in 1990 the coalition actually gained a majority of the vote Australia-wide but did not gain a majority of seats. However, the vote in Canberra was out of kilter with trends in the rest of Australia.When those 1990 election results came out, I was reminded of what happened in the United States of America in 1984 when President Reagan was running for re-election and he was opposed by a previous Vice-President of the United States, Walter Mondale. Mondale carried the vote in only two parts of the United States, his home state of Minnesota and Washington, DC. Given that the vote was so far out of kilter with the rest of the United States of America, a friend of mine, who is American, said that he found it fairly depressing to think that the policy-makers in Washington, DC, could be so far out of step with the sentiment and feelings of virtually the rest of the United States of America.

It is an unfortunate fact that voting patterns throw up exactly the same pattern here in Australia. Canberra's voting patterns are out of step with the rest of Australia. When one lives and represents an area such as I do, an area which is itself prone to stereotyping, it becomes all the more depressing because that attitude of certain Canberra residents towards people who are resident on the Gold Coast shows up with depressing regularity in correspondence that I receive from various Ministers.

The Gold Coast is stereotyped as wealthy and, on occasions, some of that wealth having been earned in questionable ways. There are a large number of wealthy people on the Gold Coast. There are two good reasons: first, it is the best part of Australia to live so that, when people get the opportunity to retire, it is their number one choice for retirement and quite a number of wealthy people take their retirement wealth to the Gold Coast. The second thing is that it is a beautiful place to visit, and probably the most desirable place to live is either on the beach front or on the riverfront.

Tourists go to the Gold Coast and they walk on the beaches and they see some conspicuous consumption by the local residents. They go for boat cruises and, similarly, they see the beautiful mansions that are on the riverbank. But people forget that they can go to Sydney and see wondrous mansions on Sydney Harbour and not see the western suburbs of Sydney or Redfern or other places such as that. There is conspicuous consumption on the Gold Coast and it is very apparent. But all objective factual measures indicate that that is totally atypical of the community.

We recently had a census done and I am looking forward to the analysis by electorates of the various statistics that usually come out of a census. The 1986 pattern showed that the residents of the two Federal electorates of Moncrieff and McPherson, for example, ranked amongst the lowest in Australia in average household income. The stereotype of wealth is not borne out by that basic statistic. However, the statistics show a few other very important facts about the Gold Coast. They show that the residents of the two Gold Coast electorates have the fewest number of government employees as a percentage of their work force. In other words, we are not pork-barrelled by government, either State or Federal. The wealth and the jobs that are created locally are created by private enterprise.

The statistics also show that employees there basically work in small business. We have the highest proportion of all Federal electorates of people either self-employed or working for small enterprises. So the Gold Coast is very much small business driven. That is against the stereotype of the five-star hotels which are very important employers. However, in the sense that they are significant employers, and one hopes that is a part of the economy that will grow because they bring in tourists who spend a lot of money and the benefits flow, they are atypical of the pattern of employment and of industry on the Gold Coast.

Because we have basically a tourism industry and a small business economy, we have a very low-paid work force. A very large proportion of the work force works in retailing and in tourism, which are two areas of relatively low pay. The fact is that many people who live on the Gold Coast are retirees who are self-funded, pensioners, or living on very modest superannuation. That brings with it very particular needs, and an area of need which is becoming acute is that of aged care and the health needs of the aged.

Very recently the local State regional health authority released a report which tipped a huge bucket on both the State Government and the Federal Government for the underfunding of health care in the Gold Coast region. Just a little while ago I wrote a letter to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) in which I pointed out that the Blue Nursing Service on the Gold Coast, despite having to cope with nearly twice as many cases as allowed for by the level of funding that was struck back in 1984, is getting no more money. The Minister in his reply said that in the area of aged care he was looking at the capacity of people to look after themselves, and not just the raw data. He did not go on to say, `Mrs Sullivan, you come from the Gold Coast and we all know everybody is dripping wealth there. What about their paying for their own aged care?', but the whole tone of the letter implied that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what he meant.

—That is what he meant. Some Canberra mandarin wrote that letter for him. I would like to tell the people of Canberra, who are very influential in government policy, to cut out the stereotypes and to go and look at the facts. They should not be happy when innocent Canberra residents are resentful of the stereotype, but work to overcome the effects of the stereotype and how it affects people who live in my part of the world.

PARA.TAB: Briefly, because my time is nearly expired, I have to say that the figures will also show that the most rapid growth in youth unemployment in Australia is on the Gold Coast. It is not the stereotyped surfie dole bludger; not at all. It is local young people who can no longer turn to the traditional small business employer for jobs. Certainly the tourism industry is still doing well, and it is an important employer of young people. But the second area, and a far more significant area traditionally, is that of small business. Small business is collapsing at a record rate on the Gold Coast, because people are frightened of the future. Many people are unemployed, many people's neighbours have become unemployed, and they have become frightened of what that means. Small business is going bankrupt.

It is very sad indeed that the best the Prime Minister can bring to this Parliament and to the office of Prime Minister is the old, tired, worn-out Labor stereotype of class warfare. It is a stereotype which has served this nation badly, and it is serving my constituents particularly badly. This is a time, indeed, for one nation, and not for setting one group against another, and that will only be done when the facts are looked at objectively and are judged on their merits. If that were happening, the aged and the young in my electorate would not find themselves in the extreme difficulties they have at the moment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, one of the oldest tricks in the book is to blame someone for something he did not do. Over the past few days we have seen the Opposition in this Parliament doing this in regard to the Treasury's analysis of its so-called Fightback program. It is also a ploy used in industrial relations, as employers try to portray the workers of Australia as wreckers of the Australian economy. This always gets the union bashers opposite very excited as they rush to criticise the workers.

PARA.TAB: Representing, as I do, the Illawarra region, I am well aware of industrial disputes—especially disputes involving the Big Australian, whose record in industrial relations would not be a case study of how to run industrial relations successfully. There will always be disputes in a major industrial area like the Illawarra, but disputes brought on by the obstinacy of BHP are usually distorted. BHP usually stops short of deliberate lying, being prepared to mislead or confuse; but recently it engaged in a campaign of deliberate lying to discredit local unions, especially the South Coast Labour Council and its secretary, Paul Matters.

The South Coast Labour Council took a principled stand on the Dili massacre and engaged in some picketing of a ship loading steel for Indonesia late last year. On 3 January the following press release was issued by BHP:

SPEECH.PARA: $8 Million Steel Shipment Lost Because of Industrial Action

PARA.TAB: BHP Port Kembla Steelworks has lost a contract to supply 30,000 tonnes of steel slabs to Indonesia as a result of industrial action initiated by the South Coast Labour Council.
The shipment, worth $8 million, was to have been made in March to Krakatau Steel in Western Java.
It will now be made by an alternative supplier unknown to BHP, but which BHP believes is either Southern America or Europe.

Krakatau Steel cancelled its inquiry in late December. International Marketing Manager, Mr David Burgess, said Krakatau had been forced to switch to an alternative supplier to ensure security of supply.

The Labour Council's threat of bans on the December shipment of 30,500 tonnes on the Frangiskos CK followed hard on the heels of industrial action over the Sheet and Coil dispute in November, and the Indonesians were evidently not satisfied that Port Kembla had overcome its industrial problems, Mr Burgess said.

We are hopeful of continuing Indonesian business, but the cancellation underlines how competitive our international business is. To be successful in the international scene, it is essential to be viewed as a reliable supplier.
The fact that there are alternative suppliers only too happy to supply Indonesia means that withholding supply from Australia appears to have little influence on Indonesian Government policies.
In other words, the Illawarra region has lost significant business to overseas competitors for no apparent gain to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It ends by saying:

PARA.TAB: We would urge the South Coast Labour Council and its affiliated unions to consider these factors in the light of the difficult economic circumstances this region now faces.

SPEECH.PARA: Not surprisingly, the local media ran strongly with the story, as indeed did the national media. The Courier-Mail, in Brisbane, was especially critical in an editorial calling on the ACTU and the Federal Government to discipline the South Coast Labour Council. Quoting from BHP International Marketing Manager, David Burgess, who said such things as that Krakatau had been forced to switch to an alternative supplier, Illawarra industry and commerce leaders seized on the BHP statement to condemn the South Coast Labour Council.

PARA.TAB: There were the usual personal attacks on Paul Matters by those apologists for the conservatives, the Chamber of Commerce and the Chamber of Manufactures. One failed Liberal candidate by the name of Warren Steel, now Secretary of the Wollongong Chamber of Commerce, even publicly boasted that Paul Matters should be run out of town. He said, quoting from a telephone call he got, `Can't someone take him out and dump him at sea?'.

Chamber President, Malcolm Heard, called on rank and file members to dump Paul Matters. Most statements were made with malicious intent. There was an editorial in the Illawarra Mercury and various heavies were asked to comment. The local Federal members, aware of BHP's reputation, did not comment. But Senator Michael Baume, who bills himself as Liberal senator for Wollongong—although I must say that no-one ever sees him in Wollongong—went on his usual union bashing tirade, as did the shadow Minister for Trade, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). Indeed, from Brisbane to Adelaide the South Coast Labour Council was condemned.

What do we find? We find that a little bit of investigative journalism by the local ABC revealed that the Big Australian had been up to its old trick of telling the big lie once more, despite the fact that Paul Matters had consistently stated that industrial action had not lead to the loss of any steel contracts to Indonesia. It took a telex from Krakatau Steel to prove the point. The telex referred to a fax as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Krakatau Steel did not cancel the contract with BHP to buy 32,000 steel from Port Kembla.
2.Approximately 30,000 steel was shipped from Port Kembla on December 30, 1991 and arrived at Krakatau Steel . . . on January 15, 1992.
3.An official from BHP came to Indonesia in December 1991 and clarified the matter. He stated that apparently an incorrect statement had been issued in Australia by an unauthorised BHP personnel.
4.Both Krakatau Steel and BHP Australia are willing to continue their business cooperation now and in the future.
This was signed and sent by a Mr Ariwibowo, who is not only President of Krakatau Steel but also Indonesia's junior Industry Minister.

PARA.TAB: When the lie was proven, what do we find? What was Mr Burgess's response when he was found out to be lying? What was the man, who claimed that BHP had lost an $8m contract in January, now saying? He suddenly became very silent. This man Burgess, who said, `The loss of the contract was a blow for the Illawarra', when it was proven that he had deliberately lied, had no comment. The big lying Australian BHP said the matter was closed. BHP Port Kembla Manager, Graham Parker, has refused to respond to local media inquiries. He said that the matter was closed and nothing could be gained from further discussion.

BHP should apologise to the local trade union movement. So should all those others so quick to jump on the union bashing bandwagon. Burgess should be sacked for deliberately lying to the Illawarra people and the media. We can speculate why BHP has lied. This lie would have been accepted had it not been for the work of the local ABC journalists in the Illawarra, especially Julie Persetti and Kerry O'Connor, who read an article in the Far Eastern Review about this matter and followed it through.

Of course, we know that BHP will not upset Indonesia as it hopes to profit from oil in the Timor Gap. But, far from gaining favour with Indonesia, this lie by BHP has embarrassed Indonesia. It is not that it was a mistake—it was a deliberate lie. According to Krakatau Steel, an official from BHP visited Indonesia in late December. Indonesia at that stage indicated that it had not cancelled any steel order. Why then did BHP put out a press statement, on 3 January 1992, saying that, because of militant union activity, it had lost an $8m steel contract? It did this for one reason and one reason alone: it was an exercise in union bashing. It was an attempt to portray the union in the worst possible light as a wrecker of Illawarra jobs. It was an especially vindictive attack on the Secretary of the South Coast Labour Council, Paul Matters. As Paul Matters has said, BHP's decision to blame the union for the loss of Krakatau's interest in the steel contract was nothing more than a propaganda exercise. That is what it was, a propaganda exercise. Like all propaganda, it is based on lies. Perhaps we can add another name to the Big Australian—the Big Australian as the big liar.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are hearing a lot today about buy Australian and be Australian and Australian made and so on. I direct a few remarks to points that appear to me as a grievance with regard to the need for us to be more Australian and, by looking back on our colourful Australian heritage, to find out a little bit more about how we can be more Australian. Of course, to look back over our history, we have a period that is called our `wild colonial days'. This is equal to and, in many ways, surpasses that of nearly every other country in the world. Unfortunately, this period is almost totally ignored by our education system and by many bodies which ought to be doing more about bringing it to the attention of the Australian people. I have in my electorate a very colourful, well known and excellent historian, Edgar Penzig, who gets a lot of help from his wife, Megan. He has written quite a few good books that make excellent reading. I am sure some people have heard of Morgan the murderer which is one of his books or Bullets, blades and bravery. Others of his books are called Parasols and pistols; Bushrangers, heroes and villains. There is a very good one called Happy Jack, one on Frank Gardiner and another on the Sandy Creek bush. All of these are excellent reading and reveal that Australia has a very colourful heritage, but a heritage that we seem to be forgetting more and more every day.

PARA.TAB: For example, hundreds and thousands of school children seem unaware that mail was carried overland by horseback between Melbourne and Yass, before it finished the trip by coach, and this was 23 years before the American pony express began operations in the early 1860s. Australia had the richest goldfields, especially of the alluvial type, ever found in the world. Likewise, we had the largest pure gold nugget and the largest quartz-gold nugget, the Beyers-Holtermann nugget, found at Hill End in New South Wales. We had towns with larger populations and many more hotels than any in the so-called American Wild West.

Also, the American Wild West outlaws take a back seat to the local variety, which were known as bushrangers. For instance, Jesse James in the American Wild West committed 21 hold-ups in 16 years, whereas our notorious bushranger John Gilbert, nicknamed Happy Jack, committed over 630 robberies in just over four years. The villain Ben Hall committed over 600 robberies, as did many others, such as Morgan the Murderer and Fred Ward, alias Thunderbolt. All honourable members, and especially the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), would know all about Thunderbolt's history. All those bushrangers had tallies of several hundred. As for Ned Kelly, his tally was only about a dozen. If he had not put that tin over his head, we probably would not even have heard of him again.

In the American Western period several people carried five revolvers, a few dozen carried two and the majority carried one. One can compare this with John Gilbert, Ben Hall and company, who were always armed with six or eight. In one hold-up Hall had nine pistols and revolvers in his belt. No American outlaw ever held up a whole town, but the Gilbert-Hall gang held up three country towns during their infamous careers.

The coaching history of our country also surpasses all others. In the early 1870s, every day Cobb and Co. was putting 6,000 horses into harness and its coaches were travelling 28,000 miles every week. Mr Penzig points out that miles is the proper language. That local firm was the largest of its kind in the world. It was larger than Wells Fargo and the Adam Express Co. of the United States put together. On top of that, we had the largest coaches in the world. The biggest in America's west carried 36 passengers, which is not a bad load for a coach, whilst the Australian model, of which two were made, built in about 1860, were pulled by 22 horses and weighed in at 5 tons—not tonnes, as Mr Penzig points out. They carried 89 passengers and were the largest horse-drawn vehicles ever constructed in the world.

Yet, in spite of all this, we are still served up a meal of nothing but American Western-style films, television, comics, et cetera. Even if our film industry does make a local film set in the wild colonial days, it resembles a US Western more than anything Australian. The costumes are totally incorrect. Films such as the Ben Hall series, the Morgan film and the more recent Robbery Under Arms have been quite pathetic because the costumes have not been just as they were in the western era of this country.

Naturally, because our population sees many television films from overseas, the majority being from the United States of America, we have also lost much of our local idiom—our local terms and our way of speaking. What has been a tin in Australia since 1850, in the past 25 years has turned into an American can. What was a good bloke is now a good guy. All the teenagers and, unfortunately, many adults are using that word because of the influence of television in every home. The mudguards on all our motor cars are turning into fenders overnight. What was the bonnet of the motor car ever since the car was invented has, over the years, turned into a hood. All our headmasters during the same span of time have turned into American principals. Our universities in the last 10 years or so have now discovered a campus, which has never existed in any Australian university in the history of our country.

Suddenly all our holidays—and that is what they have been since the First Fleet landed here—are now turning into American vacations. What was once a chook dinner, or a roast chook, has now become a chicken. We had, and still have, some of the finest roughriders in the world but now, instead of taking part in a buckjump show or a bushman's carnival, they are taking part in an American rodeo. Along the same lines, what has been a stockman for nearly 200 years is now becoming a cowboy, and what for years has been the boot of a car is fast becoming an American trunk.

We have been riding or walking tracks here since the advent of European settlement, but over past years these have been turning into American trails. Likewise, the good old Aussie cattle station is in some instances now being called the American ranch. The stockyard is often referred to as a corral, another American term. One of the terms we have used ever since the 1850s is the goods train, but in the past two years we have begun to hear from newsreaders and to read in our papers `freight train'. We do not have freight trains in Australia, we have goods trains.

What can one expect when the press now spells gaol j-a-i-l? That has been in the paper recently, as has colour as c-o-l-o-r, the American spelling. What is happening? There is one song which contains the words, `It's an Australian institution, the Australian barbeque'. In Australia from the 1850s we have had a boree-log, not a barbeque. Not only does the boree-log sound just as good, but it is Australian, it is ours. So no more Yankee barbeques; let us have more boree-logs.

The good old Aussie biscuit is fast becoming an American cookie. There is another term which everybody should remember if they are not too young—the ironmonger's store. What has become of it? For the entire history of our nation it has been known as that but now it is turning into an American hardware store. We used to put petrol into our motor cars, but many petrol stations now advertise gas. For the uninformed, petrol is a liquid, not a gas. Instead of wearing moleskins, which will outlast 10 pairs of Yankee jeans, every Australian youth and many adults wear the latter. Even one of our leading country entertainers, who continually talks about Australia getting a new flag and becoming a republic, always appears at his concerts and public appearances wearing a denim shirt, jeans and striped jogging boots. He needs to have a good look at himself before he starts talking about these things that are so precious to a lot of people in this country.

We want to buy Australian, we want Australian-made, but I make a plea to the Australian people and to the education systems of this country to start teaching our children and the people of this land a little more about what it is to be real Australians who use dinky-di Australian terminology. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My problem today is with the National Party. I note the comments of the member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) about the disappearance of the bushrangers, but there are still plenty of bushrangers present, many of them in this House and amongst the members of the National Party. The National Party in my couple of years here—

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Is there a ruling that says that it is unparliamentary to call members of this House bushrangers? A Deputy Speaker did say that he did not like to be called a thief. I know the honourable member has called the whole Parliament thieves. I think that is unparliamentary.

PARA.TAB: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—The Clerk has advised me that previous rulings of Speakers have been that terms which would be unparliamentary when applied to an individual are unparliamentary if applied to members of a political party specifically, so I think the honourable member should withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you wish, Madam Deputy Speaker. I withdraw it. The National Party, in my couple of years in this place, has shown itself to be absolutely incapable of effectively putting the views of country people. That absolute inability is shown very effectively by the lack of performance in the production of the Opposition's Fightback program. That program has absolutely no initiatives that are likely to be of advantage to country and rural people, or the people of my electorate on the north coast. The National Party really needs to comprehend the types of people who make up its electorates. It has not done this and it has been snowballed by the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party, which represents the wealthy city electorates, has dominated the Fightback statement. The National Party members have lain down like dogs and allowed themselves and their electorates to be crushed.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, when we examine the proposals and the initiatives of the One Nation program we find many initiatives that are of real and direct benefit to the people of the north coast of New South Wales and to rural and country people throughout Australia. The National Party really needs to understand how its electorates are composed, and the sorts of categories that its constituents fall into. My electorate, which would not be very different from many National Party electorates, is made up predominantly of low income earners. It comprises families on low incomes, pensioners and elderly people, small business people, with the emphasis on `small', and small farmers—once again with the emphasis on `small'. What has the National Party done? It has agreed to a stance that favours the rich at the expense of the low to middle income earners of Australia—the very people who make up its constituency.

An analysis of the Fightback! document demonstrates some very interesting facts which will be of great interest to the members of my electorate and to the members of all country electorates. Under the Fightback program, 70 per cent of wage and salary earners would be worse off; 60 per cent of the self-employed and farmers would be worse off. Those figures would be even worse for my electorate because those wage and salary earners and those self-employed people and farmers by and large fall into the low income earners category at a greater rate than they do in other electorates.

Under the Fightback package, wage and salary earners, self-employed and farmers on incomes over $90,000 per annum would be better off by $105 a week. That same group, with incomes up to $57,000 a year, would be worse off by $400 a year. Self-employed and farmers with incomes up to $61,000 would be worse off by $600 a year. Taxpayers with incomes up to $30,000 a year would be worse off by $10 a week. While at the other end of the scale, people paying tax on $100,000 would be better off by over $70 a week.

The vast majority of the taxpayers in my electorate pay tax on less than $30,000 a year. The people of my electorate would be paying for handouts to the wealthy—to the Ferrari owners and the Double Bay yuppies. The members of the National Party should be saying to Professor Hewson—and he does not know anything about country people unless somebody in the National Party tells him—that they want some stimulus that will increase economic activity and demand in regional Australia, as our One Nation program provides.

Those National Party people should be telling Dr Hewson that the changes to depreciation are of direct and real benefit to country people—to farmers and business people. They should be saying to Dr Hewson—to the professor—that this is a good thing to do. The One Nation program does this. Those National Party people should be saying that the crop planting scheme, the additional funding to the rural adjustment scheme, and the additional funding to the rural counselling program are all good for country people. Professor Hewson should embrace these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member knows that it is improper to refer to members in those terms. Refer to the Leader of the Opposition in the proper way, please.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I ask the National Party: is that the sort of proposal honourable members should be supporting—a proposal that decreases GDP, increases inflation, increases interest rates, and increases unemployment? Of course it is not. However, honourable members have gone along with the Leader of the Liberal Party. They have gone along with him because, for a fleeting moment, they thought that he could give them a chance of victory. However, country people know that the motives of the National Party people are purely self-serving. The proposals are not in the interests of ordinary country people, but they are in the interests of the Liberal Party people in those wealthy electorates.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the Fightback package is now coming out. Maybe the truth was not known to the 14 members of the National Party. Those members should start questioning the generals in the Liberal Party. Honourable members should indicate that they want it fixed. They should be saying that they want initiatives that help country people, as our One Nation statement does. The Federal National Party people should be saying to the Leader of the Liberal Party that the $1.1 billion spent on infrastructure on the roads and rails that will rebuild this country are of direct benefit to country and rural people. In particular, north coast people have suffered from the cuts to rail services and many other services made by the Greiner State Government. They are appreciative of this initiative to invest in the means by which many of them get their products to ports and markets—both domestic and overseas.

North coast roads, particularly the Pacific Highway, and many other roads throughout New South Wales will benefit from the additional $20.3m for the black spots program in New South Wales. The offer to take over funding of the Sturt and Newell highways from the State Government should leave the State Government free to spend an additional $40m a year on other country roads, including the Pacific Highway on the north coast. Where is the infrastructure development in the Fightback! document? It is not there, and the National Party should be telling the Leader of the Liberal Party that it wants something done about roads and rail, not a cut of $87m in the land transport program.

The National Party people should go to the Leader of the Liberal Party and show him that the new banking arrangements in the One Nation program will be welcomed by the banking industry and by farmers and rural businesses, especially those in financial difficulty as a result of the severe rural downturn and the drought. This initiative gives those businesses and those farmers the opportunity to trade out of their problems and will assist in maintaining their viability in the long term. The additional funding to export marketing programs should be shown by National Party members to the Leader of the Liberal Party as an initiative that will assist many small businesses in rural areas to take up export opportunities. Many rural businesses will be able to gain access to export markets through the initiatives of the One Nation program. That is good, but in contrast the Professor is to cut spending in that area by $175m.

The National Party people should go and see the Leader of the Liberal Party and find out why rural people are getting such a raw deal from his document. It is not a Fightback—it is a king hit aimed at rural people. They have to ask the Leader of the Liberal Party why their constituents are not getting a fair go. While they are at it, they should be asking their own leader why he has not fought for the interests of country people. He has agreed to see them taxed at 15 per cent by a new tax which will hit country people the hardest, and has got nothing in return.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is wrong, you know—totally wrong.

—I notice the interjection but it sounds like a death rattle from the National Party. Unless National Party people start standing up for the people who elected them, standing up against the policies of the Leader of the Liberal Party, they are just not doing their job. They need to show a bit of guts. They need to refrain from lying down in front of the Leader of the Liberal Party like lap-dogs waiting for the next pack.
—I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. I find that remark totally offensive and I ask that the honourable member for Page withdraw it.
—I ask the honourable member for Page to withdraw it.
—I withdraw it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The presentation we have just heard from the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) prompts me to move away from what I was about to say. It is a terrific example of the tragedy that has beset this country during the nine years of the Labor Government. He has only been here a short time, so he cannot be held personally responsible for the tragedy that still goes on today. In fact, the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), if he were an Indian, would today be called Chief Rising Dust because his Party has been surrounded by a cloud of rising dust now for a considerable time.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I wonder whether those sorts of terms are parliamentary in the context of your ruling on my comments.

PARA.TAB: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—What was said was that he would be called that; he is not actually calling him that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said, `if he were an Indian, he would be called Chief Rising Dust'. He and his Party have been in a dust cloud now for a considerable amount of time and the recession that we had to have still exists on the ground outside that dust storm. I will say something about Canberra being part of that dust storm shortly, but I have to respond to the honourable member for Page and say that this One Nation package is a cynical political exercise to do with the saving of the Prime Minister's political future. The Fightback package is about the people of Australia and what is good for them and what is good for people in my electorate. This Government program is a cynical attempt to stay in the dust storm and drag the people of Australia into the dust storm that honourable members opposite are still creating around themselves.

PARA.TAB: People who are as decent as the honourable member for Page and who, like me, come out of small businessmen, are fully aware of the tragedy that is hitting the people the honourable member mentioned: small business, self-employed people, farmers. The two honourable members sitting opposite know that they have had people who are in dire straits in their offices.

This situation has led to 20 per cent interest rates for more than 18 months. Who have they come from? Those 20 per cent interest rates have come from the Labor Party side of politics. The honourable members opposite created this recession we had to have and we are now in a tragic situation. Every day the front pages of newspapers in Victoria show what the Labor Government has done to our people. There is a new tragedy, day after day after day.

You can get a One Nation script like that, throw it at the Australian people, have the Prime Minister dance up and down on the stage of the Parliament, turn on the vaudeville as he said he would, get a bit of excitement, and grab the front pages. What is he going to be doing shortly? He will be kissing babies next week. The week after that—

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not change a thing.

—It will not change a thing. When I rang my electorate and asked what was going on, the people said, `Russell, the One Nation is not happening. One Nation is not happening. Do not delude yourself by thinking that this is going to fix anything'. Every day in my electorate and surrounds the recession goes on and gets deeper and bites harder and hurts more people. Those people who, according to honourable members opposite, do not earn over $30,000, will have a chance under this package because they will not go into bracket creep until such time as they earn $70,000.

PARA.TAB: But what are the honourable members opposite doing to them, apart from letting them just rise up and ripping the dollars off them and claiming to be doing a wonderful job? We have now got the Prime Minister, Chief Rising Dust, out there, the guy who has been in control of the levers—the Prime Minister himself said he had the levers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on the same basis as the last point of order—and he did not say `would be' this time.
—I am sorry, I was in conversation with the Clerk—

—I was just mentioning Chief Rising Dust again and referring to the Prime Minister and using the proper term for the Prime Minister and saying to the Parliament that there is a cloud and it is surrounding the Labor Party at the moment. It is still there. Its chief is still on his horse, he is dancing around in the cloud, and he is poking his head out for a bit of vaudeville here and a bit of excitement, like he promised, there.

PARA.TAB: He has bashed a few Poms. I have two Poms working for me in my office. They see themselves as Australians first. They are actually naturalised Australians, and they love this country. I saw a woman in tears who had just been naturalised a while ago who stood up and said that her family had always jokingly threatened to send her home, that every time she was out of order, her family said, `Mum, we are going to send you home'. That woman was so proud of being Australian, and what has our Prime Minister done? Had a crack at the Poms to take John Hewson off the front page. That is what the honourable members opposite have done. That is all they have done and will ever do.

The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns), today sitting at the dispatch box, yesterday said in this House that only 8 per cent of young people are unemployed. One person unemployed is too many. But up in this House, up here in this wonderful place—a great tourist attraction—there are not a lot of thinking people who are prepared to put Australia first, as the Leader of the Opposition has done in this Fightback package. If honourable members want a fight, here is a fight, because in this package is reality. There is what we can do for Australia. There is a vision for Australia. There is a chance for people in my electorate.

I want the two honourable members now to consider this. What the Prime Minister should have done was pick up this package and run with it. That is what he wanted to do in 1985. He begged the honourable members to take this on in 1985 but they would not let him do it; they would not let him give a chance to the people in their electorates that they are now worried about.

On behalf of the people in Corinella, I say that our unemployment is now running at around one million people. Some will say yes and others deny it, but it is my opinion that it is around one million people. I do not want to say to honourable members today what I think about the Prime Minister and his role as the Treasurer of this country and the recession that has hurt families and people so badly. In deference to those families, I will not mention what has happened because I reckon that everybody in this House, every member of this House, has had some tragic situation brought to his attention that can be traced directly back to the recession we had to have but we were not going to have and that we would not allow to be had. But now we have got the recession we had to have and we have got the person that gave us that recession standing on that horse, in that dust cloud, while the whole action of this devastation takes place, especially in Victoria and around Corinella and Dandenong. Everybody in this House has heard what the employment situation is in Dandenong. In fact, we just had a major summit chaired by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy).

I said yesterday that this One Nation document was meant to kick-start the economy. It has not even given it a little push. There is not even a feeling out there that there is an opportunity for people; and they are worried about their children. I want to talk about what honourable members opposite have said about their own Leader.
Firstly, I want to explain a media release from the office of Senator Jim McKiernan, JP. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: There are now 900,700 reasons why Paul Keating should not be elected Prime Minister of Australia. The man who gave us the recession we had to have should not now be rewarded for his accomplishment.

That is one of the Government senators. Then the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) was quoted in the Australian as saying he pronounced Mr Keating an `electoral dead loss'. The honourable member for Reid is a competent politician; he has been around a long time; he is a previous State member. He said that he just believed that Keating was not a saleable commodity, and that he still had that view. If that view has changed, I am not sure.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Reid is very good with English, so I wanted to look up the dictionary and make sure what I was saying was correct. I looked up `dead loss' and I found that a dead loss is a complete loss for which no compensation is being paid. I think the honourable member for Reid knew about this One Nation package when he said that because in it there is no compensation being paid. It is all unfunded, the Government is going to borrow the lot.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Now there are two members over there that absolutely know that if one is running a business, like I have, if too much money is borrowed and one cannot pay it back, eventually the people that one borrowed that from come to collect. The world is going to come to collect on their party, and they are going to collect at the ballot-box next time round. That is because there is some vision in this Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, well, I will just finish on this one. Then it says—
—Order!

—And it says further that dead loss is a useless person or thing. So the honourable member for Reid really had an approach that he wanted to take, to explain to the Australian people about the Prime Minister—whom I have described as Chief Rising Dust. Then he said, `Electoral'. That is a constituent, elector or voter. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker Mr F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing new about the grievance I wish to vent on behalf of the people of Robertson today. It is a perennial problem which my duty to my constituents demands be constantly brought to the attention of this Parliament. I refer to the recurrent urban flooding suffered by many thousands of people on the central coast of New South Wales. When the good folk of Nyngan and other towns along the Murray-Darling system faced flooding, the eyes of the nation were focused upon them. Wide media coverage and visits by our nation's leaders were orders of the day.

PARA.TAB: Fortunately, this sort of flooding normally occurs once or twice a decade, and usually affects only a couple of thousand citizens. In Robertson, severe flooding has become a way of life. Some 8,000 of my constituents get flooded each and every year. Some are inundated as many as three times in a year. They suffer exactly the same destruction of their houses, as floodwaters destroy floor coverings and furniture and put their lives at risk, as well as the lives of their loved ones. Very little notice is taken of this widespread devastation because it happens so often. Regrettably it is no longer news.

On 9 and 10 February last, a severe rain storm following two days of soaking rain caused devastating flooding in Narara and Erina Creeks. Flood levels were higher on Narara Creek than they have been recorded in living memory. That is saying a great deal because since 1985 that creek has suffered no fewer than five floods, each categorised as a one in 100-year flood, and numerous lesser floods.

Indications are that the flood on the Narara Creek considerably exceeded the one per cent AEP flood levels between Haggerty Close at Narara and Dignity Crescent at West Gosford. The industrial area of North Gosford in Brooks Avenue suffered badly with indications of more than 1 metre. Night shift workers at the Angel Pie Co. were given only moments notice of the onrush and were forced to swim to higher ground in water infested with leeches and snakes. Their cars were submerged in the car park. Management lost thousands of dollars in lost product, ingredients, production and damage to machinery. The Gosford City bowling lanes are a total loss with a full rebuilding program necessary. In the Showground Road area the water level in houses was well above the windows. The West Gosford industrial properties between Manns Road and Narara Creek suffered similar damage. The Tascott Basin and Point Clare area also suffered similar damage with Brisbane Water Drive cut for a considerable period and many houses flooded.

In the main township of Gosford, floodwaters entered many commercial properties up to three metres deep between Carbow Arcade and Burns Place. Flood liable areas at Erina along Barralong Road, Winani Road, Lingi Street and Nerissa Road experienced a flood of approximately 10 per cent AEP magnitude. All areas normally flooded suffered yet again. Rainfall figures indicate that the rain falling on Narara Creek exceeded one per cent AEP design figures

The torrential rain the following weekend also caused severe flooding in the Narara and Erina Creek areas and resulted in substantial damage to the city's road network. Council staff were kept busy dealing with numerous emergency calls reporting damage and seeking assistance. Substantial damage to road shoulders and major scouring occurred along Brisbane Water Drive with localised flooding of properties. Similar damage occurred at Empire Bay, Green Point, Copacabana, Woy Woy, Pearl Beach and Umina. Road closures were required at various sites in Gosford including Showground Road, Avoca Drive, Terrigal Drive, Brunswick Road and the Pacific Highway at West Gosford.

The effects of the storms were also felt in the Mangrove Mountain area with numerous trees being brought down and major scouring of unsealed roads. Wisemans Ferry Road was closed because of that scouring. Repair works will eventually cost millions of dollars but that is but a drop in the ocean given the Gosford City Council already has a backlog in flood mitigation and road works exceeding $50m. The Government gave Council a $1.2m flood mitigation grant last year but obviously a great deal more is required.

I want to give particular attention today to what happened at Tascott on the morning of 9 January this year by way of illustrating just how dangerous this flooding has become. On that morning a severe flood not only caused extensive property damage but also a washaway on the main northern railway line from Sydney to Newcastle. A disaster of the dimensions of the Granville rail disaster was narrowly averted that morning. My constituents advise me that some three minutes before the ballast between the tracks was washed across Brisbane Water Drive, a northbound electric passenger train crossed the area of the washaway. If that train had been a few minutes later and coincided with the arrival of a southbound goods train, then the chances are that they both would have tumbled into the Brisbane Waters with catastrophic results.

The problem at Tascott has been critically dangerous for several years. It is the usual story of several government authorities buck-passing and refusing to get their act together. The flooding is caused by three totally inadequate culverts. The first under Glenrock Parade is the responsibility of the Gosford City Council. It has five cells at the moment and Webb McKeown Engineering Consultants reported to Council in 1989 that a larger culvert was required. They also told the Rail Authority that it had to install a new culvert under the railway line and the New South Wales Road Traffic Authority that a new culvert was required under Brisbane Water Drive.

The people of Tascott, horrified by the dangers involved and fed up with being flooded because of the procrastinations and buck-passing of three government bodies, called a protest meeting recently. I attended and agreed to take up their cause with the authorities in question and immediately wrote letters to the New South Wales Ministers for roads and railways as well as the Gosford City Council. Gosford City Council was no problem. It readily agreed to allocate funds and got on with the job of building the culvert at Glenrock Parade.
On 12 February I received a letter from Mr Wal Murray, Deputy Premier and Minister for Roads in New South Wales, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: As you would be aware, the national recession has severely eroded the level of funding available for roadworks and there are no uncommitted funds at my disposal.

I have asked the RTA to maintain close liaison with Council to ensure that the RTA's share of the cost is given suitable priority among the many proposals for works on classified roads in the city of Gosford.

No joy from Wal Murray. On 28 February 1992, I got a letter from Mr Baird, the Minister for Transport in New South Wales, responsible for the railway line that washed away. He said that Tascott presently rates seventh in the current list of 13 culvert amplification priorities in that area. As I say, a huge loss of human life was very narrowly averted, and yet that priority is only seventh out of 13. The people of Tascott are certainly getting no joy from the State Government of New South Wales, although their lives are being ruined by this constant flooding and risk to lives of other people.

PARA.TAB: If these sorts of disasters are to be averted, then I think it is time for the New South Wales Government to take up the proposals in the One Nation policy that relate to our national rail system. A great deal of money was being given in that proposal which will allow railways like that in New South Wales to give priority to the sorts of works that involve questions of human safety and the loss of lives in disasters. I would hope that Mr Baird and Mr Murray can see fit, having been given all this money for both roads and railways, to change their priorities on behalf of the long-suffering people of Robertson, who have been flooded far too often and who deserve a far better go.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must compliment the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Walker) on his measured, rational and balanced approach to representing his constituents in the speech that he just gave to the House. I think it contrasted rather amazingly with the excited shoutings of the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), the previous speaker on the Government side, who tended to devote the whole of his time to attacking the National Party. But I suppose that is fair enough in politics; and my intention when I came in today was to talk about the conduct of parliament to a certain extent.

PARA.TAB: While I certainly believe in lively debate—there must be an exchange of views across the chamber—I happen to be one of those who think that if one is going to be a parliamentarian, and a member of the national Parliament above all, one has to learn to play the ball and not the man. Our prime offender in this way is the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who does really rant and rave. He has given up the `scumbag' vocabulary, it seems, since he has taken on the new aura of dignity—dignity?—of Prime Minister, and he does not use that sort of abusive language quite as much. I notice, too, that in the five months that he spent in the wilderness on the back bench before he became Prime Minister he must have spent a great deal of that time standing in front of a mirror learning how to smile. I have known him for seven years. He has smiled more since the coup which put poor old Bob out than he did in the previous seven years. His minders are certainly looking after him to that extent.

But it is important that the people of Australia should realise that this is a place where there is exchange and interjection. I often find that people who come and visit Question Time, particularly the kids from visiting schools, say, `If we behaved like that at school, we would be in real trouble'. Question Time needs to be improved, because at the present time Question Time in this House of Representatives is not producing the sort of parliamentary behaviour or the activity that it should. What the people of Australia should realise is that there is a very good reason for it.

Questions should be answered. Unfortunately, we have a front bench of Government Ministers who specialise in not answering questions, unless they are asked by members of their own side. In that case the Minister's office has already written the question and passed it out to the backbencher so that the Minister has the answer already prepared in front of him. Anybody from the public who has been here at Question Time can see that any one of those Ministers, when they answer a question from their own side, has the answers already written out. Surprise! Surprise!

Of course, when they get a question from the Opposition benches they make no attempt to answer the question. Rather, they say what they want to say and completely ignore the question. The reason the Opposition is vociferous about this matter is that, if a Minister is making the most outrageous claims and saying the most outrageous untruths, then if we do not reject those claims that implies acceptance. If I were to say that 99 per cent of the members of the Labor Government have AIDS, they would jump up and down. Look at their horrified faces. Of course, it is wrong, and we should properly reject that. Equally, the Opposition in doing its job for Australia has an obligation not to let the untruths and, quite frankly, the false claims go by unchallenged. That is why Question Time is fairly noisy.

I listened with great attention to the honourable member for Page in his contribution. As I said just a moment or two ago, he seemed to spend all of his time attacking the National Party. It comes back to the question of truth. It is the question of truth that is of prime importance in this Parliament. On the one hand we have the Liberal and National parties' Fightback package and, on the other, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has produced his One Nation answer to it. Quite frankly, it is only a half-baked answer. In the last few days we have had the Government doing nothing else but attack the Opposition, not trying to sell the benefits of what it is trying to produce with its One Nation policies, but telling the most outrageous untruth about what the Fightback package will do. The Government has based this on an analysis which uses different ground rules. We cannot compare fish with beef and we cannot compare what Labor is saying about Fightback with the actual truth that it does contain.

The honourable member for Page suggested that a vast majority of farmers and self-employed people and wage and salary earners would be far worse off under Fightback. This is not true. It is a false statement. The Government has doctored the books to produce a result which gives the answers that it wants. As Benjamin Disraeli said, `There are lies, damned lies and statistics'. What we have with this present Labor Government is a perversion of the use of statistics to produce answers for its own ends which have nothing to do with truth or reality. I am delighted to see the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) sitting at the table because only yesterday he gave this House the figure that youth unemployment was only 8.8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.

—He says it is correct. Yes, but 8.8 per cent of what? It is not as a percentage of those seeking jobs. The actual figure of youth unemployment in Australia is 34.8 per cent. That is the real figure for young people who want a job and cannot get a job. But if we clog up the books with all of those still at school, all of those at TAFE, all of those doing other courses, who are not in the labour market, and who are not looking for a job, then we can come down to 8.8 per cent. But bear in mind that the Bureau of Statistics says the correct unemployment rate for youth in Australia is 34.8 per cent.

PARA.TAB: That is not only a shame, it is an outrageous disgrace that the kids of this country have been put into this situation. They have been put into this situation deliberately by the Prime Minister, and the man who was Treasurer for all those years since 1983. It was his recession, his policies, that have done this. This is the recession that we had to have. We have one million people unemployed. A figure of 10.6 per cent of the work force is unemployed.

The next thing that will happen is that the honourable member for Petrie will fiddle the books again and tell us that the unemployment rate is only 2.5 per cent. That is what it would be if one used the same basis that was used for the other figures. The honourable member for Petrie is not being consistent, he is not doing it properly and he is not telling the truth of it. That is the problem with the Labor Party and this Government. They are distorting the truth every time they open their mouths. It is not for the good of Australia. It is for the good of one man; it is for the good of the Prime Minister—One Nation: one job. We have to look at all of Australia and not just at the sectional groups. There is no doubt that in the coalition's Fightback package there are just so many things of great benefit to everybody. The Labor Government says in the `One Broke Nation' statement that it has reduced sales tax on motor vehicles, on sedans, from 20 per cent to 15 per cent. The choice of 15 per cent is not just by accident; that is what the GST will be. That does not apply to four-wheel drive vehicles and it does not apply to utilities. People in a business of any shape or form should understand that, under Fightback, if they need to buy a car to run that business, they will not pay a 15 per cent sales tax; they will pay no tax. The GST is rebatable for business inputs. This goes right along the line. Every Australian family will benefit from the abolition of the fuel excise. For my personal car, I will be paying 19c a litre less under Fightback and every business will pay 26c a litre less under Fightback.

We have to ensure that the debate in this Parliament is based on fact, not on lies and not on outrageous untruths. We need to have a reasoned debate where everything is looked at on the same basis, not different figures for different parties. The Labor Party has sought to change the rules in the middle of the debate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a great possibility that one of the crucial issues at the next Federal election will be immigration and Australia's intake. We have already had attempts by the Opposition to give subliminal or code messages to the Australian electorate. This is obviously an attempt to utilise a degree of racism in the community, a concern with the change in our intake and increased stress on Asian migration. That code will say that we will insist upon a greater requirement of English with regard to who comes here. It will ignore, and it will not emphasise to the Australian public, the reality that countries such as Malaysia and Hong Kong are characterised by very high levels of English usage. Some longer term communities in this country, particularly from Europe, are already complaining that the current emphasis on English discriminates against those European countries in favour of Asia.

PARA.TAB: As I said, we are seeing an attempt to give a very coded message to the Australian public that by requiring English we will change the intake. The facts of life are that in recent weeks the corporate sector in this country has said that it will not allow that if the Opposition is elected. Already some companies have said that they will take a stronger position with regard to supporting a heavy intake because of Australia's requirements.

As I said, this is a very subliminal attempt. The Opposition is trying to tell the Australian people that we can go back to the old days when immigrants came from Cornwall and Ayrshire and there were also a few Germans and Dutch and that we are going to change this by bringing in a requirement for English. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) strutted around Sydney's Vietnamese community a few weeks ago telling it that it is the greatest thing since sliced bread, that it has done so much for Australia, that we love it and that the people are beautiful. This shows the contradictions in the concern of those opposite.

Today I want to talk about some of the down to earth realities in my electorate, and to commend the work of the Auburn Asian Welfare Centre. In a leading work on the spread of the Indo-Chinese population in Sydney, entitled Spatial Distribution and Concentration of Australia's Three Indo-Chinese Born Communities 1976-86, James Coughlan clearly calculated and looked at the movement of those communities in Sydney. Of course, the reality is that there is a very heavy concentration still in Cabramatta, but a distribution of those communities throughout Sydney has also occurred. One of the greatest increases, of course, has occurred in the municipality of Auburn within my electorate, which, as of the 1986 census, accounted for 7.4 per cent of the total Vietnamese population in New South Wales. That particular community represents about 15 per cent of those born overseas—and I am not talking about their children—who in turn are 35 per cent of Auburn municipality's population.

Of course, with this growing population there is a need to provide services, and the Auburn Asian Welfare Centre is one group that is attempting to do that. The Centre's efforts have been characterised by great diligence; it is not a typical social workers' situation, with people sitting around drinking cups of coffee and empire building by stacking the local community committee with friends and other social workers. This is a group that has done a very thorough effort for the community. It was characterised by its document entitled Indo-Chinese Residents in Auburn Municipality—Community Profile, launched in September last year.

That survey, of course, followed a very important government inspired effort from the Administrative Review Council which looked at the Vietnamese community in Melbourne and the Turkish community in Sydney. It showed that, despite the urban myths about how everyone is on social security and everyone is unemployed, there is a great lack of knowledge in the Vietnamese community about their access to government organisations. For instance, in 1990 only 11 per cent of the Vietnamese community in Melbourne knew of the existence of the Ombudsman and only 13 per cent knew of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

What we saw in that study by the Administrative Review Council, over the period 1990-1991, by using Vietnamese newspapers and by using phone-ins, public meetings and the three half-hours the Vietnamese have on Melbourne radio, was an attempt to demonstrate to the community their rights of appeal and their access to these government bodies, and to see whether in that effort the knowledge would spread. Certainly by the end of that year knowledge of the Ombudsman increased from 11 per cent to 35 per cent and of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from 13 per cent to 23 per cent. That survey demonstrated a very great need. It came up with a lot of suggestions for both communities in regard to what government bodies should do to publicise their availability.

The Auburn Asian Welfare Centre relates to those problems. It has existed in the area since 1989, when it was sponsored by the western Sydney area assistance scheme—once again an initiative that everyone in New South Wales, except the Greiner State Government, thinks was quite reasonable. That Government, of course, has made very dramatic attempts to castrate the western Sydney area assistance scheme in the last few years—eventually being forced to back down, of course.

Anyway, this group started from that funding in 1989 and it has produced the profile I earlier commented on. What it showed was a need for a variety of activities by the local council and government authorities. Included amongst those was a general community service agency. It was found that the fact that Cabramatta had such a high Vietnamese population meant that government agencies tended to depend upon people getting on a train and going up to Cabramatta; there were no local agencies that had these services. It said that the group itself should seek funding for bilingual staff; that local services should be responsive to avoid this travelling; and that there should be specific labour market programs, because one of the realities is a very high unemployment situation in the Vietnamese community, way over the Australian average. At the time of the comparative survey the Australian average was 8.8 per cent, against a Vietnamese rate of over 30 per cent. The report said that government bodies should attempt to make labour programs specifically designed for those communities, and that—
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:
That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been reported recently that homosexuals will be allowed to serve in the Australian Defence Force under a new policy nearing completion. Many members of the public in my electorate and elsewhere who have contacted me in recent days are appalled at this prospect. Under existing policy, anyone who admits that he or she is homosexual, or is proven to be homosexual, must leave the Defence Force. The existing policy is there for good and valid reasons of national and personal security, of health, of moral standards, very importantly of responsibility for minors, of teamwork and of orderly discipline in a military environment.

PARA.TAB: Rather than tacitly accepting a further lowering of society standards, the Chief of the Defence Force and his service Chiefs of Staff should be leaving the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) in no doubt as to why the present policy is sound. That view is shared by many on both sides of this House. A `turn the blind eye' or Yes, Minister attitude on this will be a cop-out. As a letter to the editor in yesterday's Canberra Times said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The state has no right to weaken the nation by forcing certain of our institutions to treat as normal and acceptable gross sexual perversion among their members.
Homosexuality and the contemporary Defence Force environment are mutually exclusive. Anything less is to accept a fool's paradise. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Nine years ago today, almost exactly at this time of the day, I cast my vote which helped elect the Hawke Labor Government. I was living in the electorate of Flinders at the time and voted for Bob Chynoweth, the last relevant representative of the people of that area. Later that afternoon, I boarded a plane for America with my then girlfriend and now wife, Petrina. Somewhere between Honolulu and Los Angeles, the pilot on the plane announced, and I recall his words, `For all you Aussies still on board, Fraser lost'. There was a loud cheer on the plane and everybody ordered a celebratory drink. At that time there was a real feeling of euphoria and expectation and hope in Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is funny how history repeats itself. On Saturday I am going back to America. I have the honour of leading a delegation of young political leaders on behalf of the Australia Political Exchange Council. I go back to America at a time when again there is hope and expectation building in Australia. Whilst today we celebrate the ninth anniversary of the election of the Hawke Government, we have a new Prime Minister, a major economic statement, One Nation, that has instilled hope into Australians, and an Opposition hell-bent on slugging everyone with a hideous tax on food and clothing and the necessities of life. The battle lines are now drawn. I look back on the Hawke years with pride and I look forward with vigour and enthusiasm to the Keating years. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday of last week, a large gathering of members of parliament, the diplomatic corps, the Public Service, Canberra clergy and other persons attended the annual parliamentary service held at St Christopher's Cathedral in Forrest. A greeting was given by Mr John Langmore, MP, the President of the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship, which incidentally has a membership of almost 80 at the moment. Lessons were read by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). The address was given by the Reverend David Gill, General Secretary of the Australian Council of Churches. Mr Gill centred his address on the wisdom of Solomon. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: King Solomon was a person wearing the mantle of national leadership whose primary concern was not with personal self-interest, not with his party's performance in the latest polls, not with the fluctuating value of the shekel or the trials and tribulations of the Jerusalem stock exchange. Solomon's yearning was for wisdom and a capacity to discern the good.

Based on that wisdom, Mr Gill said, the true leader in the political or any other sphere is one who lifts people's eyes to the distant horizon, who inspires us with a vision of what could be, who is driven by a deeply held conviction of what ought to be great wisdom. I commend the address to honourable members and seek leave to table a copy of it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I was pleased to present to this House a petition signed by 2,334 Australians, all of whom objected strongly to resource security legislation for major new industrial wood processing projects. They also called on this House to support the preparation of an ecologically sustainable national forest and forestry strategy for Australia. The last point is important because unless our forestry industry is placed on a sustainable footing it will, in time, disappear.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, a combination of existing unsustainable logging practices, increased usage of capital-intensive as opposed to labour-intensive technology, and the lack of a real plantations policy has led to enormous job losses in this industry over recent decades. Resource security legislation will not reverse the trend of job losses unless there is a real commitment by governments around Australia to move out of old growth native forests and into plantations.

It is possible to have a viable forestry industry and a world-class network of national parks. To suggest that the creation of new parks will destroy the industry is utter nonsense. The Resource Assessment Commission's draft report on the Australian forestry industry supports this view. I am sure that the 2,334 people who signed that petition also supported it. It is obvious that in this time of unacceptably high unemployment the Australian public still understands that jobs and protection of the environment are totally compatible and rejects the notion that the environment no longer matters. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the efforts of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization to make ASIO more open and accountable. As a minimum, it should be forced to conform to the disclosure provisions of the Archives Act. The Hilton bombing tragedy showed that ASIO is virtually unaccountable. ASIO was at least partly responsible for a gross breach of security in the middle of one of the biggest security operations ever mounted in this country. People were killed and maimed in the main street of our largest city and in a place which was the focus of the security effort. One would have expected that such an event would be fully and openly investigated by the Commonwealth to see where our security forces went wrong, to find out what mistakes were made and who made them. But it has not happened. The closed inquiries have satisfied no-one but the security forces themselves, and have generated endless theories and speculation about the truth.

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Attorney-General to announce a full and open inquiry into the Hilton bombing is indefensible. Institutional secrecy is self-serving. It breaches the principles of accountability and the public's right to know. Secrecy is almost always a conspiracy or self-delusion. The smart money always finds out. Compared to a policy of openness, the benefits of institutional secrecy are infinitesimal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw attention to a petition which I was asked to table in parliament but which was not suitable to be tabled because it is critical of a judge. I would like to mention the complaint of the 1,330 signatories about the alleged riotous behaviour and other offences of Brewarrina 17. I will pass this on to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). I want to tell the signatories to this petition that the Minister will soon be tabling a response to the Royal Commission findings which I know will be very positive about those findings. I am quite sure their concerns will be taken into account.

—I am pleased to see the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) in the chamber. Last week, under parliamentary privilege, he made a deplorable and cowardly attack on the President of the Queensland Local Government Association, Councillor Jim Pennell. His description of Councillor Pennell as a country bumpkin and a dill has naturally outraged local government people. This anger came to a head last Friday when the councils of the honourable member's own electorate censured him and condemned his repeated criticisms of local government leaders. The resolution of censure was carried without dissent at the Burnett Local Government Association conference and reflected growing dissatisfaction with his regular and insupportable allegations about even his own council.

PARA.TAB: Apparently the honourable member is upset about the ongoing campaign by local government to have more of the Government's petrol excise rip-off allocated to roads. The facts are that the councils' pressure for more road funding has the overwhelming support of the community. To make such an unprovoked attack on a colleague in another tier of government who has no right of response not only reflects very poorly on the honourable member but also damages the reputation of the Parliament as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, when honourable members opposite talk about cowardice, I would like to talk about the Fightback package, which is a cowardly attack on the living standards of farmers, who are struggling at the present time, and working families. It is a king hit. It is a cowardly package. What it is meant to do is to shift money from the battlers to the yuppies at the top end of the market. Honourable members opposite have the audacity to come in here and stick up for special privilege. The National Party of Australia has been sold a lemon.
