The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) has been conned. Even their mate Sir Robert Sparkes, with whom I do not agree very often, said that National Party members will not be able to sell this package in the bush. They will not be able to, because they want to put a tax of 15 per cent on fruit and vegetables, meat, bread, milk and other dairy products. They have the hide to talk about compassion. They have the hide to talk about courage. It is not being very brave to tax working families and women and kids. That is what they want to do. Over the next 12 months we are going to ram this package right down their necks.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Road Safety: Wearing of Seat Belts

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to draw the attention of the House to the road safety campaign that is being conducted in Victoria at present. I believe it should be adopted by all States. The message of the campaign is that motorists should wear their seat belts. Research indicates that, if everyone wore seat belts, Victoria's road toll would be cut by up to 10 per cent. Chief Superintendent Fox of the O district described people who did not wear seat belts as lazy. He said, `Not only that; they are just stupid. They are putting their own lives at risk'. I draw this to the attention of the House because yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) failed to wear his seat belt at the Toyota plant in Victoria.

—Mr Speaker, I rise to express concern about the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Tribunal deregulated commercial advertising. I think anyone who occasionally watches commercial television will understand that that was really a backward step. What happened was that the commercial stations were not able to regulate themselves properly and we got an avalanche of advertising.

PARA.TAB: The second point I wish to make is that I wonder about the standards of assessment of the Broadcasting Tribunal. I have had drawn to my attention a program on Channel 10 called Studs, which seems to me to be an exercise in salacious—

TALK.START.PARA: —Soft porn.

—Soft porn. I thank the honourable member for Gippsland. In fact, it is demeaning to women and to men. I would have thought that the Broadcasting Tribunal might have exercised some higher standards. I say that, not because I am of a mind to be censorial but rather because it just is not worth putting on television. I also noted that at the same time the Broadcasting Tribunal expressed concern about a children's program called Fat Cat. I have to say that I think the quality of the production in it was less than desirable, but it was totally harmless. If anything, it was slightly commercialised, but it could have been restored. Certainly, when something as salacious as Studs is allowed to go on air, one really has to wonder whether the Broadcasting Tribunal knows what it is doing.

—Mr Speaker, I have been listening on a regular basis to the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) coming into this House and endeavouring to criticise the Fightback package of the Opposition. The very interesting part about it is that he is not prepared to talk about his own policies or what his own Government is going to do because the Government really has not got anything worth while on the record. Honourable members should have a look at the unemployment situation. If all the unemployed people stood a metre apart, the line would stretch further than from Melbourne to Sydney. Yet the Government wants to stand up and criticise what the Opposition is putting up as a decent and reasonable alternative to what it is doing. The reason why honourable members opposite want to talk about our systems of operating is that they have got nothing of their own that they can present.

—I am happy to respond to the discussion by the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) on the GST. If ever there was a party that did not deserve to be elected, it is that mob on the other side. The people in the bush will not accept the GST. They realise what phonies Opposition members really are. All those people on the other side are going to be back over there. There will be enough room for them because there will be even fewer Opposition members. The people in the bush just will not wear the GST.
—Order! It being 2.00 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—Before I call on Questions without Notice, I will advise members of the House about my intentions in relation to the Wills by-election. It is my intention to issue a writ on Monday, 9 March 1992 for the election of a member to serve for the electoral division of Wills, in the State of Victoria, in the place of the Hon. Robert James Lee Hawke.

PARA.TAB: The dates in connection with the election will be fixed as follows: issue of the writs, Monday, 9 March 1992; close of the electoral rolls, Monday, 16 May 1992; date of nomination, Friday, 20 March 1992; date of polling, Saturday, 11 April 1992; and return of the writ, on or before Wednesday, 17 June 1992. I advise the House that those dates have been said to be satisfactory by the three parties that are members of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. Is it not a fact that you could only produce losers out of Fightback because you forgot to allocate $1.2 billion from bracket creep to the plus side of the ledger, as you conceded yesterday? Is it not a fact that even $1.2 billion is wrong—it should really be around $3 billion—and that a further $2.5 billion should be added in because you assumed no revenue from the black economy? Is it not a fact that you have short-changed Australian families by more than $5 billion in your analysis and this is the basis for the dishonest claim that most taxpayers will lose from Fightback when in fact they will be much better off?
—What is the question?
—The honourable member for Hinkler will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the only people in Australia who now think that most Australians will be better off under Fightback are this dishevelled mob who sit opposite. They are still desperately trying to convince themselves that what the Leader of the Opposition told them, when he led them up the garden path, was actually true. But everyone else in Australia knows that, on the basis of the Treasury analysis, 70 per cent of Australian households, of wage and salary earners, will be worse off.
—Wrong!

—And, in relation to the interjection from the Leader of the National Party, 60 per cent of farmers and self-employed will be worse off. I have absolutely no intention of responding to this fifth attempt to ask again the same question that was asked yesterday on four separate occasions, and on each occasion I answered the question fully. I am going to make this additional point just to ram home a very unpleasant reality for the Opposition: this is essentially an argument—a fairly arcane argument, I might say—about how one should adjust the tax scales to account for the effects of inflation or the effects of wage movements. On the one hand, the Opposition essentially is now saying—this was made perfectly clear a couple of nights ago when the Leader of the Opposition put out a press statement saying that the adjustment should have been on the basis of a 3.5 per cent movement in earnings rather than a movement in the CPI—that if you want to maintain the position of a taxpayer at one point in time compared with another point in time, and if you are going to preserve the equality of that taxpayer's position, you should adjust the tax scales in the intervening period by the movements in earnings in that period, whereas the Treasury said, `No, that is not right. You should adjust the tax scales for movement in the CPI'.

TAB.TAB: During yesterday's discussion, somebody asked me what practice has been followed in relation to this issue. I went back to a period when the taxation scales were indexed, and that was a period from July 1976. The Leader of the Opposition ought to remember this because he at the time was advising the then Treasurer, Sir Phillip Lynch. The then Fraser Government decided that it would index the tax scales from July 1976 in order to cope with this question of bracket creep, in other words, to index the tax scales.

PARA.TAB: What did it use as its measure? What was its legislative measure? Did it legislate to adjust the tax scales for movements in earnings, or did it adjust the tax scales for movements in the CPI? What does Budget Paper No. 4 in that Budget say? It says the following:
The indexation provisions of the law embrace the income brackets of the rates scale, the general rebate, rebates for dependants—

ANSWER.PARA: and other things. Then it goes on to say:
These are to be automatically adjusted each year for increases which have occurred in the consumer price index.

So this was the mechanism decided upon by the Fraser Government, decided by Sir Phillip Lynch as Treasurer and advised as he was by the now Leader of the Opposition. But now, of course, it becomes convenient for the Leader of the Opposition to say something entirely different—to say, `No, no, no, that was then; now we are going to do something else'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have completely lost the point.
—Order!

—The principle of tax indexation, as legislated for by this crowd when they had an opportunity to do it, and in fact did it, was to adjust the tax scales by movements in the CPI. That is exactly the analysis that the Treasury brought to bear—
—And how much did the CPI go up by?
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.
—in trying to make the calculation of how the Opposition, if in government, might adjust its tax scales for bracket creep now.

PARA.TAB: So all this stuff that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is going on with about magic puddings full of money that can be handed back is just nonsense. It has nothing whatever to do with that. It is how one adjusts the tax scales to ensure that bracket creep is either not collected or is appropriately returned. This is just another demonstration of the fact that the Leader of the Opposition has totally flexible principles. He has no principles whatsoever. He just picks them up, he makes a collection of principles as he goes through life, in a way which happens to suit him at the time. He is totally politically capricious.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Following the release of One Nation last week, could he inform the House whether the Government stands by the excellent One Nation plan and what the Government intends to do regarding this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government not only stands by One Nation, but of course we are completely proud of it. It is a comprehensive plan that will include: the creation of 800,000 jobs over nine years—900,000 on the Opposition's reckoning; major incentives for private investment; major capital works programs which will benefit the nation over a long period; a revolution in aviation; a change to power generation and distribution; encouraging development of Australian ideas; an immediate boost to spending of $300m for a payment to taxpaying families with children; ongoing increases in the family allowance supplement; and increases to welfare groups. That is done in such a way as to return the Budget quickly to surplus within three or four years from now.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—On the other hand, what we see with the Opposition's Fightback policy is that yesterday the man who has enjoyed the longest political honeymoon in Australian history says he is trying to do his job in difficult circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Mr Cadman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mitchell!
—Yesterday we saw the end, the demise, of Fightback.

PARA.TAB: Mr Taylor interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Groom!
—Because yesterday at the Press Club in an address, the Leader of the Opposition said on policy—just be clear, on policy—that he is going to change:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . we are going to turn the policy knob up a couple more times between now and the next election. . .
He went on to say in this question and answer:

When I say we are going to turn the notch up, I am talking about turning up the notch in a reform sense, not in terms of trying to buy additional electoral support, and if there are tax changes and improvements that flow from reform, we are always happy to pass those on.

Decoded, that means what the Australian Financial Review took it to mean: Hewson vows to top up tax cuts. There we are—the Fightback proposal, put together over a year, all supposedly costed and stitched up—

PARA.TAB: Mr Taylor interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Groom will cease interjecting.

—All supposedly internally consistent, is now going to be topped up with tax cuts as a desperate person finds that his Fightback package has been, with all the Opposition handcuffed to it, hit, with two weeks of parliamentary scrutiny and scrutiny by the Treasury, with an Exocet missile which has blown it to pieces, handcuffed as they are to it. The Leader of the Opposition now says that he is soldiering on under difficult circumstances. This is unbelievable. At the Press Club he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Look, but I am trying to do a professional job in difficult circumstances.
He has a 20-point lead in the polls, a six-month honeymoon, but he is in difficult circumstances. I tell you what, brother, it will be more difficult as time goes by.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—That is point one. So what are we going to do now that Fightback's political life is over, to all intents and purposes? He has now given us notice: we are going to have Fightback mark II. What will that be based upon? Upon picking up bloated estimates of inflation. He went on to say—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order under standing order 145—
—You can tell when they are under pressure.
—Order! The honourable member for Perth will cease interjecting.

—Sir, the question directed to the Prime Minister was specifically about the One Nation package. I ask, Sir: when are you going to ask the Prime Minister to keep his answer relevant to the question before the House?

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The honourable member may be aware that in the past Speakers have frequently said that members and Ministers can illustrate their answers by example.
—In the speech the Leader of the Opposition at the Press Club said this:

ANSWER.PARA: I said we are right. Fightback is fully funded; One Nation is not fully funded, it is unfunded. It relies on growth, very optimistic assumptions most people have said about growth.
In the transcript he said:
Let's assume we get the growth that they—
that is, One Nation—

say will flow through from `95-'96, we'll be able to deliver all the Fightback and all of One Nation and still have a few billion dollars on the bottom line, on which we can have scope obviously to do more.

In other words, in the speech he says it is unfunded and relies on growth assumptions that are very optimistic, and then in the transcript, in the questions that follow, he blackguards the assumptions on growth and says:
If they get that growth, we've got even a few more billion to play with.

That is the billion which he will then pass back as tax cuts or, alternatively, as the Treasurer indicated, pick up the assumptions under the Murphy model for growth and inflation and then basically try to spend the money in a grab for votes that will destroy the nation's fiscal policy. On page 5 on employment, the Leader of the Opposition says:
So it is a judgment and I say a judgment. I do not walk away from the fact that about two million jobs. . .
There it is in the Australian this morning:
Dr Hewson also admitted yesterday that the forecast 2 million jobs the Coalition trumpeted when it launched its Fightback package. . . was "only a judgment".
So it is a judgment: He said:
I say it is a judgment. . .
Then he said:
People are wondering why we did not judge it should be three million jobs.

In other words, we should take two million as being reasonable because the Opposition could have made it three million. Now we are down to the real nitty-gritty of the Fightback package: the thing is that the two million jobs claim was totally fraudulent, just a judgment off the top of your head; it had no basis in econometrics whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: You are now about turning up the knobs on more change for Fightback mark II as Fightback mark I slips under the waves. How are you going to do that? Are you going to increase the Budget deficit? Are you going to claim that you can cut more than $10 billion out of government spending? Surely you are not going to claim that. Are you going to claim the Murphy inflation forecast of 6 per cent and 7 per cent without Fightback, or 10 per cent with Fightback, or are you going to claim the Government's growth figures and say that that allows you a few more billion, which you could use not to produce a surplus by 1995-96, but to produce basically another Box Hill tax grab—another Box Hill tax bribe—of the variety which the Liberal Party ran in 1987 and in 1990?

Basically, you are saying, `I tried the tight approach—I tried to stitch it up—but then that terrible Government and Treasury came along and took it apart. I had two days to defend myself against the Treasury estimates, including a speech to the Press Club, and could not and did not. Now it has basically gone under the waves. I was not able to run the scam about the ABC being part of the conspiracy. What I will do now is turn up the knobs, produce another package a la the Liberal Party 1987 or 1990, and basically just go and buy my way into office'.
Opposition members—Rubbish!
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—I will not name some of you. But when I was in political exile, not so long ago, some of you came up to me, very confidentially, talking about your prospects and saying, `It was a great risk that the Leader of the Opposition took. He pinned us to this Fightback proposition. God, it offends all the political rules'. But what are Opposition members saying now?
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister just made allegations about members of this side of the House. I ask him to name them.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order.

—The Liberal Party, as an organisation—its front and its back bench—must now be wondering about the Leader of the Opposition's style, his parliamentary ability, the Fightback package and the whole sense of it, which the Treasury has just trounced.
—You ought to be ashamed of yourself—presiding over a Question Time like this.
—I warn the honourable member for Goldstein.

—The Leader of the Opposition got up proudly and said that this was a package of support for business. If it were a package of support for business which did not blow the deficit out, it had to be at a cost to someone else—and that was, of course, households. How dare the Treasury point out that most people in households—four out of five—would be worse off under Fightback. Of course they would have to be worse off if you put across a package which benefited high income earners and businesses. Of course there would have to be losers—and the losers would be households.

PARA.TAB: You could not rebut it. You had a chance at the Press Club. Instead of rebutting the numbers, you went in and attacked the ABC and the Treasury as being conspirators. Then, in the most ominous development in our political life in six months, you are now going to turn up the notch on a Fightback mark II to buy your way back into office, assuming all the shonky inflation numbers in the back of the Murphy model—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. We have now listened to the Prime Minister for over 10 minutes.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.

—Mr Speaker, on previous occasions you have asked Prime Ministers to bring their answers to a close. In accordance with your upholding the conventions of this place, I ask you to apply that ruling on this occasion.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I will be concluding in a moment. I conclude on these points: basically, Fightback, politically, as a document, has had it. It has taken the Exocet and it is sinking. But the Leader of the Opposition just says, `Don't worry; let it go; I'll give you a new boat. I'll put a new one on the water for you. But this one will not pretend to be stitched up, funded, covered and the rest of it; this will be a la Box Hill 1987'. —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Perhaps the Prime Minister would like to announce a general poll rather than a by-election.
—Order! If the honourable member for La Trobe makes interventions like that again, I will deal with him.

—That is the reality. The Australian Financial Review was entirely reasonable in saying, `Hewson vows to top up the tax cuts'. The tied up, stitched up, Fightback package, with everything supposedly costed and funded, with nobody losing and everybody winning, has gone. I suppose those opposite will now go back to the people in the private sector who have been hired, supporters of the Liberal Party who will now be in the backrooms saying, `How can we get this guy out of trouble? How can we save him with this package? How can we now stitch together something else?'. We know that you cannot cut government spending any more; you can only blow out the deficit. This Government will not support, and will attack, any chance of any policy and any Party wishing to stretch out and diminish national savings into the 1990s. Mr Speaker, I can tell you that after eight, nearly nine, years of rigour—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. You are the custodian of the rights of honourable members on both sides of this House.
—Can you get to the point of order?
—On that basis, Mr Speaker, you should apply the rules you have previously applied and the conventions you have previously applied and make this Prime Minister finish his answer.
—Order! As there is no point of order, you should resume your seat.
—We will not allow nine years of rigour, of producing a structural Budget surplus, to be wrecked by you—any of you. That particularly includes the Leader of the Opposition.
—My question is directed to the increasingly desperate Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my right.

The weak will line up to a national wage case for a national wage adjustment, which the Leader of the Opposition is opposed to. Yet he has the temerity to put a question to me about taxpayers who earn under $20,000, particularly when the tax cuts that he proposes are there simply to fund the impact of the goods and services tax and, as the Treasury says, do not even adequately fund them, do not even compensate them for the impact of this shocking 15 per cent impost upon them.
Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mitchell and the honourable member for Ballarat will cease interjecting.

—Not only does the package not fund the 15 per cent impost upon them, but as well as that the Leader of the Opposition will oppose a wage application for maintenance of wages before the AIRC. Then he has the temerity to get up and ask a question about the financial welfare of those who earn under $20,000.
—Order! The honourable member for Aston!
—You have opposed every wage increase since 1983, and you think for your paltry tax cuts—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. We are 25 minutes into Question Time. There have been only three questions asked—
—Will you get to the point of order?
—Only three questions have been asked—
—The honourable member for Hume might get to his point of order.
—Mr Speaker, I am getting to my point of order. The Prime Minister took in excess of 15 minutes to answer the last question and on this occasion he is refusing to answer the question put to him.

—The Treasurer points out to me that not only have we indexed the tax scales for inflation since 1983, but also the effect would have been that if the July 1983 rate scales had been indexed by average weekly earnings, personal taxpayers would have paid $2 billion more than they have actually paid under the 1990-91 rate scales.

PARA.TAB: The fact is we have paid more. The reason for that is we have cut the bottom rate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. When I became Treasurer, the tax-free threshold was $4,900 and the bottom rate from $4,900 on was 30 per cent. That is now $5,400 and the bottom rate is 20 per cent. But I never heard any support from the Leader of the Opposition for that. I never heard any support for the family allowance supplement; I never heard any support for the national wage cases. Now you drag out those pathetic tax cuts of yours which do not even compensate for GST and you think you can ask a question with some sort of sincerity. You have got to be joking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of recent developments in enterprise bargaining? Can the Minister advise the House whether these developments are consistent with the Government's comprehensive industrial relations strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member for Calwell, I can say that it has been a major element of the Government's industrial relations strategy in recent years to move to a system of enterprise, or workplace, bargaining as the principal means of wage determination. That has been pursued through the award restructuring approach, section 115, relating to certified agreements in the Industrial Relations Act and, more recently, the enterprise bargaining principle and the national wage principles which require any wage increase to be based on actual implementation of efficiency measures designed to effect real gains in productivity. So we now have in the system a principle which is driving enterprise bargains based on increased productivity.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to advise the House that this strategy is now bearing fruit. Although it is relatively early days since the implementation of that principle, there are over 40 enterprise agreements which have been ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission to this date. There are also a substantial number of agreements which have not come to the Commission—and they are probably not likely to—which will remain as over award agreements.

Quite clearly, the move to enterprise bargaining is on and it is likely to become very widespread in the next year or so. All of these agreements are designed to increase productivity and improve competitiveness. Perhaps none bears that out more so than the Toyota agreement, which covers 6,000 employees. Its objectives are linked to obtaining international best practice manufacturing standards, including things such as: achieving international quality levels; realising cost structures similar to those of other sister plants overseas; supplying product to the marketplace on a timely and cost-effective basis; and providing a rate of return on investment comparable to other Toyota operations.

I am sure that everyone in the House would agree that those are worthwhile objectives. There is an array of productivity improvements to achieve that. We have all of this happening under the umbrella of the accord, with agreement about the overall wage outcome and with agreement that the inflation rate coming from all of this should be such as to keep us at a rate comparable to that of our major trading partners. As we have announced in One Nation, it is our intention to move shortly to amend the Industrial Relations Act to further facilitate the making of enterprise agreements.

In contrast to all of that—which clearly shows that there is an effective strategy in place to develop enterprise bargaining—we have from the Opposition a demand that there be a major industrial relations reform to bring on enterprise bargaining, as though nothing was happening; whereas in fact, as I have already shown, there is a major move in that direction and a very effective implementation of enterprise bargaining.

What we have from the Opposition in this area is a policy which is ill-defined, confused, confrontationist, inflationary and exploitative. The Leader of the Opposition said in Fightback that this was the most important part of the Fightback package. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The centrepiece of Fightback is industrial relations reform. I know the focus has been on tax. Well, there is a 20-point plan in Fightback, and the most important point is industrial relations and wage determination reform.

Yet in the whole 656 pages of Fightback, guess how many pages were devoted to this central point—two. Of those two, one was devoted to expenditure cuts dismembering the Department of Industrial Relations and most of the programs. Only three-quarters of a page related to this most important area of policy. So I do not think the Opposition can really say that it regards this as so important if it gives so little time to it.

PARA.TAB: The policy is incredibly confused and misleading. The Leader of the Opposition says that there will be three streams: a centralised stream, a certified agreement stream and a voluntary agreement stream. The Opposition spokesman says that there will be two streams: a centralised stream and a voluntary agreement stream. The Leader of the Opposition says that he will retain a centralised award system as one stream. But then he says that if he had his way there would be no wage increases ever of a centralised nature. What sort of a stream is that?

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say that

—He did say that. He said it in Perth on 23 January when he was talking to the Chamber of Commerce. He said, `If I could have my way, almost immediately there would be no more wage increases unless they were negotiated at a workplace by workplace level all around Australia'.
—Anything done by the Commission is within the centralised system.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—He said that there would be no more centralised wage determination. If you have no more centralised wage determination, what is the point of having a centralised stream? It is a stream which obviously has only a short shelf life, and it is a delusion to say it is there.

PARA.TAB: It is also the case that this policy would be massively exploitative because it would provide that in the voluntary agreement area the only protection would be a guaranteed minimum wage and occupational health and safety standards. The shadow spokesman in this area, the honourable member for Bennelong, has admitted that that guaranteed minimum wage could be less than current award rates. He said in an interview with Laurie Oakes on the Sunday program on 16 February:

ANSWER.PARA: The protection is that they will be guaranteed a minimum wage.
Mr Oakes said:
Which could be lower than award wages now, as you've said?
John Howard said:
In some cases it could be.

So there we are—less than award rates. It is also a policy which allows employers to sack their work force and then re-hire it under a so-called voluntary agreement. Some voluntariness! This was put to the shadow Minister by Mr Oakes. He said:
But let me put this to you. If I'm an employer, and I can sack the workforce and re-hire them on your minimum wage, why wouldn't I? I'd be mad.
Mr Howard said:

Obviously, Laurie, the influences of the strength of the economy and so forth are going to influence—I mean some people are going to be—according to the state of the economy the bargaining position of the employers and employees is going to fluctuate.

In other words, `You are damned right, Laurie'. This policy is massively deficient. It is also clearly inflationary, and especially in the context of the introduction of a GST. It is also very confrontationist, with talk about slashing the power of the unions, beefing up the Trade Practices Act and widening the scope for deregistration. This policy, the centrepiece of Fightback, is clearly a policy shambles. It is no wonder that the whole policy is a shambles when its centrepiece, its major point, is a complete disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again addressed to our increasingly desperate Prime Minister. I will try the last question in a slightly different form and see whether we can get an answer this time. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about political insensitivity! Mr Speaker, you have just heard an answer that went right to the heart of the wage fixing principle for the low paid, and here is Dr Hewson quoted in the Age of 25 January as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: No more national wage cases in Australia; no more wage increases which are not matched by improved performance; no more centralised wage determinations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you answer the question?

—I think I am doing pretty well, frankly. The thing which most protects those people in the work force who do not have a lot of industrial bargaining power and who rely upon national wage adjustments to maintain their living standards will be basically wiped out under a policy which says, `No more national wage cases'. The point of the question is to be concerned about their means. The point of this point is that you do not care about their means. You will basically knock them out by denying them national wage cases.

PARA.TAB: Not only that, your tax cuts are basically there simply to compensate for the GST, and the Treasury says they do not even do that. So you would actually be taking money from them under the tax system—not helping them—and knocking out their access to national wage cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Answer the question. You will hit them with more tax.
—Order! I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—The Leader of the Opposition has a front to be up asking questions about taxpayers earning less than $21,000 when the Government has reduced the bottom tax rate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent, lifted the tax-free threshold and put in the family allowance supplement. Once you program him for one question, he cannot get off it. You ought to know that.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. What the Treasury papers tabled the other day did reveal, to the acute embarrassment of the Opposition, is that the overwhelming majority of Australians do very badly indeed under the Opposition's proposals. It is fairly simple to understand why when we bear in mind that, as a result of the imposition of the new tax on food, clothing and a few other things, the revenue that is raised comes from each and every Australian—man, woman and child—to the tune, on average, of $23 a week.

PARA.TAB: This is a massive money laundering system whereby $40 billion is moved from one point to another. What members of the Opposition have been trying to tell us through all the $40 billion smokescreen is that somehow every Australian will be better off. The reason they get to that is that they are basically obsessed by models. But most Australians are not that obsessed by models.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, ha, ha. You have spent the whole week arguing about models, you poor little thing.
—You have been attempting to defend your model against the professional criticism from the Treasury, and you cannot do it. We do not rely on models—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—We are more interested in the real effects on real people. That is the point which really hurts members of the Opposition. They know that there are real Australians out there who know just how much they are going to hurt. You recall, of course, that the Minister for Finance referred on an earlier occasion to this shopping basket—the food link survey which the Leader of the Opposition has waved around as evidence of the fact that most householders will not be badly affected by the imposition of this tax.

PARA.TAB: At the very great risk of subjecting Louise Sylvan of the Australian Consumers Association to the criticism that she has joined the conspiracy which is dedicated to destroying the Liberal Party and propping up the Government, it is worth quoting what she said the other night. Louise Sylvan is someone who is obviously dedicated to representing the interests of ordinary Australians and ordinary consumers.
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, they laugh, of course. Because she had something critical to say, she is automatically to be disparaged, automatically to be denigrated and automatically to be dismissed. What did she say about the food link survey? She stated:

ANSWER.PARA: The Foodlink survey was not a good representation of the average family's fortnightly shopping. In that survey only $7 was spent on meat, for example, yet $22 was spent on cleaners, another $18 on personal hygiene products, like toothpaste and soap, about $14 on confectionary type products and another $13 on pet food.
This is the Harpic and Pal story. She continued:

This is out of a total budget of $142 for the fortnight. So this is quite an unnatural family. One would have to say, in fact, that they have a predilection for junk food and that they probably have too many pets and an absolute fetish for cleanliness.

The point is that one has to look for unnatural people and unnatural families in order to find beneficiaries under this particular proposal or else one has to find sort of jacked up models, which the Treasury, of course, has been able to systematically demolish.

PARA.TAB: In the end, there are real effects on real Australians as a result of the proposals from the Opposition. For example, fresh food products will generally go up by 9 per cent; clothing prices by 11 per cent; electricity charges by 11 per cent; and family telephone bills by 8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the things which will come down, poor little darling.
—The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

—I shall give a few more specific examples that come from an ordinary supermarket about what would be the impact on real prices faced by real Australians in real households in Australia. A container of two litres of milk goes up from $1.85 to $2.03, an increase of 18c or 9.6 per cent; a kilo of apples goes up from $1.99 to $2.19, an increase of 20c or 10.1 per cent; and 500 grams of margarine goes up from $1.84 to $2.01, an increase of 17c or 9.4 per cent. So it goes on until one comes to some preferred examples of the Leader of the Opposition. Pal goes from $1.08 to $1.10, an increase of only 2c or only 1.5 per cent; and Harpic from $2.75 to $2.77.

PARA.TAB: We could then go on to motor vehicles because we know that motor vehicles are the particular passion of the Leader of the Opposition. What do we find as a result of the imposition of the Opposition's tax on motor cars? We find that the Falcon goes up by $704, the Jaguar goes down by $7,700 and the Ferrari goes down by $15,000.
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.

—There is this notion in economics about `inferior' goods and `superior' goods. As far as the Leader of the Opposition is concerned, inferior goods are things like food and clothing, and superior goods are things like Ferraris and Jaguars. This is the kind of level playing field that the Leader of the Opposition really wants to create—the level playing field that equates jam with jewellery and blue jeans with business cars; and, of course, puts the prices of Magnas up and those of Maseratis down. These are things which Australians understand. They do not need any complicated or, might I say, shonky models from the Leader of the Opposition to understand the real effects of his proposed tax.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—What we know and what an increasing number of Australians know is that most of them—an overwhelming 70 per cent of Australian households—will be worse off. And I can tell you that over the next 12 months more and more of those 70 per cent will find out exactly why.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister and it deals with real Australians and real and actual jobs. Is he aware that the Coronation Hill project, omitted from the One Nation statement, would create 630 jobs? Is he aware that export income generated from mining the gold, platinum and palladium from Coronation Hill would generate half a billion dollars of export income, as pointed out by Senator Walsh and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie?
—What is your question?
—Order!

—Since when in a recessed economy are 630 jobs and half a billion dollars of export income a thimbleful? Why is he persisting with his illogical attitude to Coronation Hill? Finally, is he simply matching and supporting the former Prime Minister's description of Labor's three-mine uranium policy as being illogical?

—Whenever you hear a Leader of the National Party put a question about industrial policy, development policy, you really have to ask what is happening here. This is the Party that virtually destroyed Australia's manufacturing industry by killing it with tariff protection.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—You talk about the added value. Any of those numbers that you have given would pale into insignificance compared to the added value of 40 years of participation in the post-war trade in goods and services which you kept us out of.

PARA.TAB: I made the point about Coronation Hill. The Government has made a decision about this mine. It is a small deposit in the big scheme of our mineral developments; it is not large. The Government considered all the issues, including the Aboriginal heritage issues, and decided against it.

The question is put because of the message of the last two weeks—and that is that Fightback has had it. Fightback, as a political document, as a political strategy, is sinking under the waves. The fact is that the Leader of the Opposition could not defend it at the Press Club, when he had a golden national opportunity to rebut Treasury's and the Government's claims made in the House during the last two weeks.

He is now speaking of turning up the knobs. If it happens that from the reform there will be a bit more cash—or absconding with the Government's growth rates after he attacks them as being unreal and then saying he can expropriate them and then have billions to spare—then that ought to be the most ominous sound for any member of the coalition parties.

You must know by now that Fightback, as a strategy, has run its race. It served you well, it got you going, it picked you up in the polls, but you know that at its kernel it is dead. You know that the people who understand these issues know that it is dead. It will now be a case of diminishing returns for you for the balance of the time that you stay married to it. That is why more devious minds have obviously put to the Leader of the Opposition that he get off Fightback and on to another proposal—a Fightback II or anything else you want to call it.

But the fact is that the heyday, the salad days, of easy riding after the presentation of Fightback over the last couple of months during the parliamentary summer interregnum—those good days—are finished. Basically Fightback, as an economic strategy, is as dead as a doornail. You could not defend it; the Government blew it to bits; and the Treasury demolished what was left of it thereafter. Fightback is finished, and you are now asking me about Coronation Hill! Old son, you will need more—much more—than Coronation Hill to save you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Tourism. I refer him to the latest figures which indicate that 1991 was a record year for inbound tourism. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tourism industry has experienced record growth during the 1980s. In fact, the number of arrivals in 1991, at about 2.4 million, was an all-time record. It is particularly noteworthy in that the first part of the year was clearly suffering a hangover from the Gulf war period. The latter part of the year showed very considerable growth rates, in a world context where the international tourism industry was flat. If we can do this well when we have that recessed international economy, imagine what we can do with policy settings right for the course of the 1990s.

PARA.TAB: In the latter context, the One Nation statement, brought down in this chamber a couple of weeks ago, indicated a number of key areas of policy reform. There will be further dramatic reform of the aviation industry—an area that I nominated on day one of being Minister for Tourism as the most important policy jurisdiction for the tourism industry. The depreciation regime has been substantially improved and substantially extended. The amortisation rate has been increased to 4 per cent and additional funding has been provided to the ATC.

It is always worth relying on others to indicate just how well this package has been received. In that context, the response from the industry has been overwhelming. It has been particularly overwhelming when compared to—and it stands in stark contrast to—what the Opposition has proposed.

For example, the Australian Tourism Industry Association said that with this reform package `we are opening the door to a new era in tourism in Australia'. The tourism task force indicated that the Prime Minister `has delivered in a spectacular way to the industry'.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is John Brown's group.

—If those opposite want me to quote, I will go on. There are numerous examples of these. A couple of days ago the Courier-Mail in its `Tourism' section under the heading `Industry happy with its "One Nation" deal', said:

ANSWER.PARA: Winners are grinners. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —John Brown again.
—Order!
—It said:

But in terms of meeting that objective, which is what the One Nation package was in large measure about, let us compare one aspect of the Opposition's policy. Price Waterhouse, I would have thought, in these matters is something of an umpire.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on; wind it up.
—The honourable member for Mitchell will cease interjecting.
—Oh, but, Mr Speaker, he is—
—I warn the honourable member for Mitchell.
—Price Waterhouse has analysed the effect of the Opposition's policy. In what it describes as `a glaring example' of the distortionary impact of a consumption tax, it says:

ANSWER.PARA: The Coalition has specifically rejected the argument that international tourism should be zero rated.

Every chief executive officer of every tourism organisation of any significance in this country has now called upon the Opposition to review that particular policy proposal. Let me go on to quote what is the sting in the tail:
However, as building construction is exempt, tourist industry operators will be unable to obtain input credits on these supplies.

—In any event, I am winding up this answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—But let me repeat, for the edification of those fools opposite who brought up this particular package—

. . . Thus they will be subject to double taxation
Well, good on you!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Hooray!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order!
—I direct my question to the Prime Minister—
—Order! The House will come to order. Members on my right will cease interjecting.

—It touches on the matter he raised in answer to the Leader of the National Party on the question of adding value. —I am not aware of Comalco's statement. I do not doubt that the honourable member quotes it correctly, but all of these things are policy choices for companies. That means there is a dramatic acceleration in the cash flow, that is, the depreciable amounts, and therefore the cash flow of the business. Of course, with new projects or even additions to existing projects, so-called brown fields projects, the development allowance would provide a healthy new one increment to company cash flows in the event that such proposals are developed.

The Liberal Party may take a dim view of One Nation because it takes a totally different view of the world from its view.
