INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The emergence of a new underclass among Australia's youth resulting from the tragedy of youth unemployment and the government's failure to provide appropriate education and training opportunities and access to work experience.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nine years ago today this Government came to office promising jobs, jobs, jobs. It now presides over an economy in which over one million Australians cannot find the jobs that they want and in which the unemployment of young people is becoming a matter of the gravest national concern. We are witnessing the demoralisation of a generation of young people; the creation of a new under-class in this country comprising young people who neither can find work nor, under this Government, are likely to have any prospect of finding work. On the most recent figures, 34.8 per cent of the young people of this country under 19 looking for full time work are unemployed. Over 40 per cent are either unemployed or underemployed. What that means is that 320,000 young Australians cannot find the work that they want.

PARA.TAB: The worst unemployment, not surprisingly, has been in the Labor-governed states of Victoria, Tasmania and Queensland. In regions such as south-west Victoria, Mackay-Fitzroy and North Adelaide, unemployment rates amongst young people are approaching 50 per cent or more. Even these sorts of rates massively understate the real disaster which Labor has visited on Australia's young people.

During 1991 some 91,500 full time youth jobs simply disappeared. Over 80,000 young people who would have filled these jobs have disappeared completely from the unemployment rolls. Many of these have simply gone back to school, where their unemployment is hidden from public view. Many of these, unfortunately, are unwillingly in the classroom, and this affects the standard of behaviour in classrooms and makes the tasks of the already grossly overburdened teachers even more difficult.

In January this year there were 630,000 families with one or more members unemployed. Of these some 227,000 had unemployed offspring—young dependent members of the family. When family members are seeking work and cannot find it, families are placed under enormous stress. Indeed, family breakdown becomes more likely and young people are more inclined to leave home. The fruitless search for jobs eats away at the self-respect of this country's young people, and the collapse of self-respect in turn makes it increasingly difficult to take effective action. Over 90,000 young Australians under the age of 24 have been out of work for a year or more. Many have simply stopped looking.

In some cases the loss of self-respect becomes self-destructive. The rise in youth suicide is, regrettably, attributed by researchers in this area in significant part to the rise in youth unemployment, and I regret to say that the area of Australia most neglected by this Government—rural Australia—shows this problem in its starkest extent. Whereas the male suicide rate amongst young people in Sydney has remained relatively stable over the last 25 years, this rate has more than doubled in rural cities, and increased more than fivefold in rural shires and smaller towns. The rate of suicide has increased most in the past five years. Professor Brent Waters and Dr Michael Dudley of the Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Unit at Sydney's Prince of Wales Children's Hospital attribute this to a loss of identity and the economic crisis in rural Australia. They identify youth unemployment as very likely to be a major factor.

What we have emerging here are the ingredients for a permanent under-class of alienated young—Labor's truly forgotten people. A forensic psychologist, Mr Tim Watson-Munro, was reported in the Age of 15 February this year as saying that we have prime social conditions for the emergence of American-style organised gangs, with the associated violent crime, drug and alcohol abuse, depression and despair in teenagers from a range of backgrounds. Geoffrey Barker, also in the Age of 11 February, wrote of the `systematic betrayal' of young Australians and warned that this betrayal threatened to create:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a generation of alienated men and women with powerful resentments against a society that will not provide them with work or education or any short-term prospect of getting either.

In recent weeks the Government has been engaged in a cynical and callous exercise to lie about the figures for youth unemployment. We have seen the Minister's claim that the real figure for youth unemployment is 8.8 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I understood the honourable member for Goldstein to say that the Minister was engaged in a callous exercise to lie about the figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it was a callous exercise to misrepresent these figures in a quite deliberate way. This dishonest statistic used by the Government arises from the inclusion of the total youth population, including all those in full time education, to work out the unemployment rate. Of course, this is not done for any other age group and no other country works out its unemployment rate in such a way.

PARA.TAB: Mr Baldwin interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister shall have his opportunity to speak. The Minister will remain silent.

—The unemployment rate is always a proportion of those looking for work. Is the Government going to include all retired people and all those engaging in home duties in its statistics for unemployment? Of course it is not. It knows that such an exercise would be ridiculed. The fact is that the youth participation rate in the work force at 59.8 per cent is not far below the participation rate for the total population. The effort of the Government to suggest that there is some special factor that justifies a completely different method of counting youth unemployment is total nonsense.

PARA.TAB: What this unsavoury exercise in statistical manipulation reveals, however, is that this Government has given up on Australia's young people. It has run out of real policy solutions and it is now resorting to lying—Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw that; it is now resorting to misrepresenting the situation with statistics—in an effort to sweep under the carpet what has been a major policy failure for which the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), who is at the table, is responsible.

Not only is there a human tragedy involved in the inability of the Government to address this issue, but also the taxpayers of this country—this will be of interest to the Minister—have invested some $48,000 in each and every student who completes 12 years of schooling, $40,000 in each student who completes year 10, and, on average, $74,600 in a student who does three years higher education after 12 years of schooling. The total investment of the community in the education of young school leavers who are now unemployed can conservatively be estimated at over $4 billion.

That vast commitment by the community to these young people has been betrayed by the failure of this Government to ensure that international standards are promoted and achieved within the schools; that the very significant minority experiencing major problems in acquiring literacy and numeracy skills are properly identified and assisted; that there is a flexible labour market which can accommodate these students; that there is a tax system which provides business with incentives to invest and employ these young people; and, above all, that there is an education and training system that can provide these young people with the access, the skills and the knowledge that they need to obtain and hold jobs—jobs that are internationally competitive. Unless our young people have the knowledge and the skills which will enable them to hold jobs against the educated and skilled young people of other nations in the international marketplace, those jobs will not be real jobs.

The reality, unfortunately, is that over a million Australians—many of them school leavers—do not even have the basic functional skills in literacy and numeracy. They have been betrayed by a government which, throughout its entire term of office, has failed to promote the proper monitoring and testing of the key competencies which young people need to make themselves attractive to employers.

The Government has totally failed over these nine years in office to exhibit any interest in knowing the standards of skills and knowledge that our young people are acquiring. We now have over one million Australians who do not have the skills to make them employable. Why has the Government not acted? The reason for this betrayal goes to the heart of the very character of this Government. Its union mates would kick up a fuss if the Government attempted to introduce the proper monitoring of standards. They are more concerned—wrongly—about embarrassment to their members than they are with the future of Australia's young people. This is a government which has promoted mediocrity at every turn. In doing so, it has damaged most the prospects of young people from those sections of society that it falsely claims to represent.

Young Australians are making a sound judgment that better education and better training are essential if they are to increase their job prospects. That is the major reason why we have seen the massive increase in retention rates at school and the explosion in unmet demand for TAFE and university places. But when school leavers and others seek to further their education through TAFE and university courses, what do they find? As many as 150,000 of them have found the doors locked against them.

They find a TAFE system which has been neglected and ignored by a government whose attention has been absorbed by the forced restructuring of the colleges of advanced education and the universities. This restructuring in itself has become a major threat to education standards and to the future prospects of university graduates holding down internationally competitive jobs over this decade. This Government has overregulated the system. It has worked for uniformity and it has worked for mediocrity. It will not allow these institutions the freedom to create additional places for these young people.

What about TAFE? TAFE has been denigrated throughout the nine years of this Government. We now see in the One Nation statement a claim by the Government that it will spend $720m over the next three years on TAFE. That is following, in rhetoric at least, the major fully funded commitment by the coalition to increase—
Mr Baldwin interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —But is it going to be spent? Is the Government going to get the agreement of the States? We see the Minister trying to bludgeon the States and get around them with bilateral agreements. But will the States go along with him? He does not know that yet. That is still up in the air. There is no firm commitment from the States as yet. We will see what happens when that commitment is achieved.

PARA.TAB: Let me point this out: this Government in that One Nation statement, this `One Nation, One Job' statement, has no fully worked out strategy for training and higher education. There is a statement that it will create institutes of vocational training—that is, the Government will create them. But it is not going to control TAFE colleges; they will remain with the States. Where do these institutes fit in with the schools and universities?
There are no details on this in One Nation. One Nation devotes seven pages to education and training and labour market programs to help Australia's young people.

Fightback! contains a 57-page comprehensive strategy to address these problems, which will enable young people in this country to approach their education and training with the knowledge that there is a government which cares about the standard of the education that young people will be offered, a government which is going to offer opportunities and incentives to employers so that there will be jobs for these young people when they leave, and a government which has a fully thought out approach. Unless we have this approach, this forgotten generation—these betrayed young people, this growing underclass in this country—will become a worse national problem. It will not be addressed by the shallow sort of approach, the changing fashions and shifts of focus that we see constantly under this Government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —What absolute breathtaking hypocrisy; what absolute crocodile tears. The honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) comes in here and professes to feel concern for young unemployed people and young people who cannot get access to education and training. What is his solution?

PARA.TAB: What is he proposing in TAFE? The coalition has said in its Fightback package that it will increase TAFE spending by $75m—a one-off increase in the next calendar year. The Government already exceeded that in the former Prime Minister's statement of November last year. We have already committed an additional $100m to the TAFE system, which we have subsequently decided to build into the base for the TAFE system. We have already exceeded it.
In the mischance that the Opposition gets into office, its policy will mean that TAFE places will have to be significantly cut by some 15,000 or so based on the commitments in the Fightback package.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is totally false.

—That is not totally false. The honourable member should read his policy. His policy states that the 1991-92 Budget is the basis of his figuring. He has allowed an additional $75m for TAFE. Subsequent to the Budget, the Government increased TAFE funding by $100m annually and built that into the base.

PARA.TAB: But, of course, that is only the beginning of the Government's commitment. We have committed that the following year after that $100m there will be a further $70m, and then the year after a further $70m on top of that. Aggregated over three years, we are looking at an additional commitment of $720m into the TAFE system compared to the Opposition's measly $215m. In practical terms, that translates into a difference of 100,000 TAFE places less under those opposite as compared with what will be provided by us.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The honourable member for Goldstein.

TALK.START.PARA: —He comes in here and claims to be concerned about young people's access to education and training. He is an absolute hypocrite of the worst order.
—The Minister must withdraw.

—I withdraw. That relates only to TAFE. Let us turn to labour market programs. These are the relatively short training and work experience programs. The Government, under various decisions included in the Budget, and further enhanced in the One Nation package, will be funding some 350,000 such short term labour market and training programs for the unemployed to complement the other education and training activities.

PARA.TAB: What will the Opposition do about that? Of course, it will cut funding by $140m. These are the programs designed to ensure that people who become unemployed do not become totally disconnected from the labour market; that they maintain some contact with the world of work; that they get some work experience and some training; and that the particularly disadvantaged ones have their specific problems such as literacy and numeracy addressed in the hope—and with the intention—of going into further education and training and/or employment.

What will the Opposition do about those programs? It claims to be concerned about the unemployed. But it will cut them, whereas in the One Nation package we increase them substantially. This is the contrast right down the line. How will it assist these unemployed people? Will it abolish the CES? This is the crucial job brokerage organisation, whose role is essential if we are to identify people with particular problems, with particular disadvantages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk to youth workers.

—Yes; part of the CES network is the youth access centre network. That has been formally evaluated. Some 90 per cent of young people who have contact with the youth access centre network, which is part of the CES, express great satisfaction with the service with which they have been provided. What will the Opposition do? It will abolish it. It is right down the line.

PARA.TAB: What will the Opposition do in higher education? We have committed ourselves over the next three years to a $13 billion program to build the higher education system, to raise the funding for students and to provide an additional 35,000 places. What will those opposite do? We will raise the total real funding per full time student by some 7 per cent in real terms. Those opposite say that they will maintain the current level of funding per student; we say we will increase it by 7 per cent per student.

But worse than that, the Opposition will move away from a higher education system which, according to a paper delivered a couple of weeks ago by Dr Don Anderson of the ANU, in terms of equity of access for low to middle income earners—which those opposite claim to be concerned about—is one of the best in the world. I quote from his paper:

TALK.START.PARA: —You have never addressed the industry.
—If the honourable member for Goldstein continues to interject I will warn him.
—He states:

SPEECH.PARA: Participation in Australia compared with the other countries was more equal overall. . . The reason for there having been a relatively more equal social mix in Australia is, I believe, due to a combination of measures facilitating access which are found in few other countries.
That is the conclusion of Dr Don Anderson of the ANU. He did an international comparison of accessibility to the higher education system in a range of countries such as the United States.

PARA.TAB: What will you do with that system, acknowledged by those who formally studied it to be one of the most equitable in the world in terms of access? The system has grown enormously in the last few years by 120,000 places. There have been over half a million domestic students since 1987. In other words, we have seen growth equivalent to seven medium sized universities since 1987 alone. What are you going to do? What is he going to do? He spelt it out in clear form—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the Minister would help if he were to address his remarks through the Chair. That certainly does encourage interjections.

—What will the honourable member for Goldstein do to the higher education system? He will institute a system of fees for all students in all courses. I quote from his speech delivered a couple of weeks ago entitled `Governance and Funding of Higher Education':

PARA.TAB: It is for this reason that the Coalition has undertaken to allow universities to determine fees for all courses—

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat: all courses—
and all students.
That is what he has in mind. He seriously put forward on a Lateline interview last week—

TALK.START.PARA: —He cleaned you up.

—Oh, rubbish, come off it; he did not. He put forward up-front fees as a solution for access to low to middle income students. What order of magnitude are we talking about? It might assist the honourable member were he to actually read the Industry Commission report, which he never ceases to quote. If he were to read that, he would see that typically we would be looking at course fees of $12,000 per annum. For more expensive courses, such as medicine and veterinary science, we would be looking at course fees of about $20,000 to $25,000 per annum. We are looking at a colossal financial impost in excess of $100,000, depending on the particular course in question. But he will put that in the way of students trying to gain access to higher eduction.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member may well solve the unmet demand problem. He will suppress demand for places from people who do not have wealthy backgrounds, who cannot afford these colossal fees. Of course, he says, `That will be all right. We will provide loans at attractive rates and that will be okay'. So they will be able to have these loans, which, in some cases, will be comparable to a home loan, compounding at a commercial rate of interest.

But the honourable member says he will provide them with an attractive rate. This is a very important point. The United States Government operates a system whereby people gain access and finance their higher education through loans. What does the United States Government do? It forks out $3.4 billion to make those loans even remotely accessible. We are looking at real interest rates—so we need to add inflation to that—of 11 per cent per annum, which is what the banks demand.

Even with those massive subsidies provided by the United States Government, for which no provision at all is made in Fightback!, we are looking at real interest rates, after people complete their degrees, of 8 per cent in the first couple of years and 10 per cent in the remaining part of their degrees.

Those opposite are looking at putting a gigantic financial barrier in the way of people trying to gain access to higher education when, according to Dr Anderson, we have one of the most equitable systems in the world.

When the honourable member for Goldstein is challenged on this, he refers to an Australian Bankers' Association survey, which he seems to think will lend some support to his position. The Australian Bankers' Association, in its submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly the private sector will require a commercial return. Government policy however may require that student borrowers have some interest rate relief. Any relief given to borrowers will necessarily have to come from government. . .
What is the financial provision for that in the Fightback package? Nil.

PARA.TAB: Occasionally, the honourable member talks about scholarships. He says that he will provide full-cost scholarships that will cover the cost for people wanting access to the $25,000 a year medical courses. He will provide a number of full-cost scholarships and will fully cover those costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a total lie.
—The honourable member for Goldstein will withdraw that.
—I withdraw.

—What financial provision do we find for that in the Fightback package? Nil. All these things will be costless. We will have a costless loans subsidy scheme and a costless scholarship scheme. The whole higher education scenario that the Opposition outlines is an absolute and total joke. It comes in here putting that forward as some sort of serious proposition.

PARA.TAB: Let us run through what those opposite are doing. They are going to cut funding for TAFE. They claim to adhere to the Finn targets for participation in post-compulsory education and training, but they are going to provide something like one-eighth of the funds that are necessary to meet the Finn targets to the year 2000. Even in the next three years those opposite will provide no more than one-third in real terms of what the Government will provide for TAFE.

They are going to slash training and work experience programs for the unemployed; they are going to dismantle the CES, including the demonstrably highly effective units in the youth access centres designed to assist young people in particular; and they are going to reinstitute an elitist and inaccessible higher education system where people will gain access increasingly by virtue of their own or their parents' financial means rather than their ability. So it is a simultaneous attack on both equity and excellence in the system.

Even the commitments that are made by the Opposition cannot be taken seriously because a $4 billion hole in the figuring of the Fightback package has been clearly identified by the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance, which the Opposition has never been able to answer successfully. That is the Opposition's scenario, and I put it to the House that it would be an absolute disaster.

I make a couple of comments on the unemployment statistics because they are important. A huge amount of distortion goes on here. We see Opposition spokespersons putting out statements saying that one in three young people are unemployed. Senator Baume, in particular, likes to do this. The reality is that, due to a revolution in participation in education and training over the last 10 years which has been absolutely profound, we have seen a doubling of school retention rates and a huge growth in higher education. There has been insufficient growth in the TAFE sector, admittedly, but that has been a State responsibility up to now. We are now trying to negotiate with the States to massively build that sector. But there has been a participation revolution so that now 66 per cent of young people in the 15 and 19 years age group are in some form of education or training.

Consequently, in terms of unemployment, the 30 per cent which is quoted is the number of young people unemployed as a percentage of those actually in the labour force, but the majority of them are not in the labour force. Looking at the population group in seasonally adjusted terms, according to the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures 8.8 per cent of people in the 15 to 19 years age group are unemployed and seeking full time work. That compares with a figure of 12.4 per cent when those opposite were in government. There are now 40,000 fewer young people unemployed and seeking full time work than was the case when the lot opposite were in power. That puts that figure into perspective.

We do not say for a minute that the current youth unemployment situation is acceptable; nobody has suggested that. Urgent measures have to be taken to address that problem. As a Government, we are taking a comprehensive array of measures to address it. We are looking at introducing a whole new system of entry level training which will greatly broaden access to training. We are underpinning and supporting that with a huge injection of new funds for the TAFE system over the next three years. We will continue to build the higher education system with further growth, with an emphasis on getting the funding rate per student up and having a proper quality assurance structure.

We are going to improve the mobility between the various sectors by encouraging institutions and TAFE systems to develop improved articulation and credit transfer arrangements between higher education and TAFE. We are looking at the labour market programs to try to ensure as far as possible that not only young people but people generally who participate in these short training programs, called labour market programs, for the unemployed get some recognised qualification. Such competency based training will be the first step into a longer period of education and training. So we have a comprehensive approach to the balanced development and expansion of the post-school education and training system—something which is totally lacking from the Opposition.

The Opposition spokesperson has come in here with a set of commitments in Fightback which involve cutting all down the line, cutting opportunities comprehensively, and those opposite cannot deny that. They accuse us of not getting it right, but when I say cutting, I am basing that on the Fightback! document itself, which at page 321 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The expenditure cutting program has been calculated initially against 1991/92 data, as shown in the budget papers, to take account of decisions made in the 1991/92 budget.
Subsequent to the Budget we committed an additional $100m to TAFE; therefore, the proposal of those opposite involves a cut of $25m in TAFE. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —To accept the contribution of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) to this matter of public importance is to believe that there is no crisis in higher education and that there is no problem with youth unemployment. I do not believe—leaving politics aside—that there is a single member of this Parliament, apart from the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and probably some of the closeted senior Ministers, who believes that. Honourable members could not regularly visit their electorate offices and meet with the people of their constituencies and believe the nonsense that has been served up to us by the Minister.

PARA.TAB: There are 50,000 qualified students unable to obtain places in tertiary institutions. They are beating a path to our doors. Yet the Minister has weaved this constellation of mythical programs and assistance that will cure the aspirations of those 50,000 young students. It is an utter nonsense. It is a matter of despair for me and the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) and all of us on this side that this Minister is so out of touch. Do not angry parents or disillusioned, embittered young people visit him? Is he not getting some feedback from the tertiary institutions themselves that Labor's centralised, outdated way of controlling the universities through a massive bureaucracy has failed?

One of the big lies of all time is where the Minister would have us believe that there is not a problem with youth unemployment. He tries to tell us—and we have heard it again today in the tradition that if one tells a lie often enough it becomes accepted as the truth—that youth unemployment is 8.8 per cent and not the 34 per cent or the seasonally adjusted 30 per cent which the Australian Bureau of Statistics tells us it is. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has used the same calculation to reach the conclusion that 30 per cent of young people between the ages of 15 and 19 years are out of work as it has to determine the national level of overall adult unemployment of 10.75 per cent.

The Minister has taken all the young people between 15 and 19 years of age who are seeking work and lumped them with all those other young people who are in some training or in post-secondary education and are not seeking work.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has fiddled the books.

—He has fiddled the books amazingly. The Bureau of Statistics has shown that one out of three young people seeking work—not one out of three young people who exist—is unemployed. The figures are quantified for us. There are 154,800 young unemployed people seeking full time work.
—Where is your source for that?
—The Australian Bureau of Statistics is the source for these figures.
—When?

—The January figures for unemployment. The honourable member is unaware that 154,800 young people in January were seeking full time work, and the Minister is unaware of it too. It means that one-third of young people are seeking work. So the Minister has wrongly and grossly misrepresented the tragedy of youth unemployment by trying to pretend that it is an unworrying, easily acceptable figure of 8.8 per cent. Nobody believes that, and if the Minister continues with that gross misrepresentation—to put it as politely as the Standing Orders will allow me—he will be ridiculed from one end of this country to the other.

PARA.TAB: The tailor-made recession of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has broken the back of Australia's youth. Their first experience with adulthood and citizenship will be the CES office. There is no doubt at all that this recession has broken their belief in their capacity to contribute to the national well-being and prosperity. It has broken their belief that their skill and knowledge will be rewarded with a job and recognition, and it has robbed the nation of the reservoir of ability and enthusiasm upon which our recovery depends.

The consequences of this are felt no more deeply than within my own portfolio responsibilities of science and technology. The impact on science graduates has been startling. We can determine this with accuracy by looking at the latest Graduate Careers Council of Australia annual survey of graduate career destinations. The Careers Council survey studies career movements of those graduates who finished their courses in 1989 and 1990 and came on the market in 1990 and 1991. The survey confirms that the recession is not just biting the unskilled and so forth; it is eating into the stock of young graduates emerging as the new core of the labour force who have not previously been employed.

There are two factors at work: the impact of the recession as such; made worse by the expanding pool of students, but without an expanding job market to absorb them. On the one hand, we are pushing students into the system, but on the other hand we are denying them jobs. The big problem is the disillusionment and the deep disaffection this will generate. They will not forgive Labor, and they should not. The rest of the community will not forgive Labor, either, for turfing one-third of young people between the ages of 15 and 19—I stress—onto the unemployment heap. This is at a time when we need the best young and enthusiastic minds to lead industry change and to build up the knowledge intensity for the manufacturing sector, as well as the service sectors and the primary industries. We are sending them all the wrong signals.

During the decade we have been battling the decline in talented graduates entering the sciences. Now the recession will send another message to school leavers, that is, that the sciences are vulnerable occupations. Graduates from core scientific and technological disciplines have borne the brunt of the unemployment slump and the Graduate Careers Council survey demonstrates this.

Compared with last year, full time employment amongst engineering graduates has collapsed by more than 40 per cent for aeronautical engineering. There are between 15 and 20 per cent fewer job opportunities for other subdisciplines, such as civil and mechanical engineering.

Does the Government know that the Australian Institute of Engineers has created its own unemployment and counselling office? If there is not a problem, why does the Institute of Engineers have to take such drastic measures?

The picture is grim. It is just as bleak for scientific graduates. The number of computer science graduates working full time has fallen from around 92 per cent in 1990 to 75 per cent this year. It is expected to fall dramatically in the years to come. Even in the crucial science disciplines, like mathematics and chemistry, employment rates have fallen off by more than 14 per cent in the last year. Other graduates from physical and applied science courses are facing even greater employment pressures. The figures mask even greater difficulties facing the graduate market. The surge in the number of students staying on to complete further studies conceals the employment pressures for Australia's latest crop of science graduates. The skills base upon which industrial competitiveness depends has been rocked.

I made some of this statistical information known three or four weeks ago by way of a public press statement. The journalist, naturally, rang the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) to get a response. What was the Minister's reply, in effect? It was, `Oh, this is just to do with economic cycles; don't worry about it'. I was incredulous when a journalist from one of the national newspapers told me that that was the Minister's response—`Don't worry about it'. There has been no considered comment or analysis of the problems with science and engineering graduates' employment prospects.

The lightweight from the New South Wales right wing has been too busy spending time providing support for the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) in his push for the prime ministership to worry about his own responsibilities. He does not want to get caught up in issues like youth unemployment; he has other numbers to count—for his mates from the New South Wales Right. He may be a lightweight within that faction, but he has soaked up its social conscience all right, which is to abandon anything that will not push one into power.

The private interests of the individual Ministers in this Government far outweigh the public interest. We have seen a classic demonstration of that from the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, who sought to deny repeatedly that there were problems in either youth unemployment or access to tertiary education.

This callous disregard for the future prospects of young people will condemn this Government to opposition at the first available opportunity. So we want an election, as the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) called for during Question Time, at the same time as we have the by-election in Wills. Bring on the election to give young people some hope for the future. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Goodness, there are two great lies in the world: the cheque is in the mail, and the coalition parties care and bleed for Australian youth. Let us start with the suggestion that the Opposition parties are bleeding for youth employment—that is a bit of a whopper! Instead of a comprehensive safety net of labour market programs, those opposite should have a look at their own Fightback program. What are they going to do? They are going to slash spending by $140m, they are going to cut Jobstart wage subsidies by $62m and they are going to abolish the self-employment assistance program.

PARA.TAB: Instead of supporting Australian youth who are unemployed by maintaining essential advisory and support structures, those opposite are going to amalgamate the CES and the DSS and contract the job placement services out at commercial rates. Then the ultimate betrayal: they are going to charge 15 per cent GST on top of that. What about the other big whopper we heard during the week on the Four Corners program by the shadow Treasurer, who told the Australian people—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the youth unemployment rate?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland has spoken in the debate!

TALK.START.PARA: —He said, like the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), that a third of our young people are unemployed. They know the figure is less than 9 per cent. I will spell it out for them. From April 1983 to January 1992, the number of 15- to 19-year-olds who were unemployed and looking for work fell by 40,600, as spelt out by the Minister. Is that too complicated for those opposite?

—Okay, I will supply some other figures. When the coalition lost office—do those opposite remember that?—there were 157,600 unemployed teenagers. In January of this year, unlike the figures the honourable member has, there were 117,000, a reduction of almost 26 per cent. No-one is suggesting—and the Minister did not suggest—that those figures are acceptable.

PARA.TAB: What about the blatant betrayal of that present group of youth unemployed? Those opposite have a voucher policy. They are going to keep those unemployed out of higher education. What about their policies in terms of vocational training? They are going to keep them out of vocational training. Then there is the Opposition trifecta: the doom—they are going to slash the job market programs and the advisory and maintenance support. Really, Mr Deputy Speaker, the comments made this afternoon by the honourable member for Goldstein and the honourable member for Gippsland are just unbelievable. Following the release of the economic statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), it is patently clear that it is still this Government that leads the debate on all the pertinent issues affecting education, employment and training of young Australians. As certain as night follows day, no thinking person in this nation could think otherwise.

The contributions this afternoon by the honourable member for Goldstein and the honourable member for Gippsland have been nothing short of contemptible. When issues affecting this nation's youth are debated in this House, more often than not what we get from the front bench is nothing but derision and contempt, and the backbenchers over there know that is true. The body language from the Opposition front bench, particularly during the last two weeks, has suddenly taken a decided turn for the worst. We can actually see it over there: the come-hither look, the glad eye, the smirk that they have had for the last two months has disappeared. It has done a disappearing trick; it has gone.

Those opposite did not like the One Nation package. They do not want to believe it. They are in trouble. They are in trouble again; and they all know it. The reasons are quite simple. The coalition espouses, as it has in this debate, nothing but contemptible propaganda. Like all propaganda, the Opposition espouses nothing more than a monologue. It does not want informed debate; it does not want a considered response from the Australian people; it simply wants an echo. Well, I think the Opposition is in for a shock. The majority of the Australian people not only will fail to respond to the coalition package at the next election—they will silence the echo.

George Bernard Shaw once said that we are made wise not by the recollections of the past, but by responsibilities for the future. With that quote in mind it is well worth an examination of the Opposition's track record of the past and its ability to take responsibility for the future. The Opposition must think everyone in this nation suffers from acute memory loss. This Opposition is so skilled and so expert at circumvention and pious fraud; this Opposition is so famous for chicanery and pettifoggery; this Opposition has no shame: it is expert at contrivance, gimmickry, diversions, red herrings and sophistry.

This Opposition confirms yet again in this matter of public importance that those propositions are correct. So the Opposition bleeds for the present generation of unemployed youth! I think not; I think not. The present generation of unemployed youth did not just arrive at 15 years of age; they arrived at some time post-1968; an informative year 1968, a very informative year. That was the year the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development recommended to the government of the day some pretty simple straightforward recommendations. What were they? I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) knows what they were. They were simple; they were straightforward; and, as far as employment, education and training were basically concerned, they numbered but one, two, three. One did not need a calculator; there were only three of them: lift retention rates, expand university places and expand vocational training. How in a period of 15 years did the coalition take responsibility for the future of our youth? The coalition ignored the advice—
Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo knows it. The coalition continued with a resource policy based on agriculture and mining, with no value adding and no concentration on the resources between the ears. Not only did the coalition betray Australian youth, it betrayed this nation. In 15 years it increased retention rates from a miserly 25 per cent to 36 per cent. In 15 years it ignored vocational training and the disadvantaged of this country in terms of offering them places in higher education. The coalition operated on non-policies; it applied its energies to neglect and indolence, and its all-consuming passion for maintaining the status quo. I kid you not, Mr Deputy Speaker, the coalition could stand still in a cyclone.

PARA.TAB: Now the coalition wants to go back with the Fightback package to the Australian people and say, `Trust us, nudge, nudge, wink, wink. Give us another go'. However, the coalition has contemptuously forgotten the past and refuses to acknowledge the present, and it has no idea of what the future is. This is 1992, not 1968. When members opposite go back to their offices and look at their little calendar dates, they read 1968. The coalition is 25 years too late with this debate; it is in a time tunnel of the past.
Compare what this Government has done for higher education to what was done in the past. Could any coalition government in the past think of an increase of 120,000 students

SPEECH.PARA: over five years—the equivalent of 12 new universities? What has been the coalition's record in the past on vocational training, the Cinderella sector of education? What has it been with primary and junior primary schools? It has largely been by State responsibilities. Who has led the debate on those issues in this Parliament? Not only has this Government not betrayed the past or present generations, it will not betray future generations.

PARA.TAB: It is a salutary experience to contrast the Government's achievements in higher education with what the Opposition proposes. Commonwealth funding through Department of Employment, Education and Training has increased by $1.2 billion, or 41 per cent in real terms. A further $300m or 7.2 per cent in real terms is planned over the next two years. Capital funding is up by the massive amount of 444 per cent and research funding is up by 260 per cent.

I appreciate that the Opposition promises some ups too—inflation up, interest rates up and unemployment up, but not much from the neck up. With the Opposition voucher systems, equity of access for our youth would go out the window. Few students, as the Minister has pointed out, could afford fees which would average $12,000 a year. The Opposition would ration the current rate of access according to ability to pay. In reality that would be in important but relatively expensive areas such as engineering, science and agriculture, some of the areas the honourable member for Gippsland was so concerned about. This Government will create a new high status, better resourced vocational training sector. Instead of an extra $720m in vocational training in three years, Fightback offers a one-off increase of $75m—a blank cheque for the rest. When it comes to vocational training, Fightback actually implies a reduction of numbers in the level of opportunities for Australian youth.

When it comes to the betrayal of Australian youth, I will defer to the Opposition; I will always defer to the Opposition. It is the past master and it freely admits to being the future perpetrators. It is all there for the Australian electorate to see and in 12 months time, it will certainly see it. (Time expired)

—On behalf of the Committee of Members' Interests, I present the report on the operations of the Committee for 1991.

—I present the fifteenth report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the following Finance Minutes on reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts: first, the supplementary Finance Minute on report 305, Review of Finance Minute on Report 270—`The Implementation of the Offsets Program' and, secondly the Finance Minute on report 310, the business migration program. I seek leave to make a statement on the papers.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Finance Minute on report 310, the business migration program, provides coordinated departmental responses to a number of recommendations made by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its report on the business migration program. These responses, being from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Taxation Office, are separate to those responses to policy recommendations that have already been made by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand).

PARA.TAB: The Committee report 310 on the business migration program recommended that the accredited agents scheme be abolished, that the business migration program be replaced with a new category of entry targeted towards migrants with business and entrepreneurial skills, based on a points system with concessions for age and English language skills. The Government accepted all these recommendations from the Committee.

It is gratifying to note the alacrity with which the Minister has moved to implement the major recommendations of the Committee, although this no doubt says something about the nature of the problems identified by the Public Accounts Committee. The Minister announced the winding up of the business migration program by accepting the key recommendations of the Committee on 25 July 1991, only five weeks after the report was tabled on 21 June 1991.

This action was followed by an announcement from the Minister of the acceptance of the recommendations concerning the replacement category of entry for migrants with business skills on 17 December last. This new category of entry will, as recommended by the Committee, be based on a points system and recognise the business and entrepreneurial skills and background of the migrant. It will also seek to ensure that these skills are maximised for the benefit of Australia by establishing baseline criteria for all applicants, which include: an overall successful business career; a genuine and realistic commitment to engaging in business in Australia; registration with a business advisory agency in the State or Territory of intended residence; and signing a declaration acknowledging the Australian Government's requirements in relation to his or her entry into this country as a business migrant.

The Minister has also taken measures, in line with the Committee's recommendations, to toughen the standards for business migrants. These include the provision of ministerial discretion, via legislative amendment to the Migration Act, to cancel the status of business skills migrants if they have not made a genuine effort to meet the objectives of the category within the first three years of their arrival. At the same time, the Minister has initiated a mandatory comprehensive monitoring system for business migrants, with financial penalties for those who default. The business skills category of migration has been in operation since February this year, which means that the Minister has taken only seven months to implement the recommendations of the Committee from the time the report was tabled.

The sorry tale of the administration identified in the Committee's report of the business migration program is one that signals to the Parliament the importance of the scrutiny work undertaken by a great many of the committees of both Houses. We believe that in conducting this inquiry the Public Accounts Committee has proven again that its effectiveness as a watchdog on behalf the Parliament and the taxpayers of Australia in identifying, investigating and rectifying instances of maladministration in government departments remains paramount.

The other document that I have just tabled is a supplementary Finance Minute on the Committee's report 305, which was titled Review of Finance Minute on Report 270—`The Implementation of the Offsets Program'. The operation of Australia's offsets program has been a matter of concern to the Committee since 1987—quite some time before I became the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee—and it continues to present problems to the Committee. For the moment I only wish to say that it will be the subject of further discussion by the Public Accounts Committee. I commend both of these finance minutes to the House.

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I take great pleasure in introducing the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991. The purpose of the Bill is to allow the Commonwealth to approve the shareholders' agreement relating to the establishment of the National Rail Corporation. The Bill represents another major step in the implementation of the Government's micro-economic reform program which is directed at creating a more productive, efficient and flexible economy.

PARA.TAB: The Bill involves significant restructuring: in this case, of rail institutions, technology, management and work practices. Without such initiatives we will be unable to meet the community's current needs, let alone our future needs. It is an important transport reform. Transport affects almost every area of Australian economic and social activity. As a significant intermediate cost, efficient transport is vital to the competitiveness of the Australian economy. Even small improvements in the efficiency of our transport system offer potentially large economic and social gains. This is highlighted by a number of major studies in recent years, which have exposed the deficiencies in our transport system and the potential gains from reform.

In 1989-90, the Industry Commission estimated that a more efficient land transport system, including a more efficient rail system, alone could realise an additional $6 billion in gross domestic product every year. Of this, $4.4 billion was attributable to rail. More recently, in its October 1991 report on rail transport, the Industry Commission confirmed the importance of reforming the rail industry. Australia cannot afford to ignore such gains, particularly given their potential for contributing to economic growth and our standard of living.
One of the major problems in the rail industry is the inability of the existing systems to obtain their proper share of interstate freight, particularly on the eastern seaboard.

SPEECH.PARA: This is due in the main to the quality of the service that rail delivers. Terminals are inadequate, work and management practices need improvement, and reliability needs to be greatly improved. It is widely acknowledged that much of the problem lies in the fragmented management of rail. That said, the position is not irredeemable. Industry has said that it would make greater use of rail if a reliable, quality service were provided. Indeed, rail can confidently be said to have a bright future, provided it can be operated efficiently.

PARA.TAB: There are some types of traffic where rail beats the competition hands down. The most obvious example of this is the carriage of freight over medium to long distances. If rail undertakes the tasks to which it is best suited, and is efficient, it can carry goods at a lower cost to the community than road transport. And there will be savings in terms of accidents, air and noise pollution and energy costs.

Accordingly, the Federal Government has positively promoted the revitalisation of the interstate rail freight system. This is part of a broader set of transport industry initiatives and objectives within which each of the transport modes can undertake the tasks to which it is best suited. It is not a matter of favouring one mode over another. What the Government is striving for is an integrated transport system that will provide the community with an efficient and competitive land transport system.

That rail can be a success in Australia has been clearly demonstrated by the Commonwealth's own railway, the Australian National Railways Commission. AN has long practised the commercial approach that will be taken by the National Rail Corporation, and its success is clear for all to see. The Industry Commission acknowledged this achievement in its recent rail report. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate AN, its employees and management for the effort they have put in since its creation in 1978. I expect that the skills and expertise built up by AN will prove to be a valuable asset for the National Rail Corporation.

Recognising the need for change, the Commonwealth and all the mainland States except South Australia signed an agreement establishing the NRC at the Special Premiers Conference in July 1991. For the first time, all interstate rail freight operations will be brought under one management structure.

The NRC has been incorporated under the Companies Code as a strictly commercial corporation at arm's length from government. The directors of the company have to comply with all relevant provisions of the company law, including the obligation to act in the interests of all shareholders. The company has been established for the purpose of conducting interstate rail freight operations on a commercial basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The company will:
.operate on a strictly commercial basis, with a financially viable corporate plan, and be subject to the Trade Practices Act 1974;
.have access, by ownership or other appropriate arrangements, to the assets, including track infrastructure, necessary to achieve commercial viability;

.operate under labour arrangements incorporated in an enterprise award, which reflects best practice in productivity standards through efficient work and manning practices, determined by the technical capacity of its equipment and commercial considerations;
.have the capacity to contract out activities where that is the most efficient approach;
.provide access on a commercial basis to the NRC network and to terminal facilities for private and public sector operators;
.have the capacity to provide services to governments, with the charging for such services being on a strictly commercial basis;
.not be responsible, financially or in any other way, for redundancies that may arise in rail authorities resulting from its formation and transfer of functions and assets to it;
.be subject to all rates, taxes and charges;
.not have the shield of the Crown; and
.be treated as an ordinary incorporated company.
Any new rail projects undertaken by the NRC will be subject to the normal State and Federal environmental legislation.

PARA.TAB: It is expected that the cash equity injections of $415m provided for by the agreement, together with commercial borrowings by the NRC, will lead to the speedy elimination of interstate rail deficits. The NRC is expected to break even within three years and become totally self-supporting after five. The meeting of this target will, in itself, be a major achievement. Interstate rail freight deficits are currently around $375m a year.

The NRC was incorporated in September 1991 and directors were appointed to the board. The board is recruiting a management team who will negotiate an enterprise award with the unions and develop a corporate plan, including an investment strategy. These must be completed prior to the injection of capital funds by the shareholders.

The enterprise award to be negotiated by the NRC with rail unions will reflect the most efficient work and staffing practices, determined by the technical capacity of its equipment and commercial considerations. It is proposed that the NRC employ only those people that it needs for its operations: other employees will remain with the existing rail systems.

The NRC is scheduled to commence actual rail operations in the next few months, beginning with marketing and terminal operations. Customers will then no longer have to deal with up to five separate rail authorities to transport freight across the country.

The establishment of the NRC heralds an historic development in the revitalisation of Australia's rail industry. The Corporation will provide a strong impetus to overall reform in the rail industry and the land transport sector in general. For the first time in the history of this country, the NRC will ensure that rail investment decisions are based on commercial considerations with the needs of a national network being paramount. Problems of the past, which led to three different track gauges, different signalling technologies and varying work practices, will not be permitted to continue.

The Prime Minister announced on 26 February funding of $454m over the next two financial years for the establishment of a national rail highway: a standard gauge network linking all mainline State capitals.
This program will complement the NRC's own investment program. It includes:

SPEECH.PARA: .a substantial upgrading of the Melbourne-Sydney rail link, including a separate freight line from Campbelltown to Enfield, which will reduce transit times from 13.5 to 12 hours by 1994, allowing rail to provide a reliable, quality service and compete for a greater share of this market;
.similar improvements between Sydney and Brisbane to improve rail's reliability and reduce transit times from 18 to 16 hours;
.conversion of the Melbourne-Adelaide line to standard gauge; and
.improved intermodal connections to be provided to the ports of Brisbane, Melbourne, Adelaide and Fremantle.

PARA.TAB: The conversion of the Melbourne to Adelaide line to a standard gauge with complete the standardisation of the intercapital rail links around Australia and, for the first time ever, this nation will achieve a national integration of that standard rail network. The Government will be seeking to reflect this funding in the Commonwealth's equity in the NRC.

I now turn to the provisions of the Bill. The Bill provides for the Commonwealth to approve the shareholders' agreement relating to the establishment of the NRC. A copy of the agreement is provided in a schedule to the Bill.

The Bill also provides that the company does not have the protection of the Crown. That is, it is simply a company incorporated under the Companies Code, subject to all Commonwealth, State and local government legislation. The Bill provides for the legislative transfer of assets and contracts, and for any third parties to be compensated if they suffer any damages as a result of such a transfer. The Bill also provides that the Governor-General may make regulations consistent with the Act.

I draw attention to two amendments made to the Bill in the Senate. One of these clauses, 13, provides for the appointment of the Commonwealth Auditor-General as the company's auditor. The other clause, 16, provides for the tabling of the company's official reports before each House of Parliament.

The Bill provides that the Commonwealth may pay money in accordance with the shareholders' agreement, but does not of itself appropriate such moneys. These are appropriated in the Budget. The Commonwealth's cash equity contributions to be made under the NRC agreement amount to $296m over the next six years, including $40m in 1991-92.

In addition, the establishment of the NRC will have an impact on the deficits of railway systems. Total losses on interstate rail freight, including AN, were estimated to have amounted to $377m in 1989-90. The NRC is expected to break even within three years and be fully self-sufficient within five years, leading to a reduction in the call on all taxpayers, State and Federal.
It is with a great deal of pleasure that I present the explanatory memorandum for this Bill and I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hawker) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to set in place the final stage of the legislative framework to meet obligations under the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, so that Australia can proceed with ratification of the Convention.

PARA.TAB: When the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Bill was introduced in 1990 it was then said that it represented the first step in the process of Australia's ratification of the Convention. Ratification of this Convention is in accordance with the Government's ongoing commitment to the international fight against illicit drug traffic and abuse.

The Convention seeks to ensure that the international community cooperates in the adoption of a wide range of measures aimed at stemming the illicit drug trade. It was said in August 1990 that ratification of this Convention will achieve one of the aims of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, which has the support of all governments in Australia. The States and Territories have been aware of the proposed Convention and the Commonwealth's wish to become a party to it from the beginning of the drafting process in 1985, and their views were sought at each stage of the negotiation process.

Since that time the Government has continued with a process of consultation and negotiation with all of the States and Territories to identify areas of the Convention which can be given effect to by State and Territory legislation. The purpose of this consultation was to preserve the existing balance of responsibilities between the States and Commonwealth in the drugs area. The Government has been, as was said in the second reading speech in August 1990, very much aware of the importance of not encroaching on areas of State jurisdiction in this field, and fully supports the continuation of the cooperative approach to drug law enforcement with the State and Territory governments and their law enforcement agencies.

In particular, the Government has sought State and Territory cooperation in enacting legislation to meet the mandatory obligations which the Convention imposes on parties. This includes legislation relating to money laundering where the money or property has been derived from a drug trafficking offence against State or Territory law. Unfortunately, there have been delays in some of the States and Territories, and some legislation is still to be enacted.

The amendments give effect to particular obligations created by the convention. These are obligations with respect to criminalising money laundering, and confiscating the proceeds of drug offences. The legislation relies on the external affairs power and therefore follows the terminology of the Convention where appropriate.

First, the Bill provides a shorthand description of various forms of conduct which are called `dealing in drugs'. The conduct identified as `dealing in drugs' reflects the activities required to be prohibited under the convention. Most of those activities are already subject to criminal sanction under existing State and Territory laws. In this Bill the expression `dealing in drugs' does not create offences.

Secondly, the Bill defines an offence called `a State drug offence'. This is conduct which is both a drug trafficking offence in the terms of the convention and a serious offence under the law of a State or Territory punishable by at least 12 months imprisonment. Use of the phrases `dealing in drugs' and `serious State drug offences' is merely a way of simplifying the reference to these activities in the later provisions of the Bill.

Thirdly, the Bill creates the required offences of laundering money or other property that is known to have been derived from a `serious State drug offence'. These offences are described in much the same terms as those used in the Convention.

Finally, the Bill makes provision for regulations to prescribe States and Territories to which the legislation will not apply. This means that the operation of the offence provisions in the Bill will be limited to those States and Territories which have not legislated to create offences of money laundering. Once these States and Territories have enacted conforming legislation, the regulations will be amended so that the legislation does not apply to them.

It is intended that these Commonwealth offences will, in the event of a conviction, attract the confiscation provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 with respect to `tainted property'. This is intended to enable compliance with the confiscation requirements of the convention in relation to those States and Territories which do not yet have confiscation of proceeds legislation.

In applying these new Commonwealth money laundering offences, it will not matter that the conduct which is the `dealing in drugs' offence, for example manufacturing drugs, occurred in one State or Territory, and the money laundering conduct, for example the transfer of property, occurred in another State or Territory. Also, it will be possible that confiscation of proceeds action might be taken against property in a third State or Territory. Even where the State or Territory law is adequate to meet the obligations imposed by the Convention if all of the relevant conduct had occurred there, it may not cover conduct that crosses State or Territory borders.
This Bill does not affect the validity of any State or Territory legislation creating money laundering offences or any confiscation of proceeds provisions, and does not limit their operation.
I do not anticipate that the proposals put forward in this Bill will have a significant impact on government expenditure in the foreseeable future.
This Bill is the final legislative stage in the process of ratifying this Convention. I table the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will replace the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901. That Act was one of the earliest enactments of this Parliament, in fact, Act No. 11 of 1901. That shows the importance accorded to provision for interstate service and execution of process on the creation of the Commonwealth. The Bill largely implements recommendations of the Law Reform Commission in its report on service and execution of process.
The Act now provides for—
.interstate service of court and other process;
.interstate service and enforcement of subpoenas;
.bringing prisoners interstate to give evidence;
.interstate enforcement of civil judgments of courts;
.interstate arrest and return of persons to face criminal

PARA.TAB: charges; and

SPEECH.PARA: .interstate enforcement of lower court fines.

The reference to the Law Reform Commission which led to its report was given by the Hon. Neil Brown, QC, on behalf of the Attorney-General in 1982. The reference resulted both from concern that the Act was in need of reform, and from suggestions from several State Attorneys-General that the Act should be extended to the process and decisions of tribunals.
The State Attorneys were concerned that the process issued by tribunals, such as a consumer claims tribunal, effectively stopped at State borders.

PARA.TAB: In its report the Law Reform Commission found that, while the Act had remained largely unchanged, changes in Australian society since 1901 have been dramatic. Business outlook is increasingly national and, for many purposes, State and Territory boundaries have become artificial and even meaningless. Reflecting these findings, the Commission recommended a major updating of the procedures in the Act, and their extension to the process and decisions of tribunals. The Act is, of course, concerned with the effective operation of State and Territory process and so of State and Territory bodies—the courts, police and correctional authorities.

Accordingly, since the Law Reform Commission's report was tabled in December 1987, the Government has carried out an extensive and detailed program of consultation with the States and Territories about the Law Reform Commission's recommendations and about proposals to improve on those recommendations. The Government has been particularly concerned to focus on the practical application of its recommendations for State and Territory courts and agencies. We are grateful for the helpful comments and suggestions provided by State and Territory law departments, police forces, correctional authorities and tribunals.
With respect to civil proceedings in courts, the Bill greatly simplifies procedures for the interstate service of process and enforcement of judgments. In particular—

SPEECH.PARA: .The Bill sets out an exclusive method for interstate service of process. At present a plaintiff can use procedures under the Service and Execution of Process Act, or under State laws. This can cause problems especially where a plaintiff attempts to use part of the procedures under the Act and part of the State procedures in the one proceeding.

.The Bill adopts the Corporations Act 1989 rules for service on companies, and the same rules for service interstate on natural persons as apply for service intrastate of similar process on natural persons.

.Safeguards are set out relating to minimum time limits for interstate service of initiating process and subpoenas, and to the payment of expenses for interstate witnesses. Provision is made for notices to be attached to subpoenas setting out the rights and obligations of the person served.

.No endorsement will be needed on process commencing a proceeding against a person in another State. Solicitors will be able to use the one document for service anywhere in Australia, supplemented by an information notice as prescribed when service is interstate.

.Also abolished by the Bill is the need for a particular connection between the cause of action and the State in which proceedings are commenced. Instead, the Bill provides for a stay of proceedings in an inferior court where there is a more appropriate forum to determine the matters in dispute between the parties. Combined with the cross-vesting legislation which provides, amongst other things, for transfer of proceedings between supreme courts, this will enable cases to be determined in the most convenient venue.

.The Bill abolishes the requirement to obtain leave to serve a subpoena interstate. It also provides improved procedures for the making and determination of applications for relief from interstate subpoenas.

.Under the Bill judgments can be enforced interstate by a simple registration procedure in the appropriate interstate court. The judgment will be registered on lodgment of a sealed copy of the judgment, or of a fax of a sealed copy.

PARA.TAB: One area where the Bill diverges significantly from the Law Reform Commission's recommendations is the interstate service of subpoenas on persons who are under some kind of restraint which affects their ability to comply with the subpoena. Examples include persons on bail subject to reporting requirements, on parole, home detention, periodic detention or various forms of alternative sentencing options.

A person subject to a restraint which might be breached if he or she complied with an interstate subpoena will be required where State law permits, in the first instance, to apply under State law for `consent' to comply with the subpoena, for example, where a witness is on bail, by applying to a court to vary his or her bail conditions. If no `consent' is given a warrant can be issued and a magistrate will decide whether the person should go interstate on bail or in custody. The Bill also provides for interstate service and execution of process of State and Territory tribunals.

Honourable members will recall that the Law Reform Commission's recommendation for procedures to enable the interstate service of subpoenas issued by investigative tribunals was implemented last year by the Service and Execution of Process Amendment Act 1991. Under the Bill initiating process issued by a tribunal performing an adjudicative function of the kind specified in the Bill can be served interstate. This includes a tribunal performing a disciplinary function, for example, a tribunal determining whether a person is a fit and proper person to carry on a particular profession.

Judgments of tribunals performing an adjudicative function will be enforceable interstate by registration in a court in the same manner as judgments of a court. It will be possible for subpoenas issued by tribunals to be served interstate where leave is obtained from a court, judge or magistrate. Differing requirements apply about who may give leave depending upon the function being exercised by the tribunal and its jurisdiction. The Bill will streamline procedures for the return of persons interstate to give evidence or to face criminal charges.

The requirement for interstate warrants to be endorsed by a judicial officer of the State of apprehension is abolished. The Bill also enables copies of warrants, including fax copies, to be acted upon. This removes the need for the issue of a provisional warrant while the original warrant is being sent interstate. The Bill substantially reproduces Part IVA of the Act which provides for the interstate enforcement of lower court fines. Part IVA was inserted in 1963, has been subsequently amended, and was excluded from the reference to the Law Reform Commission. Minor changes have been made to ensure consistency with the rest of the Bill.

This Bill is an important law reform measure. It makes radical changes to existing procedures and moves into new areas relating to interstate process. I believe that honourable members, the States and Territories, the legal profession and other interested persons should have an adequate time to examine the Bill closely before it is debated. I would welcome any comments and suggestions on the Bill. The Bill is expected to have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I table the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Mr Rocher had moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "while not opposing the passage of the Bill, the House notes that the Bill adds a further complexity to an already complex wholesale sales tax system and calls on the Government to abolish this ramshackle system and replace it with an efficient and more equitable goods and services tax

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1992 is a measure to reduce the wholesale sales tax on passenger motor vehicles from 20 per cent to 15 per cent and is part of the package of measures the Government brought forward in its so-called `One Nation, One Job' statement, which was revealed to the Australian public last week. It is interesting that this particular issue has not generated a great deal of interest amongst speakers on the Government side of the House. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party has only had one speaker in this debate, other than the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Baldwin), who introduced the Bill, and no-one else in the Labor Party seems in the slightest interested in discussing it.
