PARA.TAB: That is because the Labor Party, since the `One Nation, One Job' package announced last Wednesday night, has actually not been interested in talking about the package at all. Indeed, in the eight days that have elapsed since the introduction of that package, I do not think more than 10 or 15 minutes of the Parliament's time has been taken up by Labor members proclaiming, as they would see it, the great merits of their package.

It is quite interesting that since the introduction of this statement, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) described as the most important economic statement made in the history of Australia, Labor members have spent practically no time talking about it, and instead have spent nearly all their time talking about the Opposition and the Opposition's policies, and producing all kinds of spurious and amazing claims about how, if the Opposition is elected to government, we will all be washed away by tidal waves and the sky will come crashing down and kill those few people who are left.

To get back to this Bill, it is, as I said, a Bill that reduces the tax on passenger motor vehicles. I notice that this has led to some comparisons between the sales tax treatment of motor vehicles under the Labor Party, compared with the tax treatment of motor vehicles under the coalition's goods and services tax proposal. One of the claims that the Labor Party members love to make is that under the coalition's goods and services tax, expensive cars such as Ferraris and Maseratis will be cheaper.

Labor members love to use Ferraris as an example, not wishing to be reminded of the current Prime Minister's E-type Jaguar that he once owned and the fact that he was an enthusiastic member of the Antique Cars Society, or something, in New South Wales some years ago; a reference in Who's Who that he has had struck from its pages in recent editions. Interesting! The serious point I am making is that they love to claim that we would reduce the price of expensive cars, and they feel that they are onto a better argument now that they have actually reduced, or are proposing to reduce, the wholesale sales tax on passenger motor vehicles.

Let me say in response to that argument that it is worth remembering that during 1991, and during the current Prime Minister's term as Treasurer, the Government reduced the luxury car tax—that is, the tax on cars which were valued above about $44,000—from 50 to 30 per cent, and in doing that, reduced the price of a new Ferrari series 348 by $30,000, which is the equivalent of average weekly earnings. It is interesting to reflect on the quality of the Government's argument that the coalition will bring down the price of Ferraris in its goods and services tax package, when it brought down the price of Ferraris last year by $30,000.

I think a slightly more mature level of debate is required from the Government, and if it wants to get into those sorts of slanging matches about those sorts of issues, I say to it, `Be careful, because there may be some quite scary skeletons sitting in your cupboard, and we are the first people, you can rest assured, to rush around and open those cupboard doors'. I have actually been doing that during the day and in the context of this Bill. As my speech progresses I shall, one by one, open a number of cupboard doors and pull out the skeletons left there by the current Prime Minister in the context of the goods and services tax.

On this Bill let me make this point: it is clearly nothing short of a political stunt. It is actually not an attempt by the Government to improve the taxation system in relation to the motor vehicle industry. If it were, first of all it would ensure that where purchases of motor vehicles were made as business inputs, the tax paid would be fully refundable, so that we would not have the effect of sales tax cascading through into prices, thereby increasing prices, not only to consumers but also of our exports.

Indeed, the sales tax on cars, in one way or another—be it a tax on cars of company sales representatives or on company cars used for other purposes—is all passed on in the form of higher prices in the goods sold by individual firms or, indeed, the services sold by those firms, and they flow through into export prices, where exports are relevant.

If the Government were serious, that is the sort of change it would have made—but it is not. The Government has not done that. If the Government were serious it would do another thing: it would not only reduce the tax on passenger motor vehicles—voters' taxes, I suppose—it would reduce the tax on commercial vehicles as well. The interesting thing about this legislation—this demonstrates the complete irrationality of the legislation—is that the sales tax remains as it was on vehicles that are used by businesses, such as utilities, vans, four-wheel drive vehicles and so on, in an endeavour to earn income. In the worst recession in 60 years the Government retains that tax, which is ultimately passed on to consumers or in higher export prices, or both. However, the Government reduced the sales tax for voters by five percentage points.

I do not think the public will fall for that. I think it is so manifestly a stunt. It is too manifestly a stunt. I am sure the advice of Government departments was to do something that was rational. We might reflect on the fact that one of the prouder boasts of the current Prime Minister when he was Treasurer was that he rationalised the wholesale sales tax system so that there were only three different rates of wholesale sales tax, or four if we count zero as a rate—10 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. This was a boast of the present Prime Minister when he was the Treasurer not long ago.

This Bill introduces a fourth rate, so that we now have 10 per cent, 15 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. It is not done in an attempt to introduce a measure which is economically rational and makes long term sense for the future of this country; it is just a bribe for voters, and I think voters are getting fairly sick of bribes.

The amendment moved by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) really brings us to a broader debate about whether a wholesale sales tax regime is an effective regime to have. Would it not be better to have a goods and services tax as do 59 countries such as Indonesia, Taiwan, Germany and Japan and many South American countries; indeed, certainly every continent, and most countries of most continents? Having gone through a cupboard in which I found some skeletons, the material I found states:

SPEECH.PARA: There are three main advantages of a (consumption) tax:
First, it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale tax, which has multiple rates—
that is a criticism of it and, by the way, it has an extra rate in this Bill—
numerous exemptions, and fails to tax the services sector.
It continues:
Second, it will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax. No other tax has the same potential for this purpose. . .
That is, if one wants to fund one's reductions in personal income tax rather than blow out one's budget by $22 billion, as the `One Nation, One Job' statement does. The statement continues:
Third, it generates tax from those who will continue to evade or avoid income tax. That provides a useful `net dividend' for distribution to the rest of the community. . .
The virtually zero exemption, single rate structure of the tax. . .
This is the fourth rate—the fifth rate if we include zero—applying to our wholesale sales tax. I repeat:
The virtually zero exemption, single rate structure of the tax—
that is, a consumption tax—
is a crucial design feature. It will assist both administration and compliance. . .

For businesses, this is a simple tax. They will also benefit from no longer carrying the cost of the wholesale sales tax which they pay and have to finance on their stocks. I am really going to rub this in. The quote continues:
At present, the tax system contains three major indirect taxes,—customs duty, the excises, and the sales tax levied on manufactured goods at the wholesale level.

They are similar to the wholesale sales tax, which is the subject of this debate. That statement is not true—there is also the fuel excise and payroll tax. They are effectively indirect taxes; they are consumption taxes of a sort. The quote continues:
This structural of indirect taxes is highly discriminatory—
that is interesting—

. . . there is no logical justification for a tax which discriminates against manufactured goods compared with services, particularly in a society which has seen services replace goods as the dominant field of economic activity.
Moreover, the existing wholesale tax is fraught with anomalies and complexities, which render administration and compliance unduly burdensome.
Among its other feature which make it an undesirable tax are—
this is the wholesale sales tax, which is the subject of this debate—
Its multiple rates and exemptions, which distort both demand and supply decisions
Valuation difficulties in determining a wholesale price in a world of widely varying distribution arrangements
The fact that the tax must be carried by retailers when goods sit in stock, with retail margins applied to the tax-inclusive wholesale price
A high proportion of the tax, about a half, is a tax on industry inputs.
For all of these reasons, we are inclined to scrap the entire sales tax.
. . . few people are aware that they are paying the tax when they buy their car, their washing machines, their bottles of lemonade or dishwashing liquid, it is politically a quite attractive tax.

That is referring to the wholesale sales tax. Mr Deputy Speaker, you and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan), who is at the table, could be excused for thinking that the demolition job on the existing wholesale sales tax was done by none other than the present Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson); the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith); or another member of the coalition. But no, all those words were the words of the present Prime Minister back in 1985 when he absolutely demolished the existing wholesale sales tax in very fluent speeches and in very fluent arguments.

PARA.TAB: Having done so, he suddenly discovered that it was politically inconvenient and, not long after, decided that the great hope for the Labor Party was to go out and campaign against the tax and pretend that if it was introduced everybody would be plunged into dire poverty—that ordinary Australians' living standards would fall way below the living standards of people in southern India, or somewhere such as that. Of course, people are not going to believe that. They will believe it even less when they are continually reminded what the honourable member for Blaxland, the Prime Minister, thought when he was the Treasurer and which, no doubt, he secretly believes to this very day.

One of the arguments we get from the Labor Party now is that the goods and services tax—I have alluded to this in the context of the Ferraris and so on—will reduce the price of luxuries. Remember this? On 9 June 1985 the present Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the things in the 30 per cent schedule are today everyday items, such as TV sets, video tape recorders, biros, these sorts of things. And there are very few which are luxuries. . . I mean, I just don't think we ought to skew the whole tax system around to worry about a couple of items like that.

He also said that people believed that if a goods and services tax were introduced and personal income taxes were reduced that would somehow be a slug on the poor. However, the honourable member for Blaxland, when he was Treasurer, not the Prime Minister as he is now—unbelievably—said:
I think the public understands that they now have to buy all these necessities —
that is, the necessities of life—
and they have to buy after they are slugged every week, and if we relieve their tax with large net tax cuts they are better off.
He went on to say this:
At the moment we all have to buy the necessities; if you're not buying them you can't live.
Brilliant! I continue:
And you buy them now out of your after-tax income, after it has suffered these very high, oppressive marginal rates.
What we are saying is you buy the same necessities, but out of your relieved tax income.

Why was that such a strong and convincing argument in 1985 but now our proposition is supposed to be the most terrible ever put forward by humanity—this cruel and wicked goods and services tax, which was such a favoured son of the current Prime Minister back in 1985?

PARA.TAB: These quotes are the most revealing quotes that I think have been read out in this chamber for some time. It is just unbelievable that people such as the Press Gallery simply do not have the capacity to rake over some of these quotes every time the Prime Minister stands up and attacks the Opposition for introducing a goods and services tax. Come on! One does not expect 17 million people in this country to be completely stupid. But the Prime Minister is trying to treat them in that way.

The arguments that the Prime Minister used to use just go on and on. The argument about how a goods and services tax would be inflationary is an argument that he passionately argued against. I do not have time now to read out the quotes, but he passionately argued against it when he was Treasurer. He utterly rejected the arguments and, no doubt, regarded people who put that proposition forward as scumbags, scum and all the sorts of things he likes to call people. Now he is arguing that the goods and services tax is somehow massively inflationary and that it is going to have a terrible effect on this country.

A recent International Monetary Fund survey of 35 countries which had introduced goods and services taxes showed that in 29 cases there was no effect on the underlying inflation rate—only a shift increase in the price level at the time of introduction. In the six countries where there was a change in the underlying rate of inflation, to quote the IMF, `this was associated in each case with expansionary wage and credit policies'. In three of those six cases, the introduction of the goods and services tax was associated with an increase in the overall tax burden. In other words, it was not offset with personal income taxes.

The Labor Party now claims—although it did not use to claim this—that a goods and services tax is somehow regressive. This is despite the fact that the Prime Minister used to argue that people buy the necessities of life out of their after-tax income and not before they have paid income tax; they are de facto taxed because they are bought out of after-tax income. In any case, the wholesale sales tax, the fuel excise and the payroll tax all impinge on the purchases of so-called necessities.

How equitable is the present tax system? The Labor Party, with its one million unemployed hanging round its neck, loves to argue that it cares about the poor and that what it does is equitable. The 1988-89 household expenditure survey showed that, in relative terms, the wholesale sales tax burden on grocery items bought by the lowest 20 per cent of income earners—the poorest one-fifth of Australians—is three times as high as for the top 20 per cent. Those low income earners pay 1.38 per cent of their income in wholesale sales tax, while the top 20 per cent of income earners pay only 0.44 per cent. What is so equitable about that? Where is the equity in the current wholesale sales tax system?
Let me conclude by opening the cupboard and pulling out one of the skeletons of the now Prime Minister for the last time. He said this on 7 June 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: We must all recognise that it would be all too easy in this debate to inflame fears and prejudice. And we should realise that some people will be trying to do just this.
Guess who is doing it now? The Prime Minister continued:
It would be all to easy to let the discussion collapse to the lowest denominator.
Ho-hum, Prime Minister!
The emotive claim of the screaming headline will always be a strong temptation.
Ho-hum! That must make the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), who is at the table, blush. The Prime Minister continued:
But the question is whether we have, as a nation, the maturity to pursue a dispassionate debate in order to achieve such overdue change.

Does that not say it all? He is right. This country does have the maturity to absorb a change which has taken place in every significant country in the world. When people are confronted with these constant quotes of the Prime Minister from 1985, the scare campaign that the Labor Party runs simply will not wash.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). This Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1992 gives effect to the Government's announcement in One Nation to reduce the rate of sales tax on a limited range of cars from 20 per cent down to 15 per cent. I take it that the Government, in selling its One Nation package, is relying almost totally on the filibuster that we have put up with and the tirade of abuse that we were subjected to during Question Time by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and one or two others.

PARA.TAB: We are debating an important proposition and I wonder why there are not more members of the Government here in the chamber or prepared to debate us on this issue. Unless I read the speakers list incorrectly, there are no Government speakers involved in this debate at this time. Yet this is an important matter. As the honourable member for Mayo has said at some length, the whole question of the wholesale sales tax—not only this particular change to the law which is being proposed by the Government, but the whole range of issues related to wholesale sales tax—is absolutely fundamental to an understanding of what the Opposition proposes in its Fightback package.

Our proposition is very simple: rather than fiddle around with wholesale sales tax, which the Government has been doing for years and attempts to do once again in this legislation, we will abolish all wholesale sales tax. That is our solution to the ramshackle range of wholesale sales taxes that we are subjected to at present. This particular legislation picks up on the proposition that the Prime Minister put to us in his One Nation statement in respect of family cars. As I think the Prime Minister pointed out, this will result in a price reduction of a little over 3 per cent, or about $800, on the average sedan. To the extent that that happens, the Opposition does not oppose this legislation.

Much has already been said about the One Nation package and I am quite sure that the debate on it will go on from now until the next election. In legislation that was debated yesterday we were talking about how the Government proposes to hand out tax cuts to rich people at the expense of the poor. When we look at this particular measure—perhaps a little critically notwithstanding our intention to support this legislation—we must also wonder about the rationale for it. The Prime Minister said in his statement:

To stimulate the demand for passenger motor vehicles (other than luxury vehicles), the rate of wholesale sales tax applying to sub-luxury passenger motor vehicles will be reduced from the present general rate of 20 per cent to a new rate of 15 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I found this statement—as did, apparently, a number of constituents who were in the process of buying cars—rather misleading. In other words, it did not at that time define what sorts of motor vehicles the Prime Minister was actually talking about.

PARA.TAB: For instance, I had one constituent who was negotiating at the time to buy a Toyota Four-Runner SR5 Limited, which is a small four-wheel drive sedan. After hearing what the Prime Minister had to say, this constituent relied on that information in his negotiations to purchase that particular vehicle. Of course, he has subsequently found out—having done the deal—that that particular vehicle is not subject to the sales tax reduction. When we did look at what the Prime Minister actually proposed, we found that the sales tax reduction from 20 per cent to 15 per cent applied only to a fairly limited range of vehicles.

In the second reading speech the Minister said that this reduction in sales tax will help stimulate the demand for those particular vehicles. We are speaking in general terms about family sedans—Commodores, Falcons and so on. I would question whether that will happen. I have talked with some of the dealers in my electorate and asked them whether there has been a rush to buy those particular cars. The answer is no. I was quite disappointed to hear that, because that is the rationale for this legislation—at a cost to revenue, I think the Prime Minister acknowledges, of approximately $40m in 1991-92 and $185m in 1992-93. That is a fair bit of revenue forgone, particularly if the idea does not work. But I suppose that if it does not work, it will not cost any money.

Theoretically, the reduction in price ought to stimulate demand, but the plan makes a couple of assumptions which I do not believe are tenable. Firstly, it assumes that people have the money now to rush out to buy a new car. We all know, of course, that there are not many people at the moment who are able to do that. People have been so badly affected by this recession that I do not think this reduction of $800 in the price of a car, assuming it is passed on—and I will come to that in a moment—will assist people to rush out to buy a new car. Secondly, the proposition assumes that people are confident enough about the future to want to buy a new car. After talking with a number of my constituents, I believe that buying a car is the furthest thing from their minds.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't get a job in the first place.

—They cannot get a job, that is so. Their concern is not whether to buy a new car; their concern is where the money is coming from for the groceries when they go to the supermarket on Thursday or Friday. On those two assumptions, I do not believe that we can expect any increase at all.

PARA.TAB: On simple economics, if one wants to talk about price elasticity—and we do not want to get too theoretical here—the reduction in price, to the extent that it occurs, will have a very limited effect on the demand for these particular cars. In that sense it merely becomes yet another cheap little electoral bribe. The whole range of issues outlined in One Nation have been illustrated by us, I believe with some effect, to be really just an attempt to buy votes. Of course, we have the prospect of the Wills by-election, the date of which was announced today. That will be the Government's first priority.

I would challenge any honourable member to refute that dealers have been just about willing to give cars away in recent times. My local dealers have been trying just about everything to sell cars. They have cut their profit margins to the bone; they have offered to give just about every conceivable extra to convince people to buy a new car. There has never been a better time to buy a new car if one is interested in doing so.

Sales of new cars have declined so markedly in recent times because of the economic downturn, as the Prime Minister acknowledges in his speech. He said that the sales of passenger motor vehicles had suffered heavily in the economic downturn. They will continue to do so, of course. People needing or wanting to buy a new car would have done so by now because they could have done a really good deal. Of course, they will not do so now. I do not believe that $800 will have a great effect at all.

We also need to question whether the $800 will be passed on to the public. The Prime Minister made the point in his speech that the Government expects this cut in tax to be passed on in full to car buyers. That is some expectation! Dealers' profit margins have been cut to the bare bone; they are hardly making any profit at all on the sale of new motor vehicles. I would not blame them for one minute if they quite reasonably took the opportunity to get a little bit of profit. As I have already pointed out, they will have difficulty selling motor vehicles in the future, just as they have had difficulty doing so in the recent past.

The Prime Minister said that he expects the reduction will be passed on. It is a bit like his statement in respect of speeding up the construction of Brisbane Airport. He said he will urge the Federal Airports Corporation to speed that up. So far his urging has fallen on fairly deaf ears, I can assure him, so I am not sure what he means by `urge' or `expects'. In any case I do not know whether he was aware when he made his statement that retail prices on these cars are set to increase in the next few weeks, so those increases will virtually absorb the impact or effect of the $800 reduction in wholesale sales tax.

The truth is that, in this economic climate that the Government has created, sales tax could be lifted completely, it could be wiped from 20 per cent to zero, and it still would hardly stimulate demand. If the Prime Minister had gone that far and said, `I am wiping sales tax on new motor vehicles', I doubt whether even that would have caused people to rush out to their Holden or Ford or Nissan dealer to buy a new car the next day. That is the economics of the matter.

Whilst we do not oppose the legislation, we point to it as yet another measure that has not been fully thought through. To me at least, the rationale for it is not entirely clear. The plain fact is that the people of Australia have completely lost confidence in this Government and in its ability to manage the economy. I can assure the Prime Minister that in these times a new car is the furthest thing from the minds of Australians. That is a fact.

Australians have been hurt by this recession, and they have been hurt badly. We have said time and time again that it is our worst recession in 60 years. We have almost one million Australians unemployed, the highest number of unemployed people in the country since the Depression. We have record levels of bankruptcies. We could go on. The Government's response has been fiscal stimulation. We have said, and we will continue to say, how risky that policy is—although, of course, the chickens will not come home to roost in respect of the outcome of that until after the next election. As it is a risky policy, we question whether it is wise.

The Prime Minister, when he was Treasurer, totally misread the signals in the economy at that time and strangled the economy. Of course, now the Government claims we have low inflation. It is a wonder we do not have deflation. Now the Prime Minister will embark on a fairly significant stimulus to the economy at a time when there are some signs of recovery on the doorstep. Of course, we run the risk of going back into another severe boom-bust cycle in 12 or 18 months time.

The other response of the Government has been through handouts, poorly targeted, with the prospect of creating 800 jobs. I can assure the Prime Minister there will be very few of those jobs in the motor vehicle industry as a result of this particular proposition. In fact, the motor vehicle industry has been scaling down employment for years. The irony is that when we look at this attempt to create jobs in the motor vehicle industry, and look at that industry alone, we find that it stands as an incredible indictment of every aspect of Labor Party policy. The motor vehicle industry, which this Bill is designed to assist, has been heavily protected for 40 years. Behind that wall of protection trade unions have introduced work practices which have led to appallingly low productivity.

The result is, interestingly—and, as I say, almost ironically when we are talking about legislation to reduce the price of cars—that cars in Australia are far too expensive. They have always been too expensive. The average motor vehicle in Australia is thousands of dollars more expensive than it ought to be. Is it not interesting that in the One Nation statement, where the Government talks about restructuring and so on, we find an attempt to bring down the price of motor vehicles? Yet we need only to look at that industry to find an indictment of Australian work practices and productivity levels.

I believe that only the Opposition will act to make Australian industry competitive. Under our goods and services tax proposal, all cars—not just a limited range—will be made more affordable. The important point that the Prime Minister does not want to talk about—and neither did the Treasurer in Question Time today—is that cars purchased for business purposes will be tax free. At the moment, even when people buy a Falcon or Commodore at the reduced rates, they pay wholesale sales tax at the rate of 15 per cent. Under the goods and services tax, the GST that applies on the purchase of a motor vehicle used for business purposes will be completely rebated. If that term is too technical, let me say that it simply means that there will be no sales tax on motor vehicles purchased for business use. I think that is a significant advantage for business.

We need to have an honest, intellectual debate in this chamber about the effect of the goods and services tax rather than, as I said earlier, the sort of tirade of abuse we cop here in Question Time from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. I wonder when I listen to them whether anyone understands them. I am glad the Treasurer was never a schoolteacher, if that is the way he learned to put his case, because I do not think anyone understands him in here, let alone in the community. If we were to have an honest debate about the effect of the GST we would see in terms of motor vehicles alone significant advantages for business in that it will not have to pay any sales tax at all. Any goods and service tax that applies to the sale of new motor vehicles will be fully rebated, effectively meaning that there will be no taxes on the sale of new motor vehicles.

The wholesale sales tax, as we understand it, is beyond fixing. We have described it as a hidden tax, which it is. People do not know how much they are paying. On motor vehicles alone, counting the zero rate that applies, people are paying some five different rates of wholesale sales tax. Different rates of sales tax apply to a whole range of goods. People do not know how much they are paying. Here again is a real benefit of the goods and services tax system. People will know what they are paying. They will know what the Government is taking from them at the time they purchase a particular item. At the moment they do not. The average person one speaks to in the street has no idea what the sales tax is on a television set or on numerous items on the supermarket shelves. In my view, all we get from the Government is what amounts to misinformation.

Honourable members opposite talk about the few products which will be subject to GST on which there is no wholesale sales tax. At least we got almost an inkling of honesty today when, for the first time in my memory, they actually acknowledged that the price of these things was not going up 15 per cent. I thought that was progress. At least they were prepared to acknowledge that the price of some of the things they talk about will go up significantly less than 15 per cent, for a number of reasons.

Even today members of the Government failed to recognise that people will simply be compensated: they will have more money to spend. The move that we propose from direct to indirect taxation, with all its inherent benefits—and the present Prime Minister is one of its greatest advocates—means that people will have more money to spend, more disposable income, and will be more than fully compensated for the effect of the goods and services tax.

The Opposition, as I say, does not oppose this legislation. We have some grave concerns about the economic impact of the One Nation statement. We wonder about the rationale of some of the proposals and, in this case, we are bemused by the Government's fooling around with the wholesale sales tax any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we come to the end of the first fortnight of sittings in the new parliamentary year, before I go on to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) I want to touch upon a letter which has just been boxed in the media area by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I think he has hit the nail on the head because Australia, with record unemployment, is an economy still sick and looking as though it will remain that way for a number of months or years. The statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has done nothing to address the problems that are confronted by all Australians or to enable businesses to create jobs. I want to comment on a couple of points the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has made in his open letter to the Prime Minister. Obviously there is a lot of nervousness on the back benches of the Government, and I think it is clearly demonstrated in the honourable member's letter. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Also, for the symbolism of One Nation, you—
the Prime Minister—
have done nothing to confront the policy of multiculturalism, surely the most immediate threat to Australia remaining One Nation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! We are talking about the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1). I fail to see what multiculturalism has to do with that. I would ask the honourable member to confine his comments to the Bill before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was certainly addressing the One Nation statement. I was referring to a letter to the Prime Minister which referred to the One Nation statement, and the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill is a result of the One Nation statement.
—We will confine our comments to the Bill before the House, which has nothing to do with multiculturalism or letters to the Prime Minister but to the sales tax laws amendment.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1992, which is before us this afternoon, makes provision for the measures announced in the Prime Minister's One Nation—albeit `Ruin Nation'—economic statement. I anticipated this type of legislation coming before the House on 12 November last year when addressing the Parliament on the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. That Bill was about removing sales tax from oil for agricultural production and from vehicles used exclusively on the production premises. As I said when I was addressing that Bill, and as we have always said from this side of the House, this is not the way to go about addressing sales tax problems. Clearly, that amendment to the sales tax laws has done nothing to help our productive sector.

PARA.TAB: It was claimed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) this afternoon that we on this side of the House have got the Fightback package wrong as far as agriculture is concerned. Let me tell the Minister that the amendment to the sales tax laws of November last has done nothing to help a farmer wanting to buy a vehicle for use in primary production. Most farmers, while they certainly want to use their vehicles on the property, also want to use them off the property, and they have been unable to make any use of that sales tax amendment of November last year.

This Bill is a further apology to the Australian people for the ill-conceived, ramshackle wholesale sales tax system operating in Australia today. It has made a half-hearted attempt to reduce the burden on a small section of the community. However, until this Government moves to abolish the wholesale sales tax system in its entirety, legislation such as this will be trotted out before this House, whilst ever this Government has the government benches, in an attempt to appease certain sections of the community.

If the people of Australia were to take literally what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) told them last Wednesday night, we could forgive them for believing they would be markedly better off than they are. In his statement the Prime Minister said:
From tomorrow the sales tax on new cars currently subject to the 20 per cent rate will be permanently lowered to 15 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: This all sounded well and good. The Prime Minister, however, neglected to advise the people of Australia of the many qualifications and exemptions from this sweeping statement. I would have liked to be able to confirm to my constituents that all new cars subject to the previous 20 per cent sales tax rate are now being sold at the rate of 15 per cent. However, I know this not to be the case. I must say that the 15 per cent sales tax rate is a very curious figure. I am wondering whether the Prime Minister plucked that figure out of the air, or whether a little bit of research was done to come up with that figure of 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or envy.

—Or envy, as my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield says. The fact is that panel vans, delivery vans, utilities, dual cabs, jeeps, lorries, motor buses and off-road four-wheel drive vehicles, such as the Nissan, Toyota, Mitsubishi, Ford and Holden varieties, are all subject to the 20 per cent sales tax rate.
—No support at all.

—None whatsoever. Families living in rural Australia who were watching the Prime Minister on television—that is, if they could get a clear picture that night—thought that they might be able to trade in their family vehicle on a brand new one and save something in the vicinity of $800, the Prime Minister's suggested figure. But no, wait for it: their family vehicle is a four-wheel drive and therefore not classified as a new family car. It is no cheaper today than it was last Thursday.

PARA.TAB: Some honourable members may suggest that it is the family's choice to purchase a four-wheel drive and that they should revise their decision and purchase a nice comfortable family sedan. Chances are they would love to, but chances are they cannot, will not and do not. Many rural families purchase four-wheel drive vehicles out of necessity owing to the appalling road conditions which are a direct legacy of this Government's neglect of the road systems in Australia. This is a reflection on the manner in which the Government has treated the motorist, as well as the fuel tax arrangements that have been used as a milch cow for propping up other parts of Australia. These families will receive no relief from the temporary Prime Minister's economic statement. The open letter from the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) to the Prime Minister confirms that he is a temporary Prime Minister.

This Government has been totally preoccupied with the golden triangle—Melbourne, Sydney and Canberra—and the better cities program, and has neglected the wealth generating rural areas of Australia. The 20 per cent sales tax rate will still apply to all motor vehicles except those specifically identified as passenger motor vehicles. Passenger motor vehicles have a very narrow definition and do not include those commercial and four-wheel drive vehicles I spoke of earlier. Clearly, we have an iniquitous regime where some vehicles have attracted the 20 per cent sales tax and will now become cheaper, while others remain the same price. In Australia, motor vehicles are now taxed at 15 per cent, 20 per cent or 30 per cent, depending on the whim of the Government, whether it is logical or not.

If a school bus is government owned, it is not subject to any sales tax. However, if it is privately owned, it is subject to a 20 per cent sales tax rate. In other words, the Government owned variety is sales tax exempt, whilst the privately owned and run school bus is burdened with a 20 per cent sales tax. These school buses are often used privately to run children to sporting activities or bring them to school, yet the proprietors have to pay a 20 per cent sales tax rate. There is no relief.

TALK.START.PARA: —No rebate.

—Absolutely no rebate, as the honourable member for Wakefield says—a situation we would rectify. Coach lines and tourist buses are two of the few exceptions where sales tax exemptions are operative. If these vehicles, whether they be coach lines or tourist buses, are operating for reward, that is, charging passengers a fare, they are considered sales tax exempt. That is where they differ from the privately owned bus. They are, therefore, not burdened with the 15 or 20 per cent rate of sales tax. That is certainly a sensible scenario. A vehicle operating in such circumstances is running as a business; the bus is in fact a business input and should not be taxed. By exempting buses from the burden of sales tax the Government has accepted the principle that business inputs should remain free of such a tax impost. Of course, that is the principle that applies consistently throughout our Fightback package in the area of sales tax.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, a plumber who buys a utility or panel van for use in his or her business receives no such sales tax exemption. What does he or she pay? It is twenty per cent sales tax on the business vehicle. A furniture removalist who buys a pantechnicon, a truck or a lorry for his or her business does not receive any sales tax exemption. What does he or she pay? It is 20 per cent, not 15 per cent—and no relief. Yet this is another business input. Heavy transport operators are massive losers. They pay thousands of dollars of sales tax on their vehicles and equipment, but they are not given any tax relief in this package. It applies to the tarpaulins of the transport operators, it applies to their stock crates or their refrigerated vans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fan belts, even.

—As the honourable member for Wakefield says, their fan belts, their tyres and it goes on. There is no relief in this package for the transport sector. It pays 20 per cent on all inputs. The list goes on and on. Time will not permit me this afternoon to go into all the areas which this package does not address and which this Government still taxes.

PARA.TAB: Small business people have not been recognised by the Prime Minister's `Ruin Nation' statement. They have been forgotten, as we have seen during the life of this Government. The Government has annihilated them, and we have seen this in the record bankruptcies in the monthly figures.

The Prime Minister's economic statement re-emphasised his Government's policy of discrimination clearly against the productive sector. This Government's mentality is to tax the productive sector until it is incapable of producing and operating. This statement should have addressed the removal of taxes from our export industries—all business inputs, not just some. We have seen in the statement that there is going to be some relief for some motor vehicle operators but not the business sector; school buses are exempt if they are government owned but if they are privately owned, they are not. The list goes on with its inconsistencies. Of course, if there is ever a time when we should be addressing the need to increase our export competitiveness and drive our export sector along, it is now. That was confirmed by yesterday's balance of payment figures where we saw another deficit, one of $861m that is owed to overseas countries. That is another $861m which will be added to the $144 billion bill that we have outstanding. Whilst we have these sales taxes on our business inputs, export industries have no hope of ever being able to compete with the rest of the world.

I want to turn my attention back to the man on the land and raise a further objection to the levelling of the 20 per cent sales tax on the humble Australian farm ute. This vehicle is made in Australia and its sale would promote Australian jobs. Sales tax exemption laws, as they apply to primary production and mining, allow for the purchase of a four-wheel-drive, one tonne, tray-top vehicle. The miner or farmer may purchase this vehicle free of sales tax if an undertaking can be given that it will be used 50 per cent of the time in the process of production. Ironically, this vehicle is not manufactured in Australia. The Australian made farm ute—the Falcon or Commodore—is, and its manufacture would create jobs; but it cannot be bought sales tax exempt.

While the farmer would be permitted any number of sales tax exempt four-wheel-drive, one tonne, tray-top vehicles, he would be denied sales tax exemption on the Australian made farm utility, unless giving an undertaking that it would be used exclusively in the process of production, that is, within or between contiguous properties but otherwise not off the farm.

As I mentioned earlier, so many of these vehicles are used on-farm and off-farm to run to town to pick up supplies. In 1991-92 alone approximately 40,000 four-wheel drive vehicles were imported into Australia. I believe this figure reflects the fact that one-tonne tray top four-wheel drive vehicles are tax exempt for farmers, but the Australian-made farm ute is not. This figure, as I said to the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) is quite alarming. If we are to get jobs, we have to consider and address the inconsistencies in this Bill.

The purchase of these vehicles could well be at the expense of the Australian-made utility. What does reducing the sales tax rate from 20 per cent to 15 per cent on a few selective cars do for Australia's employment rate? The Government has made a new family sedan $800 cheaper while vehicles such as the four-wheel drive remain at the same price. However, the one million unemployed or the four million Australians earning less than $20,700 do not have the spare $25,000 to $35,000 to purchase a new Holden Commodore or Ford Falcon, regardless of whether it is $800 cheaper or not.

The measures this Bill brings into effect will not assist Australians to become more able to buy a new car in the future. These measures do not make Australians more productive; they do not induce competition and they do not make business imports any cheaper. This Bill achieves very little other than to cause massive headaches for those answering inquires at the Australian Taxation Office; in fact, since the statement was made last week many members' offices have been inundated with calls from motor car dealers wanting to get the fine print. That has been very difficult to find; the Australian Taxation Office sales tax department was not quite sure itself—it had lists, supplementary lists and revised lists, such are the complexities of our sales tax law, to which this Bill has just added another dimension.

A coalition government would remove the inequities in the current sales tax regime so evident in this Bill. No longer would Australians have their motor vehicles taxed at 15 per cent, 20 per cent or 30 per cent; a 15 per cent GST would apply at the point of sale to all new motor vehicles without exception. Furthermore, the 15 per cent collected on all new motor vehicles under a coalition government would be completely refundable if the vehicle were bought for commercial or business purposes, no matter whether the vehicle was a tourist bus, a prime mover or the humble Australian farm ute. If the vehicle were used in the process of production, the GST would be refundable.

I think it is obvious to all of us on this side of the chamber just what a benefit that would be to the business sector and what benefits would flow through to our motor car industry in Australia. Business vehicles would be massively cheaper than they are today. Of course if there is one thing we need to do in Australia it is to ensure our motor car industry becomes more efficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of deja vu about this debate. We have heard it several times in this Parliament, usually when the conservative parties are in Opposition. However, I have to take strong exception to the remarks made by the honourable member for Mcpherson (Mr Bradford). He obviously has no knowledge whatsoever of the Australian car industry, nor the people who work in it. He has his standard line that if people work in Australia for wages, they are responsible for any problems that may exist in their particular industry. He takes no account of anything that happened during the periods when there were conservative governments in Australia.

PARA.TAB: It might interest some people in this House, particularly those on the other side, to know that in recent reports published on the motor car industry in Australia—the Industry Commission report and reports by the Motor Industry Authority—it has been made clear that productivity in the Australian motor vehicle industry is comparable with that of Europe. It is not comparable with that of Japan or Korea, and that is understandable: nor is any other part of the world comparable with those markets and it must be said that the production runs in those places are certainly hardly comparable with that of Australia.

The honourable member for McPherson said that this Government had built walls of protection around the motor car industry. Anyone who knows anything about the motor car industry knows that is a totally false statement made for political purposes, with no basis in fact. The motor car industry's protection has been reduced under this Government from 140 per cent in 1980—the last time it was adjusted by the conservative governments under the 1980 plan; they are official figures—to 25 per cent at the end of the current plan.

There is a significant difference between 140 per cent and 25 per cent, and that has occurred during the period of this Government. It is not additional protection, but less protection. I will not kid the House or say to the House that I am entirely satisfied with that arrangement. I believe the competitive problems of the industry in Australia competing with certain Asian countries on price, production or volume are extremely difficult.

I think it ought to be mentioned, seeing that the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) also made some suggestions about protection, that it was the McEwen plan that built the bad practices into the motor vehicle industry in Australia and which changed the structure of the motor car industry to a one six-cylinder sedan vehicle industry which very nearly destroyed the industry when the market moved to four-cylinder cars because it totally lacked flexibility. I do not remember Sir John McEwen ever leading the Australian Labor Party. I do not think many people in this place would now be prepared to stand up for the McEwen plan for the motor vehicle industry. The McEwen plan applied for a considerable period of time and was only replaced by the Whitlam Government, only to have protection increased and altered after the advent of the Fraser Government. So do not let us talk about who provided the protection.

It may be that bad work practices were in the industry, but one has to take into account that productivity in almost every section of the Australian community fell during all the years of the Fraser Government. It might even be interesting for some of those opposite to know that at the end of the Fraser period the government was spending a greater proportion of gross domestic product as a government than when it came to office.
The goods and services tax is going to do everything! Somewhere it has built into it the miracle of the loaves and fishes and a few other miracles; it is just going to achieve everything.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very perspicacious.

—No, because it is dishonest. The coalition will reduce the cost of some cars and increase the price of others. There is an attempt to suggest that 15 per cent wholesale is the same as 15 per cent retail; it is not. In fact 20 per cent wholesale is the equivalent of 15 per cent retail so that people who suggest there is going to be a reduction in those 20 per cent vehicles by a change to the 15 per cent wholesale tax are misleading. The tax on the two levels of vehicle, because of the different places at which they are applied, will turn out the same and there will be very little difference.

PARA.TAB: This tax reduction was brought in to try to halt a slide in an industry which is very important to my electorate. The class of vehicles is clearly set out in the Customs definitions. These definitions were not thought up a fortnight ago; they have been there for some time. If dealers do not know, it is because they did not find out—and I doubt that they do not know. This tax reduction is an attempt to encourage people to buy vehicles which are made in Australia, because all of the Australian made vehicles, with the possible exception of the two at the top of the Holden and Ford ranges, fall into the category of cars which are in the 20 per cent range.

It is true that there have been falls in employment in the car industry. It is also true that over a long period of time restructuring has been taking place in the Australian car industry. It has been modernising and becoming more competitive. By definition, that means an increase in production per person, the mechanisation of plants and that the number of employees required to operate those plants is reduced. If some of those opposite, when they were in government, had concentrated on the equipment which was being provided to Australians in some industries by their managements, and on the amount of resources which was being invested in lurks and perks, such as the free executive motor cars—which are to be brought back under the Opposition plan—there may have been some investment in plant and equipment, thus increasing the productivity in this country.

Half the effort of management in this country was directed to looking for ways to get tax free income and some form of benefit for which they did not have to do anything. What about the worker—the bloke down on the floor? If we put an old-fashioned crane on a wharf to unload a ship, it is unloaded slowly, no matter how hard the wharfies work. If we put a decent crane on a wharf to unload a ship, the productivity goes up. The Opposition, under its policies, is always looking for someone to blame other than the people who should have been carrying out those reforms and introducing that form of productivity. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) told us in Question Time about the sorts of increases in productivity that have taken place.

I also take some umbrage at the suggestion that the tax on the vehicles that ordinary people buy should be made equivalent to the tax on luxury cars—all of which, incidentally, are imported. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) said we should not talk about Ferraris because there is some unfair connection—and there probably is, but there is for most of the things said in this place.

What does the goods and services tax actually do in respect of a $250,000 motor car? It gives a $15,000 reduction in tax. The same person who buys that car is getting a 17 per cent compensation package in income tax—much more than the 6 per cent compensation given to a person on a lower income. Where does the money come from to pay for that $15,000 reduction? It is equivalent to the goods and services tax on 100,000 $1 loaves of bread. That means that 100,000 $1 loaves of bread will be 15c dearer—not to produce revenue or redistribution, but to make one $250,000 car $15,000 cheaper. That is what the Opposition calls looking after the poor. The person who buys that car will save 17 per cent on his or her income—which, to buy the car, would have to be $200,000 a year. There is another $34,000—the tax on about 40,000 loaves of bread.

A goods and services tax has only one virtue: it enables the Opposition to hide the redistribution of income to a small section of the community behind what is said to be an equitable tax. The crocodile tears which come from those opposite about people with incomes under $20,000, who have benefited from a number of changes which have been brought in by this Government, pale into insignificance when we look at how they achieve their compensation on $120 or $130 a week—they have to save about $30 a week to break even under the goods and services tax. How can they?

We hear the honourable member for Mayo citing percentages of amounts spent on sales tax. One per cent of $1 is 1 cent, one per cent of $100 is $1 and one per cent of $100,000 is $1,000. There is a difference. It is still one per cent, but the person who pays the higher percentage, according to the honourable member for Mayo, does not spend nearly as much money because he or she does not have nearly as much money.

Two honourable members opposite have already said that the goods and services tax will have no effect on the sale of cars. It may or may not have any effect. If it stops the fall in the sale of cars and, therefore, maintains employment in that industry, I will be satisfied but disappointed. But I am prepared to say to this House that there will be an increase in car sales in the areas where the sales tax reduction has taken place. As the majority of cars in that area are substantially manufactured in Australia, people in my electorate—who work for the Ford Motor Co., in that case—will gain employment. If they gain employment, or maintain employment, it is a worthwhile move. There will be no benefit for them from reducing the price of luxury vehicles, as is proposed under the GST. As I have already said, under the GST there will be a $15,000 saving—$12,000 on a Jaguar. But compared with existing arrangements, the price of a Falcon will go up $700 under the GST.

I think the honourable member for McPherson did the House a disservice when he stood up and attacked Australian workers who work in one of the most modern industries in this country, in which there is large scale investment taking place now. The Ford Motor Co. has recently invested $40m in Australia. It did not invest it because it thought its workers were not good. The company is in trouble in the United States, as I think everyone knows, but it has invested $40m in new plant and equipment and it has another investment package on the way. It has confidence in Australians to produce motor cars in a competitive form, even though it will not take as many people to do so.

Confidence exists, but we have knocking, whining, ill-informed people in this House who see their political future, not Australia's future, as paramount, who stand here and talk about who brought in the overprotection of the car industry. Do not let us have any mistake about that. The first was John McEwen and the second was Phillip Lynch. There was 140 per cent protection when we came to office—and the honourable member for McPherson stood up and said that this Government has created protection in the industry! I hope the industry can stand the reduction in protection that has taken place, because it has been massive over the last eight years. I support this Bill. I hope it achieves the purposes for which it was set out: to maintain and create jobs in the car industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate, but I should like to make a comment or two about the remarks made by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). As the member for a large rural electorate, I do not claim to have the understanding of the motor vehicle industry that he clearly displays, given the location of the electorate of Corio. I respect both his comments and the impassioned plea he made on behalf of the voters within his electorate.

PARA.TAB: I think, however, that he was at the very least ungracious in the remarks he levelled at the Opposition. He presumed that we have been guilty by association of being prepared to offer protection to the car industry, and he failed to point out that this Opposition—the Liberal and National parties—has been supportive of the Government for the past 10 years in the changes that have been made to tariff protection in Australia. He might have given a good deal more credence to his remarks had he been prepared to pause and recognise that it is a damn sight easier for the Opposition to oppose the Government than to support it.

I respect the knowledge that the honourable member for Corio has of the industry, but I think he allowed his emotions and his political prejudice to colour the remarks he has just delivered in this House. He went further than that. He stood up and said that the GST, proposed as an alternative to the sales tax being debated in this House, was being put forward to deliver everything; that we, the Opposition, had painted some sort of utopia arising in Australia as a result of the GST. That, Madam Acting Deputy Speaker, is arrant nonsense.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has been prepared to concede that this is not a solution to all of Australia's woes, and the honourable member for Corio and every other member opposite would do well to pause and ask themselves why on earth an Opposition, which could sit here on its hands and watch the Government fall into its lap, would propose a tax change. The honourable member for Corio says that the GST is blatantly dishonest and deceitful, and designed to hide various tax changes. Exactly the opposite is the case. Why would we, probably 12 months from a poll, propose so dramatic a change and document it in such detail if we were not prepared to debate it? They are the sorts of truths the honourable member for Corio might ponder before he allows his political prejudice to paint us as the villains in this piece.

We are dealing tonight with the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No 1). I am speaking to an amendment moved by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). It might be helpful at this stage of the debate to remind the House and those who are listening what the amendment says and precisely what we are debating. The honourable member for Curtin has moved:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . "while not opposing the passage of the Bill, the House notes that the Bill adds a further complexity to an already complex wholesale sales tax system and calls on the Government to abolish this ramshackle system and replace it with an efficient and more equitable goods and services tax

Colleagues who have spoken before me have made the point that the object of all the reforms sought by the Opposition is to remove much of the complexity that currently exists in wholesale sales tax and offer the people of Australia a tax which is not hidden but is conspicuous and to which any changes would be so conspicuous that the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fisher) have said they would be obliged to resign if rate changes were contemplated.

PARA.TAB: The Bill before the House suggests that sedan cars manufactured in Australia should have the existing wholesale sales tax reduced from 20 per cent to 15 per cent. Along with the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), I am a little cynical about the 15 per cent figure. It parallels all that is proposed in the GST and the Fightback program. It suggests that the Government is wanting to say to the electorate, `We would like to offer you the advantages of Fightback without the disadvantages that you think are part of the GST'. There is almost a smack of `all gain and no pain'.

At that point, as I said earlier, the people of Australia should ask themselves: why would an Opposition suggest anything as painful as a change to the sales tax system in Australia if it did not believe it was absolutely essential to do so? If the Opposition was not prepared to be answerable to the electorate, why would it document it in such detail in the Fightback package?

One of the tragedies of this Parliament this week is that the debate about tax changes has been so much about semantics. While the Government has wanted to trundle in all sorts of statistics, without necessarily giving them a base and making a direct comparison between its One Nation package and the Fightback package, the people of Australia have been left perplexed, not knowing whether one option or the other is attractive. I suggest to the people of Australia that they would do themselves a service if they paused, not to be confused by all the statistics that have deceitfully come into this Parliament, but to ask themselves why on earth an Opposition would be prepared to put in such detail and table it in the Parliament if it were not prepared to stand by those statistics and did not believe they were in the national interest.

Madam Deputy Speaker, you know why. The shadow Minister at the table, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), knows why, and I know why. It is because this nation is so far in debt that only a dramatic change in the way in which we can go about levelling tax will provide an opportunity to lift us out of debt—$163 billion in debt, so the newspaper told me yesterday, having gone up from about $38 billion when we lost office. This is what this Government is bequeathing to the people of Australia and we, the Opposition, as the alternative government, have proposed sales tax changes to enable us to go about repaying that debt.

But it is not easy; it is not comfortable. There is no easy option. Somehow—this is not a matter of Opposition propaganda—we have to raise Australia's export performance by 3.5 per cent and sustain it. In 20 years, under both Liberal-National Party and ALP governments, that has never been done. That is why we say that our attitude to sales tax has to change. Australians have to get the message that, unless they are productive, they are doomed to a growing debt and doomed to bequeath that growing debt to their children.

We propose dramatic changes, dramatic changes that directly affect the legislation currently before the House. We propose to remove the wholesale sales tax altogether and replace it with a goods and services tax. Why? Because the application of a sales tax, on Australian motor vehicles and all sorts of goods, is unfair. Does the House know that, for example, we do not pay a wholesale sales tax on an in-ground pool, but we do pay it on an above-ground pool? What does that say to the people opposite who pretend to represent the people who are more likely to put in above-ground pools than in-ground pools? People do not pay wholesale sales tax on built-in wardrobes, but they do if they buy a wardrobe and bring it into the house. They do not pay wholesale sales tax on toothpaste, but they do on toothbrushes. They do not pay it on cotton buds, but they do on cotton wool. It is an absurd tax. In order to change the Australian attitude to tax, we propose to take away sales tax altogether.

The Bill before the House suggests that there ought to be a change in the attitude we take to sales tax on sedan vehicles. We agree with the change, so we support it. But, as the amendment clearly points out, the change does nothing to address the confusion that currently surrounds the wholesale sales tax system. As the amendment says, for that reason we will commit ourselves to the people of Australia when we are in government, and the ALP, if it had any gumption, would stand as it did when its present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) advocated the very changes that we see are now necessary in the tax system.

Frankly, this Bill supports the inequity that already exists in wholesale sales tax. Why? Because it applies only to sedans and not to other vehicles. As the honourable member for Maranoa has pointed out, a small businessman who drives a utility or a delivery van or a farmer who says, `The way in which I run my farm means that a ute is an essential part of my business' would not be able to get the reduction from 20 per cent to 15 per cent that is being offered in the One Nation package. There is another inequity in the way in which this sales tax applies.

Small businesses, plumbers, people who mow lawns—those very people we want to encourage to come off the unemployment queues and into business—will not get the advantage that the Government is prepared to offer Australian families with this one-off reduction from 20 per cent to 15 per cent. Why not? Perhaps the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), who is at the table, will offer us an explanation. But may I suggest that there are fewer voters who drive vans and utes than there are families who drive sedans.

While I am talking about farmers and the implications of this Bill for those whom I represent, I acknowledge that the Government has been prepared in its One Nation package to offer farmers $10.8m this year and $6m next year as a one-off payment to encourage them to plant crops. But, frankly, grateful though my constituents are for the gesture, what the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is doing in the GATT negotiations is far more important to them. A determination by the Minister at the table and the Government that we ought to take a new attitude to industrial relations and accelerate waterfront reform would be far more valuable to them than this gesture as well.

I do not mean to be mealy-mouthed in saying that; we are grateful for the $10.8m. But we should not lose sight of the fact that Australia's capacity to meet the competitors from overseas that we face unfairly is largely affected by the costs of production with which primary industry is currently saddled.

I was horrified to hear the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in this House today—in answer to a question and in a challenge to the goods and services tax—say, `So what about payroll tax? Are there any farmers who pay payroll tax?'. I could not believe that he would be so economically ill-informed as to not recognise that the payroll tax being paid by every big business in Australia—54 per cent of New South Wales employees are employed by businesses which pay payroll tax—is most surely passed on to the consumer, invariably the farmer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Food processors.

—Or, as the honourable member for Gippsland points out, food processors. From a rural Australian point of view, the Government's reduction from 20 per cent to 15 per cent in the sales tax incurred on family sedans will have very little impact on the number of cars sold in Australia because so few people are in the new car market and even fewer farmers are in the new car market at this stage.

PARA.TAB: What would we in the Opposition do? As the amendment by the honourable member for Curtin points out, we propose to remove the sales tax altogether and replace it with a goods and services tax. But that would not be an additional cost to business. Every business cost that incurred a GST would have the GST rebated against it so the real cost effectively fell. As if that were not carrot enough for the changes we propose, in addition all export goods moving off the Australian shore would be GST rebated as well, providing a deliberate incentive to Australians to be part of the export industry.

From rural Australia's point of view, what happens when we remove the wholesale sales tax? We do not merely take a 20 per cent tax and reduce it to 15 per cent; we take every trucking operator and tell him that on his rig, on which he is currently paying 30 per cent wholesale sales tax, he will pay nothing at all. It will be replaced by a GST and the GST will be rebated to him because the rig is part of his business cost. The tyres, the fan belt and the spare parts that make up that trucking rig, and which currently bear a wholesale sales tax, will not bear it any more because the wholesale sales tax goes under the Fightback package and is replaced by a GST which is rebated to that trucking operator because it is an effective business cost. And as if that were not enough, in addition we remove the petroleum excise from fuel and replace it with a GST. But that is tax neutral because the fuel, wherever it is incurred as a business cost, has the GST on it rebated as well.

What does that sort of change to wholesale sales tax do to rural Australia? It provides a dramatic fall in the cost of servicing every rural Australian community. Those honourable members who come into this House—particularly the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) who comes in here on adjournment debates and simply wants to pour ill-informed criticism all over the Opposition—might be prepared at least to pause and consider the change in the cost of production we offer rural Australians by not simply applying a GST, but removing a wholesale sales tax and making the GST that applies rebatable because it is a business cost.

The changes proposed in this amendment are all contained in the Opposition's Fightback package, which is detailed and costed. I find it just a shade galling to have spent all this week in this Parliament watching that costing being criticised by the Government as though it had found some new loophole in the Fightback package. Am I supposed to be so gullible, are my electors supposed to be so gullible, as to believe that former Prime Minister Hawke, desperate to find any hole at all in the package—and he had two months in which to do so—failed?

Do honourable members not think that the former Prime Minister, desperate to retain office and knowing that all he had to do was find some flaw in the Fightback package, would have done so while he was there? Am I to believe that some new flaw has been found simply because the new Prime Minister, using venom as his principal weapon, wheels in a barrow load of statistics? I am not that gullible and neither is my electorate.

As an alternative to our proposal to take the sales tax regime and rub it out, those opposite have come in with a proposal that takes a 20 per cent sales tax on cars and reduces it to 15 per cent. That is nothing more than using a bandaid on a wound that badly needs stitches. Unless the Government is prepared to heed the advice being freely given by the Opposition and do something about Australia's productivity in order to reduce our debt, that same wound will rapidly become septic and amputation will be the only option we face.

We owe it to future generations of Australians to be all about generating wealth. What the Government proposes with its One Nation policy is nothing more, as my Leader has said, than a Bankcard-led recovery: spending it today and hoping to recover it tomorrow. We say that there is an alternative to the legislation which is currently before the House—that is, to remove wholesale sales tax altogether and, with it, all of the inequities that currently exist in the administration of the wholesale sales tax regime. We will replace it with a tax that is transparent—which can be seen and recognised by every Australian—and a tax for which we deliberately go about compensating those Australians who may find that they are disadvantaged without that form of compensation.

I conclude where I began. I was a little distressed to hear the honourable member for Corio want to give me nothing more than a history lesson on protection, without recognition of the bipartisan support that has existed in this Parliament wherever the Government has been prepared to do something in the national interest. In an electorate like mine and that of the honourable member for Gippsland, bipartisan support for wheat, wool and tariff reform has been difficult. What we seek from the Government is bipartisan support for taxation reform because that would really turn this nation around.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been moved by the inspirational address by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) to make a brief contribution in the time allowed to me. Suffice to say that the people of South Australia are well represented by the honourable member for Wakefield. I want to puncture—in the three minutes that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister assisting the Treasurer (Mr Baldwin) has generously allowed me to participate in this debate—once and for all the myth that farmers and rural people will not benefit by way of the Opposition's Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: What has to be understood is that between 75 per cent and 80 per cent of farmers' costs are fixed. The input costs are beyond the farm gate. So a farmer has control only over 25 per cent—or 30 per cent at the very best—of his or her own costs. Consequently, when the Fightback package abolishes wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and fuel tax, all of this is terribly important to the competitiveness of a farm because it means that, when the products actually go beyond the farm gate to be processed or exported, they are that much more competitive.

Moreover, for farmers there are direct benefits in the Fightback package, particularly through the tax system where we lift the tax free threshold from $5,400 to $7,000 and for incomes up to $20,000 the tax rate is reduced from 20 per cent to 16.2 per cent. Compare that with the Government's One Nation package, which almost mysteriously discriminates against low income earners, in that people with incomes up to $20,700 a year receive no tax cuts whatsoever. They will continue to pay the 20 per cent tax rate. It is amazing that the Government would abandon four million workers and income recipients—farmers, students, retirees and low income earners making up almost half the work force, or half the Australian adult population.

Let us put to one side, once and for all, the nonsense that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) tried to perpetuate in Question Time today by arguing—fruitlessly to anybody who has studied the Fightback package—that farmers are not winners. They are direct and indirect beneficiaries of a low tax regime as set out in the Fightback package.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of speakers have referred to the fact that not all vehicles are going to have their rate of wholesale sales tax cut. Without going into any detail, the basic rationale is that the ones on which the Government has reduced the rate of sales tax are those which are subject to the relatively higher rate of customs tariff, for instance, 35 per cent on imported vehicles. It was felt that, given that most of those other categories of motor vehicles—commercial vehicles—do enjoy a significantly lower rate of customs tariff, and given the relatively high proportion of those that are imported, the basic set of decisions that we have taken is appropriate. I also say that this issue, in a sense, reflects the general distinction between the Government and the Opposition. We are seeking a structure of the wholesale sales tax which, while it does have different rates, is inherently progressive; whereas the Opposition is going for a flat rate which the Government and I would argue is inherently regressive.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Baldwin) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Mr Beddall:
