That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill which makes a number of amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901. Essentially, the Bill makes three key proposals. It also includes a number of minor technical amendments. Before I turn my attention to the detail of the Bill and the amendments which have been put in place, I would like to express my concern to the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) in the strongest possible terms about the time given to both the coalition and the industry to study the Bill. The Bill was introduced into the House only last Wednesday, the day before the failed `One Job' statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). We are debating this legislation just one week later.

PARA.TAB: It is worth putting on the record that the representatives of the industry who are most affected by this legislation, namely, the customs agents and importers, received their copy only last Friday—three working days ago. Given that most of the industry representatives operate their own businesses and participate in industry activities outside working hours, the Minister has given them little or no time to convene a meeting and to give the Bill the full scrutiny which it deserves. However, in spite of this the Minister probably expects support from these organisations for the initiatives which we are debating here tonight.

It is interesting to note that this legislation was scheduled to be introduced into the House of Representatives late last year. But because of a lack of time the Bill was held over until this parliamentary session. I am making this point for a simple reason: the Bill obviously has been ready in its final form for quite some time—since December of last year at least. I see no reason why the Minister could not have circulated a draft copy of the Bill to me, to members of the customs agents' industry and to the Law Reform Commission to give us all time to study this Bill thoroughly.

I am raising this matter because I understand that two other Customs Bills are to be introduced and debated this session. Perhaps the Minister will give his assurance in the course of his final remarks that in debating that legislation we will not have a repeat of this week's events. Finally, I would like to place on record my thanks to the head of the Legal Services Branch of the Australian Customs Service, Mr Ken McInnes, for making himself available over the weekend to provide a briefing on the provisions of this Bill.

I move now to the provisions of the Bill. The coalition will not be opposing the Bill. However, I give notice that I will be moving a second reading amendment toward the conclusion of my remarks. Also, I foreshadow the coalition's intention to refer this Bill, for reasons that I will outline later, to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for scrutiny.

As I have already mentioned, as well as a number of minor technical amendments, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill makes three key proposals: it provides the legislative framework for the electronic lodgment of information relating to imported goods; it provides for the advance reporting of prescribed information for ships and aircraft at all domestic ports of call; and it amends the administration and accountability of claims for rebate under the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

Given that each of these amendments proposes significant change, I would like to address each of them individually. The first proposal amends the Customs Act 1901 to put into place the framework to facilitate the introduction of the electronic transmission to the Australian Customs Service of information concerning imported goods. It also provides for the electronic lodgment of import entries and entry authorisation in respect of such goods.

The system to be implemented, known as Compile, will be along the lines of the current structure for the electronic lodgment of export data; indeed, the Compile system has been developed to complement and operate in conjunction with the existing electronic export lodgment regime. This amendment will result in some benefits to both customs agents and importers. To start with, the administrative arrangements will be streamlined and the paperwork burden reduced. This will have a positive impact on agents and importers' cost structure, although I suspect it will be quite minimal. Obviously, the coalition welcomes this. Any reduction in the burden placed on business can only be a good thing.

I would like to point out that the benefits that will accrue to business from this measure pale into insignificance when compared with the comprehensive initiatives contained in the coalition's Fightback package. Just to illustrate, the coalition will remove the burden of wholesale sales tax from all inputs to business. In the case of customs agents' business, we will abolish the 20 per cent wholesale sales tax on computers, phones, office furniture and all office stationery. The sales tax on a company motor vehicle will be removed, as will fuel excise—something which I will refer to later in the course of my remarks.

We will complement this measure by rebating all of the GST paid on business inputs as well as eliminating payroll tax, the training levy and customs duty. In contrast to the Government, the coalition will undertake comprehensive and meaningful reforms which will result in significant and sustainable benefits to business. Indeed, compared with the coalition's program, one could say that the initiatives proposed by this Bill merely tinker at the edges of a highly uncompetitive and expensive business cost structure.

Secondly, the electronic lodgment of import information, as provided by this Bill, will allow importers faster access to their cargo. As the procedure currently stands, customs agents are required to manually convey to customs officers all of the appropriate material regarding the importation of cargo. Customs officers are generally located in a Customs house in each capital city and major regional centres.

Assessment of the application and advice on authorisation to collect the goods take a minimum of four hours; although it is interesting to note that 10 years ago the same procedure took two weeks. The system which the Bill will put in place will cut the assessment time from four hours to around 10 minutes—a substantial saving in anyone's language. This is achievable because all of the information which previously had to be hand delivered will now be conveyed to Customs electronically. Likewise, the assessment of a cargo, including risk assessment and the notification of authorisation to collect the goods or, alternatively, of the need to provide additional information, will also be communicated back to the importer or agent electronically.
As I understand it, much of the Compile system has already been developed and is in place. Indeed, those elements which classify

SPEECH.PARA: goods into tariff categories and which assess the duty payable can already be used by customs agents. The passing of this legislation will allow customs agents to press the button, so to speak, so that they can convey and receive all the information via computer. Given that the Compile system is already in place and largely operational, it is prudent to make some remarks on its performance.

PARA.TAB: I am advised by the users of the system that it is efficient and most effective; indeed, I understand that last year Compile received a Public Service award commending its efficiency and operation—although I suspect that the significance of this award is undermined somewhat given that Compile was compared only with other government computer systems rather than the entire private sector system.

There are, however, a number of problems with both the profile element of Compile and with Tap-in—a computer system designed by Customs to complement the Compile system. Tap-in is the reference tool leading to the creation of an import entry and its subsequent transmission to Customs via Compile. Tap-in provides a database containing the Customs Act, tariff classifications, rates of duty, as well as other information. The operational capacity of Tap-in, from a Customs agent's perspective, is less than desirable.

Indeed, in spite of the system's potential benefits, many customs agents refuse to use it. There is a desperate need for this system to be re-figured and updated so that it is in line with current legislation, tariff classifications and valuations. Similarly, there is a need for some amendments to the profiles contained in the Compile system. I am advised that it is difficult for brokers to determine the differences between the requirements of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Australian Quarantine Service and the community protection obligations of the Australian Customs Service.

For example, Compile fails to differentiate between different types of sporting goods. The system will ask for quarantine details on all sporting goods which are entered into the system, when it is really only sporting goods using animal or natural fibres which need to be assessed for quarantine purposes. This increases the administration of import entries, adds to the assessment time of goods and represents some delay to importers.

The Government should take the opportunity to update and upgrade the profiles contained in the Compile system in the lead-up to its becoming fully operational. It should also use this opportunity to upgrade and modify the Tap-in system so that it is more user friendly and responsive to the needs of customs agents.

My other concerns about the Compile system lie not so much with the legislative framework as with the introduction and administration of the scheme. Specifically I am concerned about the content and the format of the new deed of agreement between the Australian Customs Service and individual agents, which authorises and outlines the conditions of use of Compile and, more particularly, electronic lodgment.

When the electronic lodgment of Customs entries, as opposed to the transmission of these entries, was introduced the Australian Customs Service presented to customs agents the deed of agreement, which was, they stated, final. Indeed, it was presented to the agents as either take it or leave it, in a manner of speaking—hardly a fitting attitude for a government department which relies on extensive public contact in order to successfully carry out its brief. It is gratifying to note, therefore, that Customs did weaken and allow discussion on the agreement. However, it took some three months of ongoing negotiations before a final position agreeable to both parties was reached.

I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this is not a satisfactory state of affairs. Consequently, I am seeking from the Minister an assurance that these circumstances will not be repeated in the course of developing the new Compile deed of agreement. Indeed, the Minister should take some action to ensure the draft agreement is circulated for discussion and the appropriate negotiation period is allowed—although, as I understand it, the Australian Customs Service undertook to supply the Customs Brokers Council of Australia with a list of the changes proposed to the existing deed of agreement for consideration. The Customs Service undertook to distribute this by the end of January. It is now nearly the middle of March, and we have not yet seen anything.

In scrutinising this Bill, albeit in the very short time given, I was pleased to note that the Customs Service has put in place appropriate measures to guarantee the security of information supplied by importers. The security measures introduced by this Bill include the allocation to each importer of a unique identity code known as the PIN number. The computer system will cross-reference this PIN number with other information contained in its database to verify the legality of the user and will hence allow access to the network.

There is, however, some confusion about legality regarding the use of the PIN number, namely, whether it falls on the individual user or on the corporate identity. This is something which needs to be studied more thoroughly. I am sure this will occur as the Bill moves through the Senate and through the committee process. Secondly, there is some concern about issuing the new passwords over the phone. While this is only done when an old PIN number has been lost, it still represents a high risk operation.

In concluding my remarks on this portion of the Bill, I would like to point out that the use of the electronic lodgment system is optional. The current manual lodgment system will remain in place. As such, there is no need for importers, unless they so desire, to spend vast sums of money to purchase new computer hardware. As I have already mentioned, the Compile software is compatible with the existing export lodgment system software, thus removing the need for business to upgrade or purchase new equipment.

The second proposal in the Bill provides for appropriate information to be transmitted by an aircraft or ship prior to its arrival in a domestic port. Under the previous legislation ship masters and aircraft captains were required to present to Customs officers upon or within 24 hours of arrival the details of cargo being carried. A 1990 amendment to the Customs Act provided for this information to be lodged electronically prior to the arrival of the vessel at the first Australian port of call. The prescribed information is still to be presented by hand upon arrival at all subsequent ports.

The advanced reporting regime has given Customs the opportunity to better scrutinise cargo and assess and target risks. Indeed, it is in line with the Customs community obligation protection requirements. The regime has given importers faster access to cargo carried on board vessels when that cargo is unloaded at the first port of call. Again, this can only be of benefit to business. I should point out that there are some anomalies in that this facility is only available to importers when the goods are unloaded at the first port of call. There is still some time delay when cargo is unloaded at subsequent domestic ports of call. It is pleasing to note, therefore, that the Bill removes this anomaly by extending the advance reporting regime to all domestic ports of call or ships or aircraft. Consequently, all importers nationwide will have the same speedy access to their cargo.

Secondly, the information to be provided has been extended to include the number and names of crew members on board, as well as the number of passengers carried. This will provide for the advanced checking of crew numbers and crew members and allow for the appropriate number of processing officers to be available for the passengers when the ship or aircraft arrives. The initiative should result in a more streamlined method of processing passengers and crew, something which overseas travellers will welcome and which could possibly be described as well overdue.The coalition will support this amendment. Anything which facilitates better community protection and at the same time modifies a cumbersome administrative procedure and assisting business deserves support.

I now turn to the third element of the Bill, namely, the changes to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. That scheme provides for rebates of excise or customs duty on diesel fuel purchased for specific off-road uses in mining operations; primary production, including agriculture, fishing and forestry operations; and in residential premises; hospitals; nursing homes and homes for the aged. Excise and customs rates of duty on diesel fuel are adjusted in February and August each year in line with the movements in the CPI. Rebates differ between different categories of claimant.

During the last financial year over $836m was paid in respect of 229,131 diesel fuel rebate claims. This is an increase over the previous year of just over 11 per cent in the amount paid and of just over 5 per cent in the number of claims submitted. In 1989-90, 217,086 claims were submitted with over $752m being paid out.

There are a number of quite significant problems with the administration of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. This was confirmed by the Australian National Audit Office in its 1991 audit of the scheme. It found, and I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of weaknesses in the current procedures which are adversely affecting the processing of claims. Some of those weaknesses stem from the design of procedures and some from their implementation.

The Audit Office went on to identify the following key problems with the diesel fuel rebate scheme: the complexity of the eligibility criteria caused difficulties in determining which operations were eligible for rebate and to what extent; the payment of the rebate was based on a forecast of eligible use prepared by the claimant, as against actual use; weaknesses in the rebate control procedures included the fact that a variety of documentation was being accepted as proof of purchase of fuel; the extent of overpayments under the scheme was not known; and investigation functions were compromised to achieve processing targets.

PARA.TAB: It is reassuring that this legislation is designed to address in part some of the administrative problems of the scheme. The resulting streamlined administration scheme will be welcomed by users. The coalition also believes that this is a step in the right direction, albeit a very small one. But this is something which I will address in more detail later on.

Before doing this, I take the opportunity to bring to the attention of the House what I regard as a very serious problem with the administration of the diesel fuel rebate scheme, a problem which, I might add, has had severe repercussions on business. Late last year it was brought to the attention of my office that the Tasmanian regional office of the Australian Customs Service had adopted an unofficial `go slow'. This was, I understand, in protest at the reduction in staff numbers in the Tasmanian regional office. Staff numbers were reduced from 101 in 1988-89 to 85 in 1990-91.

I would not have thought that this was unusual, given the efficiency gains which were supposed to be achieved from award restructuring and other productivity measures. Customs officers obviously thought otherwise and indicated they were, in fact, overworked. One of the casualties of this `go slow' was the processing of claims for the diesel fuel rebate. Instead of the two to three weeks normally taken to process claims, the time ballooned to eight to 10 weeks. Some claimants waited well over three months to receive their rebate. We are not talking about insignificant amounts of money here. The average claim is for around $22,000, although a number of the claims were for amounts between $57,000 and $60,000.

I might point out to the House that the claims were of this size because many loggers, who are large users of diesel fuel, submit their claims every two or three months. This is for a number of reasons but primarily to reduce their own administrative burden.

Secondly, many loggers use their diesel fuel rebates as a financial safety net or as a means of meeting larger bills when they become due. Consequently, this unofficial `go slow' and the subsequent withholding of payments has had a devastating effect on the businesses of the claimants, something which will only compound the impact on businesses of the worst recession for 60 years. Indeed, one logger that I know of has been forced to put two of his trucks up for sale in order to pay his debts, which otherwise could have been met by this rebate. This is a deplorable situation.

The livelihoods of many of Tasmania's struggling small businesses are being put at risk because of the wilful action of a few Customs officers. It is distressing, to say the least, that a number of government bureaucrats can hold the private sector to ransom in this way. Moreover, it is a direct consequence of this Government's poor policies that businesses have to pay excise on their fuel and hence have to be put through this cumbersome procedure in the first place. Accordingly, I move:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House regrets the Government's failure to take advantage of the opportunity provided by this Bill to introduce more extensive changes to customs and excise legislation, including:
(1)abolishing the excise duty on fuel, including diesel fuel: and
(2)reducing other customs and excise and similar taxation burdens on business by adopting proposals such as those contained in the Coalition's `Fightback' program".
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

—Petroleum excise is a heavy consumption tax levied on a particularly narrow base. The petroleum products excise currently collects around 25c from every litre of fuel. This tax is so onerous on individuals and business that the revenue collected by government has increased from $1.3 billion in 1982-83 to $6.6 billion today. The Industry Commission stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that a significant proportion of existing excises fall on intermediate or business use. It is a general principle of taxation that taxation of intermediate goods has costs which can be avoided.

The Industry Commission concluded further that rates of petroleum excise were too high; that a strong case could be made for exempting the intermediate use of petroleum products from excise; and that a broadening of the community tax base by introducing a value added tax would have a number of benefits.

PARA.TAB: Consequently, the coalition would scrap the fuel excise. That is what the Government should do if it is serious about fixing the problems in the economy today. It would abolish the fuel excise levy rather than proposing any more amendments. The benefits from the coalition's action plan would be substantial, particularly for all business. It would mean our businesses would become more productive and more competitive and able to gain a true world competitive standard. For business it would mean that fuel prices would drop by 26c per litre, as all input costs to business would be rebatable. The present wholesale sales tax system is a cost on our exports of $1.7 billion. If we are truly to get our industries and our domestic market world competitive, we need these sorts of amendments and changes to the system. This Bill does not pick up that amendment.

In conclusion, I would like to reiterate the coalition's position on this Bill. We support the broad thrust of the amendments being proposed by this legislation. We are, however, concerned about the haste with which it has been introduced and rushed through the House. The natural consequence of this is that both we and members of the industry who are most affected by the amendments have had little time to study them. Indeed, we have not been in a position to give the Bill the full and frank scrutiny it deserves.

Secondly, we are concerned about the lack of consultation undertaken by the Customs Service, particularly with regard to what will be a revolutionary new scheme. Therefore, to allow community discussion and to facilitate more thorough scrutiny of the provisions of the Bill, when the Bill reaches the Senate chamber we will be seeking to refer it to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 is an omnibus measure proposing a series of amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901. There are three main proposals in this Bill. The Opposition has moved a second reading amendment which the Government will oppose, and which I will certainly oppose. The Bill proposes firstly to amend the Customs Act 1901 to provide the legislative framework for the electronic transmission to the Australian Customs Service of information concerning imported goods, and the electronic lodgment of import entries in respect of such goods.

PARA.TAB: The Bill proposes secondly to amend provisions of the Customs Act relating to the advance reporting regime for ships and aircraft and their cargo, passengers and crew, to enhance the operation of that scheme. The third amendment proposed to the Customs Act is to improve the accountability and administration of the diesel fuel rebate scheme in response to the Audit Report No. 27 of 1990-91 by the Australian National Audit Office, tabled in the Parliament on 16 May 1991.

The proposed amendments for the electronic communication and lodgment of import information are a continuation of the improvements and updating of entry facilities which were initiated by the EXIT amendments for export information introduced into the Customs Act by Act No. 111 of 1990. With regard to cargo reporting, the proposed amendments will enhance the ability of Customs to fully risk-assess incoming cargo, crew and passengers for the detection of narcotics and other prohibited imports by ensuring that all advanced reports are communicated to Customs at each port or airport of call in Australia rather than only at the first port or airport of arrival. This is important because drugs certainly are a massive problem for the Western world. It is necessary for us to streamline our efforts through every avenue open to us to prohibit the entry of prohibited drugs.

The third amendment relates to the diesel fuel rebate scheme and is designed to streamline the present claims procedures and improve the accountability and administration of the scheme. There are also other minor proposed amendments to the Customs Act and the Excise Act. From 1990 to 1994, in dollar values, the cost of implementing the new scheme will amount to a total of $1.883m.

I would like to compliment the Australian Customs Service. It does an admirable job. It is always very easy to find fault with or to criticise various departments, but Customs has always done an outstanding job, particularly these days with sophistication, massive air travel and shipping, particularly in the north of this country. There should be recognition of the dedication of the men and women involved in our Customs Service. In relation to diesel fuel rebate, there is a benefit to agriculture of approximately half a billion dollars per annum, something that deserves recognition. Of course, this leads to a reduction in input costs, which also deserves recognition.

I also compliment the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) for the way in which he is handling his portfolio. There is often rhetoric and emotion involved in accusations of dumping in this country and accusations of action that should be stopped immediately. There are proper procedures through the Customs Service and through the Anti-Dumping Authority. When one goes through these procedures one finds that the case is often much different from what one has originally read in the paper. In the South Burnett Times recently, the editor, John Cameron, pointed to what we should do if we want to achieve the labelling of food products—which has a big bearing on imported foods. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If so, tell your retailer or an Australian food producer. But do not tell the governments because they will do nothing.

I had already informed the editor that the Government had an inquiry under way and we needed the cooperation of the six State governments to achieve labelling of foods products. As of 28 February the new National Food Authority foods standard took effect, which means that now all the imported, unpackaged fruit, vegetables, fish and nuts on sale to the general public must have their country of origin or a sign with `Imported' clearly displayed nearby. I do not know whether the editor of the South Burnett Times will recognise that and put it in the paper, but it is important because primary producers and the general public will know the facts only if they are properly informed.

PARA.TAB: The rhetoric and the nonsense that comes from particularly National Party politicians and supporters in Queensland often disappoints me. They use rhetoric and say that any produce coming into this country is dumped or is heavily subsidised and that we should ban it, without regard for bilateral trade or for the effect that would have if we placed protective barriers on those products.

The shadow Minister for primary industries in Queensland, Trevor Perrett from the electorate of Barambah, recently came out in a scattergun approach and said that heavily subsidised and dumped products are flooding into Australia and destroying Australian markets. The point is that $6.3 billion worth of processed and semiprocessed Australian food product is exported annually—right now! If we took the advice of this character, the shadow Minister for primary industries, we would see retaliatory action which would devastate the beef industry, the sugar industry, the wheat industry, the wool industry—the large industries. We have to find markets for some 80 per cent of these industries because we have such a small domestic market.

Every time there is a bit of pressure put on these politicians, instead of telling the truth and saying that we have a proper procedure through Customs and through the Anti-Dumping Authority, they simply say that the product is being dumped and the Government should do something about it. It is just unfortunate that they do not have the courage to tell their own supporters the truth. It is a great pity that the National Party does not pay some of these clowns to go over to Europe and find out what the real trade scene is about instead of attacking the Customs Service, the ADA or the Government.

I would like to read into Hansard an article headed `Pick `n Pay critical of Golden Circle'. I am not criticising Golden Circle, because it does an outstanding job; I have visited its processing plant. But the article states:
Pick `n Pay grocery chief, Peter Dove, has criticised Golden Circle for not being able to supply canned sliced pineapple during the peak summer months from November to February.
Mr Dove said Golden Circle complained about import competition but never had enough stock to supply the market throughout an entire season.

SPEECH.PARA: That is because seasons are often cyclical and there are down times in the market. Some processors actually have to import to keep production up. For a period we have often had rhetoric about banning products and then found a shortfall at the same time. It would be handy if in Queensland the National Party told the full story. That would mean that it would be unpopular, perhaps, but it would be better if its supporters and all farmers were better informed of the facts instead of the nonsense that certainly does the rounds.

PARA.TAB: I now move on to the amendment moved by the Opposition to the second reading of this Bill referring to the abolition of the excise duty on fuel, including diesel fuel. The Opposition has been asked several times how it is going to fund roads and it has not responded. The Opposition has said that it is going to use road user charging. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) has a large electorate like mine and I would like to ask him what level of road user charging he is going to put on semitrailers, four-wheel drives and ordinary vehicles. If the Opposition were to take fuel excise away, unless it would allow roads to run down it would have to put thousands of dollars of registration fees on people, up front—a one-off hit, a one-off whack. It would not be user pays as under the present system, but a one-off whack. As I have said in this House before, I would like to see the local government authority in Queensland put those opposite under scrutiny, because so far it has been very quiet on an issue that directly affects its livelihood, that is, roads.

The Opposition should come clean and say exactly what level of road user charging it is going to use if it abolishes excise, because at this stage it has not said what it is going to do. As to the rhetoric about the money from excise not all going into roads, which has been doing the rounds for ages, I point out that all bar about 5c per litre goes into road use and road trauma; only about 5c does not. That amount goes into education, defence and all the other services that are provided in this country. Again, when the Opposition is put to the test as to what areas it will fund if excise is taken away, it simply does not answer. That is why I would like to see this issue of road user charges answered by the Opposition, because we have to fund roads and, if the Opposition wants to abolish excise, it would have to find the money from somewhere. That has not been said. That is a challenge that needs to be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —You aren't funding roads now.

—That is nonsense, because our level of funding is better than it ever was under those opposite. The reason I attacked the President of the Queensland Local Government Association recently—and I am happy to do it time and time again—is that, for seven years under the State National Party Government in Queensland, transfer charges took $400m off local authorities. Neither Jim Pennell, Alec MacIntosh, Chairman of Kilkivan Shire, nor Bill Roberts, Chairman of Murgon Shire, ever raised one whimper of criticism because their mates were in the State National Party Government in Queensland. They were prepared to sit back and cop that. Every time we come to a Federal election these same clowns come out and attack the Federal Government. But I could not expect much more from Bill Roberts. He is on record as supporting racial segregation in schools, so one could not expect much more from someone like that. If there is ever a remake of Deliverance he would be very well suited for a big part in the show.

PARA.TAB: As to the other part of the amendment about reducing other customs and excise and similar taxation burdens on business by adopting proposals such as those contained in the coalition's Fightback program, I totally oppose that proposition. It is interesting to note that the experience overseas is very indicative of what would happen here. In an article from the Herald-Sun of 21 November 1991 it was stated:
Britain's consumption tax, known as Value Added Tax, is successful—so successful that the Government decided in March to raise even more money with it.
The VAT was raised by 2.5 per cent to 17.5 per cent.

It originally started a few years ago at 7 per cent. Of course over in Britain there is a difference: food, newspapers, travel and children's clothing are zero rated. It is a bit different here: food would be taxed at 15 per cent. I do not think that is fair, particularly given the fact that people on low incomes would be those worst hit—the disabled, the aged, farmers, many of whom will not have an income or at least only a very small income this year—and many households will be much worse off. In fact 60 per cent of farm and self-employed households will be worse off under the goods and services tax of the Opposition.

I do not believe that these two amendments, which would change the revenue base and inflict the weight back onto those people, should be supported. I totally oppose these amendments. In doing so, I will say what I said earlier today in this House and what I will keep saying: under a goods and services tax primary producers would have to pay a 15 per cent tax at the retail level on their products—the dairy industry would have to pay 15 per cent on its products; the cereal producers would have to pay a 15 per cent tax for the domestic market; the fresh fruit and vegetables industries, the poultry industry and the pig industry would all have to pay that 15 per cent tax on their products.

It is ironic that the shadow Minister for primary industries in Queensland, the member for Barambah, was complaining about imported pork but he does not mind the Federal coalition wanting to put a tax of 15 per cent on the retail sale of pork produced in Australia. If we followed his line and banned imported pork, I wonder what he would say when the United States of America and Canada retaliated and banned our beef exports. I suppose he would then try to find a genie to pull out of his hat or to blame somebody else. The problem is that these cowboys need to get their facts straight if they want to get into the real world. If they want to talk about trade, they need to know what they are talking about, not simply to try to please the preselection process of their own local National Party of Australia and the League of Rights in the South Burnett.

One of the worst aspects of the goods and services tax would be the inflationary effect at a time when Australia has inflation whipped and down to the best levels I have seen in my time. That gives us a competitive ability to see wool sold overseas. The Opposition would run inflation into double digits and destroy Australia's competitiveness. That does not make sense. The only reason that has been done is to shift the burden from the top end of town down to the bottom end, down to the Aussie battler, to make them pay for food, for meat, fruit and vegetables. That is what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you give the Aussie battler tax cuts?

—I will take on the interjection of the honourable member for Forrest: in regard to tax cuts he knows as well as I that this Government reduced the rate of tax since 1983 from 30 per cent to 21 per cent. The Opposition wants to drop it to 16 per cent and put a 15 per cent tax on top. That is a 31 per cent tax; the Opposition wants to lift the tax rate again.
—Rubbish.

—No, it is not rubbish; the Opposition wants to lift it back again. What the shadow Minister is omitting is the fact that the family allowance supplement was put into the system to put a hedge underneath the living standards of those people, something the Opposition opposed because that money came from the fringe benefits tax, which got rid of the free lunch and the spivs on the Gold Coast who were not paying their share. What did honourable members opposite do? They opposed one of the most equitable taxes we have ever brought in. That money goes into the family allowance supplement. So honourable members opposite should never tell us that we have not looked after the battler at the bottom end of the scale. Honourable members should look at the facts: 60 per cent of farmers will be worse off under the Opposition's tax.
—Two thousand are walking off their land this year.

—Over the next six months, as the cold hard truth sinks in, members of the Opposition will have a lot of difficulty holding the line. As I said earlier today, in Queensland Sir Robert Sparkes said that the coalition could not sell this tax. While I do not necessarily agree with much of what Sir Robert Sparkes says, he is a shrewd politician and he knows full well that there is no way the coalition will be able to sell a tax on food and clothes, on the basic necessities of life, just to give a tax break for Ferraris, Maseratis and the top end of the counter.

PARA.TAB: The other irony is when the coalition produces its food basket and says, `This is a normal standard family'. As the Treasurer said today, there was more emphasis placed on Harpic than there was on fruit, meat and vegetables. Perhaps that is because a lot of people on the other side can afford to go to posh restaurants every night and do not understand what it is like to actually have to cook a normal family meal at home for a spouse and three or four children.

That is what this is about. This is another aspect of these amendments; it is another part of shifting the burden down to the bottom end of income earners and away from the top end of town. At the same time I think it should be recognised that this Government has reduced taxation—company tax down to 39 per cent and the top rate of tax down to 47 per cent—but when the Opposition was in government it did not look after the big income earners, but it had holes so big in the taxation laws that one could drive a Sherman tank through them, whether be the straw companies or all the rorts that were open for anyone who had a couple of smart accountants. The Government has created a little bit of equity right across the system. That is why I will not have a bar of these amendments, because they are unfair, unjust and un-Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I listened to the chairman of the country task force of the Prime Minister I wondered whether he really understood the country. I always find his comments quite disturbing. As a member who has a large rural electorate, I hope he listens to what I have to say because our amendment tonight goes to the heart of the problem that is in much of rural Australia and certainly in much of my electorate.

PARA.TAB: In addressing the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill this evening, I would like to direct my comments exclusively to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The legislation before the House is designed to correct deficiencies in the administration of the scheme. The requirement to lodge original purchase invoices with each claim will be removed and during 1992 the Government expects to present new regulations to enable invoices to be replaced by a schedule of fuel purchases prepared by the claimant. I must say that this is a sensible approach.

It would be remiss of me to ignore the more alarming deficiencies, and indeed inequities, in the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Diesel fuel rebate exemptions fall into nine categories. They are farming, forestry, commercial fishing, residential premises, mining, medical institutions, hospitals, nursing homes and aged people's homes. I have to wonder how the Government arrived at these categories.

I think it is a bit like a game we used to play when we were kids, pin the tail on the donkey. The Government is not sure what it should exempt, how it should exempt and where it should exempt so it is taking a wild guess and, as I said, it is a bit like pinning the tail on the donkey in order to make a decision.

The very fact that exemptions exist denotes the importance to the belief, upheld by the coalition forces—the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia—that taxes on business inputs should be fully rebatable. As we examine the list further, we can see that mining and farming are eligible for a diesel fuel tax rebate. But what about Avgas? What about petrol that is used in these industries? So often a petrol-driven machine is seen working beside and complementing a diesel-driven machine. We are faced with the ridiculous situation where a diesel-powered machine is operated tax free while its petrol-driven counterpart is subjected to fuel excise.

Let me give the House an example. I hope the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) is listening because he has condemned these amendments tonight. Just look at the statistics of how many new tractors, new headers or new harvesters have been purchased by farmers over the last nine or 10 years. There has been very little investment in new machinery. There is a very good reason why this is so and it is certainly one of the reasons agriculture is in decline, because farmers have not been able to afford to upgrade their machinery.

Take a diesel-driven harvester out in the paddock harvesting grain. There are still quite a lot of petrol-driven machines harvesting grain. There is the diesel-driven machine, with no tax on it, going down the paddock and beside it is one driven by petrol, with a tax on it. It delivers the grain into a truck and the grain will be taken to the on-farm storage. The truck will be a petrol-driven truck, or it could be a diesel, but in either case this same inequity exists. If a farmer has a diesel harvester, he will get a rebate; if he has a petrol one, he will be paying the tax.

The grain is delivered to the silo, the on-farm storage. As many as 99 per cent of farm elevators putting grain into silos are petrol-driven machines. They are not machines that drive along the road; they are stationary engines driving an auger, putting grain into a silo, yet the farmer has to pay tax on the petrol. If it is a diesel machine, he gets it tax free. I have never seen a more glaring inequity.

Aviation gasoline, which is used in agricultural aerial work, including mustering, is also subject to a fuel excise. The farmers and graziers are footing the bill for airport infrastructure and air traffic control that they derive no benefit from. Avgas excise amounts to $6.5m per year in the agricultural sector. These machines, helicopters and light aeroplanes are used in mustering; they are used in the day-to-day operations of checking waters and fences on properties. They rarely see a civil airport. Most of the maintenance is done on the property, yet the farmers and graziers are paying $6.5m a year in avgas excise, for no benefit. It is purely and straight out a tax on the day-to-day operation of the farm. Another good point about our Fightback package is that we are going to abolish fuel tax. No ifs and buts; no diesel only or petrol. It is diesel; it is petrol; it is avgas.

Another blatant inequity is the example of the commercial fishing boat, compared with the tourist vessel. Whereas the commercial fisherman can claim a diesel fuel tax rebate, the tourist operator cannot. I have to ask the honourable member for Hinkler why the commercial fisherman can claim a diesel tax fuel rebate but the tourist operator cannot. Does this mean that the Government is placing a greater emphasis on the commercial fisherman over the tourism operator who takes the boat out to the Whitsundays or the Barrier Reef? We all know how important the tourism industry is to us, so why should we want to discriminate between the two? After all, tourism is Australia's fastest growing industry, the largest private sector employer and the biggest earner of foreign exchange for the nation.

I must qualify `biggest earner'. In Question Time this afternoon the Minister for Tourism (Mr Griffiths) said that it is a very important industry—and I acknowledge that; it is. However, it provides gross income to the nation, not net income. I hope that the Minister takes note of that. Whilst we may earn $7 billion a year gross from tourism, Australians also travel overseas and spend almost the same amount out of the country. Nevertheless, tourism is a very important job creator, and I ask why we discriminate between the commercial fisherman and the tourism operator. I really do not believe that we have had an adequate answer from any members of the Government in their speeches. It is just a case of the Government not knowing the donkey's head from the donkey's rump—to revert to my `pin the tail on the donkey' analogy.

The diesel fuel rebate scheme is absolutely riddled with inequities. For example, why are residential premises entitled to a diesel rebate on electricity generation, while electricity authorities are not? I have four or five towns in the west of my electorate: Bedourie, Birdsville, Windorah and Jundah, all of which get their electricity through the electricity authority putting a diesel driven generating plant in their towns. They are very small towns, but those electricity authorities pay fuel tax to generate that electricity for those small towns. Yet if the electricity were generated at a residence, there would be no tax. I suggest to the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) that he would certainly have been well off in here tonight addressing some of these problems, because he would have quite a few towns in his electorate with similar problems.

Fuel tax was originally introduced for the sole purpose of funding road maintenance and construction. Over the Labor Government years, fuel excise tax has been used to fill the Government's coffers. It has become a revenue raising mechanism. It is not being used for the original purpose for which it was brought into this House. Despite a 120 per cent increase in fuel taxes over the Labor years, road funding has fallen by 20 per cent in real terms. I know that that contradicts the honourable member for Hinkler, who I notice has left the House. I guess it is just that he does not like to hear the truth of the matter. Furthermore—and conveniently for the Government—it is no longer necessary to introduce legislation to increase excise payable. It is adjusted automatically twice a year with the CPI. It requires only the stroke of a pen. Surely this is a case of inflation breeding more inflation.

The railways of Australia are a very important part of our infrastructure. In 1990-91 the Australian railway systems consumed a massive 514.3 million litres of diesel fuel. The railways paid a total product excise on that fuel of $130.14m. This Government has just woken up to the fact that it had better do something about these shiny railways. It is saying, `We have been using them as a revenue source, but now we had better start putting some of the money that they have been paying all the time we have been in government back into the rail system of Australia'.

The Queensland Government railways alone—and this will interest the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall), who is at the table—paid $23.75m to the Federal Government in excise. A lot of this fuel tax ultimately is paid by the consumer. I would have thought that the honourable member for Hinkler might have stayed in the House and listened to this because he has cane trains in his electorate. The cane industry is a very important industry in his electorate. These cane trains are pulling cane from the farms to the crushing plant, and they are attracting fuel tax because they are diesel driven. The passengers, the tourists who come to Australia, pay the fuel tax in the price of the ticket they purchase to travel the coast of Queensland on the railways. In Queensland alone, $23.75m worth of fuel excise was paid to the Federal Government.

The coalition government is going to abolish fuel tax and replace it with a 15 per cent goods and services tax. However, this GST will be refunded to business inputs, saving the Australian railways, for example, $130.14m. That is not an insignificant amount. It is a massive amount of tax which ultimately is paid by the consumer. So often it is an export industry that is paying that tax because so much of our export commodities are moved by rail for some part of the journey. The coalition is not talking about dabbling with the existing flagging wholesale sales tax regime; we are talking about comprehensive reform. The impediments to production propagated by this Government must be removed for Australia to have any hope of becoming internationally competitive.

I want to touch on another aspect of fuel tax—the iniquitous way it affects local government, particularly in my electorate of Maranoa. It is an area of immense agricultural resources and wealth, very much like much of rural Australia. It is a very large rural electorate. It is three times the size of Victoria. Flying from east to west is the same as flying from Brisbane to Launceston. Like much of rural Australia, it has been unrecognised by this Labor Government. The Labor Government has actively promoted policies to eliminate rural communities.

The Barcoo Shire, which is in the electorate of Maranoa, covers an area of 61,900 square kilometres—about one-tenth of the size of the electorate itself, which is 625,000 square kilometres. Barcoo Shire has a population of 454 men, women and children—about 120 families. The headquarters of the Barcoo Shire is at Jundah and there is another office in Windorah. The outstanding figure, however, is that the gross value of agricultural production for this area amounts to $31.7m. That represents the combined work and effort of about 120 families—as I say, 454 men, women and children. Last year the Barcoo Shire alone used 390,000 litres of fuel at an average cost of 66.6c per litre. Therefore, the Barcoo Shire paid a fuel excise bill of $90,000.

We have a ridiculous situation in which we have graders grading the roads in these shires, paying diesel fuel tax, then constructing roads and paying tax. Trucks carting gravel to them are paying fuel tax. Dozers digging the gravel out of the ground to put into pits and loaders putting it onto trucks to make roads are paying fuel tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Monty Python stuff.

—It is absolutely Monty Python stuff, as the honourable member for Mallee says. In our Fightback package we are going to return that $90,000 to the Barcoo Shire Council, and will do the same for every other shire in Australia. About 120 families are paying the bill of $90,000, which is $750 per family in the Barcoo Shire alone. They are paying it in rates to the Barcoo Shire Council. That is three times as much as the Government said it would pay in family allowance as a one-off payment in an attempt to win the electorate of Wills. An amount of $750 is being paid in fuel tax per family in one shire alone.

PARA.TAB: Another example is the Diamantina Shire—a very important shire—which is on my far western boundary. It encompasses the towns of Birdsville and Bedourie. I think everyone in Australia has heard of the Birdsville Races. It is a shire with an area of 94,690 square kilometres and a population of 243 people—about 50 families. The gross value of agricultural production and the combined work and effort of the people within the shire amounts to $15 1/2m. That figure is down a bit compared with the figure for Barcoo. The reason is that, in the last four to five years, the Diamantina Shire has been totally destocked because of the TB and brucellosis eradication campaign and is only now starting to restock. Even with those low stock numbers, the latest figures show that $15 1/2m—mainly in export income—has been generated in the Diamantina Shire.

The Diamantina Shire has 1,671 kilometres of road. Last year it paid $75,000 in fuel tax. Do honourable members know how many kilometres of sealed roads the Diamantina Shire has? It has 7.8 kilometres out of a total of 1,671 kilometres of roads in the shire. The sealed roads are around the towns of Bedourie and Birdsville and a little way out of town; yet last year and the year before, it sent $75,000 to Canberra—and it will probably have to do it again this year. What has it got for it? Nothing. Most of the roads are unformed. They have 7.5 kilometres of sealed road out of a total 1,671 kilometres of road and they contribute $15 1/2m. The place is practically destocked, yet it provides all this export income.

This is a very important area for tourism. The Burke and Wills dig tree is just down the road from Birdsville. People who want to go out there now have to go in a four-wheel drive, for which they have to pay a 20 per cent tax. We were led to believe last week that tax on passenger motor vehicles would be reduced. The area around Birdsville is a very picturesque and historical part of Australia.

These are just two typical shires within the electorate of Maranoa. They undisputedly generate enormous wealth for Australia, as does much of the electorate of Maranoa. However, they receive nothing in return but taxes, bad roads and a high cost of living. Eighty per cent of Australia's export earning income originates in rural Australia. An investment in rural Australia is an investment in Australia's future. I support the amendment the Opposition has moved tonight. I believe it is a sensible approach and it will assist much of rural Australia, as my examples have shown tonight.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the House this evening. The Government strongly opposes the amendment moved by the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), the shadow Minister for small business, housing and Customs. In an attempt to have Fightback adopted by stealth, the Opposition has tried to sneak in this amendment.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting that the honourable member for Forrest said that we should accept the Industry Commission's reports in toto. I am not sure that his colleagues, the National Party members, would accept that view in relation to the dairy industry. I think the Industry Commission's view on the dairy industry is radically opposed by the members of the National Party.

The honourable member for Forrest made a couple of points and I would like to address them. He sought assurances that the new agreements contemplated in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill for the Compile system would involve consultation. Naturally that is the case, as has always been the case with these measures in the past. Usually agreements will deal with technical matters, including training, commercial agreements, fees payable and other terms and conditions by which parties will communicate using the Compile system.

In the agreement we outlined the rights, deliberations, liabilities and indemnities of the users of the system. With the Customs Service as the receiver of messages transmitted via the system, it is, therefore, appropriate and essential that the potential users be consulted on the proposed terms of any new agreement. I assure the honourable member for Forrest that this will occur in the new Compile user agreement in the Bill, as occurred when electronic lodgment was first introduced Australia-wide on a completely contractual basis in September last year.

The honourable member for Forrest was critical of a lack of consultation in this process. It may stand as a valid criticism if this was a new proposal, but this proposal has been around for approximately two years. It mirrors the EXIT program that was introduced. The electronic lodgment initiative is not new. I wrote to the honourable member for Forrest on 25 February about the proposal and provided him with a great deal of detail. As usual, we offered a briefing and any exchange of information that he required. His office contacted my office on Friday. His office spent considerable time in discussion with an officer of the Australian Customs Service on Saturday. The office of the honourable member for Forrest also rang, leaving a message for the officer to brief him on Monday of this week at 8 o'clock. Unfortunately, as is normal, that was before the officer arrived at work, and then it was too late, according to the honourable member for Forrest.

There is nothing out of the ordinary in the way this Bill has been presented. A substantial amount of detail has been provided to the honourable member. It has been nine days since this Bill was introduced in the House and debate is taking place this evening. The items in this Bill are not new. They have been around for a considerable time. I will not delay the House because there are other matters to be discussed, but I indicate clearly that the Government will oppose the amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Beddall) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 27 February, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are ostensibly debating what is called the Government's economic statement, but I suggest the term is a misnomer; rather, it is a political statement. Its aim is to preserve one job—the job of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—and it is surely destined to fail.

PARA.TAB: The contrast between the coalition's Fightback proposals and the Prime Minister's random mishmash of unfunded promises cobbled together with a wish list could not be greater. The unemployment problem this time around is worse because of the disappearance of a large number of unskilled jobs during the 1980s. Many of those jobs have disappeared forever. In the light of that stark occurrence, we need to examine the nation's skill base and ensure that Australians, and especially young Australians, are learning the skills that a modern, internationalised economy needs.

The contrast of the Government's package with the Liberal-National coalition's program is dramatic, for the coalition has put forward a coherent strategy for jobs for the 1990s. The coalition's approach is to concentrate on growth through the creation of a more flexible economy, freed of the damaging centralised industrial relations system. Reforms to communications, the waterfront and transport will cut business costs and encourage new jobs in exporting industries. Enterprise bargaining and voluntary employment agreements will make wages, salaries and employment conditions more flexible; open job opportunities for young people; lift productivity; and create more wealth, more savings and, more importantly, more jobs. Education and training reforms will lift the skill levels of those seeking employment through more competitive, responsive and accessible training institutions.

It has become painfully obvious that the Government is walking away from a whole generation of young Australians and burying its head in the sand over the extent of unemployment among young people. One reason for that may be that, in an interview on the World Today earlier this week, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) showed himself to be completely unfamiliar with the statistics relating to youth unemployment. In fact, in answer to a question from Richard Palfreyman, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are far fewer young people actually looking for work . . . about 450,000 back in 1982-83. The number is now about 290,000.

That happens to be totally fallacious. The Minister has, in fact, shown that he cannot read a simple table. The figures that he quoted are the figures for those in employment in those two years in the 15- to 19-year-old category.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the total number of unemployed, one finds that in 1983 there were about 216,000. The figure today is about 218,000. The actual rate of unemployment has risen amongst young people from 25.9 per cent to 27.3 per cent. The number of underemployed young people has gone up from 58,600 to 105,500. It is quite clear that the Government has no real conception of the problem and its extent. This is revealed by this dramatic blunder by a senior Minister.

There is an urgent need to integrate economic reform with education reform. Without the latter, without a better educated, better skilled work force, we as a nation will not be capable of taking maximum advantage of the opportunities offered by a modern, internationalised economy in a truly competitive and productive Australia. Does the Government make the vital connection? Does the Government acknowledge the overriding importance of education and training on the way not just to economic recovery but to fundamental restructuring and revitalisation of the Australian economy? The answer would have to be a resounding no.

One indicator of the difference in scope of Fightback's comprehensive policy for education and training and that of the Government's `One Job' package is the sheer amount of space the two documents devote to education and training. The Government's package gives seven pages to education and training and to the labour market. Fightback contains a comprehensive strategy covering 57 pages for education and training and a further 14 pages on labour market training programs and active assistance to help the unemployed.

These differences in scale reflect enormous differences in substance. On the one hand, Fightback presents program decisions across the whole field of education and training, totalling some $3 billion for new programs across this decade, together with a comprehensive strategy of structural change for making schools, TAFEs and universities more responsive to the needs of those they serve. Fightback provides a comprehensive alternative to Labor's doctrine of mediocrity and bureaucratic control, a doctrine which dooms young Australians to falling further and further behind their peers in other nations.

The Government's statement exemplifies the fact that education and training policy under Labor lurches from one preoccupation to the other, without any coherence or focus. In this statement schools are almost entirely neglected. The rigid centralisation and regulation of higher education which has locked out 50,000 qualified young Australians is maintained, and the focus has shifted almost entirely to TAFE.

Before turning to what the Government has done in relation to TAFE, let me draw the very clear and sharp contrast between the approach of the two sides of this Parliament to schools and to universities. There is one commitment to schools in the Government's package: an increase of $7m this financial year for upgrading facilities and equipment in non-government schools and to underpin increased student retention rates. Next year there will be a one-off $15m increase, and the following year a one-off $8m.

The first thing that has to be said about these increases in capital support for infrastructure spending is that they are derisory. Since 1981 the real value of capital grants per pupil has declined 29 per cent. Massive contributions to infrastructure spending are increasingly being called for from parents who want to exercise choice in their children's schooling. Existing needs and projected new needs for new schools have been costed by the National Catholic Education Commission at about $1 billion, yet on the present formula some 73 per cent of the capital expenditure will have to come from parish and community sources.

The families who have suffered most from the Government's irrational and ideological opposition to parents exercising schooling choice for their children are low income families. They are the ones who are most disadvantaged by the Government's efforts to prevent them exercising choice. Fightback proposes a major commitment of resources to assist low and middle income families to exercise educational choice. Under a Hewson Government capital support for non-government schools will be doubled and per capita grants for low and middle income parents will be increased by up to $490 per annum per child. Parents will also have opportunities for choice within the government school sector expanded by a schools of choice program for state school systems.

Fightback recognises what the Government does not: that there is an urgent need to lift standards across schooling, to lift standards of literacy and numeracy, and to improve language skills and levels of attainment in vital areas such as science and technology. Fightback recognises that to do this there must be a proper monitoring of standards and a willingness to invest in quality teaching. A national standards monitoring program will be established and major professional development initiatives for teachers undertaken. Under Fightback the aim will be to encourage excellence and foster choice and opportunity.
What does Mr Keating's economic statement have to say about these vital matters? Nothing; it is all too hard for Labor and so the caravan moves on.

Turning to the Government's policy for universities, the gross over-regulation of higher education is a prime reason why thousands upon thousands of young, and not so young, Australians are currently being locked out of the system. The savage inequity in the system which allows overseas students to buy a place but denies that right to Australian students is enforcing an artificial cut-off—a dividing line that says who will have the benefits of a tertiary education and who will not.

The program of the coalition will return autonomy to the universities to manage their own affairs and will remove them from the centralised industrial relations system which has locked them into rigid and inflexible structures in regard to conditions of work and salaries. The commitment of increased resources to higher education in Fightback is double that of the Government's statement, and the Government has failed completely to face up to the issue of structural reform and the creation of a student market.

Let me make one thing abundantly clear, because from his remarks earlier today the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) pretends not to understand: the coalition has an absolute commitment to fund at least an equal number of places for students as is provided for in the rolling triennial program. Therefore, any suggestion whatever that access to higher education will be narrowed by the coalition's program is totally false. The system will be better resourced, will have more places, and will therefore be more equitable.

The Government, I regret to say, is intent on spreading disinformation about the coalition's policy. It is deliberately seeking to confuse people on the issue of full fee students. The Government's suggestion that under the coalition policy most students will be paying full fees or something approaching them is completely untrue. All students who are currently funded by the taxpayer and who meet their educational obligations will continue to be funded by the coalition.

The coalition is proposing that students who do not otherwise have access to university should be allowed to gain entry on fees negotiated between the university and themselves. At present, these students are excluded completely by the Government's system of quotas. But, unlike the Government, the coalition believes Australian students are entitled to the same rights as overseas students. The Government's deliberate scare tactics do it no credit at all, and I draw the attention of the House to the fact that the Minister has never proffered a satisfactory explanation for his refusal to accord Australian students equal rights with overseas students.

The fact that TAFE has at last caught the Government's attention is welcome. There is undoubtedly a pressing need to lift the level of skills in the work force and to give young Australians training of international standard. TAFE was badly neglected by the previous Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the present Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). His preoccupation was the amalgamation of the universities with the colleges of advanced education, and TAFE was simply left out in the cold, with no attention paid to how it might relate to the new mega-institutions the then Minister was intent on forcing into existence.

The Deveson and Finn reports finally showed the tremendous needs there were in this area. Fightback made it clear that the coalition accepted the targets for growth in the training system set out in the Finn report. In particular, the Liberal and National parties accepted that by the year 2000 we should aim to have 50 per cent of 22-year-olds with at least some formal training certification, diploma or degree.

We went further than that, however, and set out a comprehensive strategy to lift the capacities of the training sector to meet the needs of young Australians—and, indeed, older Australians seeking reskilling. This strategy involved an unconditional and immediate commitment to increase TAFE funding by some $520m over the rest of this decade. This was a fully funded commitment within the Fightback program.

It also involved a commitment to work with the States to put them on a sound financial basis so that they were in a position to make their own financial commitments to fund growth in the TAFE system. This is a commitment we were able to make because, unlike the Government, we indicated we were prepared to accept, as a proper basis for discussion with the States, the tax sharing arrangements put forward by the Premiers which were rejected by the former Prime Minister in his panic about the challenge by his successor.

Unlike the Government, we did not rule out the possibility that a genuine partnership with the States for the development of TAFE was a real possibility. These two commitments together were effectively Finn option two. For ideological reasons, the Minister has preferred a complete Commonwealth takeover.

The Government has followed the lead of Fightback and recognised that there is a need for the Commonwealth to put additional resources into TAFE on a continuing basis. The new promises of TAFE funding in this statement are increases of $70m a year for each year in the 1993-95 triennium. These increases are, however, conditional on the Commonwealth getting the agreement of the States to surrender funding responsibility, and effectively control—whatever the Government may say—to the Commonwealth.

The Government also states that it will develop a new and expanded system of institutes of vocational training. This new system will build on the TAFE network. There are no details about this new system. There are many questions to be asked about it. What will its relationship be with the schools and with higher education? When the Government talks about flexible use of funds for public and private providers, is it referring to a voucher scheme? Clearly, the Government has not thought this issue through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to take part in this debate tonight on the subject of the Government's One Nation statement which, undoubtedly, judging from the reception that it has received from everybody in the community—apart from the Opposition in this Parliament—seems to have hit just the right note. When one looks across the spectrum of the nation, one sees that a wide range of groups have applauded the One Nation statement. I think it has been a great credit, not only to the Government but particularly to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), that in very difficult economic circumstances the Government has been able to put together a plan for recovery—a plan for long term expansion—which has so obviously hit the right chord and attracted support from the overwhelming number of people in the community.

PARA.TAB: I said that it has received support from a wide ranging group in the community. This ranges from the trade unions on the one hand to—and I mention this group particularly—the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales on the other. I think it is indicative of the fact that this Government is acting in the national interest. The nature and name of the statement, One Nation, picks up a theme which I think illustrates the fact that this Government not only is concerned for narrow sectional interests—as is so obvious from the policies of those opposite—but also stands for policies which seek to benefit the whole of this nation.

I have mentioned the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales. I want to make particular reference to the bulletin which it has put out entitled Manufacturers' Bulletin. This bulletin, dated 6 March, indicates quite clearly in unequivocal terms how delighted it is with the statement that the Prime Minister made so recently. On the front page of the bulletin is an article headed, `Statement puts Manufacturing Back on the Right Track'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister's Economic Statement provides a good balance between economic recovery and solving some of the economy's long-term structural problems, the President of the Chamber of Manufactures, Brian Smith, said.

PARA.TAB: "The good part about this statement is that it is not the `fistful-of-dollars' reminiscent of past recovery packages where only demand was boosted, resulting in blow-outs on the current account deficit.
"This package attempts to boost the supply-side as well.
"This statement is the first time in 20 years that an Australian Prime Minister has recognised a strong manufacturing industry as a national goal and done something about it.
"The key changes from manufacturing's perspective are:

SPEECH.PARA: .Making Australia's depreciation system more internationally competitive;
.The extra 10% development allowance for major projects;
.The speeding up of the project approvals process;
.The boost to productivity from changes in transport and energy infrastructure;
.The encouragement of private sector provision of infrastructure through special tax preferred bonds;
.Extra funding for the TAFE system to ensure a higher proportion of workers have had some vocational training;
.Greater access to start-up and patient development capital for small business via Pooled Development Funds.

PARA.TAB: "These measures help to foster a pro-business environment and boost the incentive to invest in manufacturing.

SPEECH.PARA: That is some praise from an organisation that I think historically could be described as not a particularly great friend of Labor. When we see the way that this statement has been so well received across the community is it any wonder that we hear from the Opposition the carping, irritated comment that it is annoyed that the business community has received this statement so well. When one looks at the statement, it is quite obvious that this Government has gone for an approach which is overwhelmingly in the national interest.

PARA.TAB: I also want to refer to further reports following the Prime Minister's statement. It was interesting that in the Adelaide Advertiser on the same day, 2 March, in articles in a column called `Monday Money' one of the articles written by Malcolm Newell was headed `Benefits of the Keating Plan'. Another article in the same area was headed `Hewson Policy Misses'. I think that tells a pretty interesting story about the general attitude in the community to the issue of economic recovery. On the one hand the Government that, after all, is responsible in this nation for putting us on the road to economic recovery has put in place a responsible, effective plan which will lead to economic recovery, which is in the national interest, and which has picked up the best of all the ideas that were put forward by community groups, business, small business, the unions, social policy lobby groups and others. On the other hand, we see an Opposition that has sought to put in place a policy which is called Fightback. When we look at Fightback we can now get a clear impression of the differences between the two parties. There is no doubt the community is rapidly appreciating the difference. On the one hand we have a vital, effective economic package which has been put in place by the Government; on the other hand we have an effective one dimensional approach to policy by the Opposition—a GST.

The sad thing about the Opposition is its inability to be able to develop a real and effective policy in the economic area. It has been its flaw and its failing for close on a decade now, and it certainly does not seem to be able to get out of it. As the Prime Minister has said on a number of occasions, when we look at the Opposition's package it has really been based on assumptions about what it could do that was different from the Government. As I said a moment ago, the Opposition has come up with one dimensional policy making—a GST, a GST, a GST. What is the solution to the economic problems—a GST. What is the solution to unemployment problems—a GST. What is the solution to environmental problems—a GST. What can help Fitzroy win the next premiership—a GST.
