That is the sort of approach the Opposition has got. It seems to have no policy settings at all, except simply applying a 15 per cent consumption tax.

I can tell the Opposition now that the community will not wear it. Members of the community will not wear this consumption tax; they are not interested in it at all. When the next general election comes around the community in Australia will resoundingly reject what the Opposition has put up. As far as I am concerned, that will be an important and strategic point in Australia's history because I believe that, once and for all, consumption taxes will have been put off the political agenda in this country.

There is no doubt that New Zealand is suffering very badly as a result of the consumption tax. One only has to look at the article by John Morine that appeared in the January edition of the Australian Small Business and Investing magazine headed `The G.S.T.: How Will You Cope?'. It referred specifically to small business and made some very telling points. It is clearly the case that, under the Opposition's proposals, small business will be the tax collecting agent for the Federal Tax Office. It is also the case that people in the small business community are now starting to realise that. In that article Mr Morine made the following point:

SPEECH.PARA: This article has disclosed a number of strong arguments against the introduction of GST. Of these, the most persuasive is that complying with the GST legislation will require business to divest itself of about 20 per cent of its resources. This serious redirection of resources will lower the business income subject to company income tax by the Australian Government.

What he is saying, of course, is that small business will be spending a huge amount of its resources on collecting this tax and on paying the tax on behalf of the Government. People in my electorate who are in small business do not want a bar of this. When I have written to them, spoken to them at meetings or communicated with them, I have had the overwhelming response that whatever they do, they do not want to be tax collection agents. They do not want to be collecting this tax. Furthermore, they do not want to be paying it.

PARA.TAB: As we move to the next election we are going to see a realignment of forces in this nation. I think it is fair to say that traditionally many people in small business have been supporters of the Liberal Party, and possibly of the National Party. On this occasion we are going to see them deserting the Liberal and National parties in droves because they are now becoming acutely aware of the serious implications that the GST will have for them. When they look at economic recovery they will see that, on the one hand, the Labor Government proposes economic recovery—tax cuts without a 15 per cent consumption tax. On the other hand, they will see an opposition with few policy settings, but a flat-footed adherence to this GST whatever happens. I think we will soon enough see the results of that when the next general election comes around. Members of the community are going to reject the Opposition out of hand for seeking to thrust this unwanted tax on them.

In my few remaining minutes, I want to deal with a couple of other matters. I am particularly delighted that the Government has chosen to implement such a wide ranging and important spending program in relation to infrastructure. I personally think this is long overdue, and I am delighted to see that we are now going to implement this program which will involve the expenditure of $1 billion on rail and road infrastructure over a three year period. I think it is well targeted expenditure. When I looked through the document produced by the Parliamentary Library on articles that have appeared in the national press in relation to the February economic statement, there was not one criticism that I could find of the Government's expenditure proposals in relation to infrastructure. That shows how well targeted the proposals are. Just to make it clear, there were comments in there that people wished other projects had been started as well, but I did not see one comment made in criticism of the projects that were chosen for special funding.

In addition, the Government introduced a package which will see an expenditure of $860m on increased payments to low income families over a period of three years. How welcome that was. That is $3 per week for many families. That will certainly be a very worthwhile fillip to many people in the community who are suffering at the moment.

I know that in my own electorate there are many people who are doing it tough at the moment. I certainly sympathise with them. I am pleased that we have been able in the One Nation statement to do something to help those people most in need in the community.

In addition, of course, there was an extra $720m for capital works and places in the vocational education and training sector, including TAFE. I must say I thought the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) had a fair bit of gall to be criticising the Federal Government on this score. When we look at the history of this Government over the past nearly 10 years now, one thing that we can say is an outstanding achievement of this Government is the improvement in the education system. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear the comments of the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) on the Government's One Nation package. I remind the House that this is the fourth economic statement brought down in 12 months. That really makes one ask when the Government will get its policy settings right. Of course, we have also had four Treasurers in the same period. It really makes one wonder how this Government will hang together over the next 12 months, if it goes that far. That is the scenario in which we find ourselves debating the fourth economic statement in 12 months. This is the fourth time that the Government has tried to get Australia back on the rails after the disastrous eight years of government.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Makin, referred to our coalition Fightback package as being `one dimensional'. Of course, I reject that entirely. The package put together by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and our National Party colleagues is comprehensive, well documented and has great support out in the community. I want to indicate the support of our present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for this type of initiative by quoting his remarks on changing and reforming the taxation system in Australia. These remarks are from 1985 when he recognised that Australia's taxation system needed radical change. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia faces a clear choice: that it either does something about the high marginal rates impacting on average weekly earnings and finds another base in the tax system or it doesn't.
There is a very clear choice. He is looking for another base to the taxation system. He went on to say:
Without a decent tax system, you can't in the long term keep a dynamic economy and you can't keep a fair country if only some of the people are shouldering the tax.
Who said that? Our Prime Minister. He described this much more extensively in three clear points outlining the reasons for and the advantages of a taxation system based on a GST. He said:
Let me say that if I believed that the proposed switch to a consumption tax would have dire consequences, I would not have a bar of it.
I wonder what has happened. He said:
There are three main advantages of this tax:
First, it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale tax—
What is the GST all about? It is about doing away with the wholesale sales tax system. Our Prime Minister said that it was an anomaly ridden system which, he continued:
has multiple rates, numerous exemptions and fails to tax the services sector.
Second, it will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax. No other tax has the same potential for this purpose.
No other tax, but a goods and services tax. He continued:
Third, it generates tax from those who will continue to evade or avoid income tax and that provides a useful net dividend for distribution to the rest of the community.
And earnings from this system, from accessing that black economy, will provide net income for the gentleman driving the tram.

He recognised that there were great benefits in a goods and services tax. Yet, as I said, in this package—the fourth one in 12 months—he has not introduced that tax which he was proposing and which he fully backs. One must ask: why is that?

PARA.TAB: We are having this debate tonight for two reasons: firstly, the Federal Government has to respond to a political set of circumstances to get back to setting the agenda and trying to be in front of the Opposition, because the Opposition has been running miles ahead of the Government; and, secondly, the Government has to re-stimulate the economy. There are two key factors in having this debate. There are political reasons because of the circumstances in which the Labor Government finds itself. We have a fourth statement in 12 months because the political reality is that the Government is down in the polls and the Prime Minister has to reassert his leadership in this country—or at least try to. Secondly, we have to re-stimulate the economy.

What does the One Nation package include? In order to stimulate the economy, the Prime Minister says that we need to put in about $2.3 billion by July 1993. He says that there will be a one-off family payment in April 1992—not far away—of $317m. I guess that is for the Wills by-election. There will be a cut in sales tax on cars from 20 per cent to 15 per cent. There will be small business relief of $10m.

The debate in the last two weeks has really focused on the Opposition's Fightback package and the Government's One Nation package. I believe that at the end of the day we will find that people will not study all the minutiae of both these packages, but they will ask about the credibility of the people putting those packages forward. I think it is here that we need to look at the record of the Government.

People know the record of our present Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland. That record goes something like this: overseas debt has risen by 520 per cent from $35 billion in 1983 to $183 billion now. What a record that is! In 1983 that debt was $2,000 for each man, woman and child. It is now over $10,000 per man, woman and child. For a four-member family there is an overseas debt effectively of $40,000.

In regard to the balance of payments record, 1972-73 was the last time we had a positive balance of payments in this country. We have headlines now stating that things are looking good when we have a balance of payments deficit for the month of $800m. It is just incredible that this country has sunk to that level. There has been a quantum leap in the balance of payments problem for this country in the last eight years, and I will illustrate that.

Under the previous coalition Government the balance of payments averaged $4 billion a year. That has risen to $12.9 billion, or by 320 per cent, in a short span of time and is a negative balance of payments problem for this country. In addition, there was an incredible leap in bankruptcies in the years in which our now Prime Minister was Treasurer of this country—up 159 per cent compared with the Fraser-Howard years. The level of unemployment is the highest since the Great Depression—at 10.6 per cent. One could go on commenting about the record of this Government.

It is an incredible record, a record of achievements by our Prime Minister—record unemployment, record bankruptcies—and it goes into the social welfare side of our society as well, not just the economic side. We find that there is an increasing crime rate. Virtually every aspect of crime in Australia—rape, burglary, break and enter and so on—are on the increase at a far greater rate than the population increase.

Teenage and young people suicide rates are up. Youth homelessness is an enormous problem in many of our great cities. There is disillusionment in the community with education, particularly in the tertiary sector. In schools around this country parents are concerned about falling standards. They understand that Australia is not keeping up with the rest of the world and they want a better product in our classrooms. There is a lack of vision. There are long hospital queues. Reward for effort is low. So people are finding life extremely difficult. That is the record of this Government. Last week the Government came in here with a package which it says will, as it is put in the second last line of the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . give back to us—
talking about Australians—
our sense of purpose and our confidence.

I say to the people out there: who took away our sense of purpose? Who took away our confidence? Why have people in Australia lost their sense of purpose? I say to the House that it is because of the so-called leadership given to this country and the economic policies of the last eight years. That is why people have lost confidence and that is why people have lost a sense of purpose.

PARA.TAB: In regard to reward for effort, many people say, `Why should I go out and work when I am better off on welfare?'. This Government has taken away the incentive for honest, decent, hardworking people to work. One could give plenty of examples, but time does not permit it.

The record we see here is one which, sadly, has affected the lives of many families in this country. People will not go through all the details of either of these packages but they will have a look at the credibility of the leadership of this country. When we look at that and measure up the record of our Prime Minister today, and when we look at some of the things he has said in the past, I am sure that people will have no doubt that they will elect a coalition government at the next election. Let us go back to some of our Prime Minister's notable quotes. In a speech on the 1988 Budget he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are well on the way to prosperity.

Perhaps the honourable member for Blaxland was well on the way to the Lodge at that stage—I do not know. Maybe he was, but what about the rest of us? What about the other Australians out there, the one million unemployed, the young people out of work? Our Prime Minister also said:
We won't destroy business activity, we won't destroy employment. . .
When was that? February 1990. Goodness gracious me—two years ago! And what has happened in that time? About 300,000 people have been cast onto the scrap heap of unemployment. He said:
We won't destroy business activity . . .

No, just another 15,000 or so small businesses went broke during that time. What an incredible statement. Why should Australians trust the honourable member for Blaxland when he made those statements in the recent past but has not delivered? There is no way in which the One Nation package will deliver long term benefits to this country. The Prime Minister said in March 1990:
We won't let there be a recession.
What have we had? The worst recession in 60 years in the meantime. In 1991 he said:
I think a lot of the lay-offs are behind us. I think they laid them off last year . . .

But what has happened in the meantime? Another 200,000 people are unemployed, out on the scrap heap. That is the record of this Government; that is the record of this Prime Minister. Over the next year the Australian people will be looking at the credibility of the Prime Minister and the record of the future Prime Minister of this country, the present Leader of the Opposition. There is no doubt what the Australian people will do when the next election comes around. They will abandon this approach to running Australia, the One Nation approach. It has been cobbled together in a few weeks in response to the Fightback package. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —A little later in my remarks I will deal with the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Braddon, in respect of credibility. I am sure that there is not a member of this House who does not feel for those wage earners and their families who currently are out of work and are looking for work.

PARA.TAB: The very clear and positive objective in the One Nation package brought down by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last week is to give a lift to the economy, to get economic activity under way, so that in the coming four years 800,000 new jobs—meaningful jobs, jobs that will improve the infrastructure and the economic performance of this country—will be generated.

We will not be harping about the waterfront. It is fascinating that when the Opposition has learned a song about a sector of the economy it cannot forget it, and it is oblivious to improvements that take place between the time the song is learned and the current time.

We will push on to improve infrastructure, road and rail services, and the overall efficiency of the engines of this country. The $2.3 billion package of expenditure on rail, road and port connections will greatly improve our transport systems. Thousands of jobs will be generated in those industries. The cost of carrying out those works will be substantially lower because of the current flat state of the economy. Jobs will be generated by this investment in infrastructure, and works will be carried out at a substantial discount because of the keenness of competition. Those improvements will generate continuing economic benefits to the economy and, most of all, we will get an improved infrastructure.

In the present state of the economy, this is the time to generate major capital works such as those announced in the One Nation package. I will not go through all the depreciation measures included in the package, but the short description of them is that they considerably reduce the period over which a business can write off investments in new plant and equipment. That will lead to an improvement in productive capacity, the generation of jobs, and an improvement in our competitive position both at home and abroad, and it will lead to decisions by companies to go into new plant and equipment. One company in my own area, the Hunter, is now looking at six new projects which have come back to live consideration as a result of the Government's package announced last week.

Turning to the tourism industry, the 4 per cent depreciation rate on tourism buildings and accommodation buildings will give a substantial lift to investment in the tourism industry and again create the infrastructure we need to deal with the growing numbers of tourists coming to this country.

Again in my region, that investment in new buildings and structures will generate demand for steel and steel products that will flow through to BHP Newcastle and BHP Whyalla through the purchase of new steel rails. That will in turn help that region and the local economy and the people living there, and it will recreate jobs.

Added support is to be provided for young Australians in terms of assistance for apprentices: increased payments to employers to take on first-year apprenticeships, to retain second-year apprenticeships and to deal with other apprentices to enable them to complete their time or even to get back to work under group apprenticeship schemes. All those items will help the employment position and help us in our task of ensuring that, as the economy picks up, we have an adequate supply of skilled people.

I want to make mention very quickly of the rail improvements. The improvement to the national main line rail freight system is very welcome. I am very pleased that the Government is tying that investment to a corresponding improvement in operational performance. The first fundamental point is that there is better equipment and the second is that there are better ways of operating that equipment—the operational practices and the operational arrangements. I am pleased especially for my colleague the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) that I see $3.5m being invested in upgrading railway workshops at Port Augusta. That is important. It is a great city and it is a great community. I must say something in respect of the local member; he has my commendation as well.

I put it to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), that when upgrading takes place on the Newcastle to Brisbane railway line, particular care be taken to ensure that where bridges are replaced, they not be replaced on existing alignments which carry the old speed constraints. It would be useless to be squandering money by replacing bridges that are long overdue for replacement without straightening out the tracks so that trains can run at high speed on those tracks. In looking at the rail improvements to be carried out between Brisbane and Melbourne and right through to Adelaide, ultimately we are looking at a much more sensible arrangement between rail, sea and road, where each form of transport will be performing the task to which it is most suited economically, socially and technically.

The investment in roads is again part of the continuing policy of this Government since 1983 to establish a national highway grid right round this country linking our State capitals and linking Adelaide, Alice Springs and Darwin, and Brisbane and Cairns. The addition of the Sturt Highway and the Newell Highway gives alternative links between Adelaide and Melbourne through to Brisbane. The Government is about bringing together the communities of this nation, bringing the markets and productive centres of each part of Australia closer together. Travel times are reduced and travel conditions are made safer.

When we looked at tourism we found that 91 per cent of passenger journeys in this country are made by private car. So, regardless of what role trucks play, there is an expectation by Australians that there are safe and adequate road facilities for them when they move about their country. For many people in this nation there is no alternative. They do not have easy access to airports and they do not have access to rail services, and they do need road services.

I turn now to the assistance to small business. I will come to the goods and services tax a little later, but I want to state what this Government included in the package last week for small business. The package includes a substantial increase in capital gains tax relief for small and growing businesses, which will increase capital mobility and growth in that sector. There is a three-month extension to small business for 1991-92 company tax payments. There is no increase until 1994-95 in the prescribed minimum superannuation levy for businesses with payrolls of $500,000 or less. There is a tripling of the funding support to $12m for assisting small and medium enterprises into export markets through the export access program. Small business, like all businesses in this country, will benefit from the improved depreciation arrangements. They will enable many of them to carry out plant replacement and plant and equipment upgrades that they would not be doing without the assistance of the increased depreciation allowances.

In the export access program there are smaller firms which do not have sufficient in-house expertise and resources to maintain their own export development programs, and in that group there is a widespread, latent demand amongst those businesses to get out into the export markets. But they do not have the expertise or the backing. The export access program allocation of $12m will mean that something like 700 small businesses will now be able to benefit under that program rather than the 250 that were able to benefit under the $4m that was available in that program. It will improve access to the program by businesses in all States and regions of Australia and will enable additional markets, particularly in Asia, to be targeted. That is about doing something positive for small business, not something that is destructive of small business, to which I will refer in a moment in respect of the goods and services tax.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Braddon talked about credibility. Let me say something about credibility and this publication from the Opposition, the Fightback! document. What I will quote shows the arrogance of this document and the arrogance that comes through persistently from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Anybody in this country who queries or questions what is in this document is treated with that same arrogance by members of the Opposition and the Leader of the Opposition. I turn to page 301 where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . for a majority of groups, those in the lowest income decile enjoy above average proportionate increase in their real disposable incomes. Thus, the fairness of the package for the whole population stands up when put under the group-by-group microscope. The package is fair for all Australians: anyone who says otherwise does not want to face the facts;

It is the Opposition that does not want to face the facts. That has been evident this week when those opposite have been decimated by the Prime Minister and decimated by the production of the Treasury survey of the goods and services tax. I turn to the question of credibility. Page 116 of the document states:
The key elements of our private sector strategy are:
.we will continue to provide preferred tax treatment to the family home—in other words we will not tax the family home;
I do not know who the author of that statement on page 116 was. I turn to page 225 under the heading `Calculating the Goods and Services Tax Impact on a New Home' where it states:
In the case of an average home the net Goods and Services Tax impact is $2856 after discounting the effect of abolishing wholesale sales tax and petrol tax.

There are the inaccuracies, the misrepresentations and, dare I say, the untruths in that document. It is a fraudulent document; it is a sham. Let me go to the case of a family with two children and one income of $20,000 per year. I do not go to figures calculated by me or estimated by other politicians in this building; I go to the Taxation Commissioner's documents and his estimates of product consumed by a baker when it is assessing a baker's income tax return. The Taxation Commissioner over a long period has established that a baker uses for himself $178 worth of product and for each child between four and 16 years of age the amount is $89.

PARA.TAB: When I go through and add up the Taxation Commissioner's figures established for the consumption by a family of two adults and two children of the products of the baker, butcher, fruiterer-greengrocer, grocer and milk vendor—all the basic essentials that are currently tax free in this country without a goods and services tax—I get an annual purchase figure of $8,182. The GST on that is $1,226. The income tax reduction for that family under GST is $814. That family is $412 a year worse off.

All this cant this week from the Opposition about being worried about people on incomes of $20,000 and less is shown to be hypocrisy by those figures. They are not my figures. They are not estimates. They are the hard numbers used by the Taxation Commissioner in assessing the incomes of each of those categories of employment.

Then we go to what GST is about. What those opposite are saying to people is, `We are going to get this country going. We are going to put everybody on their feet. We are going to impose a 15 per cent tax on everything you can put into your mouth and onto your back'. It is as simple as that. It is a brilliant plan! It will reduce inflation, despite its inflationary effects; it will reduce interest rates; and it will generate employment.

The Leader of the Opposition reminds me of the salesman with the spiel who says, `Have I got a deal for you. I am going to put the price of bread, butter, milk, jam and fruit up by 15 per cent. But don't you worry about that, because you are all going to have more money in your pocket'.People are not that stupid. They know that it is impossible and they know that what those opposite are trying to do to them is shift the tax burden from higher income earners down the line to middle to lower income earners.

I have not got time to go through all the examples. I have mentioned a couple of them. They are there. But in the case of small business the GST would be an absolute nightmare. We would go from 71,000 tax gatherers under the current sales tax system to about two million tax gatherers. It is not just the people in small business who are involved; it is all the other people doing transactions—offices, trusts and all sorts of associations. Even the punters get caught. Lotteries, the TAB, the racing industry are all exempt from tax under the GST, which means everything they buy is subject to tax. That means that even the odds go down for the punters. Those opposite could not even let the punters alone; the punters are caught up in it. But for average small businesses the cost of GST collection is about an additional 2 per cent per annum to their expenditure. On a margin of net 3 per cent, 2 per cent is most of the profit.

Let me just refer to the Canadian example. I have one sentence to finish. This is the Canadian experience of the goods and services tax. I say this loudly and clearly to Australian small business. The statement is:
The findings from this survey—

SPEECH.PARA: of small business—
clearly illustrate the horrific impact. . .

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: the GST has had on small and medium-sized Canadian businesses in its first several months of application.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Thank you for your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—It is no wonder that the Australian people are confused about the Opposition's proposal when we hear from a fairly longstanding member of the Government who further clouds the issues. But I am sure that as time goes by the issues will become much clearer. It is really no wonder that there is at this stage of the week thorough confusion out there in the electorate about this debate.

PARA.TAB: The Government's only weapon has been to attempt to cloud the issues at every step. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has resorted day after day to his old tools of trade—invective, abuse, sarcasm, misrepresentation. But it is interesting that the word that has come up in this debate very often tonight—and I think this is the key word—is credibility. It seems that the focus is on the Prime Minister himself. It will be his credibility that will be tested at the next election. In fact, it will be tested sooner than that; it will be tested in the Wills by-election. People will not believe him. Why should they believe this man who has constantly and consistently misled the Australian people over the years that he was Treasurer? Nothing, I do not believe, will cloud that memory, for he stood in this place time after time and he went out into the electorate and misrepresented to the Australian people the extent of the problems that this country was facing. He lulled them into a false sense of security.

Time and again in this debate we have been reminded of the things that the Prime Minister said. It started early—I remember, with my interest in economics—with the J-curve. We all went back to our economics textbooks to find out what this fantastic J-curve was. Day after day in here it was the J-curve that was going to save Australia. But the J-curve turned into a U-turn and we heard nothing about the J-curve. Then it was going to be the soft landing; it was just around the corner. For months and months it was going to be a soft landing and, `Oh, I won't let there be a recession. No, you can trust me. There won't be a recession while I am the Treasurer of this country.'

For months and months we talked about this `r' word. Do honourable members remember the reluctance of the Government? For a long time it was a sort of downturn; then it got to be a significant downturn; then suddenly the `r' word slipped out and we started talking about the recession.

Ultimately, this contest that we are facing in Wills, and ultimately in the country in the next 12 to 15 months, will be about credibility. I think that the Prime Minister, when he was Treasurer of this country, did so much damage to the fabric of our society, to families and to young people. We have only to look at the unemployment rate among our young people to realise the damage he did there—so much damage that nothing will wipe the memory of his activities as Treasurer from the minds of the Australian people.

I believe the die is cast. I think the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) knows that. I think Government members know that. They know that the odds are totally stacked against them at the next election; they are stacked against them because, when the chips are down, the Australian people will look at the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland, and they will not believe what he said.

Our fundamental criticism of the Prime Minister's One Nation statement has been that it is incredibly dangerous as a document; it is irresponsible and it is a desperate grab for votes. Of course, we have pointed out ad nauseam that it is unfunded, and in that sense we are saying, `Where is the money coming from?'. The Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) gleefully got up here one day and could hardly help himself explaining that if it were funded it would not be fiscal stimulus. It was really exciting for him to explain that little bit of economics to us. But the very point that we were making was that this fiscal stimulus at this time is very risky. In effect, in the short term there would probably be no effect at all, but the longer term effect is one of great risk. We could see the Australian economy plunge back into a boom-bust type cycle once again.

The Prime Minister's credibility is once again on the line. He is prepared to take that risk. He is prepared to take further risks with the future of this country and with our children. I believe that, when it comes to the crunch, he will be rejected comprehensively by the people of Australia and that he will be judged for the way in which he did his job when he was Treasurer.

There are, nevertheless—and I am not going to damn the Prime Minister with faint praise here—some initiatives in this One Nation statement that we applaud. Needless to say, the initiatives that I am talking about are ones that have come out of the Fightback package. He has at least picked up some of our policies. I represent a tourist based area and some of the policies that the Government is talking about in the tourism and aviation industries are indeed welcome. I was quite impressed that, when the Prime Minister brought down his statement, he actually used the word tourism. He started talking about tourism. We had not heard that from the former Prime Minister. Of course, we have had a series of fairly lacklustre tourism Ministers. But at least there was a recognition—and I applaud that—that the tourism industry actually exists. The Prime Minister describes the tourism industry in his statement as one of the economic stars of the 1990s. I certainly agree with that. The changes that he announced in his statement to amortisation rates on tourist income producing buildings are welcome and they will allow buildings to be written off over 25 years instead of 40 years.

One of the criticisms of the tourism industry in recent times has been the extent of foreign ownership. That has certainly been an issue in my own electorate from time to time, although of course it is true that we would not have the hotels and resorts that we have without foreign investment. On balance, I am quite prepared to accept that there are positive benefits from that sort of investment. It has provided jobs and, of course, it goes on providing income for Australia.

However, I believe—and I think all honourable members would agree—that it is desirable that Australian companies and individuals are encouraged to invest in tourism. There has been a marked reluctance on behalf of Australians to do that. I think we have not taken a long enough term perspective on tourism as a profitable area for investment. Perhaps our banks and financial institutions are somewhat at fault there and some of the people and countries that have been prepared to invest here have taken that longer term perspective. The Japanese are particularly notable for that, being prepared to take the longer term outlook and to accept lower returns in the short term with a view to recouping their investment and getting a decent return on it in the longer term.

As we find a recession around the world, we have now seen a marked downturn in foreign investment in this country and despite our best efforts to continue to attract that foreign investment, the extent of that downturn has become very marked. Foreign investment in the tourism sector fell from $3.9 billion in 1989 to $1.9 billion in 1991. That is a significant fall indeed.

If we are going to see the tourism industry, to use the Prime Minister's words, as a `star' of the 1990s, we will have to provide infrastructure for the sort of tourists that we expect to attract to this country. The projections for tourism from overseas through to the end of the decade are very optimistic. If we are going to meet those projections, we have to have the infrastructure, the hotels and the tourist attractions in place for people to visit this country. Those accelerated amortisation rates and indeed the matching accelerated depreciation on other fixed assets—things that go in the hotels—are also welcome, with the increase in the rates for depreciation for those up to 20 per cent.

As I said, the Prime Minister's statement picked up a lot of the Fightback package in respect of tourism and aviation. The latter is one area in which I believe the Opposition's policies have been well ahead of the Government's. We have consistently been in favour of the third runway at Sydney Airport. The Government has constantly dragged the chain on that; it has been the longest, most drawn out process one could imagine. However, the Opposition has been way ahead in all its policies, while the shadow Minister has been way ahead of any of his counterparts on the Government side in recognising the potential that tourism has for this country. It has taken a former Minister of this Government, the honourable John Brown, to do what the Government ought to have been doing, and that is promoting tourism and making people aware of the potential tourism has in this country. We were not getting that leadership from the Government for a long time. It was only the other night that I heard the Prime Minister, for the first time, say something about the tourism industry. I congratulate him for that; it is good to see that the Government is catching up here.

Airlines are a very important part of the tourism industry. We have just witnessed a real fiasco in terms of airline deregulation. One can talk about the two-airline policy until the cows come home; the Government blames it on the Opposition—well, the circumstances were very different when it was introduced. We could have otherwise had a one-airline policy, but history shows that we developed a two-airline policy; eventually that went by the board, as it should have, and then we had deregulation.

I was quite astounded when I realised how uneven the playing field was for the entry of other airlines into the airline industry. I am not going to go to great lengths to go in to bat for Mr Grey and Compass, but the plain fact is that it is a very uneven playing field. The reason for that is that there were no terminal facilities available.

In my home airport of Coolangatta, all the terminal facilities there, without exception—even the old East-West terminal—are owned by either Ansett or Australian Airlines. When I say `owned', I mean they have long term leases. Immediately prior to airline deregulation right across the country, the Government gave long term leases on all the facilities to Australian Airlines and to Ansett and only gave the backdoor entry to newcomers. In other words, there were provisions in the leases that any incoming operator was to negotiate with one of the existing lessees. Of course that meant that any new operator was going to be very much disadvantaged.

The Government has recognised that. I do not want to speculate on why it went ahead with those leases. One could attribute all sorts of motives to the Government but now the Government is talking about what should have been done in the first place, and that is provide common user terminals. The coalition has urged the provision of those for some time. We will go much further in respect of airport management. We will privatise airports. Coolangatta, my own home base, is an ideal prospect in terms of privatisation. It is one of the few Federal Airport Corporation airports that makes a profit, and I know that it would be a very attractive privatisation proposition for a local consortium.

The Opposition would also refine the role of the Australian Tourism Commission. We are committed to maintaining its funding but we will give it a much sharper marketing focus. There are some things in the package that we have been prepared to accept. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This important debate affords honourable members an opportunity to reflect on the vastly different approaches to economic management offered by the Australian Labor Government and its conservative Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Australia, as are other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, is in a recession, which like booms and recoveries seem to be inevitable features of the business cycle. Downturns have occurred in the Australian economy every seven or eight years since the Second World War. The last two—in 1982-83 and in 1974-75—were greatly worsened by world recessions, while that of 1967 was diminished somewhat by the impact of the early Vietnam War boom.

This recession has in part been the international response to the stock market collapse of 1987 when, in order to avoid a repeat of what occurred in 1929, Western governments aimed to maintain confidence by boosting liquidity. Of course the situation turned out to be quite different from that of 1929, and the countercyclical measures used actually became procyclical. This caused problems with our external account via an overheated economy and action needed to be taken to restrain economic activity. Our own recession was then further exacerbated by the rural crisis and the downturns in some of our key export markets, particularly Japan and North America.

The key feature of this Government since its election in 1983 has been its commitment to structural change and building an open, competitive and vigorous economy with a diverse export base, making its independent way in the Asia-Pacific region. We have boosted the service sector and those competitive parts of manufacturing, reduced the economy's dependence on primary industry exports and reformed micro sectors of the economy which had suffered from the neglect of successive coalition governments.

This commitment has always been accompanied by an emphasis on compassion and equity during this process of economic reform. Likewise, One Nation is not therefore simply a response to the current recession. It represents further progress in Labor's reform strategy of the internationalisation of the Australian economy and the maintenance of social compassion.

The Opposition parties have also been looking at economic reform in the context of recession and last November released their own policy package, Fightback, which offers an alternative approach to Australia's predicament. I would like to say a few words about that. The centrepiece of the Opposition's package is the 15 per cent tax on all goods and services, which would raise about $18 billion net. That would be used to fund the abolition of payroll tax, petroleum excise and some customs duty which are paid now almost exclusively by business. The personal income tax cuts, biased heavily in favour of the well-off, will be funded by fiscal drag. This simply means that people pay more income tax as they go into higher tax brackets due to inflation, not due to higher real wages. These income tax cuts do not require a GST burden; they can be funded out of fiscal drag.

The Opposition also proposes a significant reduction in Government services and spending of about $6 billion net, which would actually have to be a good deal more severe than that because the revenue shortfalls have already been identified and do not come out in the Opposition's package. Fightback is nothing more than a set of proposals to redistribute income—and therefore wealth—from the needy to the wealthy. It is all about setting a few policy mechanisms and then forgetting about the recession. It proposes no measures aimed at economic recovery.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:
That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Robert Brown—I require the question to be put forthwith without debate.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Instead of providing an economic stimulus, the re-distributional effects of the Opposition's consumption tax and its large expenditure reductions can be expected to have an immediate contractionary outcome for the economy. It is, in other words, about government getting out of economic activity.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, the Commonwealth Treasury analysis released this week estimates that if Fightback were implemented the economy would not grow for some years to come, inflation would rise and overall as many as 70 per cent of Australians would be worse off. Table 3 in the Treasury's papers shows that all taxpayers earning less than $35,000 a year would be worse off under the Opposition's package.

All this should not be very surprising, given the approach of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to economic policy. The Labor Party is quite happy to consult with and seek advice from those sectors of the community that actually run the economy: that is, business leaders, trade unions, the State governments, various statutory authorities and those who do or do not benefit from economic activity, such as the representatives of welfare recipients. Members of the Opposition, under the Leader of the Opposition, listen to no-one except the theoretical colleagues of the former professor from academia. So they ruminate about abstract concepts while we govern.

Let me say that the process of government is not merely about setting macro-economic policy levers at the right setting. It is not about set and forget. Certainly, market signals must play a part, but within national, political and social objectives. Within this context, economic modelling is the preserve of the economic purist but is only one tool available to government. The Opposition, unfortunately, has made it an obsession.

Labor's approach is altogether different. By the end of 1991 the Government had become aware of the likelihood that this particular cycle would see a fairly weak recovery mode. The Government took advice on what measures were needed to force the pace of growth, and decided on a level of stimulus in line with the recommendations it received from a wide ranging process of consultation during the early part of this year. It received various recommendations from business, unions, welfare representatives, corporations and State governments. The stimulus that was agreed on by almost universal consensus now amounts to $2.3 billion, compared with what is effectively a neutral package from the Opposition. After four consecutive Budget surpluses formulated during the boom of the late 1980s, a deficit is now appropriate to end the downturn in the cycle and to speed up the recovery phase.

There are two principal advantages to the Government's package of measures. Firstly, the one-off social equity payment to families in receipt of family allowance, plus the permanent increase in family allowance supplement payments, provides a quick boost to confidence and expenditure at the cost of $300m. This is accompanied by an immediate reduction in sales tax and, therefore, the price of new motor vehicles. Secondly, all the other revenue and expenditure measures are designed not only to help stimulate economic activity but also to contribute to Labor's longer term goals of the reform of the micro-economic structure. The major measures include $1 billion for the upgrading of Australia's national infrastructure in order to boost the efficiency of our transport system, a restructuring of our electricity generating and supply grid, $750m dollars to expand and improve the TAFE educational system, and a new, more competitive, capital depreciation regime to reduce by half the write-off time for assets and to encourage investment in new technologies.

Before the One Nation package was formulated I, like many other people, was consulted by the Prime Minister on the appropriate initiatives to undertake. Not being short of ideas I, of course, wrote a couple of letters to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—

TALK.START.PARA: —Personally?

—An avenue that was, of course, not available to honourable members opposite, who are being rather noisy. I suggested an injection of about $3 billion into the economy to stimulate economic growth—and, in fact, $2.3 billion was announced in this statement; a firm financial commitment by the Federal Government to the multifunction polis; the standardisation of rail links, particularly between Adelaide and other capital cities and ports; a tougher approach to the dumping of foreign products on Australian markets—and I am pleased to note the announcement of a tougher food labelling regime in this respect; some direct initiatives to assist the car industry so important to Adelaide, which has now received a reduction in sales tax; assistance to homeless people—there are a number in my seat, and the Government has announced the $5m package made available to emergency relief organisations during this year and the next, particularly to outfits such as the Salvation Army and the Adelaide Central Mission in the middle of my seat; and further assistance to the restructuring process in the textile, clothing and footwear sector, which has been granted an additional $61m.

PARA.TAB: Many of these measures are of particular benefit to regional economies such as that of South Australia. As a State with a larger manufacturing base than most, it is imperative that producers not be inhibited from investing in technologies that maximise productivity growth. The new depreciation rules will definitely advantage an economy such as that of South Australia. It is also imperative that we have efficient transport links to the rest of the country, and the standardisation of the Adelaide-Melbourne rail line will do this, as will the upgrading of the rail links to Port Adelaide and the expenditure of over $60m on highway improvements between Adelaide, Sydney and Brisbane.

The reduction in the sales tax on new motor cars has already been of benefit to General Motors at Elizabeth and Mitsubishi at Tonsley Park, whose products fell by around $800 per unit. This reduction in sales tax and increased production will be of substantial benefit to the local automotive components industry. The multifunction polis at Gillman in Adelaide will also benefit from the contribution of $40m towards initial construction. The MFP is a key to saving Australia's future as an economy based around industries of the future and integrated into the Asia-Pacific region. But, before overseas companies can be expected to put their money into this project, the Australian public purse needs to show some commitment to the project, and this allocation of $40m dollars does just that.

I note in passing for those, particularly honourable members opposite, who believe that such high-technology centres can be left entirely to the market for development, that Tsukuba City, North of Tokyo, which I visited last year—an extremely successful MFP—absorbed $10 billion of public funds before private corporate capital moved in to produce high-tech developments in any sizeable quantity. I do not believe we will need that level of public investment, but some will be required, and we are now giving it.

These and other measures outlined in the One Nation document will return the economy to low inflationary growth, provide for the creation of 800,000 jobs over four years and, as the cycle moves on and up, return the Budget to surplus. In addition, the Government's package will deliver personal tax cuts so that most Australians will pay a maximum rate of 30c in the dollar without a consumption tax.

All this is in stark contrast to the Opposition's approach, which is largely passive. Labor is taking positive steps to kick-start and reform the economy. The Opposition, on the other hand, has placed a taboo on positive initiatives being taken by the Government. It appears that poor quality roads, decrepit railways and weak technical and vocational training can be fixed up by the imposition of a tax on cornflakes. It cannot. The rest of the community recognises that it cannot. There has been a hugely positive response to One Nation from wide sections of the community who were, of course, consulted during its formulation, including people such as business leader John Prescott from BHP and the former Liberal Party boss, John Elliott, as well as the media.

It is no wonder that the Opposition has dropped into paranoia mode and is now blaming the messengers who brought the bad news of this positive community response—messengers such as the Sydney Morning Herald and the ABC—and has then condemned the Treasury for doing its proper job and exposing the glaring weaknesses in methodology to be found in the Opposition's package, or mouthing the cliche `unfunded' for a program designed to be stimulatory, or shouting `inflationary' at a Government that has produced the lowest inflation rate for three decades.

The Australian public now has a base to compare Government and Opposition—either interventionist stimulation replete with social compassion, or a free market set and forget redistribution from the needy to the greedy. We can all see already which way the public is going to go. In fact, as we have seen over the last two weeks, Fightback is already finished.

After two weeks of parliamentary scrutiny, it is clear that in the first place its figures do not add up. But, if they did, what they would produce, all other things being equal, is higher inflation, no national income growth for a few years, no reduction in unemployment for the same period of years, and a huge redistribution of national income from needy families to business and to those on higher incomes.

In the hope that some of my constituents from Adelaide are listening, I close with a message about what they can expect as an immediate result of this package, in case they think it is merely about macro-economic reform and changing the settings.

On 2 April 1992, a one-off payment of between $125 and $250 will be provided to family allowance recipients. In addition, low income working families on family allowance supplement will receive a boost to their payment of $3 per child per week. A two-child family receiving family allowance supplement will be more than $400 better off over the coming year. Job Search and Newstart allowees and pensioners and beneficiaries with children will have their additional child payments increased by about the same amount. If we aggregate these payments, about 9,100 families in the electorate of Adelaide, which I represent, will receive a total of more than $3 1/4m as a result of the Prime Minister's One Nation statement. This money will provide a boost to local spending. Much of it will end up in the tills of local businesses, who will see what it means to get this economy going again, to kick-start it and to move it into the 1990s on a sound fiscal and economic growth basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel I owe the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) an apology. Since his entry into this Parliament at the last election, I have always regarded him as a lightweight. I now find myself having been under a misapprehension, because tonight he has told the House and his colleagues in the Labor Party that he has the ear of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Prime Minister contacted the honourable member for Adelaide and asked him to help draft the One Nation economic statement. The honourable member for Adelaide, again as he has told us tonight, bravely rose to the occasion. He put pen to paper and wrote to the Prime Minister and, believe it or not, the Prime Minister almost entirely adopted the honourable member for Adelaide's suggestions. Good heavens! Here I am, having never heard him speak in the Parliament, having seen no evidence of his contribution to this Parliament, now finding that he was really a heavyweight behind the scenes. It is true that it is best in life to talk quietly and carry a big stick.

PARA.TAB: I am sure the members of the Government would be interested to know that the true architect of the One Nation strategy was actually the honourable member for Adelaide, not the Prime Minister or the factional heavies. So full marks to the honourable member for Adelaide for telling us so modestly tonight that he has been a principal architect of One Nation. Why is that something he would boast about—if it were true, that is? For heaven's sake, he really ought to hang his head in shame for being a participant in what is essentially a political document.

If I had to differentiate between the Fightback package of the coalition and the economic statement of the Government, I would say that one is a political document wholly and solely to buy the Government out of trouble, compared with a detailed, sophisticated, fully documented and fully funded economic statement. It is typical of the New South Wales right wing, which threw up the Prime Minister to occupy the Lodge, to reduce national interest to private interest and to substitute the job security of millions for the job security of one—the honourable member for Blaxland.

It seems to me that the best way to sum up the One Nation strategy is to describe it as a `fingers crossed' strategy: let us buy now, borrow, and just hope that enough time will pass for things to improve so that we can just get into the next election. Even if the honourable member for Adelaide came down in the last shower—as it seems from his contribution tonight that he did—the people of Australia certainly did not. That strategy, one of deceit, most certainly will not succeed.

There is one other aspect of the honourable member for Adelaide's speech that caught my attention, other than that self-proclaimed major contribution to the One Nation strategy, and that is that he said, remarkably, that the Opposition's Fightback package is passive compared with the proactive One Nation—in the terminology of academics such as the honourable member for Adelaide.

It is passive, is it, to abolish $9.6 billion worth of wholesale sales tax—the hidden tax that all consumers and businesses pay but are not really aware of? It is passive, is it, to reduce income tax by one-third, by $13 billion? It is passive, is it, to abolish fuel excise, currently at 26c a litre? It is passive, is it, to abolish the compulsory superannuation levy, and passive to abolish the training guarantee levy and customs duty, and the coal export levy—$20 billion in all?

When the honourable member speaks about an economic strategy needing to be proactive, he really means handouts, subsidies, tariffs, bounties, some way of a government choosing one industry, or a segment of an industry, to assist ahead of another—in other words, going weak at the knees, depending on which is the most powerful lobby group or special interest group. That is his idea of `proactive'. Our idea of assistance to industry is to remove the level of taxation presently crushing our industries and our businesses. People speak of assistance to export industries. We are abolishing wholesale sales tax, which is a $1.7 billion impost on our export industries. Overnight, they will be $1.7 billion more competitive.

Let us get the terminology right. When the Government speaks of assistance, it means buying the votes of special interest groups by way of borrowed taxpayers' funds. When the Opposition speaks of assistance, it means real alleviation of the taxation burden and the clearing of the impediments for an efficient industry, such as reform of the labour market and the waterfront, and micro-economic reform of the transport and handling system.

Let us not have any of the fantasy of the honourable member for Adelaide, with his vanity and conceit, proclaiming to us—and to his constituents, who no doubt will be the poor recipients of thousands of Hansard copies of that speech of his—that he is the Prime Minister's right-hand man. Nor do we want any of his nonsense that the One Nation policy is proactive because it spends some borrowed money on infrastructure. By the Government's own admission, we already have a deficit of $5.6 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reckless.

—It is utterly reckless, as the honourable member for Goldstein advises the House. Moreover, according to Access Economics, our Budget deficit could be $9 billion. Remember that figure—$9 billion? I seem to remember that when the honourable member for Blaxland became Treasurer he threw that figure at the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and other members of the former Fraser Government, year in and year out. Of course, the $9 billion in 1983 never materialised. Eventually the honourable member for Blaxland had to come in and admit that there really was never going to be $9 billion. That was Treasury's worst case scenario, which never eventuated. Now the Government has told us that it has a deficit of $5.6 billion. It has borrowed another $2 1/2 billion, so it is getting very close to what Access Economics fears will be a $9 billion deficit. Is it any wonder that we now have a foreign debt of $145 billion net?

PARA.TAB: I know that those whom the honourable member for Adelaide declares will be listening to his burst of wisdom tonight will think that these billions of dollars roll off my

SPEECH.PARA: tongue easily. They do not. They are staggering amounts that cannot be easily dismissed. They mean that this Government is hopelessly out of control in its spending and, moreover, that the nation's borrowing debt is so heavy that it will plague generations to come.

PARA.TAB: Australians have to understand that we will not solve the foreign debt very easily. An incoming government utilising the Fightback package can have a drastic effect on labour relations, the wage fixing system, the waterfront and the efficiency of our land transport system. Our rail freight is losing $5 billion a year. We never hear discussed that V/Line is losing $5m a day in Victoria. Moreover, the Fightback package will immediately boost business to the tune of the eradication of $20 billion. We can do all that, although none of us would be so foolhardy as to put a timetable on the benefits flowing back to the Australian people. But they do know that we will make an immediate start and, provided there is a change of attitude in conjunction with the fiat of a coalition government, I believe there is hope for this country and that unemployment can be reduced.

Foreign debt cannot be easily erased and it is consuming up to 20 per cent of our monthly exports. We have a trading imbalance running to the tune of some $15 billion a year and interest repayments of 20 per cent on foreign debt. We have very grave problems. If there is one message that people need to grasp more than any about the Government's economic statement, it is this: the promises it makes are phoney—if not immediately, in the near future—because they are not funded. It is borrowed money.

The Government is already in significant Budget deficit and this further spending on infrastructure and expansion of the public sector will only add $2.5 billion to the existing $5.5 billion Budget deficit. I very much fear that will have the effect of pushing up interest rates, particularly as the Government enters the capital borrowing markets.

In drawing to a conclusion, I again wish to put before the House the benefits of the Fightback package, particularly as they affect my rural constituency of Gippsland. The farming community desperately needs some injection of incentive, as do all small and medium sized businesses, big business, individuals and families. That is what is missing from society and from business communities generally: incentive—incentive for businesses to reinvest and grow, and to create jobs and incentives for families to take responsibility, especially in the education and health fields. Quite frankly, there needs to be a significant reduction in the level of business input costs and the taxation levels on working men and women and their families.

Until we bring about that low cost environment so that input costs are reduced across the board, we will not get an economic revival in this country. Leave aside all the economic jargon and the huge figures. As I said earlier, their impact is often lost. People have asked me, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) and other colleagues, `What hope is there for the future? Australia is gone. What can we possibly do to bring about change?' The answer is simple: lower the burden of taxation on business and individuals so as to bring down the level of input costs to provide incentive.

The Fightback package has been widely received by the Australian electorate. We in the coalition do not rest on our laurels. We intend to go out and if we have to stand toe to toe with Government members and slug it out, we will do so because we know we have a blueprint for the future which outlines a vision of the Australia we want to bring about. We have won the confidence of the Australian people and we intend to retain that confidence and win the next election.

Motion (by Mr Robert Brown) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it saddens me that, despite many months of professional and detailed approaches to both the Federal and the State governments and appropriate Ministers and departments responsible for our health services, many hospitals and nursing homes are facing a crisis situation of major proportions. No wonder many Australians today are cynical of government. We know that the major problem that exists within our bush nursing hospitals relates to the classification of those hospitals, excluding them from public hospital arrangements under Medicare. Unfortunately, the shuffling of responsibilities and buck-passing between the States and the Federal Government is confusing any satisfactory resolution of the issues.

PARA.TAB: Even worse, government policies and guidelines are continually changing, leaving these small groups of dedicated people extremely frustrated and almost beside themselves in trying to cope with the rapidity of such change. This Government, I remind the House, told us in 1983 that many smaller, acute hospitals throughout our electorates, particularly throughout rural Victoria, should build 10-bed nursing homes attached to their hospitals in order to ensure their viability.

Through community generosity and raising of funds, despite some horrific economic circumstances over the years, committees met these government policies and right across the State they expanded a wonderful range of health services that met the needs of the community in our towns and within our own rural environments. However, probably due to the mismanagement of our economy and the lack of government funds to meet the earlier commitment, the rules were changed. Now government criteria for a 10-bed nursing home has been extended to 30 beds. In my region the endeavour to meet this requirement is both frustrated and restricted.

We are told that the health region of Ballarat is oversupplied with nursing beds, but two-thirds of these beds are available in the city of Ballarat itself. It is accepted that many beds are not needed there and can be relinquished. The fact is that they have not been relinquished and there are no formal procedures to ensure that relinquishment takes place.

I plead with the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) to meet the needs of these isolated communities. They are prepared to go way beyond any reasonable social obligation. They deserve better than conflicting periodical policy changes that can only be interpreted as divisive and destructive policies. These nursing homes have to expand to 30 beds to be funded.

I turn now to two particular examples which are causing me concern. The Birchip Bush Nursing Hospital has just received a letter indicating that special funding will cease for Birchip on 31 March next if redevelopment does not take place. The hospital advised the Minister and submitted a redevelopment plan on 29 November last year. In other words, the hospital has met its obligations and has met the Minister's obligations, but before the proposal it has submitted—at the request of the Government—has been looked at or determined, it has been given an ultimatum that top-up funding will cease.

I speak for another hospital in my electorate, the Natimuk Bush Nursing Hospital. This hospital has accepted that it must meet the Government's criteria for a 30-bed nursing home. The hospital presently has a 22-bed nursing home and eight acute beds and is prepared to convert these acute beds and other auxiliary facilities to ensure a 30-bed nursing home is built. It is prepared to meet the Government's criteria and ensure that it not only meets the health needs of the community in an adequate way, but also that it meets the conditions required by the Government.

Again, as I pointed out earlier, there is no commitment, no ability within the quota system, for nursing home beds to be transferred or to become available to meet this hospital's requirements. People living in isolated, remote communities have, through their own generosity and their own resources, contributed to the provision of health care and the wonderful range of services for the aged. It is totally unjustified and lacking in all social equity that these conditions should now be applied. Many of these facilities are new. They are modern facilities, equal to none in health care delivery and community caring.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely the Minister will not shut down these facilities simply because of conflicting government policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise following your own speech on the adjournment debate yesterday evening in relation to Louis St John Johnson, who was viciously and brutally murdered on 4 January in Western Australia when he was on his way home from what was, in fact, his nineteenth birthday celebration. As you commented yesterday, someone was convicted last Friday in the Perth Children's Court for the murder of Louis St John Johnson. He received a sentence of seven years and nine months.

PARA.TAB: I must say that, notwithstanding standing order 75, my personal opinion is that that particular sentence was totally inadequate and does not reflect the severity of the offence or the viciousness and brutality of the attack on this fine young man. I wish to add to what you had to say. The adopted parents of Louis, Bill and Pauline Johnson, who are constituents of mine, have formed the Louis St John Johnson memorial trust fund. They have written to me, and I am sure they have written to you also, Mr Deputy Speaker, to convey the objectives of this trust.
Whereas I might not agree with every single element of those objectives, I must say that I find them to be a positive and constructive way of perpetuating the memory of their

SPEECH.PARA: son, Louis. All I can say, if anything, to those honourable members who may have known of Louis or may have some awareness of Louis' life, is that the objectives of the trust reflect this fine young man's life and the terrible way in which he came to his death.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
